HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORTS: MANHATTAN UP CLOSE -- RELATIONS;
Not for the Faint of Head

BYLINE: By BERNARD STAMLER 

 BODY:
Forget the summer potboilers. This month Ruth Gitlin, Silda Wall Spitzer, Lilly Stern and the others in their circle will be reading Proust -- "Swann's Way," to be precise, an intimidating work where madeleines, the small, shell-shaped cakes, play a central role. The three are members of a book group founded more than a decade ago by a half-dozen professional women who wanted to "plug the holes" in their otherwise impressive educations, according to Ms. Spitzer, a lawyer.
And though this month's book is perhaps more, well, Proustian than typical August reading, it fits a group that has sampled authors as diverse and challenging as Camus, Mark Twain and Henry James. "We've read Nobel Prize winners and Booker Prize winners," said Ms. Stern, a lawyer. "And Russian, French and English authors," Ms. Spitzer added. Indeed, over the years they have read just about every kind of fiction. 
 "We were formal and rigid in the beginning," said Ms. Gitlin, a money manager. They borrowed a book list from an N.Y.U. graduate course and spent a year or so deconstructing modern prose fiction. "We'd set an agenda and follow it," she said.
But time and experience have brought change. Perhaps half the members have departed, replaced by others. Where once none were parents, they now count some 15 children among them. And lighter fiction is allowed occasionally, said Suzanne Telsey, another lawyer and a new member.
"We even read things things from the best seller list," said Heidi Spitzer, a self-described "lawyer and aspiring herbalist" and Silda Wall Spitzer's sister-in-law.
Their meetings now draw 7 to 10 and are every six to eight weeks, with the hostess choosing a book, preparing biographical notes and providing dinner. Sometimes the meal even has a theme, like the fried chicken and chablis provided by Kate Crowley, a lawyer, for the discussion of "Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil." Every book is picked apart, as it were, sometimes with great vigor. "These are highly opinionated women," said Lisa Kaess, an economist. "I was scared the first time I came in."
Adds Silda Spitzer, describing the group's often heated discussions, "The more animosity, the better."
Ms. Crowley, who chose "Swann's Way," fears it will not win universal acclaim from members."It's like a sword of Damocles hanging over my head," she said. "But people never get personal, even if they disagree," said Ann Mackay-Smith, a writer.
"Well, not so far," Ms. Crowley replied. BERNARD STAMLER

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT: THE SUMMER SWOON -- THE STRATEGISTS;
3 Game Plans for an Altered Playing Field

BYLINE: By ERIC HUBLER 

 BODY:
IS this time different?
As stunning as this week's stock decline was, the answer to the question remains what it has always been: Nothing has changed -- unless, of course, it has. 
 Three strategists, interviewed after the Dow Jones industrial average dropped nearly 300 points on Tuesday, shared their views.
 
A Dearth of Good News
If the sky truly is falling, don't tell Robert Froehlich, 45, chief investment strategist for the mutual fund group of Scudder Kemper Investments, that he failed to give you the heads-up.
The tremor on Tuesday, he said, was more than just the ordinary dip-and-rebound script that has played out so routinely over the last several years. "I think there's a confluence of some pretty unique events causing this downdraft," he said.
First, Mr. Froehlich said, simultaneous crises of confidence threaten the governments of the world's two biggest economies -- the United States and Japan -- giving investors already skittish over earnings, for example, one more reason to rush the exits.
But don't downturns always lure bargain hunters? It may have seemed that way for the last 10 years, Mr. Froehlich said, but one ingredient is now missing. "The buying opportunity usually comes after you have an economic release the market can rally around," he said. "Now, there is no economic release to rally around."
The importance of having some good economic news to cling to, he continued, helps explain why European markets have outperformed lately (though they did tumble on Wednesday, in sympathy with the Dow's slide). "Europe is doing better than most because they have a great rallying point, the creation of a common currency," he said.
Mr. Froehlich advises a defensive posture but feels that consumer confidence should remain strong. He recommends the drug, food and homebuilding sectors, plus financial stocks that will benefit from low interest rates.
 
Interest Rates to the Rescue
Sam Stovall, 43, sector strategist at Standard & Poor's, thinks investors will look back on this period as the crisis that almost happened.
He acknowledges that the trouble spots are significant. If the Dow were just "bouncy," Mr. Stovall said, it would have turned north at 8,600, where it has rebounded in the past. Instead, it crashed right through that psychologically important level. Previous corrections of 5 to 10 percent since 1990 have involved mainly small- and mid-cap stocks, leaving blue chips aloft, Mr. Stovall said. Now, by contrast, "we are hearing companies that were Wall Street darlings caution analysts that forward earnings could be difficult."
In the past, he continued, it was just the fundamental analysts, those focusing on corporate financials, who were worried about excessive price-to-earnings ratios, low dividend yields and the like. Now, technical analysts are looking at ominous signals like the increasing number of stocks on the New York Stock Exchange that are hitting new 52-week lows.
Despite that, Mr. Stovall said, the market has a guardian angel: low interest rates. "I think in order for this market to really tank," he said, "the Fed has to raise interest rates."
It won't raise them, he said, because the Asian crisis will hurt United States corporate profits enough to slow the economy.
With low rates providing a cushion for stocks, Mr. Stovall said, there is no reason to change his picks. "I still favor the consumer cyclicals, health care and selected technology issues," he said. "But if investors are nervous and want to look to those sectors that have held up best in market pullbacks, I would look to the consumer staples -- food, beverage, tobacco and household products -- as well as utilities."
 
Smoke, Mirrors and Indexes
To Chuck Clough, 56, chief investment strategist at Merrill Lynch, the perception that we were in a bull market before last week's fall was illusory.
Though it may come as a surprise to people, a market selloff has been under way for months, Mr. Clough observed.
"The average stock has been declining for the better part of the year," he said. "The average stock on the American Exchange and the Nasdaq over-the-counter market has been declining for two years.
"The Dow Jones industrial average is only up about 4 percent from where it was last July," he said, adding that investors have been focusing for the last year on 15 to 20 stocks that have powered the S.& P. 500-stock index and created the perception that the market was stronger than it was.
The fall on Tuesday was merely "the culmination of something that's been going on for a long time," Mr. Clough said.
"I don't know how long you can run up 15 stocks and not the other 97 percent," he continued. "We might be in a position now where the market trades sideways, in a range, for a long time."
The problem, Mr. Clough said, is overinvestment -- the Asian crisis being only the most severe symptom.
Investment will slow as some of the easy capital sloshing around the world dries up, Mr. Clough predicted, but that is not as bad as it sounds. "The positive is, if that's true, inflation is going to be astoundingly low as we go into 1999," he said. "You could be looking at 4 percent bond yields over the next year or two, and that's good for financial stocks."
In addition to financial stocks, Mr. Clough would like to see his firm's clients holding a handful of very high-quality companies, because he thinks the rest of the market will tread water for the foreseeable future. And don't skimp on bonds, he said, because this is no time to be holding an unbalanced portfolio.

HEADLINE: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORTS: GREENPOINT;
Where Films Are Noir and Parking Is Dire

BYLINE: By DAVID KIRBY 

 BODY:
It's a director's dream, with decayed warehouses, rotting piers and a gritty, film-noir feel. But this is no back lot in Burbank. It's Greenpoint's waterfront, and it has become popular with production companies, upsetting some neighbors.
Last week, three productions were going on simultaneously along 12 blocks of West Street, a crumbling stretch of road near the East River, just across from the gleaming towers of midtown Manhattan. 
 At the southern end, LL Cool J and Keith Murray were shooting a music video in the abandoned Greenpoint Terminal. A block away, on the corner of Greenpoint Avenue, the independent film "Kill by Inches" has been shooting for two weeks, its lighting equipment scattered on the sidewalk. And on blocks just north of there, on Java and India Streets, a crew shooting a Miramax feature called "The Yards" took over a rooftoop and several street locations.
Paul Zawisha, an artist who has a studio on West Street, said the filming has created problems with parking. Last week, he said, "there was no parking on both sides for 12 blocks."
Walter Martin, another artist with a studio nearby, noted that filming of the Hollywood picture "Sleepers" two years ago was particularly disruptive. "Our beef is with the city," Mr. Martin said. "It gets a lot of revenue filming here, but the community, which is poor, gets nothing in return."
But a spokeswoman for the Mayor's Office of Film, Theater and Broadcasting, Julianne Cho, said the film industry is a vital player in New York's economy, conferring citywide benefits like $237 million in taxes last year and freelance work for 78,000 New Yorkers, "many of whom live in Greenpoint," she said.
Ms. Cho said her office had received "a few complaints" about "The Yards." Some were resolved, but some were "manufactured," she said, adding that the production company "provided window blacking to residents affected by lights."
Still, Greenpoint has become so desirable as a location for movie and video shoots that in January the neighborhood was placed on the city's so-called "hot spot" list of areas where filming is generally prohibited. But West Street has since been removed from the no-film zone because it is a largely industrial area, Ms. Cho said.
Lys Hopper, the production manager for "The Yards," said she was well aware of local sensitivity. "We put up signs telling people to call us about problems," she said. "And Miramax will donate money to help a local group buy a graffiti washer." She added, "I walk the fence between the company's needs and what's good for the neighborhood. That's my job." DAVID KIRBY

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
The Sky Is Becoming the Only Limit for Credit Card Users

BYLINE: By ROBERT D. HERSHEY Jr. 

 BODY:
CARL THOMSEN, a financial consultant in suburban Washington, actively uses two credit cards, sometimes piling substantial business expenses onto them. No matter how much he spends, though, his Visa and Mastercard issuers keep automatically raising his authorized credit limits, which now run well into five figures each.
The idea, of course, is to tempt people like Mr. Thomsen -- a customer with a good payment record -- to borrow ever-higher amounts at interest rates that often approach 20 percent. But for some consumers, it also means a chance to get into ever-bigger financial trouble. 
 Do not count Mr. Thomsen, 55, among the less-disciplined consumers; he usually pays off his card balances in full at the end of each month and has never asked for more borrowing power. Indeed, he said, "I've never bumped up against a credit limit."
In watching those limits grow, however, Mr. Thomsen has plenty of company these days. Banks and other credit-card issuers are raising their limits far faster than consumers are borrowing -- even as lenders report record proportions of delinquencies and charge-offs.
"Despite protestations that they're trying to get rid of the worst excesses, the marketing of card credit is continuing largely as usual, with little letup," said Warren Heller, research director for Veribanc Inc., a company in Wakefield, Mass., which rates banks and savings institutions. "One of the time-tested rules of business is that your existing customers are your best prospects."
In the two years ended in March, unused credit limits for all bank-issued cards in the United States soared 50.3 percent, to $1.78 trillion, according to Veribanc -- more than twice the growth in card charges.
This pushed consumers' potential spending power to a record 4.2 times their current indebtedness, up from 3.4 just two years ago. When the data were first collected in 1990, the multiple was a little more than 2.
Other figures, compiled by the American Bankers Association, also point to fast-expanding credit. The most common credit limit for a standard card sponsored by a large bank, the association said, climbed for the second consecutive year in 1997, to $3,500. That is 40 percent higher than the typical limit of $2,500 in 1993. And some "premium" cards -- which are not all that difficult to get -- are being advertised with limits of $50,000 and even $100,000.
The average account balance on standard credit cards issued by large banks is $1,987, the association found, up from $1,479 in 1993. For gold cards, it is $2,497, up from $2,334.
The Consumer Federation of America sponsored a report on the subject last month to bolster its opposition to a bill making it harder for people to declare bankruptcy -- a bill that lenders are pushing for Congress to pass. The organization attributes soaring bankruptcies largely to "irresponsible" promotion of credit cards and considers the banking industry hypocritical in seeking legislation that they say would make it easier to collect debts from consumers whom bankers themselves had lured over the financial brink.
The industry, increasingly dominated by a shrinking number of major banks, often responds to such accusations by saying that soaring credit lines are a statistical illusion or a reflection of banks' improving ability to differentiate between the most lucrative customers and potential deadbeats.
Lawrence Chimerine, consulting economist for Mastercard International, estimated that 75 percent to 80 percent of the increase in total credit lines reflected the issuance of new cards -- for which no reliable count exists -- rather than expanded capacity for existing card holders.
By itself, MBNA, the second-biggest card issuer after Citibank, added 11.4 million customers last year on top of a 9.3 million gain in 1996. But some in the industry say that to hasten that growth, MBNA engages in mass expansion of credit lines.
Peter Frank, a spokesman for MBNA, disputed this, saying that the company's lines have grown an average of just 8 percent in the last two years.
At First Chicago NBD, which issues the First Card, potential new card holders are offered lower lines of credit than they were two years ago, said Ralph R. Mueller, senior credit officer for First Card.
First Chicago attributes the growth of credit limits to the issuance of more gold and platinum cards, which have higher limits. It also notes that many card holders now have more cards to use; according to the Nilson Report, which tracks the credit card industry, the average is now slightly more than four cards per card holder, compared with slightly more than three in 1993.
Mainly, though, the industry attributes the expansion of credit limits to refined methods of judging their new customers' ability to pay. Banks have become "much more adept in distinguishing the most profitable customers, those most likely to use their cards and repay their balances," said Robert Stock, senior vice president for credit products at Visa USA.
 ASSUMING that issuers have reduced their exposure to new credit-card charge-offs, what risks can expanded credit limits pose for consumers? An obvious one is that a generally responsible borrower could leap into expensive debt because of an emergency -- a serious health problem, for example, or the loss of a job.
But specialists say high credit lines pose some risks even if they are not used. Access to other credit, like a mortgage, can be impaired if an applicant has too many cards with too much borrowing potential. Lenders are wary that a consumer or spouse could suddenly tap several credit sources so heavily that not all could be repaid.
"This is taken into consideration," said Charlotte Newton, vice president for consumer affairs at Mastercard. "Whether or not you use it, it's still there."

HEADLINE: The World: Fidel Without Fear;
An Old Star Loses His Punch Lines

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: ST. GEORGE'S, Grenada

 BODY:
THE high point of Fidel Castro's state visit to this 133-square-mile "Spice Isle" last week was the speech he delivered at Tanteen, a cricket field flanked by a simple grandstand and a stack of cargo containers. As a couple of thousand people listened patiently and the occasional dog ambled across the grounds, the Cuban leader lectured Grenadians for an hour and a half on the history of slavery in the West Indies and assorted other topics. 
 Since coming to power nearly 40 years ago, Mr. Castro has used all the world as his stage, but he seems to be playing smaller houses these days. Leslie Pierre, editor of the leading newspaper in this country of 100,000 people, the weekly Grenadian Voice, intended it as a compliment when he called the Cuban president "a Caribbean man." Yet that designation also implies that Mr. Castro and his message matter little these days outside a region that itself seems increasingly on the fringe of world events.
 
The Melody Lingers
Treated in recent years as a dotty old uncle in most capitals, even those of Latin America where his calls for revolution once resonated, Mr. Castro found himself saluted here by Prime Minister Keith Mitchell as an historical figure "who can only be compared in the 20th Century to Nelson Mandela." He was also serenaded with a rousing version of the "Internationale."
But the atmosphere was festive rather than threatening. Without the Soviet Union to back it up, the Communist anthem has lost its ability to frighten the capitalist world. So, too, Mr. Castro.
A decade and a half ago, the Reagan Administration's fear of Mr. Castro and his seemingly unlimited ability to make mischief generated a bonanza of aid and attention for the newly independent English-speaking states in the Caribbean. Even as the other islands were being promised preferential trade benefits as part of a regional Caribbean Basin Initiative, some 6,000 American troops invaded Grenada in October 1983 to expel Cuban forces, and Washington followed that up with a promise to bring Grenada into the circle of preferred treatment.
The 1990's, in contrast, have seen the Clinton Administration close down its regional aid office, downgrade the embassy here to a mission and slash aid, grants and scholarships. While Cuba, itself economically prostrate, cannot make up for that gap, Mr. Mitchell and his regional colleagues have seized on Cuba's own need for friends in hopes of creating a countervailing weight to Washington's indifference.
Whether such a strategy will work is another matter. "In a post-cold war world, this region unfortunately is no longer relevant" to the great powers, one diplomat in the region said. Caribbean leaders may see Mr. Castro as a useful card to play to get Washington's attention, "but I'm not sure even that is true," the diplomat added. "Cuba wants to be headmaster of the Caribbean family, but since it is a Soviet proxy no longer, the United States really doesn't worry about it."
During the heyday of Cuba's alliance with Grenada, Mr. Castro aimed high, agreeing to build an airport that could be used to bring in tourists -- and to refuel Cuban planes ferrying troops to and from Africa. This time around, what he was offering seemed modest, even innocuous, reflecting straitened circumstances in both countries: a new wing on a hospital here and 22 additional scholarships for Grenadians to study at Cuban universities.
For Cuba, the principal benefit of such aid efforts today is not that they advance a geopolitical strategy. Rather, it is that they provide employment for Cuban doctors, engineers and teachers who would otherwise be idle at home or seeking jobs as hotel doormen or taxi drivers.
Perhaps the most telling moment of Mr. Castro's visit, however, came when Grenada's Education Minister, Lawrence Joseph, acknowledged during a meeting that one thing is always certain when local students get scholarships to Cuba. Unlike those who enroll in Britain, Canada or the United States, they always return home just as soon as their studies are done.

HEADLINE: EARNING IT: MINDING YOUR BUSINESS;
A Model Career Path For a Self-Starter

BYLINE: By LAURA PEDERSEN-PIETERSEN 

 BODY:
CESAR PACHECO 3D of the South Bronx recalls vividly the day that Nicole Brown Simpson was murdered -- June 12, 1994. He nearly lost his life the same evening, after being shot point-blank in the chest during a botched robbery outside his apartment in the Castle Hill section.
Instead of watching the New York Knicks in a playoff game that night, as he had planned, Mr. Pacheco spent nearly nine hours on the operating table at Jacobi Hospital, while his fiancee waited anxiously. 
 For a time it was touch-and-go, as the Jacobi surgical team repaired his perforated lung, diaphragm and liver. "You owe us one," a surgeon later told Mr. Pacheco, then 23.
A near-death experience, Mr. Pacheco says, focuses the mind wonderfully. During his slow recovery, while contemplating the hundred or so stitches that held together the tapestry of his body, he decided that it was time to get his act together, too.
He had graduated from an alternative high school in the South Bronx and held a string of low-paying odd jobs. That wouldn't do, not with a family to support. Mr. Pacheco wanted a career. But in what?
"Trucking was the obvious choice," he now says, though when he decided to become an operator of 18-wheelers, he didn't own a car, much less know how to drive a truck. Still, having been raised near the Hunt's Point Market in the Bronx, Mr. Pacheco grew up watching the big rigs maneuver in and out of the industrial neighborhood.
Once back on his feet, he applied for a learner's permit and persuaded a friend to provide some informal lessons in driving a truck.
The next stop was Model Training Center on 14th Street in Manhattan. No fly-by-night diploma mill, the vocational school has been in business for 50 years. After six weeks of instruction, Mr. Pacheco had a commercial driver's license; now, he was certified to drive everything from ambulettes, city buses and garbage trucks to flatbeds and triple tractor-trailers.
Just three weeks later, he was hired by MS Carriers of Memphis, at $1,000 a week plus overtime, benefits and bonuses. In other words, good money, particularly for someone who until then had never earned more than $350 a week.
As a career self-starter, Mr. Pacheco is in many ways representative of a new mode of working in America. Employees and entrepreneurs find happy niches for themselves by following their instincts -- and expect to reinvent themselves several more times before retirement.
Even today's college graduates often tumble into careers very different from the ones they have just finished training for. And many workers are eagerly jumping into jobs that did not exist even a year or two ago -- corporate Web site managers, for example.
Mr. Pacheco drove tractor-trailers professionally for just two years before he had his second epiphany. It was at the funeral of a 36-year-old friend who had a heart attack during a basketball game. The friend had two young children, and his death made Mr. Pacheco realize that he wanted to spend more time with his family -- he had two children, too.
"I loved driving across the country, because it allowed me to see that there was more out there than what was in front of me in the South Bronx," Mr. Pacheco said. "But I think it's more important for kids in a ghetto atmosphere to have a full-time father around."
The week after his friend's funeral, Mr. Pacheco, then 26, was back at the Model Training School, this time offering his services as a driving instructor.
 IT has turned out to be a satisfying career switch. Part of the payoff, he said, comes from helping others gain access to a better standard of living. Salaries for truck drivers range from $35,000 to $100,000 and they can come with good benefits -- especially jobs covered by the International Brotherhood of Teamsters. Neither a high school diploma nor proficient English is required.
"I teach immigrants who were making $5 an hour as dishwashers and even a lot of college graduates who are sick of making eight bucks an hour in an office," he said.
Last weekend found Mr. Pacheco busy training a 47-year-old man, a meat packer who has been with the Pathmark grocery chain for two decades, to drive a rig.
"Some people have trouble understanding that just because a guy didn't go to Harvard Business School doesn't mean that he doesn't have dreams," he said, identifying strongly with his student.
Nor do you need an M.B.A. to see how things fit together in the economy. From the cab of his big rig, Mr. Pacheco became his own securities analyst. While he had never heard of Peter Lynch, the legendary portfolio manager for Fidelity Investments, he approached the market as if he had memorized a page out of Mr. Lynch's playbook: Invest in what you know.
"Trucking gives you an excellent idea of what's happening in different businesses through watching the flow of traffic," he explained. In July 1995, for example, he noticed that an extraordinary amount of goods was being delivered to the loading docks of Sears, Roebuck stores across the country, and he figured that meant an extraordinary amount of merchandise was being carried out the front door by customers, as well. His observation was keen: Sears stock, which had been languishing in the low $30's, started to move; by the next March it had climbed more than 20 points.
Still, when Mr. Pacheco was ready to invest for the long term, he selected MCI Communications and Sun Microsystems -- stocks that he hopes will help pay for the education of his two boys, now 10 and 3. His plan, for now at least, is to set himself up in the trucking business when his boys are a little older. For about $25,000 you can buy a secondhand rig and go into business for yourself, Mr. Pacheco explained. He would also like to buy a home in Westchester County.
It might not be the first thing to come to mind, but there are a lot of dreams to be realized by driving trucks. Currently, there are about 80,000 unfilled driving jobs in the industry, Traffic World magazine has reported. And given the surge in ordering goods by catalogue and from the Internet, it is no surprise that the Government says trucking is the nation's eighth-fastest-growing occupation.
"You can walk out this door after a $365, 10-day course, and another $175 for the road test, and get a job tomorrow," said Bob Kousoulos, a longtime instructor at Model Training Center. "You'll make back the cost of the class in a week."
Nowadays, after a year and a half on the job, Mr. Pacheco is regarded by the school's owners as one of their top instructors. He makes about $42,000 a year teaching others how to handle big rigs.
And what about the bonus he used to collect as a driver? "Seeing my family every day is my big bonus," he said.

SECTION: Section 3; Page 11; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk

HEADLINE: SPENDING IT;
In Florida's Fires, A Test for a New Insurance Policy

BYLINE: By JOSEPH B. TREASTER 

DATELINE: PALM COAST, Fla.

 BODY:
THE wildfires that swept through the piney woods here this summer provided a test, of sorts, of a new kind of home insurance that is being introduced gradually across the country.
Instead of paying whatever it takes to replace a destroyed home, as had been the case for years, the leading insurers are now selling policies that limit most payments to 120 percent of the insured amount. 
 And that has posed a powerful question: Would the scaled-back coverage be enough for people to start over? Would there be huge gaps between the cost of a new house and the insurance payment?
The answer, based on evidence accumulating here, is that the lesser coverage seems to suffice. Both the insurers and Florida regulators say there have been no complaints and, in nearly a dozen interviews, people who lost their homes had nothing but praise for their companies.
"We couldn't ask for better treatment," said Aida Meltzer, an Allstate customer who lost her three-bedroom home here in central Florida, near the Atlantic coast.
Many fire victims have collected more than they expected, and those who have come up short say they have only themselves to blame because they consciously underinsured their homes, taking what they thought was a reasonable gamble that disaster was unlikely.
The key to making the restricted policies work, consumer advocates and insurers say, is in accurately calculating the cost of rebuilding a home and then adjusting each year for inflation and improvements.
"This approach requires much more vigilance," said J. Robert Hunter, director of insurance for the Consumer Federation of America. But handled correctly, he said, it seems fair to both customers and insurers.
While State Farm and Allstate, the two biggest home insurers, limit their payments to 120 percent in most states, Allstate has a ceiling of 150 percent in California and 125 percent in New York, Arkansas and North Carolina. Industry experts say the higher limits may attract more customers, but that with careful evaluations, the 120 percent margin should work anywhere.
The industry's new approach, which requires regulatory approval state by state, has yet to be tested in the aftermath of a big hurricane or earthquake, when laws of supply and demand -- as well as profiteering -- can push rebuilding costs off the charts. In the Florida fires, the number of homes lost was not enormous, and prices for building materials seem to have changed little.
Insurers also say they do not foresee problems in areas where real estate values are skyrocketing, because coverage is based on the cost of rebuilding rather than on a house's market value. A big part of a house's sale price often reflects the value of the land on which it was built. But homeowner's insurance covers the house, not the site.
Insurance companies introduced unlimited policies in the early 1980's as a way to increase sales. They soon became the industry standard, so no insurer had an edge -- just a lot more liability.
Hurricane Andrew cost the industry $16 billion in 1992, and State Farm took the first step toward retrenchment the next spring, refusing to sell unlimited policies in Florida.
Instead, it instituted the 120 percent provision. Judith K. Mintel, a lawyer for State Farm, says the intent is to insure accurately the cost of replacing a house. State Farm allows for a 10 percent margin of error in its estimate system, she said, and throws in another 10 percent for good measure.
 SATISFIED that the concept was workable, the company began putting it into effect nationally in 1996, as state regulators approved it. And the competition has followed. The policies, which cost about the same as their predecessors, are now being sold in more than 30 states. Allstate is selling them in New York and New Jersey, but State Farm is still awaiting regulatory approval in those states; both companies await approval in Connecticut.
The companies say that they sent notices to customers about the changes and that they instructed agents to spread the word, but details of the coverage apparently were lost on many people. Fire victims here said they did not realize -- until claims adjusters told them -- that they could get up to 20 percent more than what their policies specified. For that matter, they also couldn't recall a time when they had unlimited coverage; they believed that if they were insured for $100,000, they could expect $100,000 -- no more, no less.
They were also happy to learn that they would receive several thousand dollars, in most cases, to remove the remains of their homes and for new landscaping.
By spreading money around immediately, the insurers won many friends in Palm Coast, which has a population of about 30,000, scattered over hundreds of acres of thick woods a few miles from the beach. Within hours of the fires in July, the insurers were handing out thousands of dollars for living expenses; within a few days, many people had received checks for the face value of their policies.
When Rhon Dixon, the owner of a window-blind and kitchen-cabinet company, drove up to the knee-high mound of ash that had been his two-story, three-bedroom frame house, he found a State Farm claims adjuster sitting in his driveway.
"He said, 'Do you need some living expenses?' " Mr. Dixon recalled. "I said, 'Probably.' And he said, 'What do you need, $5,000, $10,000?' I said $10,000 would be fine. Then, about three minutes later, he said: 'You're going to need a deposit for where you're living. Why don't I just give you $15,000?' And I said, 'That's even better.' "
Mr. Dixon, 42, said he had never expected to use his insurance, had guessed at what might be enough coverage and didn't aim high. He never read his policy and doesn't recall hearing about the 20 percent cushion or other beneficial provisions.
"You think your property is worth a lot, but when you talk with the tax people and the insurance company, you try to claim it's not worth anything," he said. "Until something like this happens, it just seems like you just keep paying, and never get anything back."
 NOW Mr. Dixon has been talking with contractors about rebuilding. Their calculations show his coverage was low. His policy was for $108,900; rebuilding will cost about $150,000. "It's my fault," he said. "I didn't have it insured for enough."
The gap, though, is not going to be as wide as he first thought. State Farm has already given him $21,700 more -- the 20 percent -- plus $1,300 for things like replacing his driveway, sidewalk and a patio. And he expects State Farm to supply an additional $5,000 to bulldoze and cart away his ruins and about $5,400 more for new landscaping. Changes in building codes have increased some building costs, and State Farm routinely pays a percentage of those expenses.
A more litigious person might argue that Mr. Dixon's State Farm agent should have made an effort to see that the insured value of the house was closer to the mark. Executives at State Farm headquarters in Bloomington, Ill., said that their policy is for agents, armed with the latest costs of building materials and a computer, to estimate as precisely as possible how much it will take to replace each house they insure. Mr. Dixon said the only estimate he knew of came out of his head.
James I. Jones, 62, who got out of his house just as his trees were catching fire, was also underinsured. He thought his agent's estimate of $100,000 of coverage was low, but didn't argue: he did not want to pay higher premiums. Now that concrete block walls are all that remain of his three-bedroom home, he also blames himself, not State Farm. Mr. Jones says two contractors have estimated the cost of replacing his home at $135,000.
Many of the Florida fire victims said their biggest insurance mistake was underestimating the value of their furniture, clothes and the other contents of their homes. An Allstate homeowner's policy automatically provides the equivalent of half the face value for the home's contents; on a $100,000 policy, the contents are covered for an additional $50,000. State Farm's automatic allocation is 75 percent.
Aida and David Meltzer, retirees from Baltimore, were among those whose insurance coverage worked out just right. They did not cut corners and fastidiously updated their coverage. When they added a room to their beige-and-brown ranch house in mid-May, Mrs. Meltzer increased their Allstate coverage by $10,000, to about $80,000.
After the fire, the Meltzers found it would cost about $85,000 to rebuild, well within the 20 percent margin. And they have decided to add a few frills out of their own pockets. "I'm very well satisfied with the insurance company and all the people we've had to deal with," Mr. Meltzer said.

HEADLINE: The World;
How to Bypass Sanctions and Do Business

BYLINE: By ERIC SCHMITT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
ONCE again, President Saddam Hussein of Iraq is thumbing his nose at the world community. Last week, he said he is through cooperating with international weapons inspectors and wants the crippling economic sanctions on his country lifted.
The Security Council berated Iraq for its intransigence, and demanded that Baghdad change its decision. The Clinton Administration has vowed to block any easing of the sanctions the United Nations imposed in 1991 after the Persian Gulf war until Baghdad accounts for all of its nuclear, chemical, biological and missile programs. 
 But these days sanctions aren't very popular in Washington.
 
An Ineffective Tool
 Largely in response to complaints from farm groups and business organizations, Congress and the White House have concluded that most sanctions, especially unilateral ones, are an ineffective tool in foreign policy. And in the highly competitive global market, Washington's sanctions in particular actually hurt American companies.
"No one wants to support the Hitlers of the world, but if you're the only country imposing sanctions, they have no effect," said Tom Mick, chief executive of the Washington Wheat Commission, a trade group in Spokane that has urged the Administration to end sanctions against Iran, a former top customer of Pacific Northwest wheat.
But critics of sanctions are less likely to acknowledge that most existing penalties are riddled with exemptions, waivers and legal loopholes. Exemptions are designed to permit humanitarian aid and give Presidents some diplomatic wiggle room. Farmers have been adept at using them to keep a commercial toehold, and sometimes much more, in even the most reviled rogue nations.
Congress often puts profits ahead of principle when the business interests are big enough. Just a few weeks after it angrily condemned India and Pakistan for conducting nuclear tests in May, Congress enacted sanctions but exempted food exports, removing the biggest sting the penalties could inflict. Why? Wheat farmers in the Pacific Northwest howled because Pakistan was their biggest customer, and the sanctions would have barred them from bidding on a $37 million wheat order from that country.
The same legislation that waived food exports also included a little-noticed provision that exempted fertilizer from the sanctions. That's because India is the second-largest importer of American phosphate fertilizer, mostly from Florida, which exports $1.7 billion in fertilizer.
"Fertilizer is just as important as food and medicine," said Kathleen Mathers of The Fertilizer Institute, a trade group.
Iran may still be virtually closed to American companies, but Midwestern wheat farmers from Kansas to Texas are benefiting from a year-old United Nations' program that allows Iraq to sell a limited amount of oil to buy food and medicine for humanitarian purposes. In the program's first year, Iraq bought 817,000 metric tons -- about $114 million worth -- of hard red winter wheat, which placed that country eighth among foreign buyers of American wheat. At a time when wheat prices are at 10-year low, and orders from Asia have plummeted because of the economic crisis there, the new business from Baghdad is welcome news in Topeka and Austin.
Of course, American businesses prefer to avoid sanctions altogether. Last year, as the Administration was weighing whether to impose a ban on new American investment in Myanmar because of its human rights abuses, the Unocal Corporation signed a deal with that Government to expand a $1.2 billion joint venture with the French oil company, Total, to develop gas fields off the coast.
Unocal denied that there was any rush to sign the deal ahead of impending sanctions. "It was coincidental," said Barry Lane, a company spokesman.
In other pariah states like Cuba and North Korea, American farmers and businesses are donating food or agricultural products outright with the Administration's blessing, hoping to position themselves to compete with international rivals when embargoes are finally lifted.
The U.S. Grains Council, the export development arm of the American corn, barley and sorghum industries, donated 4,000 pounds of mixed feed grain last spring to a Cuban aid organization.
Kansas wheat farmers and the wheat industry's export development arm donated 22,000 pounds of flour to Cuba in February with an eye on the day a new regime rules in Havana. "Cuba could be a pretty significant market," said Lisa Jager, a spokesman for U.S. Wheat Associates, the export arm.
 
Opening Doors
 In May 1997, Washington State and Mercy Corps International, a relief organization in Portland, Ore., donated 500 apple trees to North Korea. "We've been trying to figure out ways to open the door there," said Ralph Munro, Washington's secretary of state, who helped organize the donation.
But commercial dealings with cash-poor rogue nations are still risky. Last year, North Korea abruptly abandoned a plan to barter zinc for 20,000 tons of American wheat.
North Korea's snub came as the ship-bound wheat was only days from delivery, and left the American company, Cargill, Inc., a Minneapolis-based commodities dealer, in the lurch. "We sold the grain on the market at a significant loss," said Bonnie Raquet, a Cargill spokeswoman.

HEADLINE: FUNDS WATCH;
Goodbye, Mr. Price. Hello, Higher Fees.

BYLINE: By CAROLE GOULD 

 BODY:
IT was, to say the least, a case of odd timing: Last Monday, after Franklin Resources announced that Michael F. Price was surrendering his chief executive title and stock-picking duties at its Mutual Series fund unit, the company increased the front-end loads for small investors in the six Mutual Series funds.
The load, or initial sales charge, was raised from 4.5 percent to 5.75 percent for those with less than $50,000 invested. So not only are investors left without the skills of Mr. Price, the vaunted value investor, but many will have to pay more for the privilege of buying shares. 
 Moreover, the higher charges go against an industry trend. Front-end loads have dropped over the last 10 years, according to Cerulli Associates, a consulting firm in Boston. While 8.5 percent loads were once common, a 4 to 5 percent sales load is more the norm today.
A. Michael Lipper, chairman of Lipper Analytical Services in Summit, N.J., described Franklin's move as unusual. Franklin, he said, may be hoping that the increased sales load will "get more brokers who are looking for a higher-loaded fund to sell." Sales charges are used to compensate brokers and other fund sellers; raising them can serve as a powerful sales incentive.
Mr. Lipper said the increased loads could be an effort to lift Franklin's own stock price, but a spokeswoman for Franklin, Holly Gibson, said the increased sales load had been in the works for several months.
There is little doubt, however, that the mutual fund giant's stock could use some extra juice right now.
Shares of Franklin Resources have fallen 27.6 percent, from a high of $57.3125 on April 13 to $41.50 on Friday. That compares with a falloff of 7.9 percent for the Standard & Poor's Financials Index over the same period. But why the weakness in Franklin stock to begin with? One reason may be that the company missed its second-quarter earnings estimate of 54 cents a share by 2 cents on June 23.
But a more serious influence is likely to be the Asian economic crisis. Some investors may be looking at Franklin's international and emerging-markets exposure through its Templeton funds group, which is focused on foreign stocks. Templeton funds account for 46 percent of Franklin's assets.
"Long term, having Templeton is a great asset," said Henry H. McVey, an analyst with Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "But short term, it won't bring in as much cash as a complex which is domestically focused."
Richard K. Strauss, a brokerage and asset management analyst with Goldman, Sachs, said the market had overreacted to Franklin's exposure to Asia -- less than 5 percent of the company's total assets. "I think it will rebound when the market recognizes how limited Franklin's exposure is to Asia and as overall market conditions begin to pick up."
A host of smaller issues may also be contributing to the stock's weakness, according to Mr. McVey. He said Franklin's decision to consolidate transfer agencies had contributed to higher costs, as had rapid account growth and year-2000 compliance issues. Another factor, he said, was the introduction of the European Monetary Union, which requires a major revamping of Franklin's computers.
Greg Johnson, president of Franklin-Templeton Distributors, a subsidiary of Franklin Resources, said the loads were raised to consolidate pricing policies after the company's acquisitions of the Templeton and Mutual Series funds. Templeton already charges a 5.75 percent load; Franklin's other funds, which had charged 4.5 percent, increased their loads along with those of the Mutual Series.
So why didn't Franklin lower the loads on the Templeton funds instead?
"The representatives who sell our funds seem to favor the schedule used by Templeton, not the schedule used by the Franklin funds," Mr. Johnson said.
The higher charges apply only to people with less than $50,000 invested at the funds. Investors with $50,000 to $99,999 will keep paying 4.5 percent and those with $100,000 to $249,999 will pay 3.5 percent, down from 3.75 percent. The charges decline to zero for those with $1 million or more.
The new sales charges apply only to the company's class I shares.

HEADLINE: A New Spell for Alphabet City;
Gentrification Led to the Unrest at Tompkins Square 10 Years Ago. Did the Protesters Win That Battle but Lose the War?

BYLINE: By ANDREW JACOBS 

 BODY:
WHICH riot?"
At first glance, Freddie Weber looks like the kind of young man who might know a thing or two about the bloody clash between the police and protesters that wracked Tompkins Square Park a decade ago last week. Hair meticulously unkempt, a nail piercing his nose, Mr. Weber, 19, a self-described radical, punk-music aficionado and sophomore at the University of Connecticut, held a can of Colt 45 as he leaned against a building on Avenue A near St. Marks Place last Saturday morning. 
 "You mean the one against the Vietnam War?"
Well, not exactly.
For those old enough to remember, the uprising -- which left some 40 civilians and 13 officers injured, led to 121 official complaints of police brutality and consumed much of the East Village -- was provoked by a different kind of conflict, one that continues today, though with far less fury. Opposition to a 1 A.M. curfew in Tompkins Square Park was the spark that ignited the disturbance. But the tinder had been laid by long-simmering frustration over gentrification: the process of neighborhood change and escalating rents since glamorized by the Broadway musical "Rent."
What began as a demonstration against the curfew turned into a night of bloodshed after bottles were tossed at riot police, who responded with "appalling behavior," according to a Police Department report that attributed the misconduct to inexperienced officers and poor supervision. The six hours of violence on the night of Aug. 6-7, much of it recorded by amateur video makers and repeatedly broadcast on television, showed the officers, some of whom had removed their badges, beating and kicking demonstrators and bystanders.
In the end, a handful of high-ranking commanders on duty that night were reprimanded, transferred or forced into early retirement, but not one of the 14 officers tried on brutality charges was convicted. Though the Police Department has never called the disturbance a riot, it is rarely called anything else by many East Villagers, who see it as a definining moment in contemporary local history.
If the squatters, skinheads and anarchists who helped encourage the 1988 uprising and other episodes of unrest had hoped to halt gentrification, they have, by most accounts, been sorely disappointed. The disturbances seemed to cool development in the neighborhood for a time, but the stock market crash and recession in the late 1980's and early 90's probably had more to do with it.
These days, however, gentrification is alive and well in the East Village, thanks to plummeting crime, the waning crack epidemic and the city's robust economy. Avenue B, once a no-man's-land of drug dealers and shuttered storefronts, is lined with a smattering of new restaurants, bars and boutiques. Luxury rentals are moving briskly on Avenue B and Second Street, and even once-anarchic and drug-addled Avenue C feels tame.
A renovated Tompkins Square Park, which used to teem with encampments of homeless people, is now closed -- and calm -- after midnight, and Alphabet City squatters say they feel increasingly threatened by City Hall. "Gentrification has definitely returned to the East Village," said Edward I. Koch, who was Mayor at the time of the disturbance. "And like Martha Stewart says, 'It's a good thing.' "
But if gentrification is back, the street activism it inspired seems to have dissipated. Veterans of the "Battle of Tompkins Square," as locals call it, say they no longer know how to stop the changes, and some acknowledge that their movement has simply run out of steam. "In many ways, it feels like we've lost the war," said Jerry Wade, 49, a squatter and housing advocate known as Jerry the Peddler, who organizes a commemorative concert in the park each August. "Sometimes people just get tired of fighting."
 
'The Most Creative Years Are Behind Us'
The neighborhood's feisty spirit, which was established by 19th-century female suffragists and 20th-century socialists, isn't the only thing that has faded over the last decade. Local activists, artists and even business owners agree that the East Village's essence as a bastion of American counterculture and an incubator of unconventional politics has been inexorably chipped away.
"It might sound funny coming from someone like me, but the East Village has been cleaned up to the point that it's losing its rough and colorful edge," said Bob Perl, a real estate broker whose 10th Street offices face Tompkins Square Park. "The most creative years are behind us, and that's a real pity."
Ever since the 1850's, when German and Irish immigrants fleeing upheaval arrived, the sprawl of tenements east of Third Avenue has housed successive waves of immigrants. Jews escaping anti-Semitism, Ukrainians fleeing Communism and Puerto Ricans seeking economic opportunity replaced the Germans and the Irish. In the 1950's and 60's, it was beatniks and hippies who came in search of cheap housing and free love. In the 70's, many children of the immigrants left for the suburbs and arson claimed buildings that were abandoned by their landlords. Into the breach came the real estate investors, attracted in the early 80's by the area's deflated prices, who began renovating dilapidated buildings.
Since then, escalating rents have gradually forced the next generation of struggling poets, artists and assorted malcontents to settle elsewhere. The result, many say, is that the neighborhood's unique vitality and its tradition of artistic iconoclasm is steadily being sapped.
For Mark Russell, executive director of Performance Space 122, that means many performers no longer live within walking distance of the red-brick schoolhouse that was converted in the late 70's and is now one of the neighborhood's better-known cultural institutions. "People used to roll out of bed to come to rehearsals," he said. "Now we can't do as many late shows because folks have to get back to Brooklyn."
For Chris Flash, the editor of The Shadow, an anarchist newspaper, it means a shrinking pool of neighborhood bile and thinner crowds at rallies protesting things like the eviction of squatters and the destruction of community gardens. "The East Village has always been a school for activists," he said. "But gentrification is scattering people all over the city, keeping them from coalescing spontaneously."
 
Harsh View of Newcomers: Party Animals With Money
Longtime residents complain that more often than not, the newcomers who can afford $1,000-a-month studios are young, work-obsessed and uninterested in civic affairs or political activism. Even those who championed more development in the neighborhood have been disappointed at the results. "We didn't expect to get so many transients and so few families," said Krystyna Piorkowska, 48, a member of Community Board 3 and one of the first who called for a curfew in Tompkins Square Park. "The problem is that these people move here because they see the neighborhood as a place to party, and when they grow up, they'll move elsewhere."
But in the meantime they have also contributed to a dramatic change in the neighborhood's retail landscape. At least half of all businesses in the East Village have opened since Tompkins Square Park erupted, according to local brokers, and commercial rents on streets like St. Marks Place and Avenue A, once the most combustible parts of the neighborhood, are getting closer to those in nearby Greenwich Village, although there is still a disparity. Mr. Perl, the head of Tower Brokerage, said that average rents on Avenue A range from $35 to $60 a square foot, compared with $50 to $100 a square foot on Seventh Avenue South.
The East Village vacancy rate is a tight 3 percent, down from 20 percent a decade ago, said Christine Dyke, project director of Businesses in the East Village Association, a merchants group.
"For many years we just couldn't get anyone to open shop down here," she said. "Now our biggest problem is the high rate of turnover. Some spaces have had four businesses in two years, and that's not a good thing." She and other business owners attribute the problem to steep rents, small storefronts and the fact that the area is still not a destination spot for many shoppers.
The most frequent complaint heard from merchants and residents is that a disproportionate number of new businesses are bars and restaurants aimed at outsiders. Of the 45 establishments that serve alcohol along Avenue A, which runs from 14th Street to Houston Street, 37 have opened in the last few years, Ms. Piorkowska said. On weekend nights, the avenue is mobbed with carousing bar hoppers from uptown Manhattan and the other boroughs.
"Unfortunately we've become an alcoholic Disneyland, a sort of East Village theme park," said Ms. Piorkowska, whose organization, Save Avenue A Society, has been trying to stem the proliferation of bars.
If half the area's merchants are recent arrivals, Linda Heidinger qualifies as an old-timer. In 1981 her restaurant, Pharmacy, became one of the first new businesses to open across from the park. Four years later she opened a boutique, Alphabets, a few storefronts away. "Back then, people were afraid of the East Village and you couldn't even get a cab on Avenue A," Ms. Heidinger, 50, said. An atmosphere of chaos pervaded the neighborhood, heightened, she said, by the haze of smoke that drifted over Avenue A from cooking fires in the park. "I can't tell you how many times I had to yank junkies out of my store or throw out people who were shooting up in my bathroom," she said.
Things got worse in the mid-1980's, she said, as skirmishes over gentrification intensified and the park grew dense with cardboard shanties and plastic tents. One day, a group of youths smashed the window at Alphabets and ran off with a pile of T-shirts. "I knew who did it," Ms. Heidinger said, "because I saw a bunch of skinheads wearing my shirts in the park. They had only stolen one kind of shirt -- the ones with 666 printed on them."
 
'Still Young and Creative, But Now They Have Jobs'
But Ms. Heidinger persisted and prospered as the social strife ebbed after the homeless were evicted from the park in 1991. In 1996, she opened a housewares store, Lancelotti, on Avenue A and Fifth Street, followed by two more branches of Alphabets in other parts of Manhattan. Business, she says, has never been better. Like many merchants, Ms. Heidinger, who has lived in the East Village for 20 years, does not think gentrification has been bad for the neighborhood. "I'm just glad I no longer have to pull drunken guys out of my vestibule every night," she said.
Another pioneer who welcomes the transformation is Kathy Kirkpatrick, who opened Life, a cafe, on Avenue B and 10th Street in 1982. In those days, she said, Avenue B was an open-air drug bazaar, lined with burned-out buildings and garbage-strewn lots. Having barely survived the decade, she says she is relieved that the renaissance, as she calls it, has finally arrived. Besides local patrons, many of whom plop down with laptops and cell phones, a growing number of tourists show up, as well as people who have seen "Rent," which mentions Life three times.
Ms. Kirkpatrick recently renovated her restaurant and upgraded her menu to appeal to a changing clientele. These days she is as likely to serve martinis and frozen margaritas as veggie burgers and chamomile tea. "Our customers are still young and creative," she said, "but now they have jobs."
Few neighborhoods have as rich a concentration of cultural venues as the East Village. Some of those places have become household names, like the music club CBGB, the experimental theater company La Mama E.T.C., and the rough-and-tumble performance space ABC No Rio. None of them, however, are money-makers and all of them depend on cheap rents to survive. ABC No Rio, which has helped get the careers of many artists -- including the painter Kiki Smith and the singer Michele Shocked -- off the ground, nearly lost its Rivington Street building last year when the city tried to turn it into housing. "We really shouldn't be here," said Steven Englander, ABC No Rio's administrative coordinator. "We just fought hard and got lucky."
Another neighborhood institution, Charas/El Bohio, a Hispanic cultural center, hasn't fared as well. Late last month, the city auctioned its home, a turn-of-the-century public school on Ninth Street and Avenue B, to an undisclosed bidder for $3.15 million. Armando Perez, the group's chairman, says the city's decision to sell its building was an act of vengeance by the Mayor and his ally, Antonio Pagan, the Commissioner of Employment, who used to represent the area in the City Council. Mr. Perez, who is active in local politics, was a frequent critic of Mr. Pagan, who long maintained that Charas did not serve the community. "The truth is," Mr. Pagan said on Friday, "Charas is simply a cash cow for Armando Perez and his cohorts. To call it a community center is a farce. Nothing ever happens there."
Neighborhood residents, however, view the sale as further proof of the East Village's cultural decline. Dozens of theater and dance companies rely on the organization's inexpensive space, as does a bike repair workshop for troubled youths and a group that offers English classes to newly arrived immigrants. After it was abandoned by the city in the 1970's, Charas began renovating the five-story building with the help of donated labor and money from local fund-raising events. Mr. Perez estimates that over the last 19 years, his group has invested the equivalent of $2 million to bring the building back to life. "When we got here, the place had been so badly vandalized that even the doors were gone," he said. "Now it's a centerpiece of the community."
On a recent Friday afternoon the building was humming with activity as a half-dozen artists quietly worked across the hall from theater troupes that were loudly rehearsing in former classrooms. In the ground-floor auditorium, the Synesthetic Theater Company was gearing up for a performance. "We simply couldn't exist without this kind of space," said Mark Greenfield, 35, who was directing a scene from "Henry IV" for the Henry Street Settlement Playhouse. He said that the room he was using, which rents for $10 an hour, is often booked weeks in advance and that the only comparable space, a studio on West 48th Street, offers smaller rooms at $15 an hour. "Losing this place wouldn't just hurt the Lower East Side, but the entire city," he said.
In a studio across the hall, Tracy Zungola, 35, wearing a pair of paint-splattered shorts, was furious at the prospect of searching for new space. Over the last few years, she said, rising rents had driven her out of two nearby studios. "It just doesn't stop," said Ms. Zungola, who pays $257 a month for her space, which is lined with canvases featuring cartoonish images of meat or furniture covered by lacerated flesh. "I can't bear getting kicked out of another space."
 
'That's the Nature Of Growing Up'
Chris Flash of the Shadow has fond memories of the days when protesters and the police clashed frequently in and around Tompkins Square Park. "Back then I think we were able to keep gentrification at bay by maintaining a perceived climate of instability," said Mr. Flash, sitting in the basement offices of his quarterly publication. To keep developers apprehensive, he said, he and his friends would build trash fires in the street, break what he described as "yuppie storefronts," and paint the slogan "Mug a Yuppie" alongside automatic teller machines.
But such brazen tactics have lost favor in recent years, he said, as a sense of futility has set in among activists who have mellowed with age. "It's hard to keep that intensity and that level of anger going forever," said Mr. Flash, who is 40.
A decade ago the civil liberties lawyer Ron Kuby helped to represent some of those who were beaten by the police during the Tompkins Square disturbance. He also filed a lawsuit against the city on behalf of homeless park residents who wanted to burn refuse in garbage cans. Now Mr. Kuby, 42, is the father of a toddler who plays in Tompkins Square Park, and he says he would not tolerate smoke wafting into the playground these days. "Things that were once viewed as the energetic flourishing of experimental multiculturalism now just appear to be potentially criminal and possibly dangerous," he said with a tinge of sarcasm. "I guess that's the nature of growing up."
If Mr. Kuby mourns the disappearance of the neighborhood's radical ferment, he also enjoys the newfound civility and safety in the streets. He also occasionally indulges, somewhat guiltily, he said, in some of the area's new stores, like the Moondog ice cream parlor on Avenue A. "I don't mind that some of the bodegas whose windows were filled with old bottles of Lysol and Spic and Span but sold drugs under the counter are gone," he said. "That's O.K., I guess, as long as a few of them are left."
Still, the neighborhood's pugnacious spirit is far from moribund. During last month's auction of Charas and a half-dozen community gardens, East Village residents staged an unusual protest by releasing thousands of live crickets inside One Police Plaza. Pandemonium ensued and four people were arrested on misdemeanor charges, but in the end, the auction went ahead. "We didn't win that one, but I think we proved that the final curtain has yet to come down," said Fran Luck, a housing advocate whose retrospective exhibition on the uprising, "Ten Years of Protest on the Lower East Side," is on view at ABC No Rio.
If squatters and anarchists see yuppies as a threat to the East Village's survival, then Thomas Miller, on the face of it, would appear to be the enemy.
Two weeks ago Mr. Miller, 25, moved into a $1,400-a-month apartment on Avenue C and Ninth Street, just opposite the squat that is home to Jerry the Peddler and a few doors east of Charas. Every morning when he leaves, dressed in a suit and tie, for his job as a mutual fund analyst, Mr. Miller said, he endures a gantlet of disapproving stares. "I feel an animosity on the street that I don't think I deserve," he said last week, sitting on the floor of his unfurnished apartment surrounded by boxes he has yet to unpack.
His entry-level job at Oppenheimer & Company, he says, pays him just enough to cover his rent and living expenses. He is still desperately looking for a roommate to share his two-bedroom apartment. "I work in a corporate environment, but I don't make a corporate salary," said Mr. Miller, a soft-spoken Minnesota native who graduated from the University of Notre Dame two years ago.
During his first year in New York, Mr. Miller worked as a volunteer teacher at a school in the neighborhood as part of a program that also provided him with housing. When his stint ended, he spent three anxious months looking for an apartment in the city. Nothing he saw, he said, fit his budget. Finally he paid $2,200 to a broker, who found his current apartment, which is above a bar whose patrons occasionally keep him awake at night.
A theater buff who wants to study acting one day, Mr. Miller says he was drawn to the East Village by its culture, its color and its abundant night life. "I hate the stuffiness of the Upper East Side," he said. But as much as he likes his new neighborhood, he is disappointed by the hostility he feels on the street. "Maybe I'm part of the problem, or at least some people think that way," he said, "but I have a right to live here, too."

Photo/Chart: "HISTORY: The Times of Tompkins Square Park"
For more than 150 years, Tompkins Square Park, the oldest park on the Lower East Side, has served as a place of respite and dissent. Some major moments in park history:
1834 City condemns and buys land known today as Tompkins Square Park, much of which had belonged to John Jacob Astor. Most nearby residents are lower-middle-class immigrants, including many Irish shipbuilders.
1874 7,000 people "agitating for work relief" are involved in a riot with the police on Jan. 13.
1877 Gathering of railway workers supporting the nation's first railroad strike.
1888 Temperance Fountain is erected.
1894 One of the nation's first playgrounds built in park.
1897 Christodora House opens as a settlement house on east side of park. Today it is a luxury co-op.
1906 Monument to General Slocum steamship fire is erected. Most of the more than 1,000 passengers who died aboard the Slocum in the East River were German immigrants who lived near the park.
1930's Recreational amenities like handball courts and swing sets are added, and many pathways are paved.
1961 Neighborhood opposition scuttles Parks Department plan for a softball diamond.
1966 Bandshell is completed.
1966-69 Neighborhood and park become a haven for hippie movement, with frequent concerts and rallies at bandshell.
Aug. 6, 1988 Rioting involving hundreds of people and police officers erupts over Parks Department's imposition of a curfew.
PUB-DATE: June 3, 1991
Aug. 25, 1993 Rebuilt park is reopened.
(Source: Parks Department)

SECTION: Section 3; Page 8; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1072 words

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
With Stocks Slumping, Currency Trading Soars

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
THE refrain on foreign exchange trading desks these days is: "Volatility is being very good to me."
Most currency traders don't miss what was for them the dull, trendless and not very profitable trading that dominated the mid-1990's. It has given way to big daily movements and strong trends in many currencies, especially those at the heart of the Asian financial crisis. 
 The forces that are causing the volatility have helped to unsettle other financial markets, and the atmosphere of higher risk played a role in Wall Street's big drop in the last few weeks. But trends are favorable for the international bankers, traders and investors who make part of their living from movements in currencies, whether up or down.
"It is a nice time to be a foreign exchange dealer," said Robert White, the treasurer of Standard Chartered Bank. "That volatility provides opportunities for risk-taking and brings in customer business" as investors and financial managers try to hedge against adverse moves or buy currencies to help them enter or exit fast-moving investments around the world.
Craig A. Puffenberger, the head of global foreign exchange options at Credit Suisse First Boston, put it another way: "The volatility gives us opportunities to find things to buy cheaply and to sell them expensively."
But what is good for money traders and banks, of course, is not necessarily good for everyone. The increased volatility and sharp strengthening of the dollar against many currencies have caused some problems.
For American companies, a stronger dollar makes their products more expensive and less competitive abroad. It makes imports cheaper and more competitive in this country. Big-name companies like Coca-Cola, Dow Corning, Union Carbide and 3M all said the strong dollar had contributed to the weakness in their latest financial results.
Currency volatility increases the uncertainty for companies doing business abroad and for investors who put their money to work in overseas markets. This uncertainty raises their costs as they hedge to protect themselves against unexpected plunges or increases in a currency's value.
Exchange-rate doubts also can reach into the pocketbooks of the average tourist, abruptly raising or lowering costs for hotels and plane tickets from one day to the next.
 THE reasons for the revived volatility are many, including the collapse of economies in Asia, the inability of Japan to overcome its economic malaise and the threat of a financial crisis in Russia that could spread elsewhere.
Jeremy Fand, the senior foreign exchange strategist at BankBoston, thinks the market has taken its eye off the economic fundamentals that moved currencies in the past, like differences between interest rates and inflation rates around the world.
Instead, the market is moved by themes -- the presumed inadequacies of the new Japanese Government, for example. "The market attaches much more significance to these themes," he said, adding that traders could fixate on one as quickly as they could forget another.
The gyrations in Asian and emerging-markets currencies have helped offset the loss of profit opportunities in Europe, where volatility has evaporated ahead of the Jan. 1, 1999 introduction of Europe's single currency, the euro.
From its high to its low this year, the dollar has moved just 5.5 percent against the German mark. In contrast, the Japanese yen has had three big moves -- 3.8 percent, 4.5 percent and 6.9 percent -- against the dollar in just the last eight weeks.
 SOME beneficiaries of currency volatility have been the big banks that are the major players in the foreign exchange market, with its activity of $1.4 trillion a day.
At Chase Manhattan Bank, for example, revenue from foreign exchange trading jumped 70 percent in the first quarter of this year and 58 percent in the second quarter. Foreign exchange revenue at Citibank rose 17 percent in the first quarter and 50 percent in the second quarter.
While these returns are not a major source of revenue, they have contributed to the strong performance of these banks' stocks this year. Chase is up 26.4 percent for the year, and Citicorp, the parent of Citibank, is up 19.8 percent.
Currencies may or may not stay volatile. A rebound in Asia or a turnaround in the financial outlook for Russia could make them more stable.
But banks that trade currencies have been lifted for now, at least, out of the doldrums of a few years ago. Back then, low volatility, the broadening use of electronic trading and concerns about the arrival of the single currency in Europe led to layoffs and closures of trading desks -- as well as a decline in revenue from currency trading.
Donald H. Layton, vice chairman of global markets-international at Chase Manhattan, said the higher revenue was coming from three sources: proprietary trading, in which the bank bets its own money on the direction of currencies; higher volumes of trading from customers, which these days are predominantly money managers, hedge funds and others moving money around the the world; and the bigger spreads, or differences between the buying and selling prices of currencies that come with higher volatility. The larger spreads add to the revenue and profits from trading.
Mr. Layton acknowledged that trading in more volatile markets "means there is more risk." But he said the banks could handle that partly because more of their foreign exchange revenue comes from customer dealings than from proprietary trading.
One indication of this, he said, is the inconsequential fallout from the surprising intervention on June 17 by the United States and Japan to support the yen, which moved 4.7 percent higher in one day.
"The intervention for the market was a major event, but it was not a major profit- and-loss event to the banks," he said.
Charles Peabody, the bank analyst at Mitchell Securities, is more concerned about bank reliance on currency volatility.
In a recent report to clients, Mr. Peabody said the rise in volatility was one reason that bank activities like underwriting, mergers and acquisitions, trading, and handling of international capital flows have done so well.
"A reversal of a strong U.S. dollar and low long-term interest rates should prove disruptive to market-sensitive sources of revenues, the mainstay of the current double-digit earnings-per-share growth in the banking industry," he wrote.

SECTION: Section 4; Page 1; Column 1; Week in Review Desk
