HEADLINE: The World: Taking Stock;
Forget Which Came First. What Comes Next?

BYLINE: By EDWARD WYATT 

 BODY:
EARLY two years ago, Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan made a few cautionary comments about the economy and uttered an ominous warning about "irrational exuberance" among stock market investors. Investors were jolted upright for a few days, then shrugged, and stock prices soared even higher in the months afterward.
Last month, Mr. Greenspan gave a surprisingly upbeat report on the economy and suggested that stock prices did not appear out of line with the current good times. Almost immediately, investors grew wary, and stock prices beat a retreat that quickened considerably last week. 
 Which, among rational souls, raises perplexing questions. Does the stock market's performance have anything to do with the outlook for the economy? Can the economy be helped or hindered by the performance of the stock market? And, above all, which comes first: a strong economy or a bull market? Recession or crash?
The mystifying nature of that chicken-or-egg quandary is no longer solely a topic in ivory towers. Down in the barnyard, the groundlings know that they are expected to play a big part in determining the future of the stock market.
And last week, on cue, individual investors reacted to the market's swoon with predictable bleatings about buying opportunities and impending rebounds.
 
Bouncing Back
"Individual investors believe they have learned that the market, like Joe Palooka, always bounces back," said Ira Kaminow, an economist and president of Capital Insights Group, a Washington, D.C. consulting firm. One day the market will not bounce back, however, and a sustained decline will lead to a drop in consumer spending, now a key source of fuel for the economy.
"I think it would take a fairly substantial and persistent decline, one lasting six to nine months, for their enthusiasm and optimism to begin to wane," Mr. Kaminow said.
When the downturn comes, the effect might be more pronounced than it was during the boom.
"On the way up, the stock market's gains did not boost spending as much as people had expected," said Anthony Chan, chief economist at Banc One Investment Advisors, based in Columbus, Ohio. "For every $1 of capital gains, we've seen consumer spending rise by about 3 cents."
But if the black ink on investors' mutual fund account statements starts turning to red, he said, "for every $1 in losses we'll see a decline in consumption of 4 to 4.5 cents."
Clearly, the performance of the stock market influences whether individuals spend money, and thus affects the nation's economy. The savings rate has fallen to historic lows in recent months not because people believe that they do not need to put away a few dollars for retirement. Rather, they have grown to believe they can put away some loose change, then wait for the ever-rising stock market to turn that into dollars.
With the rest of their money -- some of which they would otherwise be saving -- individuals feel free to buy new cars, take more exotic vacations, finish paneling the basement or likewise spend on frills that they would have ignored.
That spending creates demand for goods, causing factories to hire workers to assemble automobiles, staff hotels and churn out linoleum. Sales of their products and services create greater profits for those companies; higher earnings help to boost the companies' stock prices, resulting in greater returns for Mr. and Ms. Spendthrift's mutual funds. The virtuous circle starts anew.
The rising tide, moreover, lifts even the heaviest boats. The gains that average Americans reap from their investments result in more tax dollars for Federal and state coffers. Budget surpluses, in turn, lead to calls for lower taxes and even greater optimism among individual investors. But the stock market can also work against the economy, quickly turning the virtuous circle into a vicious cycle.
The trigger can be anything -- Asian tremors, the unraveling of a merger, a border skirmish. Often, traders sell first, leaving the questions for later.
When capital gains turn into capital losses, government revenues dry up, as does spending by consumers, as does hiring by companies.
Alan Greenspan recently pointed out that the Japanese had a similar experience. Revenues were pouring into the Government during the bubble economy, then when things turned bad, the deluge turned into a drought.
"In that respect," Mr. Kaminow said, "the Japanese might be seven to nine years ahead of where we are."
In the United States over just the last three and a half years, sharp gains in the stock market have produced substantial profits for most people in their mutual funds. Those profits have been maintained even as many individual stocks have suffered big declines.
In each year since the beginning of 1995, investors have poured a record amount of money into mutual funds that invest in American stocks, and the total in the first six months of 1998 is ahead of last year's pace.
Weighting those $600 billion of investments by the stock-market levels at which they were made shows that Americans have aggregate profits of 45 percent over that three-and-a-half year span. Clearly, it would take a much sharper decline than last week's to get their attention.
"I don't think the current stock market decline is enough to drag consumption growth down to recessionary levels," said Mr. Chan said on Thursday. "Before we get there, we'll need to see employment growth slowing down."
On Friday, the Labor Department reported that the United States economy added jobs in July at the slowest pace in more than two years. Weakness in the manufacturing sector could easily be traced to the General Motors strike, but service companies, like those in the financial industry, also slowed. The stock market responded by moving higher.
A market downturn could give a sharp and sudden jolt to employment, however.
The boom in the securities market has spawned rapid growth not only in the financial services industry but also in the innumerable pilot fish that swim alongside -- more mutual fund salesclerks, more real estate agents selling apartments to bonus-toting brokers, more deliverymen bringing sandwiches to late-night dealmakers.
"If the equity market doesn't continue to do very well, the first areas you'll see it is in the Northeast," particularly New York City, Mr. Chan said. "The market has driven real estate prices in New York. The luxury sectors will start to slow. And at some point it will spill over into Main Street."
So, what is the likelihood that the current weakness will morph into a brutish downturn anytime soon? "It's a non-trivial probability," said Mr. Kaminow. "But less than 50-50. I'm more optimistic than pessimistic, but compared to a year ago, I can see the dangers more easily."
As for Alan Greenspan, he is undoubtedly happy that investors are heeding his words, said Mr. Chan. "The entire Federal Reserve is probably dancing in the street after seeing that some of the air was let out of the market."

HEADLINE: INVESTING IT;
Buying the Backbones of the Wireless Age

BYLINE: By SANA SIWOLOP 

 BODY:
GIVEN the money poured into the shares of glossy new cyberspace ventures lately, it is easy to overlook companies that are exploiting more down-to-earth technologies.
Consider the companies that build or own transmission towers for the rapidly expanding wireless communications business. 
 Yes, they may lack the new-kid-in-town sizzle of an Internet software concern. But besides building or owning wireless transmission towers, these companies often perform valuable maintenance services for phone, cellular, paging and data transmission companies. Investors have taken note.
In June, the largest tower company, American Tower, went public at $21 a share. Even in the face of the market's big drop last week, the company's class A stock closed at $23 on Friday after having traded as high as $28 on July 23.
Two other tower companies, Crown Castle International and Pinnacle Tower, are expected to go public soon. At the end of July, Crown nearly doubled the size of its offering; if it goes through at its expected price of $18 a share, the offering would be one of the largest of the year, with a market value of $1.76 billion.
It is not difficult to see how antennae towers are showing up on investors' radar.
Falling prices for wireless communications are attracting vast numbers of consumers, which means that the wireless companies are expanding their networks for sending and receiving data.
The wireless industry has also turned far more competitive, and wireless carriers have started improving their efficiency by either selling their networks -- and then leasing them back -- or establishing joint ventures with companies that will manage them.
The advent of digital television is also benefiting the antenna-tower industry, by increasing demand for new towers to accommodate new digital transmission equipment.
Victor Miller, a broadcasting analyst at Bear, Stearns, which helped take American Tower public, said the wireless industry already was using 40,000 to 50,000 transmission towers in the United States. Demand for towers to accommodate cellular and personal communications services alone could raise that number close to 100,000 by 2001, industry analysts say.
Mr. Miller, like several other analysts, said he expected the tower industry to keep consolidating. The main reason is that no single company owns more than 3 percent of the towers.
Indeed, American Tower owns or operates only about 1,900 towers, while Crown Castle has 1,219. Specialty Teleconstructors, which went public in 1994, has 801, and Pinnacle Holdings has 646.
To some investors, so-called tower economics look attractive.
For one thing, the towers are relatively inexpensive to build, usually costing no more than $200,000 each. After the towers are up, they tend to generate steady revenue, much of it from blue-chip companies that often sign long-term contracts. These pacts usually require payment in advance and contain built-in rent increases.
 SOME tower management companies have amassed impressive lists of customers. Crown Castle's clients, for example, include AT&T Wireless, Bell Atlantic Mobile, Motorola, Pagenet and Sprint PCS. Last year, the company acquired the domestic broadcast transmission network of the British Broadcasting Corporation. It is also pursuing acquisitions in Australia and New Zealand.
That kind of early foothold in the international wireless market distinguishes Crown Castle from American Tower, its nearest competitor. But Crown is also carrying more debt than its rival because of acquisitions over the last 18 months. As of March 31, it had $437 million in debt, more than three times as much as American Tower, although Crown's planned initial offering could erase much of that debt.
Randall Roth, an analyst at Renaissance Capital, an initial-offering research firm in Greenwich, Conn., said Crown Castle had enough cash flow to service the debt. But he said the stock carried other risks. Because of the company's rapid expansion, he said, "it's hard to determine where their internal growth ends and where their acquisition growth begins."
In addition, he said, the company's ability to generate enough cash flow will depend on how well it can compete with other bidders for tower rights -- and on how customers rate the quality and breadth of the company's network.
When it comes to breadth, American Tower may have a two-year lead on its rivals, analysts said. It also appears to have a more diversified customer base, with no single customer accounting for more than 10 percent of the company's revenue.
 BY contrast, during the first three months of this year, BBC accounted for about 46 percent of Crown Castle's revenue, while Nextel Communications, its second-largest customer, accounted for 10 percent.
The importance of quick expansion is perhaps best seen in a strategy change by Specialty Teleconstructors. It has been focused on building and managing towers for other companies while others were busy buying. Now the company is racing to catch up but has found that the price of existing towers has become so expensive that it is cheaper to build them.
The shift in Specialty's business plan contributed to a 12 percent decline in revenue and a 53 percent decline in profits for the nine months ended March 31, compared with the period a year earlier. But the shift from just managing to owning could eventually mean a stronger revenue stream for the company.
Specialty also expects to derive advantages from its acquisition in April of another tower company, OmniAmerica Inc., which has amassed marketing power with several wireless carriers, like BellSouth, and which also recently received an investment windfall from Hicks, Muse, Tate & Furst, the venture capital firm.
"This business is a great economic model on paper, but it's very complex -- it's not as simple as 'build a tower and they will come,' " said Carl E. Hirsch, the chief executive of OmniAmerica. "It's about building carrier relationships. It's not just about real estate."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 2; Column 3; Money and Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1032 words

HEADLINE: DIARY

BYLINE: By JAN M. ROSEN

 BODY:

THE ECONOMY
No Longer Sizzling
Economic indicators painted a far less robust picture than they had earlier in the year. The Conference Board reported that its Index of Leading Economic Indicators slipped in June, as it had in May. It stood at 105, down 0.2 percent from May. "It doesn't mean bad times for the U.S. economy, but we've seen the best," said Allen Sinai, chief global economist at Primark Decision Economics. Similarly, the Federal Reserve said in releasing its beige book that although the economy was healthy, growth showed signs of slowing as exports to Asia slumped. Personal incomes rose a scant 0.2 percent in June. The nation's unemployment rate held steady at 4.5 percent and wage growth eased in July. 

HEALTH CARE
Hemorrhaging Red Ink
Managed care, manage thyself, investors might well say. United Healthcare, one of the nation's largest health maintenance organizations, said it would take a $900 million charge in its second quarter, in part to abandon unprofitable Medicare plans. "People seem to forget that Medicare was created because private insurers could not make money on the elderly population," said Diane Archer, executive director of the Medicare Rights Center, a consumer organization in New York. Following the debacle at Oxford Health Plans, another managed care concern, the move sparked an investor stampede out of health care stocks and possibly jeopardized United Healthcare's proposed $5.5 billion merger with its rival, Humana Inc., which would create the nation's largest H.M.O.
 
AUTOS
Streamlining G.M.
General Motors, the world's largest auto maker, said it would build a new generation of highly efficient assembly plants in North America. To the dismay of the United Automobile Workers, which effectively shut down G.M. with eight-week strikes against two parts facilities, the new plants could use as little as half the number of workers currently employed at G.M. assembly plants, like this one in Shreveport, La. Outside suppliers, many with nonunion workers, would do much of the work. G.M., which reported that sales fell 38 percent in July, also announced a sweeping reorganization of its internal distribution structure that is expected to save $200 million to $300 million a year and eliminate as many as 1,000 white-collar jobs, and said it would spin off Delphi Automotive Systems, its parts unit. Ford reported a 4.3 percent slide in domestic car and truck sales for July, and Chrysler registered a 3 percent gain.
 
SUNBEAM
Less Than Sunny
Sunbeam, the appliance maker, said it would restate last year's financial statements, resulting in a "material adjustment," and possibly the results for 1996 and the first quarter of this year, too, because of possible accounting irregularities. One analyst estimated that the adjustment would be $25 million to $50 million. The stock slid $1, to a new low of $7 on Thursday. The disclosure followed an announcement that Sunbeam and Albert J. Dunlap, the former chairman and chief executive ousted by the board in June, had signed a "joint cooperation agreement" to share various documents related to lawsuits and an investigation into the financial results. But the two sides quickly began bickering about what they had agreed on. Still, one thing went right for the company: the American Medical Association agreed to pay Sunbeam $9.9 million for backing out of a deal to endorse the company's humidifiers, blood pressure monitors and other products.
 
THE INTERNET
New Frontier for Business
A century and a half ago, when Americans pushed back the Western frontier, they panned for gold. Well, so far, this century's frontier, the Internet, has not proved itself a gold mine. But business is trying. Amazon.com, showing that its aspirations extend to selling far more than books over the Internet, bought the Junglee Corporation, which operates a service that lets people shop on line for everything from clothing to computers, and Planet All, which operates a vast Internet address service. And Agency.com agreed to acquire Eagle River Interactive. The Omnicom Group will own just under half the combined company, which will be the Internet's largest ad agency.
 
DEALS
Allied Signal's Bid
Allied Signal, a maker of aerospace and automotive products, announced a $9.8 billion unsolicited offer for AMP Inc., which said it would review the offer. . . . Albertson's Inc. said it would acquire American Stores for $8.3 billion in stock, in a deal that would create the nation's largest supermarket chain. . . . Eastman Kodak agreed to buy the Imation Corporation's medical imaging business for $520 million in cash. The move shows that Kodak, after shrinking operations and its work force earlier this year, is now rebuilding.
 
SOFTWARE
A Setback for Microsoft
A Federal judge ordered Microsoft to turn over to the Government the source code for its operating systems, Windows 95 and Windows 98, and to make its chairman, William H. Gates, and 16 other executives available for pretrial depositions taking as long as the Justice Department deemed necessary to prepare for a Sept. 8 trial in the Government's antitrust suit against the company. . . . A vulnerability was discovered in Eudora, the most widely used E-mail software, just days after a serious security flaw was found in two rival electronic-mail programs. The flaws would permit an attacker to destroy or steal data or tamper with a personal computer, although no incidents have been reported.
 
CREDIT UNIONS
Victory From Defeat
Bankers were cheering five months ago when the Supreme Court ruled that the nation's laws did not permit credit unions to include more than one occupational group in their memberships. But credit unions had the last laugh. Congress passed a measure to permit them to expand their memberships, and President Clinton said that he would sign it, even though it does not require credit unions to abide by fair-lending rules that banks must follow. Alfonse M. D'Amato, the New York Republican who heads the Senate Banking Committee, said of the credit unions, "We need them in these days of consolidation and mega-mergers to serve the little guys."

HEADLINE: Coverage of Club Raids Showed Bias for Owners

 BODY:

To the Editor:
I thought your July 5 article "The Cafe Police Pop in for a Raid" was very unbalanced and biased toward the club owners. The photo caption, "Hilly Kristal, owner of CBGB's, endures a visit by Social Club Task Force agents," was too much. 
 Perhaps your follow-up article should have a photo of one of the residents living near one of the rowider venues in the East Village/ Lower East Side who has endured yet another night of lost sleep due to thumping bass, open doors allowing over-loud music, crowd noise and rowdy patrons entering and leaving.
For the record, Hilly Kristal is one of the more responsible club owners.
Andrew Rasiej's comment that the night life industry is "unfortunately not seen as a component of the social and economic fabric of New York" is simply warped logic. Enforcement of laws and regulations does not imply blindness toward any one industry.
 
MARCIA H. LEMMON
Lower East Side
 
The writer is chairwoman of the Ludlow Block Association.

HEADLINE: U.S. Oilmen Chafing at Curbs on Iran

BYLINE: By JANE PERLEZ and STEVE LeVINE 

DATELINE: BAKU, Azerbaijan

 BODY:
American oil companies, the largest players on the energy-rich Caspian Sea, are expressing growing exasperation with the White House policy forbidding American investment in Iran.
Despite an overture to Iran by Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright in June, the Administration has insisted that geopolitical strategy outstrips the commercial advantages being ceded to European companies doing business there. 
 Intense lobbying by letter, in advertisements and by oil executives personally has got nowhere in an Administration that promotes commercial diplomacy but draws a line at Iran.
"It has to be admitted there is a problem with American companies," Stuart E. Eizenstat, Under Secretary for Economic Affairs at the State Department, said in a telephone interview. "But this is a situation where the strategic interests of the United States are so great that they outweigh temporary advantages of American companies."
By moving into Iran, Mr. Eizenstat said, European companies are providing revenue that the Iranians may use to develop weapons of mass destruction.
"This seems to be a factor the Europeans discount," he said. "We don't have the luxury of discounting the strategic burden."
The conflict dramatizes an Administration in agonizing flux, trying to adapt to a changed, intensely competitive global economy in which America's allies are brazenly defying sanctions while trying also to appease a Republican-controlled Congress that adamantly supports the continued isolation of countries like Iran, Libya and Cuba.
For the first time since the fall of the Shah nearly two decades ago, Iran is aggressively marketing investment opportunities, making it a particularly hot subject for American oil companies.
At a conference in London in July, European corporations lined up to bid on 43 oil and gas projects worth $5.6 billion offered by the state-owned Iranian National Oil Company.
In contrast the American oil companies, constrained by a sanctions law and a 1995 Presidential order barring business in Iran, sent only middle-level representatives who could gather information but could not negotiate.
"The London conference provided a great opportunity for the West Europeans to gain great advantage," said Archie W. Dunham, the president of Conoco. "I hope it's only a short-term advantage."
In a letter to Mr. Clinton, Mr. Dunham made clear that as European companies increasingly disregard American sanctions against Iran, they are getting more than just a leg up. In the medium to long run, American oil executives say, it is economically not realistic to exclude Iran from the development of the Caspian as the region becomes one of the world's major energy sources.
Conoco has been a chief critic of the sanctions since the company was forced to cancel a $2 billion contract with Iran two years ago, only to watch this May as the United States granted a French-led consortium a waiver from sanctions for the same deal.
The consortium included Total S.A. of France, Gazprom of Russia and Petronas of Malaysia. President Clinton granted the waiver in return for an agreement by the three countries to clamp down on the sale of nuclear technology to Iran.
The 1996 Iran-Libya Sanctions Act, in addition to barring American business from the two countries, imposes penalties against any company from any nation investing more than $20 million there.
Mr. Dunham told Mr. Clinton that he supported the waiver even though Conoco's competitors benefited, but he warned that the European companies were gaining long-term advantages in Iran.
"It is clear that the governments of the foreign companies investing in Iran are prepared to defend the actions of their corporations," Mr. Dunham wrote. "This is because Iran is important to the economic and national development of the Caspian region."
Some American companies see Iran, one of five countries that border the landlocked Caspian Sea, not only as a place for exploration but also as an economic route for transporting energy to Western markets.
But the Administration has put considerable diplomatic effort into promoting countries that were once part of the Soviet Union -- Azerbaijan, Kazakhstan and Turkmenistan -- as new sources of energy that bypass both Russia and Iran.
Increasingly, oil companies that have already started extracting oil and gas from the Caspian are questioning the wisdom of an Administration-backed plan that would put oil in a lengthy and expensive pipeline from Baku to the Mediterranean port of Ceyhan in Turkey.
The Administration likes this idea because it anchors Turkey, a NATO ally, in the quest for oil and avoids Iran.
Expressing the growing disquiet about the proposed pipeline, an American oil executive here said, "We don't want to be stuck with a white elephant."
 As an indication of the complexities of the questions, the Administration has appointed a coordinator for Caspian Sea issues. He is Richard Morningstar, who has been director of American aid in countries of the former Soviet Union.
Mobil and Conoco have led the effort to persuade the Administration to be more flexible.
Conoco has proposed that American companies be permitted to invest the same as foreign companies -- $20 million each annually.
In May, Mobil sponsored advertisements in two newspapers asking that United States companies be permitted to "swap" oil with Iran -- deliver Caspian crude for use in Iran's northern cities, then pick up an equivalent volume at the country's southern port of Kharg Island.
The advertisements also suggested that the companies be allowed to negotiate deals with Iran, with the understanding that these would remain unconsummated until sanctions are lifted -- a precedent established in Vietnam before the trade embargo there was abolished in 1994.
Finally, the advertisements asked repeal of a ban on the use of Iranian equipment on the Caspian, a move that would free American companies to participate with partners who use Iranian-supplied equipment.
Industry leaders have been watching the progress of an application for the swap waiver that Mobil made to the Treasury Department in April, perceiving it as a bellwether of Administration policy.
Mr. Eizenstat, the Under Secretary, said the application had not yet been considered at the highest levels. But he said swaps were not a "simple solution" to the Caspian's transportation problems, and asserted that they "could create a dangerous dependency on Iran."
Even if the United States appears unlikely to budge much, oil industry analysts said the pressure will continue to build.
They cited a recent trip to Teheran by the Italian Prime Minister, Romano Prodi, followed by a delegation of top European Union leaders. Industry analysts expect more European leaders to visit.

HEADLINE: Abortion Debated in Chile, Where It's Always a Crime

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Nine years after Gen. Augusto Pinochet decreed that abortion was a crime in Chile even when necessary to save the mother's life, the Chilean Senate has taken up the issue for the first time.
Advocates of women's rights here say it is time for a change. But in fact the bill before the Senate would only tighten regulations by increasing prison sentences for anyone convicted of conducting an abortion. 
 Conservative opposition senators pushing the bill say they want to crush the "abortion industry," which experts say is responsible for up to 160,000 clandestine abortions annually in this country of 15 million people.
But the conservatives concede that they hope to make abortion an issue in next year's presidential election to embarrass Ricardo Lagos, the Socialist who is leading in the polls and who has been studiously ducking the issue.
"This is a moral question in which we have public opinion on our side," said Senator Hernan Larrain, the leading proponent of the legislation who is also a close adviser to a conservative presidential candidate. "If we pass this in the Senate, we are going to push this issue hard."
Senator Carlos Ominami, the leading opponent of the bill and an adviser to Mr. Lagos, said: "Abortion is a supercharged issue in Chile and it is a very difficult one for any progressive politician. Don't forget this is the only country in Latin America without a law allowing divorce."
At the end of an interview, he said, "I want to make myself perfectly clear that I do not favor legalizing abortion."
Abortion is illegal everywhere in Latin America except Cuba, although it is widely practiced among all social classes. Chilean law was consistent with abortion laws around the region until the Pinochet regime, with conservative church allies, put family issues at the forefront of Chilean politics.
Chileans are particularly polarized on political and social issues, with about one-third expressing very liberal views and another third expressing extremely conservative views. Each sector is represented politically, with the governing Christian Democrats leaning toward liberal economic policies but more conservative social policies.
About 50 Chileans, most of them poor women, are prosecuted each year for having or carrying out abortions. Few spend more than a few days in jail. Conservatives say that only by stiffening the penalties can the practice be deterred.
There is a good chance the Senate will approve the legislation, perhaps as early as next week. The Christian Democrats, who govern as part of a coalition, are divided on the issue. Passage in the more liberal lower chamber of the Chilean Congress is considered less likely, though still possible.
About one in every three pregnancies ends in an abortion in Chile, one of the highest rates in Latin America, according to estimates gathered in the early 1990's by the Alan Guttmacher Institute, a New York-based abortion rights group. As many as 100 Chilean women die every year from botched abortions, according to local health experts.
Four million abortions a year -- one out of every 11 in the world -- take place in Latin America despite its being the most devoutly Roman Catholic region in the world.
Abortion has always been illegal in Chile, but under a 1931 law it was allowed in cases where a woman's life was in jeopardy. But that law was repealed by decree in 1989 during the final months of the Pinochet regime.
Only El Salvador, Malta and Andorra have abortion laws as restrictive as Chile's, abortion rights groups say.
Under current Chilean law, a woman who has an abortion can be sentenced to three to five years in prison. An abortionist who is not a medical professional can be sentenced to 18 months to three years, and a doctor, nurse or midwife can face three to five years. But in most cases judges have handed out suspended sentences or allowed those convicted to serve time at night or to carry out some kind of public service.
Under the proposed law, abortionists who are not medical professionals would face a minimum of five years in prison, and a professional practitioner would face a minimum of 10 years. Judges would have less leeway in reducing or suspending sentences. The bill would not raise the sentences for women who have abortions, but would encourage them to testify against practitioners in exchange for lower sentences.
Human rights advocates say poor women, who are by far the most vulnerable to abortions carried out without proper medical care, are already regularly interrogated in hospitals when they arrive in emergency rooms with problems that appear to be abortion-related.
"I'm worried," said Lidia Casas Becerra, a leading Chilean advocate of abortion rights. "The whole criminal justice system would work against the poor if this bill passes."
Ms. Casas said that any well-to-do woman can safely have an abortion in a private clinic or hospital for $1,000 to $2,500 -- a price out of the range of most Chileans.
But, she said, poor women must turn to abortionists who lack medical training, who may charge about $200 and who use wires or primitive rubber probes.
Any toughening of the law, she said, could raise prices exorbitantly for all groups and make the whole process more clandestine.
The debate on the bill has received scant attention in the Chilean press despite a march on the Senate on Aug. 4 by 60 women who support abortion rights. Some jeered from the gallery at senators who support a tougher law.
More than anything else, some experts say, the lack of news coverage is a reflection of the fact that Chileans are extremely reluctant to discuss abortion at all.
Senator Ominami, the adviser to the Socialist presidential candidate, knows how touchy the issue is.
"Abortion," he said during a debate on the Senate floor last month, pausing for effect. "It's a strong word. It strikes a blow to the ears. It's almost inevitable that from this subject only the most acid discussions can surge."

GRAPHIC: Photo: Senator Hernan Larrain wants a tougher Chilean abortion law. (Paula Campos for The New York Times)

HEADLINE: Two Feuding Democratic Voices Call a Truce

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
Two long-feuding pillars of the Democratic Party, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and the Democratic Leadership Council, have agreed to a detente in which they pledge to stop attacking each other and to seek common ground to help the Democrats this fall and beyond.
This truce between the leadership council, the Democrats' leading centrist voice, and the labor federation, the party's most powerful liberal voice, comes after the council and the federation savaged each other in last year's dispute over trade legislation. 
 Al From, the president of the Democratic Leadership Council, went so far as to accuse the 13-million-member union group of leading the opposition to the President and of wanting "to stop change in our party."
After White House officials warned the council that its harsh words were undermining Democratic unity, Mr. From and John Sweeney, the president of the A.F.L.-C.I.O., agreed to abide by a nonaggression pact and to seek to forge some common positions. In the past, the two groups have clashed not only over trade, but also over education, reducing the size of the Federal Government and overhauling welfare.
In an interview, Mr. From said, "If we could ever bring the New Democrats, with our broad appeal to the electorate, together with labor and its organizational strength, we would have one big progressive coalition."
Showing that it wanted to mend fences with labor, the leadership council opposed a California measure, defeated in a June referendum, that would have crippled labor's political clout by requiring that unions get each member's permission annually before spending a member's dues on politics.
Although the two sides still clash over trade, they are trying to find common positions on many issues, including Social Security and charter schools, innovative public schools that are allowed to operate free of many bureaucratic rules. In the past the leadership council has supported wholesale changes in the schools, while unions have been ambivalent, wanting to insure that innovative schools did not threaten teachers' job security.
The two groups also agreed on the leadership council's call for "expanding the winner's circle" to help insure that most Americans, not just a minority, benefit from increased trade.
This agreement comes at the same time that the White House has brought many of the party's leading moderate and liberal thinkers together to try to forge a united voice and common themes that would help strengthen President Clinton's legacy and would help Democrats in this year's midterm elections and in the Presidential election year 2000.
The leadership council generally backs programs that promote market-driven solutions on economic policies. It has long fought with the A.F.L.-C.I.O. and other liberal groups that are more enthusiastic about Government-sponsored programs that protect the disadvantaged.
The council has been one of the Democratic Party's most outspoken voices in favor of freer trade. It fervently backed the fast-track legislation, shelved last fall in the face of intense labor pressure, that would have made it easier for Washington to sign free-trade agreements with other countries. Fearing that the legislation would drag down wages and eliminate jobs, the A.F.L.-C.I.O. fought it.
Despite the truce, many tensions remain. In the spring issue of its magazine, the leadership council criticized "the union hierarchy" for seeking "political allies among left-wing activists."
The council and the federation also disagree about the best strategy for the Democrats in November. The leadership council favors a moderate message that appeals to suburban middle-class voters, a pivotal swing group. But the A.F.L.-C.I.O. backs a more have-nots versus haves, class-tinged message that would mobilize the party's liberal-labor base.

HEADLINE: In Fishing Hamlet, No Grief Cormorants;
Near the Scene of a Slaughter, the Protected Birds Are Blamed for a Decrease in Jobs and Revenue

BYLINE: By ANDREW C. REVKIN 

DATELINE: HENDERSON HARBOR, N.Y., Aug. 6

 BODY:
When nearly 1,000 double-crested cormorants were found shot dead on an island in eastern Lake Ontario near here last week, Federal wildlife officials labeled the incident "a brazen act of environmental terrorism."
An animal rights group in California offered a $1,000 reward for the capture of those responsible for what it called "a brutal act of animal cruelty." 
 But around this hamlet, where nearly everyone makes a living indirectly or directly from sport fishing, the incident was likened to the Boston Tea Party, and the shooters, who have not been identified, were hailed as heroes.
"I only wish they'd killed every last one," said Ronald Ditch, a longtime fishing guide. Mr. Ditch and many of his colleagues have spent a decade pressing Federal and state wildlife officials to permit shooting of the rapidly multiplying fishing birds, which the guides blamed for a sharp decline in stocks of smallmouth bass, perch and other popular game fish.
In the surrounding town of Henderson, where vacationing fishermen help swell the population to 10,000 from 1,200 every summer, anything that threatens the fish also threatens a way of life, said Frank Ross, the Town Supervisor and a mechanic at a local gas station.
Just a few years ago, about 70 guides were kept busy all summer here taking fishermen from across the United States out into the eastern basin of the lake, which was renowned as one of the best bass-fishing spots in North America. Now there are about 20, marina owners say.
The cormorants were nearly extinct on the Great Lakes in the 1950's, depleted by the combined effects of shooting, DDT and pollution. Although never protected by the Endangered Species Act, they have been covered since 1972 by a Federal law governing migratory birds.
But now their numbers have rebounded across North America, and every spring and summer thousands settle in to nest on Little Galloo Island, 10 miles west of Henderson Harbor.
As the 52-acre island has grown to become the largest nursery for cormorants in the United States, it has also become a focus for the hatred of dozens of fishing guides and other business owners in Jefferson County, who have seen a decline in revenue as fishermen shift to waters with more fish and fewer birds.
No conclusive link has been established between the return of the cormorants and the decline of bass and other fish here. Nevertheless, marina owners and fishing guides are losing patience with Federal officials, who prohibit shooting the birds unless a clear economic loss is demonstrated.
The birds have so many enemies that the criminal investigation this week was taking on the appearance of an Agatha Christie mystery in which everyone is a suspect. Conservation officers were faced with half a dozen communities in which almost everyone, from fishing guides and gas station attendants to motel owners, had motive, opportunity and -- given the popularity of duck and deer hunting -- the necessary weaponry.
The incident also had political overtones, since local residents resent what they regard as the intrusion of unreasonable regulations written far away and long ago.
"You can only oppress people for so long and they're going to strike out," said David McCrea, a third-generation fishing guide, as he left four anglers and their catch of 20 bass and 4 walleyes at the Henchen Marina and Fishing Camp after a day on the lake. "If these birds did this in Washington or on some politician's golf course, they'd be gone in a minute."
Federal and state wildlife officials, traditionally focused on saving threatened species, find themselves dealing increasingly with problems created by species that have recovered so well from past troubles that they have moved from rarities to nuisances. That is the case with the double-crested cormorant.
The mass shooting was by far the most brutal of several recent incidents in which large numbers of birds protected under the 80-year-old Migratory Bird Treaty Act have been killed. That pact was worked out among the United States, Canada, Mexico and several other countries to protect hundreds of bird species that cross international boundaries.
Before dawn on July 23, in Carrollton, Tex., city officials used bulldozers in a pre-dawn raid on a large rookery for several kinds of protected herons and egrets, killing hundreds of birds and injuring many more. They were responding to complaints about the squawking and odor from the colony.
Around the same date, bulldozers clearing a road for a development in Conway, Ark., plowed through woodlands containing hundreds of egret nests, apparently killing many birds and sending orphaned baby egrets wandering around nearby streets and backyards.
Across the country, protected birds have occasionally been shot in anger and hunters have exceeded permitted limits for protected waterfowl, Federal and state wildlife officials said, but nothing in recent decades has come close to the systematic slaughter of the Little Galloo Island cormorants.
The extreme nature of the incident most likely sprang from two factors, local residents and wildlife officials said: the exasperating nature of the cormorants, and the nature of the community here.
The birds are voracious predators, diving up to 60 feet to hunt fish, from minnows to 12-inch bass. Each one can consume a pound or more of fish a day. They brazenly dive under boats, swooping past anglers' lures. "They're an in-your-face kind of bird," explained Russell McCullough, a state fisheries biologist.
Like the birds, most of the little towns along the shore are almost entirely focused on fish. "We've got no Kodak, no Du Pont," Mr. Ditch said. "You're either a fisherman or a farmer if you're going to live here."
For 14 years, he and other guides said, the cormorant population has risen unchecked, until now tens of thousands of birds camp out each spring and summer on Little Galloo. The birds and people were bound to clash, everyone around here says.
Tensions intensified with a recent unexplained crash of the population of smallmouth bass, which was the main species fished from Henderson Harbor for generations. Sampling by state biologists over the last 22 years has revealed a precipitous drop.
Some people in the area say that some of the anger of the fishing community is misplaced, that the fishing guides should shift their business as the lake ecology shifts.
"Everything here is a kind of weird balancing act between exotic species, native species, changes in the weather, changes in tourism patterns," said Stephen Fort, senior planner for Jefferson County. "The charter captains and the whole industry just has to adapt."
But that view was nowhere to be seen at the Henchen Marina, where the docks were busy with the late afternoon rush of boats returning from a day on the water.
Diane Gamble oversaw the pumping of gas, the sale of ice and the steady flow of fishermen sticking their catch on a board studded with pegs to pose for cameras. Her grandfather had built the marina 60 years ago, and the family had seen many ebbs and surges in fishing, but the drop in the bass these days -- and the related drop in business -- was like nothing in memory, she said.
On top of the chest for bags of ice, white wooden placards painted with the names of three dozen fishing guides sat in stacks, but only a half dozen placards hung on hooks under a sign that read "Out."
Mrs. Gamble said that just a few years ago, the numbers would have been reversed, and that most guides would be out on the water on a hot, sunny day like this.
To illustrate how the drop in bass was driving away customers, Ms. Gamble pulled out an apologetic letter sent in April by a regular visitor from Clinton, N.Y., Lorne Bradbury.
"I've been in touch with my fellow fishermen, and we have decided not to fish the area as we have in the past," Mr. Bradbury wrote. "Our decision was made on the poor results of bass fishing last year and on the predictions of a poor year this year."
He wrote that he agreed with the Gambles that the growth of the cormorant colony had to be related to the troubles with smallmouths. Beneath his signature, Mr. Bradbury typed one of the mottoes of the fishing community here: "Catch a fish -- starve a cormorant."
If the cormorant population was kept in check, Mrs. Gamble said, she doubted that people would hate the birds as they do. But when fishermen have to pass through floating cordons of the birds hundreds of yards long, their frustration is hard to contain, she said.
"Nature normally takes its course," Mrs. Gamble said. "But nature's out of balance right now."
Lieut. Christopher Hanley, who is leading the criminal investigation for the State Department of Environmental Conservation, said that no matter what the fishing communities felt, there was no excuse for what took place on the island.
"I've never seen anything like this," he said. "These were fledglings that could not fly away. This is a terrible crime."
The attack was discovered on July 29, when a team of state wildlife biologists and technicians visited Little Galloo Island as part of a study of the bird's eating habits. The study is intended to determine, once and for all, whether the birds are responsible for the changes in fish stocks.
This week, the same team returned to the island to resume the work, which involves picking up regurgitated balls of fish bones, then studying the material to determine the diet of the birds.
But the biologist and two assistants also spent time picking up more 12-gauge shotgun shells, which could be distinguished from old shells left behind by duck hunters because the new brass still gleamed in the sun.
They crossed a barren landscape of roughly heaped nests, weeds and dead birds. In the last 30 years, the colony grew from a few nesting pairs to more than 8,000 at its peak in 1996. The birds have transformed the island from a grassy spot that once attracted picnickers into a place of yard-high dunes of guano that feel like a spongy mat underfoot, a place where the few remaining trees stand like bleached skeletons, whitened by years of bird droppings.
The assistants, Brian Edmonds and Laura Brown, circled the island as they had once a week since April, stooping to bag the little clumps of fish bones, called "pellets."
They reached the spot where they realized that something terrible had happened a week earlier. "I found 7 freshly killed birds," Ms. Brown said. "Then 7 led to 200, and 200 more."
"Around here is where we stopped collecting pellets and started collecting evidence," Mr. Edmonds said.
Just offshore, fleets of young cormorants bobbed in the chop. They said the shooting happened at the tail end of the nesting season, so most of the birds escaped.
But hundreds did not. They passed spot after spot where dozens of birds were shot en masse and the desiccated carcasses were receding into the powdery soil, little more than black smudges of feathers and bones.
In the center of the island, several dozen surviving fledglings huddled in fuzzy groups, croaking and stumbling awkwardly on big webbed feet as the researchers approached. "You can get a sense of how easy it was," Mr. Edmonds said, referring to the shooting.
State biologists said they were sympathetic to the plight of people whose livelihoods were linked to fishing. But they said it was still too soon to conclude that the cormorants were the main problem.
A state biologist, James Farquhar, said the data from the diet study would be sifted by December, when a final report would be released and a recommendation made about whether something should be done to control the cormorant population.
"But obviously," he said, "someone couldn't wait."

HEADLINE: Giuliani Begins to See Results in Battle Against Sex Shops

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY and DAVID ROHDE 

 BODY:
A funereal procession of police cars crawled along a narrow street in lower Manhattan before stopping outside the storefront in question. More than a dozen police officers and city inspectors conferred on the sidewalk for a moment, then filed inside to begin a process that may become commonplace in the city of Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani:
The sex-club shutdown. 
 The procedure Thursday night had a ritualistic feel, one that recalled the shuttering of burlesque shows by Mayor Fiorello H. La Guardia in the early 1940's. Reporters and photographers who had been tipped off were kept at a distance, but not far enough to obstruct their views. Neighbors shouted their support. Then, with a police videographer recording the moment, inspectors slapped a bright orange sign onto the front door that announced the shutdown of a Walker Street establishment with the wink-wink name of Angels.
After nearly three years of court challenges, New York City has begun to enforce a zoning law specifically intended to curtail its adult-entertainment industry. And although that enforcement has generated a whole new round of court hearings that began last week, the seemingly endless litigation has done nothing to slow the city's resolve. Inspectors are dispatched every night into the shadowy world of peep booths and lap dances, diligently seeking out violations of the city zoning law.
So far, seven live-entertainment clubs have been temporarily shut down, while dozens of others are trying out ways to comply -- and still make a profit. Many more adult video and book stores, like the XXX Video Store on Reade Street in lower Manhattan, have voluntarily locked their doors and hung out signs that say: "Closed for Renovations to Meet City Ordinances -- Will Open Soon."
But with those results have come questions. Is there enough wiggle room in the language of the zoning law for some of the adult clubs to bypass its intent? Will enforcement lead to the creation of red-light districts along the fringes of struggling neighborhoods around the city? And, ultimately, does it reflect a triumph of puritanism over free expression in a city that prides itself on tolerance?
A sign of the times, perhaps, is that Norman Siegel, the ubiquitous director of the New York Civil Liberties Union, stands virtually alone as an outspoken critic of the zoning law, which he says was designed to stamp out legal activity that the Mayor finds personally offensive. He divines hope in the law's language.
"There are some confusing areas in the law because it is not that specific, intentionally so," Mr. Siegel said. "And maybe some of it will create problems for the judges, resulting in that the city won't get what it wants."
But many others, including some critics of Mr. Giuliani's, see the zoning law as a triumph for his administration. "It's a significant legislative and legal victory for City Hall and our neighborhoods," said the city's Public Advocate, Mark Green.
Former Mayor Edward I. Koch agreed. "I think it's a good thing and I commend him for it," he said.
For decades, New York City grappled with how to strike a balance between the rights of its adult-entertainment businesses and the quality-of-life expectations of its communities. By the early 1990's, the issue had risen to the fore of the public debate: depressed real-estate values had led to a proliferation of sex shops in residential areas around the city and, especially, in Times Square.
Then, in September 1994, nine months into his first administration, Mayor Giuliani proposed comprehensive zoning regulations to prohibit adult video stores, X-rated theaters and topless bars from operating within 500 feet of residences, houses of worship, schools or one another. His proposal would essentially eliminate the adult trade from Times Square, an area that was ripe for redevelopment, and banish the businesses to the city's wastelands.
"They hurt the economy of the city," the Mayor said then. "They cost us jobs. They cost us money."
The Mayor chose his words carefully. The United States Supreme Court has held that sexually explicit expressions are protected forms of free speech, as long as they are not judged to be obscene. But the courts have also allowed municipalities to use zoning laws to restrict the adult trade as long as they demonstrate "secondary impacts" that hurt the community, like increases in crime and declines in real-estate values.
And the Mayor felt confident that the city could demonstrate those secondary impacts. The Department of City Planning and its director, Joseph B. Rose, had just completed a survey of the Times Square and Chelsea sections that outlined anecdotal evidence of the harmful impact of the adult trade on neighborhoods. The report also explored the experiences of other cities -- including Boston, Seattle and Los Angeles -- in restricting adult establishments.
"That was the core of the problem," said Albert Fredericks, a former assistant corporation counsel who helped draft the law. "We had to strike a balance between dealing with a serious problem while observing the constitutional limitation and allowing some access to this kind of entertainment material."
The zoning plan was scrutinized, tinkered with and debated by community boards, the five borough presidents and various other public agencies. At a two-day public hearing, 56 of the 80 speakers opposed it; some decried the restriction on free speech, while others complained that adult entertainment would be harder to find.
Those critics complained in vain. In October 1995, the City Council overwhelmingly approved the zoning law. But before Mayor Giuliani could gloat about another triumph in his quality-of-life campaign, a series of court challenges were filed -- and eventually beaten back, including one last month before the United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit. There were so many stages in the process that the Mayor caustically began to keep a public tally of the judges who had supported the law: 23 at last count.
Now that the adult establishments have nearly exhausted their options in appealing the law's constitutionality -- their last hope is with the United States Supreme Court -- Mr. Giuliani has become more candid in expressing his distaste for the businesses and his intention to reduce their numbers.
"I realize that you can't eliminate all of them," he said last week. "We're going to have to tolerate some. Maybe on a personal basis I would wish that we could, but I understand the Constitution of the United States. I understand that there are going to be some that end up surviving. And there has to be, in order to save the constitutionality of this program. But if there's a reduction of 20, 30, 40, 50 percent, 60 percent, that will be a good thing for the city."
But in many ways, enforcing the law in the streets of New York has proven just as challenging as defending it in court. Inspectors now find themselves mastering terminology such as "completely and opaquely concealed" and "discernibly turgid state."
The broad language of the law has also allowed for subjective interpretation by adult businesses determined to survive. At Billy's Topless on West 24th Street in Chelsea, the dancers now wear bikini tops, as well as bottoms that cover their buttocks; its owner contends that, technically, he is no longer running an adult business. Other establishments have concocted various methods -- using makeup, latex, even Saran Wrap -- to create the illusion that the breasts of performers are exposed.
Causing the greatest confusion has been the law's use of the phrase "substantial portion" in defining what makes a nightclub or video store "adult." Once the city acknowledged that "substantial" meant at least 40 percent of a store's inventory, floor space -- or some combination of both -- strip clubs and video stores scrambled to comply.
A wood-paneled courtroom with a drooping American flag in the State Supreme Court building in lower Manhattan became the stage last week for a protracted and frequently comic debate over "substantial portion" and other aspects of the law. Those three days of arguments centered on the city's plan to shut down six more establishments on the grounds that they posed an immediate threat to public safety and violated the new zoning law.
Representing the adult businesses was Herald Price Fahringer, whose white hair, crisp dark suits and soft-spoken manner lent an air of elegance to discussions about lap dancing; each time he stood up or sat down, his wooden chair creaked. Representing the city was Daniel Connolly, who called a parade of police officers to describe what they had seen during undercover explorations into the sex-club netherworld.
Apparently intimidated by the courtroom's formality, the officers sometimes hesitated to define exactly what they meant by "spent condom" and "lap dance," in which a dancer gyrates on a patron's lap. When words failed them, they would imitate the gestures of the performers.
One officer who happened upon a "transvestite night" at Angels alternately used "he" and "she" to describe the person who, he said, offered to go to a hotel with him for $200. Another officer preferred specificity in delivering a deadpan assessment of what he had seen: "The females were moving their posteriors left and right. Up and down."
At first it seemed that the city might have a hard time linking the suggestive gestures of semiclad performers to an immediate threat to public safety. "There is constant touching and contact," one of the city's lawyers explained, in arguing the dangers of a lap dance. "That is how diseases are contracted. This person goes back to his family and friends."
Judge Stephen G. Crane seemed initially skeptical and jokingly told the lawyer that if he had such a fear of disease he should avoid riding the subway. But by week's end, the testimony of solicitations inside the clubs and used condoms inside and outside the clubs had persuaded the judge to permit the temporary shutdowns of two establishments operated by a former dancer named Madeline D'Anthony: Angels and the Harmony Theater, just around the corner on Church Street.
It remains to be seen whether Mr. Fahringer will succeed in arguing, among other points, that used condoms on the sidewalk do not legally constitute a zoning violation. It is also unclear whether those establishments that try to conform will still be able to make a profit. Said Councilman Walter L. McCaffrey of Queens, "The marketplace is going to begin to have an impact."
In the meantime, the move toward compliance continues. Last week, Show World, the sex emporium that looms over Times Square, ended a quarter-century of live adult performances; the "peep-a-live" performers have been let go, leaving only a few adult-video booths as remnants of its stock in trade. Its manager, Tom Simmons, said that Show World might become an arcade, or perhaps a health club.
He watched as workers piled some uprooted booths into a corner; these "confessionals," with telephone wires dangling from their sides, had once allowed patrons to watch women undress in private as they carried on intimate conversations.
Mr. Simmons said he planned to save a few of the booths. "Maybe the Whitney Museum of Art will want them someday," he said wistfully.

HEADLINE: In Europe, New Allure of Air-Conditioning

BYLINE: By JOHN TAGLIABUE 

DATELINE: ROME, Aug. 8

 BODY:
Marco Liberali decided not to fiddle around while Rome burned. Seeking relief from Rome's tropical temperatures, the 41-year-old mechanic installed central air-conditioning in his family's apartment on the edge of the city.
"What a difference it makes," Mr. Liberali said with the assuredness of the newly converted. "Humid heat is bad for you." 
 When Americans rushed to cool their air, Europeans traditionally just slowed down and endured the summer heat. But now people like Mr. Liberali, who got to know air-conditioning at the hotel where he works, have decided to stop going without.
Indeed, Europe is becoming a big market for the air-conditioning industry. Sales of air-conditioners for homes and small businesses have grown more than 20 percent over the last three years, even as they stayed flat in the United States, and the growth shows no sign of abating.
In Europe, sales of air-conditioners for homes and small businesses, including central air units for homes, are expected to reach $3.2 billion this year, from $2.5 billion in 1996. In the United States, they are expected only to inch up to $7.74 billion, from $7.73 billion in 1996.
Credit some of the growth to the pressures of a global economy, which are increasingly forcing Europeans to work summers. Air pollution is also bolstering the demand for air-conditioning, and Europeans are becoming more accustomed to it in offices and their cars, and increasingly want it in their homes.
But environmentalists are concerned. Air-conditioners consume a significant amount of energy, and their emissions help deplete the ozone layer.
To be sure, many hurdles must fall before Europe can fully indulge its new fondness for the big chill. Both electricity and air-conditioners are costly, many homes lack proper wiring, home power supplies are often weak and many Europeans view air-conditioning as unhealthy: there is simply a bias to rely on nature.
Still, the trend toward a cooler Europe is clear.
"Above all in the whole area of small businesses and homes, the use of air-conditioning is increasing," said Alfred Voss, director of the Institute for Energy Use and Rational Use of Energy at Stuttgart University.
But Europe has a long way to go before air-conditioning becomes the norm in homes. In Italy, 7 percent of homes are air-conditioned, and in Spain 11 percent, compared with 71 percent in the United States and more than 90 percent in Japan.
Hotels, post offices, police stations, even hospitals, except for operating rooms, generally do not have air-conditioning.
So it is hardly surprising that the world's biggest air-conditioner makers -- Japanese giants like Mitsubishi and Daikin Industries, and American leaders like the Carrier Corporation, a unit of United Technologies, and the Trane Company, a unit of American Standard -- view Europe as a potential El Dorado. European companies, like Riello and De Longhi in Italy, are jockeying to catch up.
"The culture of air-conditioning is spreading," said Carlo Segato, head of marketing at De Longhi, a specialist in portable and room air-conditioners.
But as temperatures climbed over Italy this summer, the country's Green Party, echoing warnings from environmentalists across Europe, argued that air-conditioners, while cooling the inside of homes, forced out warm air, raising temperatures outside. Moreover, they argued, more air-conditioners mean more ozone-depleting gases in the atmosphere, which contribute to global warming. "Turning on your air-conditioner today," said Fulco Pratesi, a Green Party spokesman in Rome, "means suffering more from the heat tomorrow."
The European air-conditioning market did not arrive overnight. It was created after World War II by the companies that pioneered the technology in the United States, including Carrier and the York International Corporation.
In the 1980's the Japanese arrived. Mitsubishi has a factory in Scotland, Daikin has one in Belgium and Toshiba has one in Britain. And the Japanese got a leg up by introducing small, quiet portables and wall models suited to small European dwellings. The Americans responded quickly. Carrier bought local manufacturers in Spain and Italy and redesigned its products to meet European demands.
European companies, for their part, took a chapter from the Japanese and copied Japanese models. The Italians introduced snappy new models at competitive prices.
De Longhi, long a maker of room heaters, began importing Toshiba air-conditioners in 1988, then built its own, and its engineers now use refrigerants that do not damage the atmosphere, including a butane mixture similar to lighter fluid.
Air-conditioning makers must scramble to find economical substitutes for chlorofluorocarbons, gases traditionally used as refrigerants, which were banned by the Montreal Protocol, a 1987 treaty signed by more than 150 countries, because they deplete the earth's ozone layer.
Subsequent accords banned the production of the interim substitute, hydrochlorofluorocarbons, after 2020.
Europe's industry is under particular pressure because Germany, Italy and Sweden, heeding environmentalists, want these gases gone by 2000. When a company in eastern Germany first produced refrigerators using butane in 1992, Greenpeace bought the first 10 prototypes.
But substitutes are expensive. Sergio Zanolin, De Longhi's head of research, said butane air-conditioners cost 10 percent to 20 percent more than conventional models. While Americans can trundle down to a Home Depot and pick up a window unit for about $200, the least expensive room models in Europe sell for almost $1,000 because of low production runs and expensive components.
This year De Longhi expects to sell about $165 million worth of air-conditioners and has even carved out a niche in the United States. In part, sales received a boost in Europe from air-conditioning's use as a marketing tool by stores, shopping centers and professional offices of dentists and lawyers.
"The last five years have seen a revolution in light commercial use," said Halsey Cook, Carrier's head of marketing in Europe.
When automobile air-conditioning caught on in the early 1990's, it was largely thanks to stagnant auto sales, which prompted car makers to offer air-conditioners to attract buyers. Five years ago, hardly any European cars were air-conditioned; now, 28 percent are.
That may be peanuts compared with the United States, where 95 percent of cars are air-conditioned, but the market continues to grow.
"It's getting started, people are buying it, and the technology now allows it," said Sandro Frigerio, who follows the auto air-conditioning market at Standard & Poor's DRI in London. He said innovation and miniaturization now enabled auto makers to cool small European cars without significant power loss or higher gas consumption.
And as Europeans grow fond of air-conditioning in cars and dentists' offices, more want it at home.
Not that sales have exploded. "The domestic market is really on the edge of a boom," said Jacques Benoist, director of certification at Eurovent, an industry association established recently in Paris to certify air-conditioning equipment. "But it didn't happen yet."
And there are many reasons.
The first, of course, is price, which is compounded by energy problems. In some countries, like Italy, sufficient electricity is scarce. Typical Italian homes are equipped with smaller circuit breakers than new American homes. In Italy, a separate circuit for air-conditioning costs as much as $400.
Partly, Europe's reluctance can be traced to the relatively mild climate, with little of the tropical heat that assaults cities like Houston or Miami. Yet temperatures in Granada, Spain, or Palermo, Sicily, can easily surpass those in New York. Thus, some experts also point to a tendency for Europeans to favor nature over technology.
"When they design a building, they take greater advantage of natural lighting and ventilation," said Bruce Anderson, head of marketing in Europe for Trane, based in Tyler, Tex. "So owners will say, 'There's no reason to have air-conditioning.' "
Such reluctance is bolstered by a conviction that air-conditioning is unhealthy.
Italian newspapers, which regularly advise readers how to deal with the heat, warn against it. The weekly health insert of La Repubblica in Rome recently warned readers that air-conditioning could cause colds and sore throats and spread "germs, viruses and bacteria" through unclean filters.
In the United States, many experts argue the opposite. In the recent heat wave, more than 120 deaths were attributed to the heat. Indeed, some European doctors increasingly recommend air-conditioning for the elderly and for people with heart trouble and respiratory ailments.
In response, European manufacturers have developed quieter and more efficient models. And increased production, economies of scale and cheap foreign imports will cut prices. In television ads, Italian importers offer cheap Chinese air-conditioners free to viewers who order mattresses.
Moreover, as Europe deregulates the energy market, electricity supplies are expected to rise, thus reducing the cost. In France the national utility, Electricite de France, offers bonuses to builders who install energy-efficient heat pumps, which warm homes in winter and cool them in summer. Italy's national utility, Enel, now penalizes energy use by charging higher rates as more power is consumed. "Ten to 15 years ago, we had power shortages," said Roberto Formigoni, Enel's marketing director. "Now we have lots to sell." So Enel is petitioning Rome's energy authority to cut rates and increase the supply for homes.
Antonietta Marconi, marketing director of GMC Climatizzatori, where Mr. Liberali bought his equipment, says it cannot happen too soon.
"I've been in the air-conditioning business for six years, and prices will fall," she said. "It will become like central heating."
Professor Voss, of Stuttgart University, agrees. "With energy prices coming down, I think it's safe to say the tendency will be for demand for appliances like air-conditioners to continue to grow," he said.
