HEADLINE: GOVERNMENT LAGS IN STEPS TO WIDEN HEALTH COVERAGE

SERIES: AFTER THE REVOLUTION: The Uninsured

BYLINE: By ROBERT PEAR 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 8

 BODY:
In 1994, when President Clinton's effort to reshape the American health care system collapsed, a political consensus emerged from the rubble: in the future, any such changes should be made piecemeal, one step at a time.
But four years later, the limits of that incremental approach are becoming clear, in the view of many experts. Most immediately, Congress is confronting demands to provide broad new consumer protections for patients fed up with the restrictions of managed care. Lawmakers also face a deeper, more intractable problem. Despite the passage of several laws intended to expand coverage step by step, the number of Americans without insurance has risen steadily, by an average of one million a year. 
 The number of uninsured has increased each year since 1987 and now exceeds 41 million, roughly one-sixth of the population.
Moreover, this steady rise has occurred despite a remarkable economic boom. The nation has created more than 14 million jobs since 1993, but most of these are in small businesses, which are far less likely to provide health insurance than are large companies.
In Congress, members of both parties keep returning to the problems of the uninsured, but the cost and complexity of the issue pose extraordinary hurdles. Lawmakers say they are determined not to repeat the mistakes that killed Mr. Clinton's plan, but beyond that, there is little agreement.
Congress has enacted two significant health care laws since the collapse of the Clinton plan. It created a new program to finance health care for low-income children last year. And in 1996 it passed the Kassebaum-Kennedy law, to make insurance more readily available to millions of people who change their jobs or lose them.
These efforts, along with previous expansions of the Medicaid program, have made a difference; without them, experts say, the number of uninsured would be even higher.
But there have been problems:
*Federal and state officials say that insurance companies have found ways to skirt the Kassebaum-Kennedy law by shunning people with medical problems or by charging them very high premiums. The law does not limit what insurers can charge.
*Sweeping changes in Federal welfare policy may inadvertently increase the number of uninsured children, offsetting some of the expected gains in coverage from the new Children's Health Insurance Program.
*The Government has struggled to carry out its duties under the new laws. Federal officials had assumed that states would quickly adopt the standards established by the Kassebaum-Kennedy law, but that has not happened in California and four other states. In such states, the Federal Government is supposed to enforce the law directly, but the Clinton Administration acknowledges it was unprepared for this immense new responsibility.
So, while officials grapple with these problems, the number of uninsured keeps growing.
 
The Workers
Patchwork System For the Uninsured
Neither the new laws nor the power of a fiercely competitive medical marketplace has delivered health insurance to Mildred Davis, a custodian and security guard in Austin, Tex.
"I have no health insurance, no dental plan," Ms. Davis said as she sat at the front desk of the community health center where she works. "When you walk into a doctor's office, the first thing they say is: 'How will you pay? What insurance do you have?' I have to go to the bank before I go to the doctor."
Like many people who are uninsured, she deferred doctors' visits and medical care until she had a serious need.
As a result, said Ms. Davis, who is 48, she had an emergency hysterectomy in January after several weeks of uterine bleeding. She received a hospital bill for $8,000 and a doctor's bill for $2,000.
"I would have gotten care earlier if I had had health insurance," she said. Instead, she waited until the pain became unbearable.
"I would get up to patrol this area," Ms. Davis said, pointing to the corridors of the health center. "The pain was so bad that I'd fall over. I lost four and a half pints of blood. I was literally bleeding to death."
Ms. Davis's case highlights the patchwork nature of the current insurance system and illustrates what can happen to uninsured people when they become ill. Even if parents have coverage through their employers, their children may be uninsured. (Many companies have cut back benefits for dependents.) Conversely, many children covered by Medicaid, the Federal-state program for low-income people, have parents who are uninsured because Medicaid's eligibility rules are much more generous for children than they are for adults.
Ms. Davis said that her 7-year-old daughter was covered by Medicaid.But Ms. Davis herself, like many of the uninsured, was caught in between. Her income was too high for her to qualify for Medicaid, and she could not afford private insurance. Ms. Davis says she hopes to get health insurance later this year when she becomes a full-time city employee.
The Medicaid eligibility rules are devilishly complex. They differ from state to state, and family income limits vary with a child's age. So a healthy 4-year-old boy may be protected by Medicaid, while his 8-year-old sister, though severely ill, is ineligible for coverage because the income limit for her age group is lower.
The plight of the uninsured may seem distant to members of the middle class riding the current economic boom. People are less anxious about losing their jobs and their benefits than they were in the recession of the early 1990's. "Health security" was the buzzword then, just as "patients' rights" is now.
But William S. Custer, an economist at Georgia State University in Atlanta, said: "The problems that the Clinton health plan was intended to address have not gone away and may worsen in the future. If the economy slows or if health costs rise much faster than prices in general, we'll probably see more rapid growth in the number of Americans without health insurance."
 
The Cost
Opting for Pay Over Insurance
Today, as in the early 1990's, the cost of coverage is crucial. Paradoxically, the Public Health Service says, the number of workers offered health insurance by their employers has increased in the last decade, but the proportion of workers who accept such offers has declined, in part because of the cost.
Philip F. Cooper and Barbara S. Schone, economists at the Federal Agency for Health Care Policy and Research, found large declines in the proportion of people accepting employer-sponsored insurance among two groups: workers with low wages (less than $7 an hour) and workers younger than 25.
They estimate that six million workers are offered health insurance by their employers or their unions but do not take it.
Rita J. Carrillo, 26, works 30 to 40 hours a week as a customer service representative for a company that schedules repairs for Frigidaire appliances in Texas. The company offers health insurance, she said, but "for me as a single mother, it's too expensive to afford."
Ms. Carrillo explained: "My paycheck after taxes is $350 to $400 every two weeks. For health insurance, they would deduct $60 from each paycheck. I would be left with $290, which is not a lot to deal with. If I could afford the insurance, I would take the children to the doctor more often. Lucky for me, they are healthy children."
Nationwide, about half of all uninsured workers are either self-employed or working in businesses that have fewer than 25 employees. When coverage is available in such companies, the employees are often required to pay a large share of the cost.
Small businesses give many reasons for not providing insurance to their employees. They say that premiums are too high, that their profits are too uncertain for them to make a commitment to insurance and that health benefits are not always a high priority for workers.
Sal Z. Valiani, who operates four dry-cleaning shops in Austin, said that he offered health insurance long ago and even paid half the cost. But, he said, employees repeatedly asked him not to deduct their share of the premiums from their wages.
"It's one or the other, a pay raise or health benefits," Mr. Valiani said, and in the eyes of many employees, higher wages are considered more important.
 
The Laws
Guarantees Prove Not to Be Foolproof
None of the measures passed by Congress in the last few years raised higher hopes than the 1996 law to guarantee health insurance for people who change jobs or lose jobs. The law is known by the names of its authors, Senator Edward M. Kennedy, Democrat of Massachusetts, and Nancy Kassebaum Baker, a Kansas Republican who retired from the Senate last year.
In signing the legislation, President Clinton said, "It seals the cracks that swallow as many as 25 million Americans who can't get insurance or who fear they'll lose it."
The Kassebaum-Kennedy law guarantees that people losing group health insurance will have access to coverage in the individual insurance market, regardless of pre-existing medical problems, but it does not limit how much they may be charged. The law generally guarantees that people moving from one job to another will be promptly eligible for coverage if the new employer provides health benefits.
The General Accounting Office, an investigative arm of Congress, said recently that the law was not working as intended. People who exercised their rights under the law were often charged premiums far higher than the standard rates. Deborah J. Chollet, vice president of the Alpha Center, a health policy research institute in Washington, said the cost of such insurance -- $10,000 to $15,000 a year, or more -- "has to be prohibitive to most people."
One insurer, American Medical Security of Green Bay, Wis., said it reserved the right to charge high-risk individuals five times the rates charged to healthy people.
Dr. Gary F. Krieger, a pediatrician who is speaker of the California Medical Association, was more blunt. "The promise of the Kassebaum-Kennedy law has proved to be a sham," he said. "Insurers are dumping patients by simply charging premiums much higher than what the patients paid when they were part of their employer plans."
President Clinton has denounced such behavior, and he says the Government will no longer do business with insurers that flout the law. But whether he can use it as a lever to increase the number of people with insurance remains to be seen. For the Kassebaum-Kennedy law does not guarantee coverage for people who want to buy insurance as individuals and have never had group coverage. And conservative Republicans say they do not want to use the law as a vehicle or precedent for more Federal regulation of private health insurance.
There are some problems, as well, in the other major initiative to expand coverage: the Children's Health Insurance Program, which provides almost $24 billion over five years to finance coverage for some of the nation's 10 million uninsured children.
Many experts fear that unrelated changes in welfare policy made by the Federal Government and the states in the last few years may have the opposite effect -- inadvertently increasing the number of uninsured children. The new welfare laws impose time limits and other restrictions on welfare benefits.
Children are often still eligible for Medicaid after they lose cash assistance, but their Medicaid coverage may be interrupted or lost. Many parents do not know that their children still qualify for Medicaid, and state officials do not always check such families to assess their eligibility.
Marilyn R. Ellwood, a senior fellow at Mathematica Policy Research in Cambridge, Mass., said, "States have tried to keep Medicaid open to those losing welfare benefits, but the number of people on Medicaid has still dropped."
The number of people on the Federal welfare rolls has dropped by 5.2 million, or 37 percent, since January 1993, to 8.9 million in March of this year.
"Falling welfare caseloads are leading to unexpected declines in Medicaid enrollment," even though many states have slightly expanded eligibility for Medicaid, Ms. Ellwood said.
President Clinton has repeatedly expressed dismay that many children who are eligible for Medicaid are not enrolled. In January, Federal officials estimated the number of such children at three million. In May, after more rigorous studies that included older children, the Government suggested a much higher figure: 4.7 million.
Adults who leave welfare often get low-wage jobs in small businesses, the type of employment least likely to offer health benefits.
 
The Solutions
No Consensus On How to Proceed
 Lawmakers say they keep looking for ways to expand coverage, but there are sharp divisions over how to do it. Republicans are philosophically opposed to price controls, which play a role in some schemes to expand coverage, and few Democrats openly advocate such regulation. Some liberal Democrats continue to push legislation that would require employers to provide coverage, but such mandates are anathema to conservatives in both parties.
Federal lawmakers in general are reluctant to dictate programs to the states. And they say they cannot find the money for the subsidies that would be needed to make insurance truly affordable to millions of low-income Americans. As a result, the plight of the uninsured appears to be a low political priority in the current Congress, much to the frustration of their advocates.
Senator Paul Wellstone, Democrat of Minnesota and a potential Presidential contender, says: "Here we are at peak economic performance, and we are being told that we cannot provide health coverage for everyone. If not now, when?"
Representative Bill Archer, the Texas Republican who is chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee, and Senator William V. Roth Jr., the Delaware Republican who is chairman of the Senate Finance Committee, want to create tax breaks to help people buy private insurance. Representative Thomas J. Bliley Jr., the Virginia Republican who is chairman of the Commerce Committee, wants to create "health marts" to offer insurance to self-employed people and businesses with fewer than 500 employees.
Senator Kennedy has introduced a bill that would require employers with 50 or more employees to offer insurance to their workers and to pay at least 72 percent of the premiums.
"Every business is expected to pay a minimum wage and to obey the child labor laws," Mr. Kennedy said. "It is long past time for businesses to contribute to the cost of basic health insurance coverage for their workers. There can be no excuse for large firms to shirk their responsibility."
And Senator Wellstone recently introduced a bill that would give states large sums of Federal money to help achieve the goal of universal insurance coverage.
Proposals like those from Mr. Kennedy and Mr. Wellstone stir little interest in a Congress controlled by Republicans, who are viscerally opposed to any new mandates on employers.
Republicans say such mandates will not work in a voluntary employer-sponsored health insurance system. There is, they say, strong evidence that employers will drop coverage (especially for workers' dependents), curtail benefits or shift costs to employees if the Government imposes new requirements. And in interviews, uninsured workers say that, while they yearn for coverage, they are very sensitive to the cost. They often pass up the offer of health insurance if it will take a noticeable amount from their paychecks.
But concern for the uninsured will not die. The Health Insurance Association of America, which helped kill President Clinton's proposals with its "Harry and Louise" commercials in 1994, is now seeking ways to extend private coverage to the uninsured.
"Newspapers, television and radio news reports may no longer focus on the plight of the uninsured as they did in 1993 and 1994," said Donald M. Peterson, who is chairman of the association and of the Trustmark Insurance Company in Lake Forest, Ill. "But for millions of Americans, the lack of affordable coverage remains a crisis."
Insurers worry that if the erosion of private employer-sponsored insurance continues, consumers will demand new Government programs, to which the industry is opposed.
Drew E. Altman, president of the Henry J. Kaiser Family Foundation, which has done many studies of the uninsured, said: "This is the biggest problem we face in American health care, and it's not on the political agenda. There's no significant solution on the horizon. The country doesn't want to put up the tens of billions of dollars it would take to provide coverage for the uninsured. We have been making some progress with the small incremental reforms, but it's like shoveling sand against the tide."
 
After the Revolution
 
This series looks at changes in the nation's health care system. The first article described the effects of the changes on doctors; a future article will examine the problems of managed care.

INTERNATIONAL 3-17
 
Investigations Begin At African Bombing Sites
Israeli soldiers took over efforts to rescue people still trapped under tons of rubble from a terrorist attack on the United States Embassy in Nairobi, as American medical teams and F.B.I. agents arrived to investigate bomb attacks there and in Dar es Salaam, Tanzania. More than 140 people were killed in what appeared to be coordinated bombings against American targets. 1
 
President Clinton said that the United States would not buckle under to the threat of international terrorism as American personnel were arriving in East Africa to help victims and launch an investigation into the embassy bombings. 11 

Floods Threaten China Cities
Chinese officials said that the nation's worst flooding in 40 years threatens to overwhelm several large cities in the central part of the nation. State news organizations reported that the army is evacuating more than half a million people from an area in Hubei Province where they may have to take emergency measures to divert water that endangers larger cities downstream. 1
 
Conditions Worsen in Kosovo
A United Nations official said that ethnic Albanian refugees driven from Kosovo have little protection against disease and starvation, estimating that half the refugee children are dehydrated and suffering from effects of malnutrition. Refugee officials said they were unprepared for the crisis. 12
 
Congo Army Recruits Troops
The Government of Congo launched a recruitment drive, aimed at enlisting unemployed youths into the country's armed forces to defend against a week-old anti-Government rebellion. The Government rounded up members of an ethnic group believed to be allied with the rebellion. 9
 
Calm Anniversary in Myanmar
The 10th anniversary of a crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators passed quietly without the violence many had feared, but also without any sign of a resolution of Myanmar's deepening problems. 8
 
NATIONAL 18-26
 
Gaps in Health Insurance Continue to Grow
Congress is confronting demands to provide broad new consumer protections for patients fed up with the restrictions of managed care. Lawmakers also face a deeper, more intractable problem. Despite the passage of several laws intended to expand coverage step by step, the number of Americans without insurance has risen steadily, by an average of one million a year. 1
 
Reliving the Pain
People in Jonesboro, Ark., a diverse college, manufacturing and farming town of 50,000, have a sense of hopelessness going into the adjudication hearing, the juvenile court equivalent of a trial, of two boys accused in the schoolyard killings. There seems to be little drama over the outcome, only a malaise as the people hurt most prepare for a fresher pain as the day of March 24 is replayed in the courtroom. 18
 
Prison Population Booming
The nation's prison population grew by 5.2 percent in 1997, according to the Justice Department, even though crime has been declining for six straight years, suggesting that the imprisonment boom has developed a built-in growth dynamic independent of the crime rate, experts say. 18
 
The DNA Question
As F.B.I. scientists conduct tests on one of Monica S. Lewinsky's dresses, trying to determine whether it contains physical evidence of a sexual encounter with President Clinton, they are employing a science that, though still sharply debated in court, is considered highly reliable and capable of answering a number of questions with remarkable speed and accuracy. 24
 
G.M. Changes Its Ways
Three initiatives by General Motors, all of which were expected at some point but not all together last week, are significant because they would change the way G.M. has done business since the 1920's. 26
 
NEW YORK 29-35
 
Controversy Over Cormorants
When nearly 1,000 double-crested cormorants were found shot dead on an island in eastern Lake Ontario last week, Federal wildlife officials labeled the incident "a brazen act of environmental terrorism." But around the hamlet of Henderson Harbor, in upstate New York, where nearly everyone makes a living indirectly or directly from sport fishing, the incident was likened to the Boston Tea Party, and the shooters , who have not been identified, were hailed as heroes. 29
 
Questions on Sex Shop Zoning
So far, New York City has temporarily shut down seven live-entertainment clubs under new zoning laws restricting sex shops, while dozens of others are trying out ways to comply -- and still make a profit. But with those results come questions. Is there enough wiggle room in the language of the zoning law for some of the adult clubs to bypass its intent? Will enforcement lead to the creation of red-light districts along the fringes of struggling neighborhoods around the city? And, ultimately, does it reflect a triumph of Puritanism over free expression in a city that prides itself on tolerance? 29

HEADLINE: BOMBINGS IN EAST AFRICA: THE WOUNDED;
3 Victims In Kenya Airlifted To Pretoria

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: PRETORIA, South Africa, Aug. 8

 BODY:
After a confusing scene at the Nairobi, Kenya, airport this morning, three wounded employees of the United States Embassy in Kenya were flown here aboard a South African military airplane as other bombing victims awaited medical approval to be transported.
Upon arrival in Pretoria, the two men and a woman were rushed to a military hospital. A member of the hospital's medical staff reported that the woman, identified as Mary Robinson, an administrative attache at the embassy in Nairobi, suffered a broken jaw and a broken bone in her left hand. 
 She told The Associated Press that she had heard what sounded like gunfire and ran from her office.
"We went out into the corridor," she said. "Then we heard this boom, and that's all I remember until I woke up in the hospital."
One of the wounded men, who declined to give his name, was wearing a bandage covering a four-inch laceration on his head and was accompanied by his wife. "The blast was enormous," he said. "I have no idea what happened to my colleagues. It was terrible. There was absolute chaos. But I'm alive, and I'm very grateful for that."
The South African jet had been equipped to carry up to 60 casualties. But as the wounded were brought from local hospitals to Nairobi airport, a doctor on board the South African airplane said American officials had decided that only patients in stable condition could be evacuated. It was unclear how many of the wounded made it to the airport.
Dr. Dawie Roux described a mixture of chaos and order at Nairobi.
"The situation at Nairobi airport was calm and quiet, except for the operations rooms where United States officials were trying to sort out where the injured should go," Dr. Roux said. "They were still trying sort out the injuries on the ground, and didn't want to change their plans about where the injured should go."
A German airplane arrived in Nairobi shortly after the South African jet, indicating that another airlift was expected, Dr. Roux said. Bruce Wharton, press and information officer for the United States Information Service, declined to identify the three embassy workers brought to Pretoria pending notification of their families. Mr. Wharton said two of the injured worked in the foreign commercial service, and the third in the economics section.
A spokesman at the South African military hospital said the three victims would be kept at the hospital for three days. "They have minor injuries, mostly lacerations from the blast, but the major factor is shock," the spokesman said.
Robert Pringle, deputy chief of mission at the United States Embassy in Pretoria, said that within an hour of the Nairobi blast his consulate had spoken with the South African air force about the need for clearance for relief aircraft.
The embassy, which he said had "well-oiled channels of communication with the South African Defense Force" had hired a private commercial airplane that was on its way to Nairobi when the offer came from the South African air force. Mr. Pringle said cost was not discussed.

Dozens of medical personnel and forensic specialists arrived from the U.S. to aid Kenya after the bombing. (Reuters)

HEADLINE: BOMBINGS IN EAST AFRICA: THE AMERICAN DEAD;
For Victims' Kin, Sudden Bad News Comes From Afar

BYLINE: By JIM YARDLEY 

 BODY:
The Friday mail brought a flimsy letter from Africa to the home of Delbert and Mary Olds in Panama City, Fla. It was from their daughter, Sherry, and inside the envelope was a Post-It sticker. It read, "Will E-mail you soon."
By Friday evening, two Air Force officers arrived with another letter. It informed the family that Sherry Lynn Olds, a senior master sergeant with the Air Force, had died earlier in the day after a terrorist bomb exploded outside the United States Embassy in Nairobi, Kenya. 
 "She was a beautiful girl," said Pat Casey, the victim's aunt, who spoke for the parents. "She was very special to her parents. It is a devastating loss to them."
For the families of the victims in various parts of the country, there was no good way to learn the bad news. The phone rang before sunrise at Bonnie Hobson's home in Lamar, Mo. Her son, Sgt. Kenneth R. Hobson, Jr., 27, had been killed. Her daughter-in-law, Debbie, was calling from Nairobi, sobbing uncontrollably.
"He's gone," she said.
It was the telephone call that did not come that worried friends and relatives of Molly Huckaby Hardy, 51, a State Department employee from Valdosta, Ga. They had seen the bombings on television. "When we hadn't heard from her, we knew something had happened," said Marsha Bates, a childhood friend of Ms. Hardy's. "If she could have crawled to a phone, she would have let us know she was O.K.."
The American death toll was not yet clear, but by last night, the State Department had identified five of the victims. They are Master Sergeant Olds; Sergeant Hobson; Ms. Hardy; Sgt. Jesse N. Aliganga, 21, a marine from Tallahassee, Fla., and Arlene Kirk, 50, a Defense Department budget officer who had just returned to Nairobi from home leave in South Bend, Ind.
The State Department also released the names of four other Americans killed: Prabhi Kavaler and Michelle O'Connor of the General Services office; Tom Shah, an employee of the political section, and Jean Dalizu, an employee of the Defense Attache's office. The Associated Press added two more: Jay Bartley, whose father, Counsul General Julian Bartley, is reported to be missing, and Louise Martin of Atlanta, an employe of the Centers for Disease Control and Prevention.
Ms. Martin, 45, worked for the health agency in Kenya with her husband, Douglas Klaucke.
Susan Bryson of Lawrenceville, Ga., said of Ms. Martin, her sister: "I still don't believe it's real. She died in a country she loved. She died doing the things she liked."
Ms. Kirk and her husband, Robert, 50, a project development officer for the United States Agency for International Development, had planned to extend their stay at home for several days, said Ms. Kirk's sister, Katherine Wright, from South Bend.
But Ms. Kirk worried that her bosses wanted her back to work sooner, her sister said, so the couple and their 14-year-old son, Robbie Jr., flew back, arriving in Nairobi early Friday morning. "They were both exhausted," Ms. Wright said. "She went home and then was rushing to get to work. She went to work late. We think she went into work just before the bomb went off."
During her six weeks in South Bend, Ms. Kirk cared for her elderly parents, Frederick Arthur, 84, and Mary, 83. "She was busy trying to get them enrolled in some exercise classes," said Ms. Wright. "She took them to the doctor. Their health is not that great."
The youngest of six children, Ms. Kirk met her husband at Indiana University. After graduating from Indiana University business school, they went to South Africa, where Mr. Kirk taught democratic principles to township mayors. During the next 25 years, they worked for the Federal Government in various positions in Botswana and Egypt and, for the last three years, in Nairobi.
The couple lost a young daughter, Kamilah, to cancer in 1992. Their oldest child, Maisha, 23, attends Tuskegee University in Alabama. Family members said the couple planned to move back to the United States next year. "It's a bitter pill to swallow," Ms. Wright said.
After a State Department career that spanned more than two decades, including posts in Brazil and Laos, Ms. Hardy had told friends and family that she also planned to return to the United States, possibly next June, to work as an instructor for State Department employees. Her childhood friend, Ms. Bates, described a woman who loved the adventure of her job. Her family had recently received letters and photographs of her remodeled home in Africa.
"She just loved being there, I think," Ms. Bates said. "She found it a beautiful place. Molly was fun-loving, just great -- an intellectual that everybody liked."
While working in Laos in 1973, Ms. Hardy became pregnant, Ms. Bates said. Like other civilian employees, she was ordered to evacuate, and her only child, Brandi Plant, was later born in Washington. Ms. Hardy and her former husband were later divorced. Her last visit to Valdosta had come in April 1997 to attend the funeral of her sister, who had died in an auto accident.
Several months ago, Ms. Hardy apparently had a potential brush with danger. "A plane went down in South Africa that Molly was supposed to have been on," said Ms. Bates, noting that Ms. Hardy ended up catching a different flight.
While riding on the second flight, Ms. Hardy called to tell her mother and daughter not to worry. When a similar call did not come on Friday, her family feared for the worst.
Sergeant Olds had returned to Nairobi in June after spending two months in Birmingham, Ala., taking courses to qualify for a promotion to chief master sergeant. Her aunt, Ms. Casey, said Sergeant Olds passed the test and was expected to receive her promotion in a few months.
Sergeant Olds had joined the Air Force out of high school, following the footsteps of her father, who is now a retired civil servant. Ms. Casey described her niece as a "free spirit" who had also served in Saudi Arabia.
During her coursework in Alabama, Sergeant Olds also spent a week with her family in Panama City, engaging in her favorite hobby. "Shopping," said her aunt with a laugh. "That sounds very strange, but that was her favorite pastime."
On one shopping spree, Sergeant Olds purchased boxes of corn meal and grits -- the ingredients of some of her favorite Southern dishes -- and mailed them to her address in Nairobi. She often sent her family presents of African jewelry, amber and carved wooden games.
Like Sergeant Olds, Sergeant Hobson joined the military as a ticket to see the world. "He knew there was more to life out there, and he was determined to see it," said his mother.
Growing up in a modest blue house behind a sturdy maple tree, he was known as a talented and popular boy. He loved to debate world affairs and play tennis, act in school plays, go hiking, cook gourmet meals and paint.
Sergeant Hobson, the son of a Vietnam veteran, dreamed of retiring from the Army at age 37, attending culinary school and then opening a bed and breakfast, his mother said.
"He had a lot of dreams," his mother said. "And if he had lived, he would have fulfilled every one of them."

Aliganga of Tallahassee, Fla., and Air Force Senior Master Sgt. Sherry Lynn Olds of Panama City, Fla. (pg. 11)(Photographs via Associated Press)

HEADLINE: August 2-8;
The No. 1 Gun Dealer

BYLINE: By TIM WEINER

 BODY:
The United States has kept its title as the world's biggest arms merchant, but Russia and France are poised to overtake it, the Congressional Research Service reported. 
 The United States has led the world arms trade for seven straight years. It sold $15.2 billion worth of weapons to other nations last year, a 44 percent share of the shrinking global arms market. That shrinkage has a number of causes: the end of the cold war, the end of a splurge of weapons purchases after the 1991 Persian Gulf war, the economic crisis in Asia and the long slump in crude oil prices, which has helped slow arms purchases by Saudi Arabia and other Arab nations.
Nonetheless, the world remains awash in arms. Developing nations alone have bought $172 billion worth in the 1990's.
 TIM WEINER

HEADLINE: GURU: Bash;
The Man to Call To Get Your Dog Past a Co-op Board

BYLINE: By ELIZABETH HAYT 

 BODY:
HE has cured a springer spaniel of what he diagnosed as "rage without reason." He has helped a Great Dane overcome sibling rivalry after the birth of its owners' first baby. At the moment, he is ministering to a bulldog with a compulsive appetite for its master's Gucci belts and Hermes bags.
Bashkim Dibra, a dog trainer who has such a cult following among Manhattan pet owners that he is known simply as Bash, like a rock star, charges $200 an hour to go to your apartment and bang on pots to quiet your barking schnauzer. 
 His clients have included Alec Baldwin, Sarah Jessica Parker, Ronald O. Perelman, Linda Wachner and Henry A. Kissinger. He's the "top dog" of trainers, said Georgette Mosbacher, the society figure.
Bash said: "Everything I do, I think of the dog's point of view. I actually think like a dog."
He said that it usually takes six to eight lessons for him to "city train" a pet on a leash, and another seven lessons to "country train" it off the leash. Given the life styles of many of his clients, a "town and country" dog, as he calls it, is a must.
In April, Bash flew to Paris for an emergency visit to a Jack Russell terrier that had forgotten its table manners. Although the dog had been trained to lie quietly under outdoor restaurant tables along Madison Avenue, once away from home, it lunged at other dogs. Bash spent two days going from bistro to bistro, teaching the dog to nibble baguette crumbs peacefully off the cobblestones at its owner's feet.
"Bash is as much a dog psychiatrist as a trainer," said Victoria Newhouse, the wife of S. I. Newhouse Jr., the owner of Conde Nast Publications.
"My dog, Nero, at 12, started to withdraw," she said. "Bash came up with the idea of teaching him a new trick every year. It would revitalize him. The challenge of learning something new made it not true that you can't teach an old dog new tricks."
Bash, who is 46 and was born in Albania, has accompanied dogs to their owners' interviews with co-op boards on the Upper East Side. While the people try to prove their own good breeding, Bash shows off the dogs'. After one such appearance at 1185 Park Avenue, he said, a board member told him, "I wish the kids who lived here could be so well mannered."
Bash and his family came to America in 1963, settling in Riverdale in the Bronx. Bash is still based there, operating his private training service through Fieldston Pets, a grooming and pet supply shop owned by his sister, Mereut. He has a degree in animal behavior from City University and is the author of "Dog Training by Bash" (Dutton, 1991), now in its eighth printing, and "Teach Your Dog to Behave" (Dutton, 1993).
In 1975, he was hired to train and domesticate a wolf pup for a television movie, "A Boy Who Cried Wolf." He named the pup Mariah. "This was my greatest teacher, the rearing and training of her," Bash said. "The wolf is the ancestor of the dog. It's the primal part of the dog that exists. It gave me insight into the mind of the dog."
When he is not making house calls (all of his lessons are private), Bash is a big kahuna on the pet charity circuit. In 1992 he started the Dog Walk, to benefit shelter programs sponsored by the American Society for the Prevention of Cruelty to Animals, and in 1993 he created Paws for Cause, a dog walk for the American Cancer Society to promote awareness that animals can also get cancer. He has been on the board of the Delta Society, which brings dogs together with people with disabilities. Earlier this year he created Canine Court in Van Cortlandt Park in the Bronx, the first dog playground in the city. And he is creating Starpet.com, an on-line animal talent agency for advertising and entertainment.
With an average of 50 clients a week, Bash logs 14-hour days, but he doesn't mind the schedule. "I'm a good barometer of the economy," he said. "There's a new wealth of people -- young Wall Street people living in Scarsdale, Greenwich, Pound Ridge. It's hot to have a dog trainer, just like it's hot to have a personal trainer. I'm like the dog's personal trainer."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 15, 1998, Saturday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Sunday Styles this week about Bashkim Dibra, a dog trainer whose clients have included many celebrities, misstated his role in Paws for Cause, a fund-raising event for the American Cancer Society. Mr. Dibra did not create the event; he was one of several people who first organized and ran it. The article also misstated the event's first year. It was 1992, not 1993.

HEADLINE: Debt Issues Scheduled to Be Offered This Week

 BODY:
The Treasury's schedule of financings this week offers today's regular weekly auction of new three- and six-month bills and the Treasury's quarterly refunding, involving five- and 10-year notes and a 30-year bond. The refunding begins tomorrow with the sale of $16 billion of five-year notes, followed by $11 billion of 10-year notes on Wednesday and $10 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.
According to traders, at the close of the New York cash market on Friday the rate on the outstanding three-month bill was at 4.85 percent and the rate on the six-month issue was at 4.94 percent. In when-issued trading, the five-year note was offered at a price to yield 5.37 percent, the 10-year note at 5.40 percent and the 30-year bond at 5.63 percent.

HEADLINE: Boeing Chairman Sees Jet Output Peaking in'99

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SEATTLE, Aug. 9

 BODY:
The Boeing Company's jetliner production will peak next year and will drop by 10 percent or more in 2000, according to the company's chairman, Philip M. Condit.
After that, how rapidly demand for aircraft will decline depends primarily on the health of economies in Asia, one of Boeing's key markets, Mr. Condit said in an article published today in The Seattle Times. 
 Mr. Condit, once hailed as the man to lead Boeing into the 21st century, is trying to quash rumors he may lose his job. He was interviewed along with Boeing's president, Harry C. Stonecipher, on the first anniversary of Boeing's merger with McDonnell Douglas, where Mr. Stonecipher had been chief executive.
A year ago, Boeing's shareholders were smiling and its plants were humming as the company worked to more than double jetliner production. But Boeing's rapid production increase, combined with problems in bringing out its new-generation 737's, resulted in snarled assembly lines and more than $3 billion in charges. And the Asian crisis meant deferred aircraft orders and deliveries.
Mr. Condit said he expected the profit per airplane to continue rising regardless of events in Asia. But he said Boeing's order-and-delivery cycle is almost certain to top out with next year's expected delivery of a record 620 aircraft.

HEADLINE: Deals to Move Global Positioning Technology Toward Everyday Use

BYLINE: By JOHN MARKOFF 

DATELINE: SANTA CLARA, Calif., Aug. 9

 BODY:
The world's two largest digital cellular phone companies and a Japanese microelectronics giant plan on Monday to announce separate deals with a three-year-old Silicon Valley start-up to produce global positioning system chips inexpensive enough to be installed in cellular telephones.
Nokia of Finland will announce a $3 million investment in the start-up, Sirf Technology Inc., while both Ericsson of Sweden and Hitachi will announce partnerships to develop global positioning systems, or G.P.S., for consumer products. 
 G.P.S. devices use signals from satellites to pinpoint a location anywhere on the globe. The technology was developed by the Pentagon and first made its way into civilian use in specialized navigational systems for ships and airplanes.
The new backing for Sirf, a relatively unknown company, is the strongest signal to date that G.P.S. technology will increasingly become part of everyday life.
Start-ups like Sirf are being joined by established contenders like Trimble Navigation in rapidly adapting global positioning technology for a wide range of consumer electronics gadgets as well as for virtually any movable object, whether automobiles or luggage.
"We will put this technology in our products beginning as early as the year 2000," said Daryl Toor, an Ericsson executive. "Our vision is that increasingly, a small portable phone will be your gateway to the world."
The convergence of portable wireless electronic devices and the World Wide Web may soon make it conceivable for consumers to type questions like "Where is the nearest pizza parlor?" into hand-held devices and receive an answer in text or even from a robotic voice.
By licensing its technology to consumer electronics companies and chip makers, Sirf is hoping it will be able to transform the G.P.S. industry, which until now has been built around different proprietary systems for every company.
"Bringing in Ericsson and Nokia is a huge coup for Sirf," said Dale Ford, an industry analyst with Dataquest of San Jose, Calif., a market research firm. "Licensing technology to semiconductor companies could become a very large business."
Sirf has been developing G.P.S. technology on smaller and smaller chips, and at the same time has been lowering the price to the point where this technology can now be an economical component in most consumer electronics products.
The company's founder, Kanwar Chadha, a former Silicon Valley executive at Intel and at the S3 Corporation, describes an array of applications for G.P.S. technologies that go far beyond currently available navigational devices used by sailors, pilots and hikers.
For example, when G.P.S. receiver prices fall below $10, probably some time early in the next century, it will be possible to use them as security devices. Anything from a car to a computer would know its location and could be programmed to automatically shut itself off if it was moved illegally.
"Nobody had been looking at the really exciting G.P.S. applications," Sirf's founder said.
By re-engineering G.P.S. receivers based on microprocessors and digital signal processors, the chips that enable sound in computers and cellular phones, Sirf executives say, the company has realized major performance improvements in the technology.
Industry analysts who have seen Sirf's prototypes said they were more sensitive than existing products, permitting them to function at an acceptable level in the urban canyons that have traditionally blocked G.P.S. signals.
Sirf engineers recently demonstrated a prototype device that was able to begin reporting location information almost instantly and could continue to communicate with orbiting satellites from the basement of a one-story parking garage.
Current G.P.S. systems usually require a number of minutes to start delivering location information and fail when they are blocked by buildings or trees.
The new technology also has privacy and security implications, in part because the Federal Communications Commission has required that cellular phones be able to provide position information to within 125 meters, or roughly 400 feet, by 2001 so they can be located when placing 911 emergency calls.
There are now two contending technologies competing to meet the F.C.C. requirement. One, developed by companies like True Position Inc., uses complex software to locate cell phones by a triangulation method based on measuring the difference in arrival times of signals received by different network antennas.
In contrast, the G.P.S. receivers provide location information based on measuring the differences in arrival time from a constellation of Air Force satellites.
Both systems have strengths and weaknesses -- and different implications for privacy. For example, while the network method may prove superior in some urban areas, G.P.S. systems will be more reliable in rural regions.
Some privacy advocates prefer the G.P.S. systems, which they argue give the user control in deciding whether or not to transmit location information.
Using a triangulation system, the phone company could determine the user's location any time the phone was turned on.
This difference has become more important in recent months because the F.B.I. has indicated that it expects cellular telephone companies to make location information available to law-enforcement agencies.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Kanwar Chadha, Sirf's founder, with a 1996 chip, left, and the newest version. (Peter DaSilva for The New York Times)

LENGTH: 1690 words

HEADLINE: Behind Blue Chips, Small Stocks Chip Away at Bull Market

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
Max G. Rodel, a 55-year-old chemist and investment fanatic, is agonizing over his stock portfolio and feeling a bit rotten about the way his small-company stocks have cratered in the last few weeks.
"It's been absolutely miserable, not only for the last few weeks but for the last few years," he said in a bout of frustration. "I'd invested in small caps for years and done well. But I'm having a very bad year investing, one of the worst in 25 years." 
 In fact, Mr. Rodel, who works part time, took a few days off from his consulting practice in Mill Valley, Calif., last week to glue himself to CNBC financial news and to peruse his subscription of Oberweis, a newsletter about small-company stocks. But as the stock market swooned, he watched helplessly as some of the stocks in his portfolio plummeted as much as 80 percent from his purchase price.
What's going on? While the stocks of large, well-known companies like McDonald's and Boeing have been battered for much of the last month, the stocks of smaller companies have been hit even harder. For instance, the Dow Jones industrial average -- a gauge of larger blue-chip stocks -- has fallen 9 percent from its high in mid-July, while the Russell 2000 index of small stocks has dropped 19 percent from its high in April.
Indeed, a study by John Manley, a securities analyst at Salomon Smith Barney, showed that the majority of really small-company issues -- 5,464 stocks with market values of less than $250 million -- had fallen 45 percent on average from their peak through Tuesday.
The evidence has prompted some Wall Street analysts to talk about a darker side of the bull market and to even suggest that a bear market is in the offing. Despite solid gains in many blue-chip issues, they say, the broader market is much sicker than many investors realize.
"It's just semantics, just a word game," said Gail Dudack, chief investment strategist at Warburg Dillon Read. "Most everyone owns stocks, and no one wants to hear the words bear market. But this is a bear market that's been working its way from the bottom up, and that's classic."
Of course, few on Wall Street are willing to view the recent selloff as the prelude to a stock market crash, noting that the economy is still growing and that foreigners continue to be eager buyers of American stocks. Meanwhile, many analysts simply see a new paradigm -- powered by baby boomers pouring money into retirement plans -- that favors index funds of the big blue-chip companies over small-company stocks. Besides, sharp declines in smaller stocks have not always infected the broader market, and on Thursday and Friday both the small and big stocks rallied, ending one of the nastiest selling bouts in recent years.
But the downturn in small-company stocks is difficult to ignore. Their weakness can be glimpsed in what market analysts call the advance-decline line, a measure of how many stocks rise versus how many fall over a given period. In the 30 days ended Tuesday, 9,394 more stocks fell than rose, one of the worst performances in a decade.
That selloff caused blue-chip stocks to decline nearly 10 percent from their records, a sizable drop that analysts generally consider a market correction. A bear market is defined as a 20 percent drop.
Whether or not the misfortunes of smaller company stocks have any greater significance in the current bull market, their weakness has many on Wall Street paying heed.
"What this says is that the bull market has become increasingly narrow," said Claudia E. Mott, who tracks small-company stocks at Prudential Securities. "There's so much to be said for the bargains in the small-stock sector, but the money is going into the big names."
How bad is it? According to analysts, the performance gap between large and small stocks is approaching the levels of the Depression. The disparity, however, is not new. Since early 1994, stocks of big companies have vastly outperformed stocks of smaller companies. In April 1997, the Standard & Poor's 500-stock index had risen 19.8 percent in the previous 12 months, but the Russell 2000 index of smaller stocks had fallen 5.1 percent -- creating a spread of about 25 percentage points.
Early last week, the chasm between small and large stock performance widened once again, to 17 percentage points. And perhaps more important, the Russell dropped into negative territory at its low on Wednesday, showing small stocks down 8.7 percent on the year while the S.& P. 500 was up 11.4 percent.
"This is close to the largest spread we've seen since October 1929 and October 1937," said Theodore Aronson, an analyst and principal at Aronson & Partners, a money management firm in Philadelphia. "You can drive the proverbial truck through that spread."
Such disparities exist despite studies that have shown that smaller- company stocks generally outperform blue chips over the long haul. In his book "Stocks for the Long Run," Jeremy J. Siegel, a professor at the Wharton School of the University of Pennsylvania, says that going back to 1925, small stocks have produced a compound annual return of 12.5 percent compared with 11 percent for the S.& P. 500. To be sure, Mr. Siegel and other studies note that if the data exclude certain unique periods, large stocks outperform smaller stocks by a narrow margin.
Smaller-company stocks have also had a relatively strong track record in earnings growth. Ms. Mott of Prudential said smaller companies outpaced larger companies in earnings growth for five consecutive quarters, a trend expected to continue well into 1999. In the second quarter of 1998, she said, small companies had profit gains of about 10 percent, compared with just 2 percent for S.& P. 500 companies.
As a result, smaller-company stocks are at or near historically low valuations. So investors are paying relatively little per share for each dollar of earnings growth.
Cheap as the shares may be, investors want to see appreciation over time, and over the last few years investors like Mr. Rodel have watched their shares slip and slide while blue chips have soared.
The reasons for underperformance are many. But chief among them seems to be the growing popularity of index funds that mimic the performance of the S.& P. 500. Millions of investors, eager to ride the bull market of blue chips, have tied their fortunes to such indexes.
Portfolio managers, fighting a losing battle against the index funds, often find themselves riding the same stocks, trying to keep pace, which creates a kind of blue-chip buying frenzy. And foreigners, increasingly eager to invest in American companies, are buying into the safest, most heavily traded stocks.
This has helped push blue chips to record highs. In fact, much as happened with the Nifty Fifty stocks of the 1970's, buying power is being concentrated in an ever smaller group of stocks. For instance, in the first half of this year, the top 10 stocks in size in the S.& P. 500 had an average gain of 24.9 percent, while the smallest 200 gained just 6.5 percent, on average.
That kind of buying does not sit well with Jim Oberweis Sr. Since 1976, Mr. Oberweis, whose office is in North Aurora, Ill., has run the Oberweis small-stock newsletter and a mutual fund that boasts an annualized return of about 25 percent over the last decade. This year, however, his portfolio of small stocks is lagging badly behind the S.& P. 500.
"We have clients scratching their heads saying, 'Why do I go through the effort to find good companies with good earnings and then they don't do well?' " he said. Meanwhile, "Coca-Cola is selling at 50 times earnings with revenues growing 7 percent. That's asinine. It may be a great company, but it's not a great stock."
For many on Wall Street, the debate over small stocks comes down to this: Is this a new era in which investors simply favor blue chips in a global marketplace, despite higher prices and concerns about Asia, or are investors signaling a bearish downturn by retreating from a broad segment of the stock market?
If history is any guide, the deterioration in small stocks usually signals a sharper downturn for the broader market. In 1929 and 1972, small-company stocks began to deteriorate well ahead of larger stocks, until the market behemoths collapsed.
There have been exceptions, notably in 1997, when sharp slowdowns in smaller stocks did not lead to a bear market, but analysts say that more often than not, bear periods follow broader meltdowns. And although this bull market -- now one of the longest in history, having begun in October 1990 -- has defied many historical markers, a growing number of analysts are concerned about its longevity, particularly now that earnings growth has slowed drastically for big companies.
Robert Farrell, a longtime analyst at Merrill Lynch & Company, noted last week that some 70 percent of all over-the-counter stocks were down 30 percent or more from their all-time highs, and he said this weakness was a sign of bearishness.
"It's only a bull market in the sense that the big major stocks haven't come down 10 percent," he said. "But if you were told 50 percent of your portfolio was down 40 percent, it would be hard to argue you weren't in a bear market."
Even more, once-bullish market commentators like Ralph J. Acampora, a technical analyst at Prudential Securities who once predicted the Dow would reach 10,000 by 2000, are turning bearish. Mr. Acampora's bearish words on CNBC last Tuesday helped send the Dow plunging 299.43 points.
But Mr. Aronson said that despite the bearish signals, nothing was exact in the global marketplace, which depends on emotions as much as calculations. "None of these statistical relationship are anything approaching E=mc2 ," he said. "There's no formula. A lot of it is market psychology."
As for Mr. Rodel, he is going to wait and hope that this is not the onset of a bear market, but a cycle that could end with small stocks taking back a leadership role.
"I have friends who only invest in the S.& P. 500 funds, and they kind of tease me," he said. "But I think I'm going to stick to my guns."

HEADLINE: No Quick Fix in Asia

 BODY:
More than a year has gone by since the collapse of Thailand's currency, the baht, signaled the beginning of the Asian crisis. Hopes that the turmoil would be contained to one or two countries, and would end soon, have long since been dashed.
The problem is worse than it might have been because Japan waited too long to deal with the aftereffects of the collapse of its stock and real estate markets eight years ago. However, Japan's new Prime Minister, Keizo Obuchi, hit all the right notes in his first major policy speech on Friday, promising economic deregulation, tax cuts, increased public spending and a program to rescue the country's banking system. But important details are still vague, and Mr. Obuchi was right to warn that it will take "a year or two" to get a Japanese recovery underway. 
 Healing sick banks is a necessity in virtually every Asian country. Having lent money to finance inflationary booms when Asia was growing faster than the rest of the world, the banks now find their loans are backed by assets whose value has collapsed or, worse, were made to companies that had plenty of political influence but no real way of earning money to repay the loans.
In Japan, the problem is both larger and more solvable than in other Asian countries. There may be as much as $1 trillion in bad debts on the books of Japanese banks, making that problem far greater, in proportion to the size of the economy, than the one that confronted American banks at the beginning of this decade. But, like the United States, Japan is a wealthy country that can afford to clean up the mess if there is the political will. It appears that will is finally present.
China's problems provide another risk for the region. There is renewed speculation in financial markets that China's currency, the renminbi, will be devalued despite the Government's promises to hold the line. Chinese exports are being hurt by the weakness of the yen and other Asian currencies, particularly the South Korean won. South Korea is winning export markets in products like steel and cement that China needs to export as it tries to reform its economy and shrink the bloated state-owned enterprises that employ most Chinese workers but lose large sums of money. It has kept those enterprises afloat, and its economy growing, through "loans" from state-owned banks, which as a result would be insolvent if reasonable accounting standards were applied.
China has enough foreign exchange to defend its currency, and its relatively closed financial system makes speculation against the currency difficult. But the Chinese leadership fears a slowdown in its economy, and it might decide within a year that it needs to devalue, even if that risks worsening the problem for other Asian countries.
Earlier in this decade, Asia's strength helped bring prosperity to the rest of the world. Now it appears that the world will have to deal with a weak Asia for some time to come.

HEADLINE: BOMBINGS IN EAST AFRICA: THE SCENE;
Caprice Of Terror: Who Dies, Who Lives

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 9

 BODY:
An Air Force employee lost a chance to spend Thursday night in Amsterdam, and lost her life when she went to work on Friday.
A 21-year-old Marine guard would probably have lived if he had been at his post, in the front of the United States Embassy here, but he had just gone to get money for the weekend at the cashier's office, in the back of the building, and was killed. 
Many of the Kenyan victims had gone to the embassy early that morning seeking visas, or jobs.
By design, terrorist attacks are ruthlessly indiscriminate. The blast that tore through the embassy here was no exception, taking and sparing lives at will as it shattered the belief that any United States' outpost could be low risk.
Still, timing blessed the most senior diplomats, who were attending their weekly meeting in the Ambassador's spacious office on the fifth floor, the top.
"That saved my life," said William Barr, the embassy's chief spokesman.
For unknown reasons Julian Bartley, the consul general, was not at the meeting, as he would normally be. Today he was the last of the dead Americans to be identified. His son, Jay, a university student who had a summer job at the embassy, was also killed.
At the senior officers' meeting, one of the main items of discussion was security, with talk about how to impart to this summer's arrivals the need for prudence in this city, which has been gripped by street crime, while avoiding a siege mentality.
"It was rather ironic," Donald R. Mackenzie, regional director for the United States Agency for International Development, recalled today.
"We wanted to tell them, 'Kenya is really a marvelous place, you can enjoy yourselves,' " said Mr. Mackenzie, who first began to appreciate the country as a Peace Corps volunteer here 28 years ago. "This has traditionally been a place with a low terrorist threat."
But at 10:35, as the meeting was ending, there was a loud thud.
"Some one next to me said, 'That's an explosion,' " recalled Paul Peterson, who arrived here only three weeks ago as the State Department's regional security officer. "I knew instantly it was a bomb."
Ten seconds later came the second and far more powerful blast, the one that tore through the embassy, leveled the building next door and blew out every window to the top of the 22-story Cooperative Bank building.
What happened is still far from clear. It appears that a vehicle loaded with explosives drove into a parking lot behind the embassy. There have been reports in local papers, unconfirmed, that gun shots were heard before the explosions.
The blast knocked Mr. Mackenzie, who was sitting near a window, out of his chair, and he suffered minor cuts. He picked himself up and quickly followed the others out of the room. They started down the stairwell, now without any light.
And with the walls crumbling, debris turned the stairs into something more akin to a slide. "The dust was just horrible," he said. "A lot of us were fearing that we could not go on breathing."
There was no panic, not even screaming inside the embassy, several diplomats recalled.
But there was random death.
Among the unfortunate were those employees who, with the weekend approaching, had gone to the cashier's office and a Citibank branch to get money. They are both in the back of the embassy, on the first floor, which took the brunt of the blast.
That is where Jesse N. Aliganga, a Marine sergeant from Panama City, Fla., was killed, said Mr. Peterson, the security officer.
Because of a strike at Kenya's commercial banks, the secretary for Mr. Barr asked for time to go from the spokesman's offices, about a half mile from the embassy, to the Citibank branch.
"She went down and she didn't come back," Mr. Barr said. He asked that her name not be published because the Kenyan Government has not released the names of the Kenyan victims.
Fate also dealt cruelly with Arlene Kirk, 50, an Air Force employee at the embassy, and Robert Kirk, who worked for the Agency for International Development. They were returning to Nairobi from vacation. Their flight from Amsterdam was overbooked and the airline asked for volunteers to give up their seats in exchange for some money and a free night in Amsterdam.
The Kirks decided to take it, Mr. Barr said, but by the time they got to the counter, other passengers had volunteered. So the Kirks got on the flight, and returned to work on Friday, when Mrs. Kirk was killed.

HEADLINE: BOMBINGS IN EAST AFRICA: IN NAIROBI;
As 155 Kenyan Lives Ended, Many More Changed Forever

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 9

 BODY:
On Friday morning, Jack Omukhani paid a visit to his wife at her job in the switchboard room of the Ufundi Cooperative House.
He had time to spare because he was on strike from his bank job. They talked of little things. His wife, Elizabeth Akino, insisted that he stay for a cup of tea to brace him against the chilly weather. He left just after 10 A.M. 
Today he picked up her mangled body from the city morgue. A half-hour after they parted, Ms. Akino was killed by the terrorist's bomb aimed at the American Embassy next door, which caused even worse devastation at the Ufundi building.
Ms. Akino was among at least 155 Kenyans who were killed in an act of terrorism that investigators say appears to have nothing to do with them.
"As for me, it was actually by the grace of God I survived," Mr. Omukhani said, as he fought back tears outside the City Council Mortuary, the main morgue, where he had found his wife's body on the floor. "I had just seen her, and we had talked."
As the death toll from Friday's bombing continued to rise, the families of victims turned to the grim tasks of burying their dead and rebuilding their lives.
The blast ripped through a busy downtown district dominated by banks and government offices at 10:30 A.M. Many of the people who died were educated, middle-class Kenyans: office workers, bankers, engineers, accountants.
In a country like Kenya, where jobs are scarce and the average income is less than $260 a year, the effects of Friday's carnage will spread far beyond the immediate families of the dead, like rings in a pond, to hundreds of dependents living in rural areas, Kenyans said.
Even for those who survived the blast and the storm of flying glass and shrapnel that followed, life has been forever altered. More than 500 people were hospitalized for wounds. Scores were blinded or permanently scarred, hospital officials said.
Many relatives of victims expressed a quiet outrage that Kenyans were paying with their lives for American foreign policy decisions. Some expressed the opinion that the American marines and officials had done too little to help dig out victims from the rubble of the Ufundi house in the crucial early hours of the disaster.
"If it's a war between the Americans and other people, they should take the war elsewhere," said Dr. Charles Onudi, who was waiting for a relative's body outside the morgue. "Lots of innocent lives are being lost."
At the City Council Mortuary today, lines of relatives snaked slowly through the horrifying rooms of disfigured and mutilated bodies. Most had been searching hospitals since the blast in a desperate attempt to find missing relatives alive. Every few minutes, there were muffled cries, followed by the sound of weeping, as people discovered their kin.
On the front gate was a list of 34 names of people already identified by the police, scrawled in felt pen on a paper bag.
No. 28 was John Ouko Onyango, a 33-year-old engineer who worked at the Kenya Power and Lighting Company. He was a polite, religious man who seemed to have a bright future ahead of him, friends said. His wife is a nurse at the Nairobi Hospital. They had two small children, the second only a month old.
Last month, Mr. Onyango purchased a new car, a sign he was coming up in the world. A cautious man, he went to the Ufundi building on Friday morning to buy more automobile insurance, his friends said.
"He was the person who was well-off in the family," said his cousin, Apollo Abiero. "He was the bread-winner. He supported four brothers and a sister."
Further up on the list was Caroline Ndolo, a 29-year-old single mother who worked as a clerk in the destroyed building at the Ufundi Cooperative Savings and Credit Society. Her brother, Frederick, a father of two boys, also worked at the bank. He is missing and presumed dead.
Friends described Miss Ndolo as a talkative and independent young woman who liked to go dancing in Nairobi nightclubs and enjoyed her single life. She had been pleased to discover that she was pregnant last year. Her boy is three months old.
"She was happy about the baby," her father, Michael Opondo Ndolo, a retired civil servant, said as he waited for his daughter's body to be loaded into a hearse. "She had a plan of opening a small shop, a boutique."
Echoing the sentiment of many grieving people here, Mr. Ndolo said the American Embassy should be moved far from the center of town.
Naftali Muyonga, a senior official in the Foreign Ministry, came to the morgue to take care of arrangements for his brother-in-law, Moises Ashton Mwani, who was a high-ranking civil servant in the Teachers Service Commission. Mr. Mwani, 50, was killed by shrapnel from the blast as he sat in a meeting on the fourth floor of another building next to the Ufundi building, Mr. Muyonga said.
"What we fail to understand is why the terrorists should pick on a peaceful country like Kenya," Mr. Muyonga said.
At about noon, Mr. Omukhani and his friends carried the body of his wife, Elizabeth Akino, out of the morgue on a stretcher and into a van. Half her face and head had been destroyed by shrapnel. The hearse took the body to a funeral home in Nairobi's center, to keep until the family can collect enough money to transport her body to western Kenya for burial.
Ms. Akino's death was a heavy blow for her family. She has two children, an 8-year-old boy and a 3-year-old girl. Her husband has been on strike from the Kenya Commercial Bank for a week, along with thousands of other bank employees. The striking workers were dismissed by management last week, and it is unclear if they will be allowed to return to work.
"I have to be worried," Mr. Omukhani said. "I don't know my fate as of now. I'm just wishing that all will go well and I'll go back to work."
Ms. Akino's older sister, Tereza Okidi, 45, said she was worried that the family would not have enough money to support the children. Ms. Okidi, a former secretary, said she had recently started a small restaurant. But she has two grown children of her own, both unemployed, and her earnings will not stretch far.
"I don't know how to start life with these small children," she said. "I can't neglect my sister's children. I can't run from the responsibility. It has found me, and it is mine."
Her friends and relatives described Ms. Akino as a strong, athletic woman. She played semiprofessional volleyball for the Kenya Commercial Bank team for several years before she gave it up to devote herself to her children, friends said.
Born in Nairobi, Ms. Akino was the sixth child in a family of nine. Her father was a mechanic. She finished high school, but never had enough money to go to college, relatives said. She was studying typing and shorthand and dreamed of becoming a secretary.
In recent years, she had grown more religious. She loved gospel music and spent much of her spare time working with women's organizations and church groups. Though she was not garrulous, she had many friends. Her desk at work was a magnet for people on coffee breaks, so much so that her boss sometimes complained.
Ms. Akino and her husband and children lived in a one-room apartment in a barracks-style public housing project in Bahati, a working-class neighborhood. She talked often to friends about her desire to move into a bigger house, buy a car and have a third child.
The walls of the tiny home are decorated with banners from volleyball tournaments. There is a showcase with trophies on one wall. Her husband also plays, for the Kenya National Team.
In the afternoon, her family and friends met at her home to share stories and talk about funeral arrangements. Several fought back tears as they gathered outside on wooden benches under a gray sky. They prayed together and then began to talk about what was needed for a respectable funeral.
"She was my best friend," said Danae Tirop, 28, who also played for the bank's volleyball team. "She was the maid of honor at my wedding. She was warm, generous, kind, understanding. She always thought of her children first."
Ms. Tirop's eyes welled up.
"On that Friday, I actually wanted to go to see her," she said. "But I decided to wait until after lunch."
