SECTION: Section A; Page 4; Column 3; Foreign Desk 

LENGTH: 1419 words

HEADLINE: Sweden, Once the World's Conscience, Now Drifts

BYLINE: By WARREN HOGE 

DATELINE: STOCKHOLM, Aug. 2

 BODY:
The waterfront palaces and baronial shoreline buildings of this northern capital stand as hardy symbols of Scandinavian stability, and the sailboats and tourist vessels that glide over the gray Baltic waters leave barely a ripple.
But for all the outward signs of sureness, continuity and calm, Sweden is approaching its future and an election with a sense of drift and loss and an unaccustomed confusion over what to do about it. 
 In this decade, Swedes have lost their feeling of being exceptional, and experienced their first unemployment, social spending scandals and a decline in competitiveness. The Organization for Economic Cooperation and Development has reduced Sweden's per capita income standing from 4th to 15th place in the world, ranking it behind its Scandinavian neighbors, Denmark, Finland and Norway, as well as Ireland and Italy.
Its largest and most successful company, the telecommunications giant Ericsson, is threatening to move its headquarters to Britain, where it finds the business climate better. Industrialists cite high personal income taxes and rigid labor rules as impediments to remaining competitive globally while doing business here.
The country that produced Gunnar Myrdal and preached racial tolerance has now developed segregated communities in Stockholm's suburbs for many of the 800,000 immigrants who have come here during the last 30 years from the Middle East, Asia, South America and Eastern Europe.
Long quietly proud of their country's position as the world's good conscience, Swedes miss being the society that attracted admiration from afar for a nation of fewer than nine million people living on the chill edge of Europe. Then, they were the future, a model of rationality, tolerance, cradle-to-grave care of citizens and generosity to people living in less advantaged countries overseas.
The nostalgia arises in every conversation with Swedes about their country and has produced an election campaign in which the most repeated claim is not a dynamic pledge to bring change but a stolid promise to restore what was.
"Restore is the key word," said Sigfrid Leijonhufvud, a political and economic columnist for the Svenska Dagbladet. "The desire is to go back to when Sweden was one of the three or four richest countries in the world, when we were listened to in the United States and labor and management used to come and tour Sweden to see how we did it and everyone looked to us for the solution."
It was the renowned Middle Way that sought to provide a humane passage between controlling totalitarianism and uncaring capitalism, and its home was Sweden.
"It was absurd, but we thought of ourselves as a kind of superpower," said Arne Ruth, an author and former editor in chief of Dagens Nyheter. "We had the certainty that progress was permanent. Now that feeling of exceptionalism has been lost, and we are just another normal nation."
Like other normal nations, Sweden faces the new pressure of competing in a globalized economy where progress is measured in enterprise and productivity. Meeting that challenge may be at cross purposes with satisfying its aging population's desire to keep huge welfare state subsidies intact.
Tentative Government attempts to trim its welfare costs are so resented that officials have promised to increase spending and abandon talk of tax cuts. "Talking about tax cuts in this campaign is like swearing in church," said Toivo Sjoren, research chief at the Sifo opinion surveying group.
The Government spends 46 percent of Sweden's gross national product on welfare, more than any other country, and its overall public spending is 63 percent of gross national product. The income taxes required to support this public munificence take 59 percent of the pay of people earning as little as $30,000 a year and oblige employers to pay up to 41 percent of employee remuneration into social security and pension plans.
While center-left parties in European countries like Britain, the Netherlands, France and Spain have cut government subsidies and encouraged private business, Sweden's ruling Social Democrats go into the Sept. 20 parliamentary elections facing irresistible demands from their aging constituents to restore what was cut.
"There are Swedes who are excited about the possibilities of the future, but more who are scared by them, and the politicians respect the scared part because that's where you get the votes," said Mats Lindgren, the chairman of the consulting firm Kairos Future.
"No one," Mr. Sjoren said, "is sure about what the way for Sweden is anymore." He produced study charts measuring the dispositions of major countries that placed Sweden in the corner representing the pursuit of stability instead of innovation. Other industrialized countries were crowded into the top quarter for their willingness to take risks and act decisively. Sweden's only companion in the forlorn bottom spot was Japan.
Stockholm offers reminders of Sweden's days as a pioneer of style and social conscience. Wheelchair runners are common, stoplights along the Drottinggatan shopping route feature a staccato beep that alters rhythm to allow blind people to cross safely. Every three or four blocks are stores that take Swedes' donated old clothes, refurbish them, sell them at bargain prices and devote proceeds to aid for Africa.
The passing car is most likely a Volvo, the Swedish make that famously sold itself not on sex appeal but on safety. Downtown offices reflect the sleek Swedish Modern style, whichrevolutionized design in the 1960's. Swedish Modern was clean, unadorned and functional.
Similarly, Swedes expect strict probity in public life. Mona Sahlin, the front-runner to become Prime Minister after Ingvar Carlsson resigned in 1995, had to leave politics after it emerged that she had used her state-provided credit card to pay for personal snacks and auto rentals. She had made reimbursements, but they were deemed too tardy.
The end of the cold war has dramatically altered the rationale for Sweden's traditional nonaligned posture. Once, the Baltic Sea was a strategic wall between Sweden and the Soviet republics of Russia, Estonia, Latvia and Lithuania. Now, one of the the first signs off the highway in from Stockholm's Arlanda International Airport points to the ferry for Tallinn, the Estonian capital. Sweden has found itself pressed to drop the neutrality it adopted in both world wars and join an expanding NATO. While determined to resist that, it has taken part in the Bosnia peacekeeping run by NATO.
In a 1994 referendum, Swedes narrowly decided to join the European Union, but the public has blamed many problems since then on Brussels. Polls suggest that a vote today would go against European Union membership. Sensing this mood, the Government of Prime Minister Goran Persson has ruled out even holding a vote on whether to join the European single currency being introduced next year.
Once a nation that spoke out on conditions around the world, Sweden has become self-absorbed. Once, it gave the world Dag Hammarskjold, Secretary General of the United Nations from 1953 to 1961, and Olof Palme, a pioneering Social Democrat Prime Minister gunned down by a still unknown assassin in 1986. Their fame on the foreign stage was an asset at home.
Now, Carl Bildt, the former Prime Minister who spent two years as chief foreign peace envoy to Bosnia, has returned home to find his opposition Moderate Party losing popularity, and predicted to poll little more than the 22 percent it recorded in the 1994 elections that brought the present Government to power.
Mr. Bildt argued that the two major parties were on the same train but that his was on the front looking forward and Mr. Persson's was on the back staring at the past. Voters still seem to favor the latter stance.
Any attempt at restructuring faces formidable cultural resistance. The work force is 80 percent unionized, and 31 percent of the jobs are in the public sector. Pressure for change is coming from frustrated entrepreneurs and young people.
"Businesses can't grow here because it's too expensive to hire people," said Mr. Lindgren of Kairos Future.
"Young people are starting to think globally," he said. "They're comparing themselves with the people around the world that they meet on backpacking trips, or on the Internet or where they've studied abroad or at a job for a multinational. Some of them are moving away, and they are the people that Sweden needs most."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS: ADVERTISING -- ADDENDA;
Margeotes/Fertitta Is Acquired by MDC

BYLINE: By Andrew Ross Sorkin 

 BODY:
The agency world continues to get smaller as yet another independent shop announced that it had been acquired. Margeotes/Fertitta & Partners in New York said that the communications and marketing services division of the MDC Communications Corporation in Toronto had acquired a majority interest in the agency. Financial terms were not disclosed.
As part of the deal, Margeotes/Fertitta, which was founded in 1973, will continue to operate as an independent agency under that name. George Fertitta, 52, a founder, president and chief executive of Margeotes/Fertitta, will continue to head the shop in that role. He will also own a "substantial majority stake" in the agency. 
 "I think 25 years is a long enough stretch to go on your own," Mr. Fertitta said, adding that, "it's nice to have a big brother to help you grow and expand your business on behalf of your clients."
Margeotes/Fertitta has 115 employees and billings estimated at $175 million to $190 million from clients including Benckiser Consumer Products, Godiva Chocolatier, the National Football League, Media One and McGraw-Hill.
Mr. Fertitta said that over the last several years, Margeotes/Fertitta has had numerous expressions of interest in being acquired by or merged with a wide range of agencies, holding companies and foreign communications companies. "Although there were attractive financial numbers offered to us, none of them offered the kind of entrepreneurial model that MDC offered us."
Miles S. Nadel, president and chief executive of MDC, said "This acquisition is an important strategic step in expanding our presence in the marketing services industry in the United States." MDC, which owns three agencies in Canada, acquired an Internet-based marketing agency in May called Cyber Sight in Portland, Ore.

HEADLINE: BOMBINGS IN EAST AFRICA: THE CONSUL GENERAL;
The Last Hope Of One Family Is Extinguished

BYLINE: By RAYMOND BONNER with JAMES DAO 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 9

 BODY:
She already knew that her son was dead.
But as Sue Bartley and 150 other mourners left a memorial service here today for the American victims of Friday's terrorist bombing, they were hoping against hope that Mrs. Bartley's husband, Consul General Julian Bartley, was still alive. 
 They listened to a reading from Ecclesiastes, heard a mournful taps, then went home to wait, grasping red roses in trembling hands.
Within hours, their wisp of a hope was gone. Using torn clothing, strands of hair and a ring, doctors positively identified Mr. Bartley's badly disfigured body this evening, adding his name to a list of 11 dead Americans that included the Bartleys' 20-year-old son, Jay.
"He was the last missing American," Chris Scharf, an embassy spokesman said.
By all accounts the father and son were an immensely popular pair whose headlong embrace of Kenyan life had been lovingly returned.
"Julian was greatly loved by Ken yans," Mr. Scharf said, "not only because of his respect of them, but also because of his ability to relate to the person who was trembling in line for a visa. He would go outside the embassy and work the line, talking to people. He was extraordinarily popular among Kenyans, even those who might be denied a visa."
After Julian Bartley was declared missing, Kenyan soldiers searched for him in emergency rooms and the public morgue. But later his body was found in a private mortuary where a tag misidentified his as a Kenyan, Mr. Scharf said.
At a ceremony at Ambassador Prudence Bushnell's residence today, colleagues "spoke about how Julian had touched so many people" as he supervised the administrative affairs at the embassy, said Donald R. Mackenzie, director of the regional office of the United States Agency for International Development.
"He's a very special person," said Mr. Mackenzie, who found it difficult to talk about his friend and colleague in the past tense. "When he talks to you, you feel like you are the most important person in the room, and not that he was looking around to see if there was someone more important around.
"He had a great sense of humor. Though I guess it isn't so funny now, he used to say to people who came to him, 'I'll take care of you from womb to tomb.' "
Mr. Bartley, 55, was born in Jacksonville, Fla., according to a statement released by his daughter, Edith, who lives in the United States and was en route to Nairobi tonight to join her mother. He grew up in South Jamaica, Queens, where his mother, Gladys Baldwin, still lives. He worked for the Foreign Service for 24 years, including assignments in the Dominican Republic, Colombia, Spain, Israel and Korea. Before joining the Foreign Service, he was a Peace Corp volunteer.
At today's crowded memorial service, held on the porch of Ambassador Bushnell's home, Mr. Bartley's friends recalled that he had once taken a night job to help pay medical bills for his son, Jay.
Jay Bartley had come to Kenya two years ago, full of youthful enthusiasm about Africa. When he died, he had carved a young man's comfortably frenetic niche for himself in Nairobi, coaching a girl's basketball team, jet skiing at African beaches and teaching friends to ride horses.
At the time of the bombing, Jay Bartley was working at the embassy in a summer job, preparing for his sophomore year at the United States International University in the Kasarani section of Nairobi, about 12 miles from the city center. The university is based in San Diego but has an 1,800-student campus in Nairobi.
Dr. Freida Brown, executive director of the Nairobi campus, said Jay Bartley had planned to spend one more year in Nairobi before returning to the United States to complete his bachelor's degree, possibly in international relations.
"When the explosion first hit, you felt detached from it," she said. "But Saturday morning, when they called me and said he had died, I was totally distraught, because I could just see him walking across that campus."
She described Jay Bartley as gentle, outgoing and caring, a lanky young man with a wide grin and soft voice. "He was the kind of kid who got up first and made his parents breakfast in the morning," she said.
On a recent trip to Mombasa with some friends, Dr. Brown recalled, Jay Bartley took it on himself to oversee the welfare of a student who had broken her leg after falling off her jet ski. "He took her to the hospital," Dr. Brown said. "Then after her foot was put in a cast, he piggybacked her to the bus. He was always looking after other people."
Dr. Brown said Jay Bartley had a learning disability that made it difficult for him to complete written tests, but that he had more than compensated with a buoyant, dogged personality and a laptop computer provided by his father. "It was a real struggle for him, but he never let that stop him," she said.
She described Julian Bartley and his wife as similar to their son: easygoing, upbeat, sociable people. "Julian always had a big smile and hug for everybody," she said. "They were three of a kind."
During a visit to the Bartley home on Saturday, Dr. Brown described Mrs. Bartley as being "in a state of shock." Yet she still had enough presence of mind to ask Dr. Brown whether she had received a cookbook from the Nairobi American Women's Association.
"She's amazing," Dr. Brown said. "She was looking after people even in this time of sorrow."

GRAPHIC: Photos: At the State Department yesterday, Edith Bartley spoke of her father, Julian, top, and her brother Jay, who were killed in the bombing of the American Embassy in Nairobi. Twelve Americans died in the explosion. (Associated Press (Edith Bartley); WCBS via Associated Press (Julian and Jay Bartley))(pg. A7)

HEADLINE: Web Concern Gets Patent For Its Model Of Business

BYLINE: By PETER H. LEWIS 

 BODY:
A small start-up company in Connecticut has been awarded a broad patent that appears to protect not just the virtual nuts and bolts of its electronic commerce system, but also its entire business model for buying and selling goods and services on the Internet.
The company, Priceline.com L.L.C. of Stamford, best known for allowing consumers to "name your own price" for airline tickets, said it would be issued United States patent No. 5,794,207 tomorrow for both the method and the use of "buyer-driven commerce" from the Patent and Trademark Office. Priceline in effect convinced the Patent Office that it had invented a new way of doing business, one that was fundamentally different from any other form of electronic commerce today. 
 Priceline's "reverse auction" method is such a narrowly specific approach to on-line business that analysts said few other Internet commerce companies were likely to be significantly restricted by the patent. But the Patent Office's growing willingness to protect an entire Internet business model -- and not just the technical wrinkles -- could set a precedent with far-reaching implications for electronic commerce.
"Internet-related business patents are extremely important," said Carl Oppedahl, a intellectual property lawyer in Frisco, Colo. He cited the continuing case of E-Data, a New Jersey business that is suing more than a dozen companies over its patent claims to control fundamental aspects of electronic commerce. Depending on the outcome of the E-Data case, Mr. Oppedahl said, "Microsoft levels of money either will or will not change hands, and there are likely to be other Internet-business-method patent lawsuits with similarly high stakes."
Several computer-related business-method patents have been upheld by the courts in the last decade. But the Priceline patent is one of the first awarded since the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit affirmed last month that a "practical application of a mathematical algorithm, formula or calculation" could be protected.
As such, Priceline's patent could touch off a race to control the underlying framework of electronic commerce.
In the Priceline system, consumers submit a bid, known as a "conditional purchase offer," to buy goods or services -- airline tickets or automobiles, for example -- from unknown sellers at a certain price, and they guarantee the offer with a credit card. Priceline presents the offers to the sellers, who then have the option of either fulfilling or rejecting the bids, or making a counteroffer. Priceline then completes the transaction.
For example, a buyer might wish to buy two airplane tickets from New York to Seattle. He or she would set conditions: the flight must be on a major airline on a certain date, allowing one change of planes if the layover is no more than two hours, and the price per ticket can be no more than $300. Any airlines that participate in the Priceline system can review the offers, and the first one that responds, meeting all the conditions, gets the sale.
Andrew B. Whinston, director of the Center for Research in Electronic Commerce at the University of Texas at Austin, said that from a traditional economic perspective, the Priceline business model was hardly radical. It seems very similar to the method by which a government agency or a corporation puts out specifications and conditional purchase orders to multiple contractors or vendors, he said.
Besides Priceline's use of cryptography and other networking technologies, what appears to be new and original, said Mr. Whinston, who holds professorships in both economics and computer science, is that by using computers and the Internet, the company is able to bring this method of buyer-driven commerce to consumers.
"Because it has one buyer and multiple sellers, it is a mirror image of Internet auction companies like Onsale.com, in which you have one seller and multiple buyers," he said.
Priceline officials said that the patent would also cover the "apparatus" the company developed to authenticate customers' identities and verify their ability to pay, to protect the anonymity and privacy of both buyer and seller, to enable sellers to browse the list of offers, and to complete the pact electronically.
Although Priceline does almost all its business on the World Wide Web, company officials noted that its buyer-driven method could also be carried out through electronic mail, voice mail or fax.
Jay Walker, Priceline's chairman and chief executive, said that the business model for buyer-driven commerce on the Internet was developed over the course of several years by researchers at Walker Digital, an unusual company he formed several years ago as a combination research center, invention factory and patent law office. The patent, Mr. Walker said, was among nearly 200 that his company had filed in the last three years, including some that seek protection for new electronic business methods as well as for the technical systems that make them possible.
Walker Digital sold the rights to the buyer-driven system to Priceline.
Priceline said last week that it had received $20 million in private financing from the venture capital firm General Atlantic Partners. The investors expect revenue from Priceline's business operations, but the real potential payoff will come from the licensing of its methods to other electronic commerce companies, Mr. Walker said.
"Priceline is really entering into an exciting space, one that I know many other large organizations, notably Microsoft, have also looked at," said Kenneth H. Smith, director of on-line retailing research at Mainspring, a Boston-based consulting company. "My assumption is they will be challenged on this patent."
Mr. Smith and other analysts noted, however, that the Priceline model was very likely to appeal to a relatively small niche of buyers who know the exact specifications and reasonable prices for the product or service they want.
Travelers must be willing to fly at unpopular times, for example, and give up their choice of airline and perks like frequent-flier miles.
Priceline asserts that it has sold 40,000 airline tickets to leisure travelers in its three months of operation, despite the fact that only a handful of domestic airlines now participate in the system. Even so, the airline industry reports that the average number of seats that fly away empty every day is about 500,000. Mr. Walker said that there was untapped demand for those seats at the right price.
The company recently broadened its offerings to include new cars, but the participating car dealers are limited for now to the New York area.
Mr. Walker said Priceline would soon expand its on-line products to include hotel rooms, automobile financing, credit cards, personal computers, home mortgages, life insurance, rental cars, cruise ship vacations and other services.
James McQuivey, who analyses on-line retail strategies for Forrester Research in Cambridge, Mass., described Priceline's broad strategy as "brilliant" but said that its success would depend on the selection of goods that are offered. "There's really no incentive for the airlines to play," he said, because all the seats are managed by relatively few sellers. "In the car business, though, power is diffused through more than 20,000 dealers."
Mr. Smith of Mainspring was also sanguine about Priceline's patent. "I think they have a real chance," he said. "More so than in any other industry, the Internet allows a new and interesting business a chance to deliver value into the marketplace. At the same time, it can quickly deliver the message from the market if the value proposition is either not wanted or not needed.
"In other words, you get a chance, but you find out very quickly if you're going to be a failure."

CORRECTION-DATE: August 12, 1998, Wednesday

 CORRECTION:
An article in Business Day on Monday about a patent awarded for an Internet auction system misidentified the court whose ruling last month helped pave the way for the new patent. It was the United States Court of Appeals for the Federal Circuit, which hears appeals from district courts in patent, trademark and copyright cases, not the United States Court of Appeals for the District of Columbia Circuit.

HEADLINE: Scientist at Work: Dr. Patricia Wright;
Saving Madagascar's Bounty for Its Lemurs and Its People

BYLINE: By JANE E. BRODY 

 BODY:
Patricia Wright's trail to Madagascar and environmental heroism began in the 1960's with an act that is now considered the antithesis of conservation: the purchase in a Brooklyn pet store of an owl monkey, and then a second one to keep it company.
Within a week of the birth of her own daughter, Amanda, the monkeys too produced a Brooklyn baby, and Dr. Wright, then a mother and housewife, became increasingly intrigued by the behavior of these nocturnal monkeys. The female monkey's only responsibility appeared to be breast-feeding. The male did all the parenting, carrying and caring for the baby. 
 Dr. Wright, who had loved the woods growing up in upstate New York and had an undergraduate degree in biology, decided she wanted to study these monkeys in the wild. Books in the New York Public Library told her that the "wild" meant the jungles of Peru, home to wild boar, jaguars and deadly fer-de-lance snakes. She consulted Dr. Warren Kinzey, then an anthropologist at City University of New York, pumping him for guidance.
Dr. Kinzey told her that without a graduate degree and university affiliation, no one would finance her effort. But she was undeterred. Through a friend, she arranged an affiliation with the New School for Social Research and persuaded Nancy Mulligan, a wildlife fancier from Rochester, N.Y., to finance the expedition for herself, her husband, their daughter, 3, and a native guide.
Dr. Wright's library research had led her to a site that turned out to have long since been converted from jungle to coffee plantations. No monkey had been seen there for 25 years. The next stop was a six-day canoe ride into the jungle, family in tow. Her guide soon got bored looking for monkeys in the dark, so one night Dr. Wright ventured alone into the jungle. Frightened by what sounded like wild boar and with her flashlight growing dim, she spent the night in a spiny tree, only to be scolded by none other than two owl monkeys whose territory she had invaded.
They were the first of many for Dr. Wright. Six months later, she returned to Brooklyn with notebooks filled with observations, the first data ever gathered on nocturnal monkeys in the wild.
At Dr. Kinzey's urging, she enrolled in graduate school at the City University in 1977. After nine years, which included a 14-month trip to the Amazon, she received her doctorate.
Then it was off to Madagascar, known for its rare species, especially lemurs. Armed with a grant from the World Wildlife Fund, Dr. Wright hoped to find the "probably extinct" greater bamboo lemur. Madagascar, in the Indian Ocean, had physically split from the African mainland about 150 million years ago, becoming a laboratory of isolated evolution. The shrinking jungles harbor thousands of species of plants and animals known nowhere else on earth. Eighty percent of Madagascar's wildlife is unique to the island, including nearly all of its mammals, 90 percent of its reptiles and amphibians, 80 percent of its plants and half its birds. The rosy periwinkle that is the source of the life-saving leukemia drug vincristine is one of 8,000 native plants. But all of this bounty was imperiled.
"Flying over the island," she recalled, "all I saw was devastation," the result of decades of slash-and-burn farming.
En route to establishing that the greater bamboo lemur, a little primate with big, watchful eyes and charcoal-gray fur, was indeed alive and doing better than expected in the rain forest, Dr. Wright discovered a new species of lemur with golden red fur, the golden bamboo lemur, which thrives on the cyanide-laced shoots of young bamboo, though how this three-and-a-half-pound primate tolerates an amount of poison that could kill a man is still anyone's guess.
"But no sooner had I found this new species than I heard farmers sawing down 200-year-old rosewood trees, each of which takes about nine smaller trees with it," Dr. Wright said. An appeal to an official to protect the forest ended with a challenge to Dr. Wright to help establish a national park.
She explained that the inroads into the rain forests were nothing more than stopgaps for the farmers living in one of the 10 poorest countries in the world. After only two years of farming on newly cleared land, the soil would be depleted, forcing them to cut down yet more forest. Meanwhile, the runoff of ochre-tinted soil ruined waterways and the loss of trees threatened the watershed. And since few Malagasy were aware of the economic potential of ecotourism, the farmers gave little thought to the fast-disappearing habitats of Madagascar's unique flora and fauna, which include 32 species of lemurs (16 of the largest ones have already become extinct).
By the time Dr. Wright arrived there in 1985, more than 80 percent of the forests had disappeared from the island and there were only two national parks in Madagascar, the last one established in 1930.
It took her five years to create the park, five years of days-long treks to visit farmers and explain the purpose of the park and its potential value to their families, five years of negotiations with village elders and government officials, five years of international phone calls and grant proposals to raise the money needed, not just to create the park but to give the villagers something for the land they would sacrifice.
In the end, with the help of $6.27 million from the United States Agency for International Development and the support of various conservation groups, there was not only a 108,000-acre park but eight new schools, 10 renovated schools, four health-care centers, a team of visiting doctors and nurses, rural libraries with books on conservation and 133 villagers working in the park. In addition, the villagers receive half the entrance fees to the park, now visited by 10,000 tourists a year.
"Pat's extraordinary contribution has been her ability to see the intimate link between the beauty and fascination of the animals and the lives of the people," said Dr. Alison Jolly, a primatologist at Princeton University who studies ring-tailed lemurs in Madagascar. "It's so easy to say that what matters is the animals or what matters is the people. Pat has been able to say that what matters is both."
Among her many prized honors is the Knight of the National Order of Madagascar, bestowed in 1995 by the President of a country that now knows the rewards of saving its rain forests.
Dr. Wright is executive director of the Institute for the Conservation of Tropical Environments at the State University of New York at Stony Brook and international coordinator of Ranomafana National Park, the rain forest in Antananarivo, Madagascar, rescued by her determination to save the only known home of the newly found lemur.
Dr. Wright is now in her 13th year of studying lemurs, most recently the diademed sifaka, a large, black diurnal primate. "I've finally come out of the dark," she noted, which makes her work attractive to Earthwatch volunteers, amateur researchers who pay to help support environmental research all over the world.
Nowadays, Dr. Wright and an expanded research team work intensively during the six months a year that are not cyclone season. Though Dr. Wright and co-workers still sleep in tents without electricity, the campsite now has two buildings: a research station and a dining hall. The onetime rice-and-beans diet has been enhanced as well by a local cook who persuaded Dr. Wright to send him to cooking school.
During the off-season, Dr. Wright teaches courses on primate conservation and behavior and ecology at Stony Brook. There she is joined by her second husband, Jukka Jernvall, a Finnish paleontologist and developmental biologist who works at the University of Helsinki when she is in Madagascar. He visits her there and they spend a month together each summer in Finland.
"We have a tricontinental marriage," she said, obviously pleased with the unusual arrangement.
She is also pleased with her study subjects. The sifaka, a spectacular leaping lemur that at 15 pounds is the biggest of the living lemurs, is a lot easier to track than owl monkeys. One by one, each animal is tranquilized and fitted with a color-coded nylon necklace. Once a year, the animals are weighed and measured, tooth impressions are taken and their reproductive condition noted.
"As with most other species of lemurs, the female sifaka rules the roost," Dr. Wright explained. "The female is first into the fruit tree where she gets the best and most fruit. Her mate dares not enter the tree until she's finished. If the male forgets and starts up the tree, she'll slap him in the face. If he persists, she'll lunge at him and may even nip him. He then backs away saying 'I'm sorry, I'm sorry, I didn't mean it.' "
And, of course, when it comes to courting, the females choose. The males fight each other, she said, but often, females do not choose the winners. According to the "wimpy male hypothesis" formulated by Dr. Alison Richard, an anthropologist at Yale University, the female, by selecting a loser, may insure her dominant status.
With the sifaka's habitat protected, Dr. Wright said the main loss of these animals nowadays is the work of another endemic species, the fossa, "a fierce mongooselike animal with big teeth and a big appetite and retractable claws that enable it to climb trees fast. The fossa is long, lean and mean and it eats lemurs."

HEADLINE: Ford Cutting Average Price On Cars and Trucks 0.3%

BYLINE: By MICHELLE KREBS 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 10

 BODY:
The Ford Motor Company announced today that the average price of its 1999 model cars and trucks will decrease three-tenths of 1 percent, or about $61, from comparably equipped 1998 models. It dropped the prices of its highest-volume cars, the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable, significantly.
"Last year, for the first time in over 30 years, we were able to hold the line on prices; this year is the first time in over 30 years we've actually reduced prices," Lloyd Hansen, controller for Ford's marketing and sales operations, said in an interview. 
 The 1999 model year, which starts Oct. 1, will mark the second consecutive year that all major auto makers will hold the line on prices.
"We've seen outright deflation in car prices over the last two years," said William P. Wilson, vice president and economist for Comerica Bank, Detroit. The bank's tracking of new-vehicle transaction prices, the price for which vehicles actually sell, shows an eight-tenths of 1 percent drop this May compared with May 1997.
Mr. Wilson said that worldwide excess capacity in auto production had created an extremely competitive environment in North America that prevented auto makers from increasing prices.
The Chrysler Corporation announced in July that its overall prices remained essentially unchanged from 1998 prices, up one-tenth of 1 percent, or about $35 a vehicle, largely as a result of regulatory emission costs. In the 1998 model year, Chrysler's prices remained virtually the same as in 1997. Price increases in 1995 and 1996 were under 2 percent. The General Motors Corporation said its prices, only a few of which have been announced, would be relatively flat. In June, G.M.'s Saturn division said that its 1999 prices would include a price reduction on its coupe. Saturn, which does not offer incentives and prohibits price haggling in the showroom, reduced prices and added equipment to some models last year as well. G.M. does not plan to announce an overall percentage of price change, but will announce prices on individual 1999 models as they are introduced. With a few exceptions, G.M.'s 1999 models will not arrive in dealerships for a couple months because of a 54-day strike by the United Automobile Workers union at two parts plants that shut down almost all of G.M.'s North American assembly plants. Most plants are back in full operation and will produce 1998 models through September to use up the inventory of parts designed for those vehicles before changing over to 1999 models.
Import manufacturers typically announce prices in late summer or early fall.
At Ford, prices of cars dropped an average of 1.7 percent; truck prices fell five-tenths of 1 percent. Prices of Ford-model cars and trucks dipped two-tenths of 1 percent; prices of Lincoln-Mercury vehicles, mostly cars, fell seven-tenths of 1 percent.
The price of the Ford Taurus LX dropped $1,000, to $17,995, including destination fees. A typically equipped SE sedan will have a base price of $18,995, down $1,080, and the SE station wagon drops $1,840, to $19,995. Prices of the Taurus's cousin, the Mercury Sable, also dropped between $1,000 and $1,800. "We're trying to put a price on the car that is a recognized value," Mr. Hansen said. "We're hopeful over time we will not have to resort to incentives."
Ford is hoping the lower prices will spur sales, as it did last year. For example, Ford decreased the prices of the Mustang, the two-door Explorer and Escort ZX2 for the 1998 model year, resulting in double-digit sales increases. Prices were decreased for the small Ranger pickup, and sales doubled. For 1999, the Ranger will be offered with a flexible fuel engine -- one that burns ethanol and gasoline -- for no extra charge; flexible-fuel engines typically cost more than gasoline-only engines.
Ford also says it is the first auto manufacturer to eliminate the added charge for emissions equipment required in California, New York and Massachusetts. Ford previously charged $170.
On other cars, the Escort and Contour particularly, Ford added equipment for the same 1998 price. Mr. Hansen said that beyond competitive pressures, Ford's pricing strategy had been to not increase prices. This year's lower prices have been made possible by reducing costs. Ford reported a total of $4.3 billion in cost reductions in 1997 and through the first half of 1998.

HEADLINE: U.S. Expects Ties to Improve Under Colombia's New President

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
The Administration says the inauguration of President Andres Pastrana of Colombia should mean the end of years of ill will between his nation and the United States, especially if he moves quickly on a pledge to stem the flood of Colombian cocaine into the United States.
Mr. Pastrana was sworn in Friday, less than a week after returning from Washington, where he met with President Clinton. 
 The Administration's decision to offer Mr. Pastrana a pre-inauguration meeting at the White House was in stark contrast to its treatment of his predecessor, Ernesto Samper, who was denied a visa to the United States after evidence indicated that a drug cartel had provided $6 million for his 1994 election campaign.
Administration officials said that during his meeting with Mr. Clinton, Mr. Pastrana, 43, a Conservative, had promised that he would try to shut down drug trafficking operations in Colombia, which are the source of most of the cocaine that ends up on American streets, and to end a decades-old guerrilla war.
Colombia, a country of 37 million, has been in the grip of an armed insurgency for 30 years. In many areas leftist guerrillas have allied themselves with drug traffickers, who underwrite their purchase of weapons.
Mr. Pastrana, a former television anchor who understands the value of dramatic images, ventured into the Colombian jungle last month to meet with the leaders of the largest insurgent group. He has promised to begin formal peace talks in the first three months of his administration.
James Dobbins, senior director for inter-American affairs at the National Security Council, said President Clinton had "expressed admiration for the courage Pastrana had shown in his election and in his steps immediately after the election."
Administration officials said they believed that by tackling the insurgency, Mr. Pastrana might be able to curb the narcotics trade.
During his Oval Office meeting, Mr. Dobbins said, Mr. Pastrana said the two problems were inextricably linked, since the drug cultivation and trafficking generally took place in the areas where the insurgency was most active.
Mr. Dobbins said President Clinton had told Mr. Pastrana that "the United States wanted to support an integrated approach to the problems of drug trafficking and bringing peace, ending Colombia's civil conflict." He said Mr. Pastrana had already accepted an invitation to return to Washington in the fall for a state visit.
On Sunday Mr. Pastrana replaced his top military commanders after a series of embarrassing defeats in clashes with the guerrillas.
The Administration made Mr. Pastrana's job easier with its decision earlier this year to lift economic sanctions that had been imposed on Colombia for two years out of dissatisfaction with Mr. Samper's drug policies. The lifting of the sanctions, Mr. Dobbins said, offers "both Governments the opportunity for a new start."
Mr. Pastrana swept into office with the largest margin in his country's history. A former Senator and Mayor of Bogota, the capital, Mr. Pastrana will govern without a majority in Congress.

HEADLINE: Jess J. Present, 77, Legislator and G.O.P. Leader

BYLINE: By WOLFGANG SAXON 

 BODY:
State Senator Jess Joseph Present, a Republican leader from upstate New York who spent more than three decades in the State Legislature, died on Saturday at his home in Bemus Point, N.Y., near his native Jamestown. He was 77.
A heart attack was the apparent cause, the Senate press office reported. 
 Since his election to the Senate from Chautauqua County in southwest New York, he had filled a string of important committee assignments. But his influence fell victim to party infighting in recent years.
He was closely allied with Ralph J. Marino, the majority leader from Oyster Bay, N.Y., who was a rival to his fellow Senator, George E. Pataki, from Peekskill, N.Y. Mr. Marino chose Mr. Present as his deputy majority leader in 1993.
With Mr. Pataki moving into the Governor's office after the 1994 election, Senator Joseph L. Bruno of Rensselaer County engineered Mr. Marino's ouster and succeeded him as majority leader. In January, Mr. Bruno named a new deputy, and Mr. Present retired from that post.
At his death, Mr. Present was chairman of the Senate Commerce, Economic Development and Small Business Committee and a member of the National Legislatures' Committee on Commerce, Labor and Economic Development. His 56th Senate District covers Chautauqua, Allegany, Livingston and Cattaraugus Counties.
Senator Present survived a scare in the 1992 election when it appeared at first blush that he had lost his seat to a Democrat, but the completed count of absentee ballots returned him to Albany once again with just 190 votes to spare. The last time around, in 1996, he sailed past his Democratic challenger with a winning vote of 69 percent to 31.
Mr. Present attended Allegheny College but enlisted in World War II to serve with the Eighth Air Force in England. After the war, he worked in a family jewelry business in Jamestown.
He started his political career in 1960 as a Jamestown City Councilman, serving until 1963. He represented the Jamestown area in the State Assembly from 1965 until he was elected in 1968 to the State Senate, where he concentrated on commerce and education. He was a past chairman of the Chautauqua County Republican Committee.
He is survived by his wife, Elaine Coates Present; two sons, Jeffrey B. and Randall L., both of Bemus Point; two brothers, William E., of Lakewood, N.Y., and Leonard R., of West Bloomfield, Mich; a sister, Anna Rae, also of Bemus Point, and three grandchildren.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Treasury Prices Steady as Strong Demand Is Expected at Auctions

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
Treasury bonds were little changed yesterday, with yields at one-month lows and prices at highs, reflecting expectations that Asian financial turmoil would bolster demand at the Treasury's $37 billion quarterly debt sale this week.
"There's a flight to quality that bodes well for U.S.-based assets," said Roger Hamilton, who helps manage $1.1 billion in bonds at John Hancock mutual funds in Boston. 
 The benchmark 30-year Treasury bond rose 2/32 , or 67.5 cents per $1,000 bond, to a price of 1076/32 , nudging its yield down a basis point to 5.62 percent, the lowest since July 10. The yield on the two-year note rose a basis point, to 5.33 percent.
Thirty-year bond yields fell on July 6 to the lowest level -- 5.57 percent -- since the Government began regular sales of the securities in 1977, as international investors sought refuge in Treasury bonds.
The problems overseas may lead investors to snap up the $37 billion in new longer-term securities that the Government is putting up for auction this week. The Treasury will sell $16 billion of five-year notes today, followed by $11 billion of 10-year notes tomorrow and $10 billion of 30-year bonds on Thursday.
Of the new securities, about $27.8 billion of debt is being refinanced and $9.2 billion in cash is being raised by the Treasury.

HEADLINE: For Sale: 5% of Maine, Plenty of Trees

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: GREENVILLE, Me.

 BODY:
Hundreds of millions of dollars' worth of forest a swath that is about 5 percent of the land in Maine -- is for sale in the northern part of the state, prompting a debate over the future of the heavily logged yet alluring woods.
Conservation groups have called for selling the land to the public to restore it to its original wilderness. Many residents here are more comfortable with the status quo of much of the century: industrial logging of the land by timber companies that give the public free access for hunting, fishing, boating, snowmobiling and other sport. But people in both camps worry that some land -- only a six-hour drive from Boston and featuring miles of undeveloped lake shores -- will be developed, profitably but irretrievably, for more tourism, recreation and country houses. 
 As paper companies liquidate their land holdings in the Northeast to raise money for their mills, millions of timbered acres from northern Maine to the Adirondacks of New York are either for sale or being considered for sale, making their availability one of the latest conservation issues in the region.
"Across the Northern Forest region, three and a half million acres of incredibly valuable land are for sale by willing sellers," said Andrea Colnes, executive director of the Northern Forest Alliance, a coalition of environmental groups. "It is historic, and it will have a defining impact on the region."
But the issue is most pressing in Maine, where practically all open land is owned by industrial forestry companies. In an unexpected move last June, Sappi Ltd., a South African paper company, announced that it would sell 911,000 acres. And another company, Bowater Inc., has said it will consider selling all of its Maine holdings, more than two million acres, after completing a pending $2.5 billion acquisition of Avenor Inc., a Canadian forest products company. In all, as much as 15 percent of the state may be for sale.
Sappi, which gained control of the land four years ago when it acquired the S. D. Warren Company's forestry operations from the Scott Paper Company, is selling heavily harvested softwood tracts in wild mountains, moose country glittering with countless lakes, streams and bogs.
As timberland it is worth at least $200 an acre, but some waterfront sections are prime real estate, and the ecological worth is inestimable.
Quietly, state conservation groups and private bidders are trying to put together deals for Sappi land, although details are not known. Their ideas include buying conservation easements or critical tracts and more far-reaching plans.
And while the tracts are so big that other paper companies are the likeliest bidders -- the outcome Sappi says it prefers -- the new owners might be tempted to carve out prime parcels for real estate developers, a prospect that has conservationists and many local people alarmed.
"East of the Mississippi, there isn't another area of wilderness-like terrain of this magnitude left anywhere," said Jim Glavine, who owns Beaver Cove Camps on Moosehead Lake, at 75,000 acres the largest lake in New England. "If you look across the shoreline, you don't see anything. Essentially, there is nothing. There are no lights to see in the evening.
"This is an opportunity for conservation-minded folks and residents and people who live and work in the area and make a living from everything from forestry to tourism to see to it that what we see when we look out across this lake doesn't change."
The most ambitious plan, if not the likeliest, would convert most of Sappi and Bowater's lands, along with other tracts, into a huge national park including parts of the Allegash Wilderness Waterway, surrounding Baxter State Park and Moosehead Lake and the 100-Mile Wilderness stretch of the Appalachian Trail.
Jym St. Pierre, the Maine director for Restore the North Woods, a conservation group that advocates creating a 3.2-million-acre national park and preserve, said, "From Mount Katahdin to Moosehead Lake, the region has the collection of natural, cultural and historic resources that qualify it for a park, and it has large ownerships with land for sale and is virtually uninhabited."
But Gov. Angus King called plans for a national park misguided. "I am dead set against the idea," he said in an interview. Like many other political leaders in Maine, he views the timber industry as too important to supplant.
Mr. King said that though it was not feasible for the state to acquire the whole tract, it hoped to make a bid for part of the land for conservation soon.
Many local residents join the Governor in not embracing the creation of a national park. People are used to the gravel scrapes and clear-cut scabs that tally forestry's contribution to the state's economy and its effects on the state's environment.
"If someone buys the land and won't let us cut on it, we are all going to be out of a job," said Charles Libby Sr., a trucker who was about to haul a semi-trailer of chips to a pulp mill. "Right now, the way I feel, we have enough tourists up here. We lock the gate down on the Interstate, it wouldn't bother me a bit. Keep them out. We've got plenty of parks."
The biggest concern of many people who live in and near the woods is that they would lose access to the land if the Government took it over.
Even though forest product companies control almost all of the woods, they let anyone fish or hunt, hike or ski, or cross their property in canoes or snowmobiles.
"Most of the tourists who come up here are ecotourists," said Toni Blake, executive director of the Moosehead Chamber of Commerce, based in Greenville at the foot of the antler-shaped lake. "They want to do the hiking and the biking and to get out in the woods. Snowmobiling is a big industry, and I think that would all change. A national park is something that sets restrictions."
Fred Candeloro, who owns a sporting camp in Kokadjo, said: "Right now with Sappi, we have the best land-use deal in the world."
The park's advocates are proposing that part of it be held as a preserve open to uses like hunting that are not allowed in parks.
"The conundrum of the whole thing," said Garrett Conover, a canoeing outfitter and guide, "is the people of Maine are desperately afraid of Federal controls because of lack of access."
He supports public acquisition of the land, which despite the relentless logging he considers the best canoeing region this side of Minnesota.
"Nobody in history ever made the mistake of putting aside too much wilderness," Mr. Conover said.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1837 words

HEADLINE: The Courtship Of Black Consumers;
Corporate America Absorbs a Growing Number of Minority-Owned Businesses

BYLINE: By DANA CANEDY 

 BODY:
Long before other girls her age were torturing their tresses with hot combs and chemical straighteners, Terri Gardner and her dog, a mutt named Cinnamon, became testers for the shampoos and pomades her father mixed in the basement of their brick bungalow on Chicago's South Side.
One day, Edward Gardner would slather Cinnamon with creams he concocted to condition coarse, curly hair. The next, he would coat his 8-year-old daughter's brown locks with a thick glaze he envisioned other black women and girls using to style their bobs and finger waves. 
 On occasion, the experiments would go horribly wrong, including one that left the girl's hair and hands tinted mauve for weeks. In time, though, Mr. Gardner perfected his techniques, and the business he created with his wife, Bettiann, grew into Soft Sheen Products Inc., one of the largest ethnic hair-products companies in the country, with sales last year of $80 million.
Last month, though, Ms. Gardner, now 42 and Soft Sheen's president and chief executive, and the rest of the Gardner family took a hard look at market trends and decided to sell their company to L'Oreal S.A. of France, the world's largest cosmetics company. The Gardners figured that with corporate giants chasing the increasingly lucrative African-American market, their growth prospects were dim without access to more capital.
L'Oreal, for its part, saw Soft Sheen as a gateway to consumers whose needs and neighborhoods it had overlooked.
As it turns out, the same calculations that lay behind the L'Oreal acquisition are powering lots of other deals around the United States. Black-owned companies in areas like beauty products, funeral services and insurance, which first thrived in a segregationist era, are deciding that it makes more sense to join big corporations than fight them. And though blacks are steadily creating businesses in a wider range of fields than ever before, some see the recent acquisitions as an unfortunate end of control by the pioneers of black entrepreneurship in this country.
At the same time, corporations buying the companies are doing so because they are waking up to an explosion of black economic strength. A study released last month by the University of Georgia's Selig Center for Economic Growth calculated that black purchasing power would reach $533 billion in 1999, up 73 percent from $308 billion in 1990, compared with a 57 percent increase projected for all Americans. Such income growth "should create tremendous opportunities for businesses that pay attention to the needs and preferences of African-American consumers," said Dr. Jeffrey M. Humphreys, a University of Georgia economist.
As a result, companies born in storefronts and basements in the 1950's and 60's that grew into thriving enterprises in the 70's and 80's have become guests at corporate America's latest merger party. It is a little-noticed trend that stands in contrast to the deal-making boom of a decade ago, when black-owned companies stayed largely on the sidelines.
To be sure, there have been high-profile sales of black-owned companies in the past, such as the acquisition of Motown Records by a consortium headed by MCA Records in 1988. But though no one has exact figures, marketing specialists say the pace has picked up in recent years. One of the biggest transactions was IVX Bioscience Inc.'s purchase of the Johnson Products Company, which makes ethnic cosmetics and hair care products, in 1993 for $67 million in stock. (IVX sold the unit last month to Carson Inc. for $85 million.)
Also in 1993, the Shorebank Corporation of Chicago bought Indecorp Inc., the second-largest black-owned banking concern in that city.
These are among the deals concluded since then:
*The acquisition in 1996 of U S Radio, then the largest black-owned radio group in the country, with 25 stations, by Clear Channel Communications.
*The purchase by Stewart Enterprises, a multinational conglomerate of more than 500 funeral homes and 135 cemeteries, of the Hillcrest funeral parlor in Albuquerque, N.M., in 1996 from its black and Hispanic owners for $1 million.
*The 1997 merger of Garrett & Davenport in Raleigh, N.C., the state's oldest minority-owned certified public-accounting firm, with Cherry Bekaert & Holland of Richmond, the largest accounting firm in the Southeast.
*The sale last March by the Universal Life Insurance Company, a venerable concern started 75 years ago, of the bulk of its business to the American Capital Life Insurance Company for $13 million.
The acquisition in May of McNeely & Associates in Milwaukee, one of Wisconsin's largest African-American law firms, by the Milwaukee firm of Domnitz Mawicke Goisman & Rosenberg.
*L'Oreal's agreement last month to buy Soft Sheen for an undisclosed price that one analyst estimated at well above $160 million.
"You are starting to see a lot of larger black-owned companies becoming attractive targets for other large companies that want to reach in and expand their market," said Alfred A. Edmond Jr., executive editor of Black Enterprise magazine.
Though the owners of the acquired companies can expect a handsome payoff, not everyone views the changing of the guard as cause for celebration. "It is the alligator eating up the goldfish," said the Rev. Jesse L. Jackson, whose Rainbow/PUSH coalition has been calling for more career opportunities and access to investment capital for members of minorities so they can more often be the acquirer in these deals.
Some large corporations, of course, have long been developing products and services aimed at black consumers. But now, more corporations are looking for a quicker route to African-Americans' pocketbooks by snapping up businesses whose legacies and brands, like Ebony magazine and Soft Sheen's Optimum hair relaxer, are as well known in ethnic households as Tide and Colgate are.
"It's all about the numbers," said Lafayette Jones, chief executive of Segmented Marketing Services Inc. in Winston-Salem, N.C., an ethnic-marketing consultant. "The American population is increasingly becoming ethnic, and by ethnic I mean African-American, Latino and Asian. We are talking about $750 billion in collective spending power."
And it's not just Americans that big multinationals are aiming at. Many believe that buying brands that have become cultural icons that represent ethnic Americana holds huge appeal in Africa and other developing countries. L'Oreal, for example, is adding to its arsenal such popular products as Soft Sheen Hair and Scalp conditioner, which softened Afros in the 1960's, and Care Free Curl activator, which was used to create the trendy mop of glossy ringlets in the 1980's known as "the curl."
Soft Sheen products are key to the company's strategy to expand into countries with a need for ethnic hair and cosmetics products. "Africa is the new major area of development for us," said Guy Peyrelongue, president and chief executive officer of L'Oreal's American subsidiary, Cosmair Inc.
The cosmetics giant's international ambitions helped persuade the Gardners to let go of their company. "We knew we had to compete with bigger players with deeper pockets," said Ms. Gardner, who will continue to run Soft Sheen for L'Oreal and will join the board of Cosmair.
As for Edward Gardner, he was once so singularly focused on the business brewing in his basement that his two sons and two daughters often waited for dinner until Bettiann Gardner retrieved her pots and pans and washed off the chemicals. Now, at 73, he takes a remarkably unsentimental view about relinquishing his venture. "Selling the company to me is just a phase, just like starting the company," he said.
Despite Mr. Jackson's lament that old-time black companies are being picked off by corporate America, there is plenty of evidence that black entrepreneurs have broken into industries that were largely closed to them in the days when Mr. Jackson was marching alongside the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. Blacks are pursuing their entrepreneurial ambitions in industries ranging from computer software to musical production to cable-television programming.
Moreover, some black business pioneers are resisting pressures to sell. One is John H. Johnson, founder and chairman of the Johnson Publishing Company, which puts out Ebony and Jet magazines.
"The big companies have been asleep and are awake now and realize there are great opportunities out there," said Mr. Johnson, who founded Johnson Publishing in 1942 when he was 24 and who added a cosmetics business to his empire in 1973 to cater to women with skin tones that range from coffee with and without cream. "They are making offers that are hard to refuse."
Mr. Johnson said he saw nothing wrong with others selling their businesses, but do not look for his family name to be peeled off the office door. He said he routinely received calls from investment bankers whose clients wanted to buy his business -- and has instructed his secretary not to put them through. "I have a granddaughter who is 9 years old, and she is already saying she is going to take over," he said.
Harold Shaw Jr., the great-grandson of the founder of Universal Life Insurance, grew up with similar aspirations but is now reeling from poor succession planning and a failure to keep pace with changes in technology.
Mr. Shaw, 35, who heads the company's underwriting division, said the financial outlook had become so bleak that in March the company was forced to sell $53 million in life insurance premium obligations to American Capital Life for $13 million. The company now believes the best option might be to unload the rest.
"It's a challenge for me personally and professionally to have to try to make something happen out of this," Mr. Shaw said, his voice trailing off. "But it will come down to prudent and real business decisions, not emotion," he added more forcefully.
Like Universal Life, Hillcrest, the funeral home in Albuquerque, faced the same fate when much bigger corporate rivals intruded on its turf. At first, the owners pinned their hopes on the loyalty of the black and Hispanic communities that they served. But those hopes faded fast after the big rivals began hiring black employees and slashing prices.
"They would open a cut-rate facility and sell services for $2,000 complete, and at the other end of town sell them for $6,000 -- and the same company owned both places," said Eddie White, a Hillcrest partner. When Hillcrest fell behind on its taxes, he said, he and his partner sold out.
Stewart Enterprises, Hillcrest's current owner, says it does not try to drive local operators out of business when it enters a market.
Though Mr. Jackson acknowledges that market forces are altering the complexion of black business, he worries that something precious will be lost.
"In the end, we'll have less pride, we'll have less control," Mr. Jackson said, "and a level of infrastructure that took years to build will go in a minute or two."

HEADLINE: Charlestown Journal;
On the Whole, Caribbean Isle Is Not Part of a Sum

BYLINE: By LARRY ROHTER 

DATELINE: CHARLESTOWN, Nevis, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Barely two miles of water separate the pair of islands that make up the tiny Caribbean nation of St. Kitts and Nevis. But if the 10,000 or so people who live on the 36-square-mile speck of land called Nevis voted as predicted today in a referendum on secession, the smallest country in the Western Hemipshere will soon be severed in two.
The United States and leaders of other Caribbean nations may worry that Nevis is too small to stand on its own. But local leaders say they cannot wait for Nevis to leave behind its status as junior partner to St. Kitts, to take control of its destiny and to become an independent state with its own voice at the United Nations. 
 "The people in St. Kitts don't know what the problems are over here," said Vance Amory, the premier of Nevis, who has led the drive for secession. "Nevis is something they have forgotten about, and we cannot continue to operate on the basis of tokenism. The days have passed when we can be told to be quiet."
On one level the issue on the ballot in this charming, cloud-capped island 250 miles southeast of Puerto Rico could not be simpler or more direct. "Do you approve of the Nevis secession bill and Nevis becoming an independent state separate from St. Kitts?" Nevis residents were asked. Voters in St. Kitts, which has about 36,000 people, were not eligible to take part.
For the proposal to be approved, two-thirds of the ballots cast must be in the affirmative. An informal poll conducted by The St. Kitts-Nevis Observer, a weekly, found that more than 70 percent of potential voters favored secession. Moreover, in a nonbinding ballot in the 1970's, 80 percent favored independence.
Prime Minister Denzil Douglas has said he will honor the result of the vote, whatever it is. "My Government stands ready to assist with whatever choice you make," he said in Parliament last week, so that St. Kitts and Nevis (pronounced NEE-vis) "can continue to live in harmony and prosperity."
But Mr. Douglas has also made clear his regret that "the secessionsit genie is out of the bottle" and predicted "disastrous consequences" if the nation split apart. To take such a step, he argued, is an act of provincialism defying the logic that has led to the creation of the European Union and a global economy.
"The people of St. Kitts and Nevis have more in common than the people of Germany and France," he argued. "If it were not for the water that separates us, there would be no justification for secession."
To outsiders, the differences between Kittitians (kit-TISH-uns) and Nevisians (neh-VISH-ans), as residents of the two islands call themselves, are indeed virtually imperceptible. But Nevisians have always complained about being forced into union with St. Kitts, a step that Britain took during colonial rule more than 100 years ago for administrative convenience. They have clung to the notion of a separate identity.
"It's only two miles of water," said Bernard Brooks, 43, who works as a taxi driver in the United States Virgin Islands but came home to vote for secession and take part in summer carnival. "But if you travel, you'll find there's a big difference between the people. Nevis people are more gentle, more polite."
St. Kitts and Nevis became independent of Britain in 1983. Its Constitution established the capital in Basseterre, on St. Kitts, and created a Parliament that reserved eight seats for St. Kitts and three for Nevis. The charter also included a provision allowing Nevis to secede, and last year, after much debate, the Nevis Island Assembly unanimously approved the vote on the issue.
Since independence from Britain, both islands have depended heavily on tourism and their respective financial sectors. But even on those points there are disagreements. People in Nevis complain that St. Kitts is trying to strangle the Nevis economy with offshore legislation and that too much of the revenue generated by Nevis from upscale tourism remains on the other island.
Nevis is for "high net-worth individuals," attracting Hollywood celebrities and British royalty, explained Mark Brantley, an Oxford-educated Nevis lawyer who is a leader of the independence drive. By contrast, he maintained, St. Kitts attracts "low-scale package tours, the secretary who saves up all year for a week in the sun," but it has the more modern airport.
The vote is being watched with some anxiety by members of the Caribbean Community, or Caricom, a regional trade and political grouping of 16 small and predominantly English-speaking nations. Several are also multi-island states whose smaller components have been known to chafe at their status, among them Trinidad and Tobago, Antigua and Barbuda, and St. Vincent and the Grenadines. There are fears that secession fever could spread.
As Edwin Carrington, secretary general of the group, said last week, "It is a source of great concern to us if there is to be a fragmentation of St. Kitts and Nevis and a creation of yet another micro-ministate in our region when all the implications and dangers that it entails come at a time when we are to integrate and not disintegrate." Mr. Carrington called the vote the region's most serious challenge since the American invasion of Grenada in 1983.
The United States, evidently alarmed that a ministate might be vulnerable to the pressures or blandishments of drug cartels, has echoed those worries. "Maintaining the federation would be more compatible with the trend toward greater regional integration, with all its considerable benefits and advantages," the State Department spokesman, James P. Rubin, said recently.
But Mr. Amory, the premier, rejected any suggestion that Nevis would be worse off on its own. "Size is not an indication of viability," he said in an interview. "There are some large countries in Africa that are not viable states," he asserted, pointing out that several small island states, among them Singapore, Nauru and Tonga, are flourishing.
Because of "technology and the way institutions are established," he added, "that idea of a criticial mass can no longer be used as a criterion."
Those who favor remaining in a federation with St. Kitts stress practical issues, none of which have been negotiated in advance of the vote. Fishermen wonder whether they will be barred from St. Kitts waters; store owners fear that tariffs may be imposed on goods moving from one island to the other, and others ask where the money for public services will come from.
"I don't think we're in a sufficient state of preparedness," said Trevor Chapman, owner of a grocery store here. "There hasn't been enough education, and there are still too many unanswered questions, the primary of which is what will be the source of our income? It's not going to be no bed of roses."
