SECTION: Section A; Page 1; Column 1; Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1874 words

HEADLINE: Taxes Help Foot the Payrolls As States Vie for Employers

BYLINE: By LOUIS UCHITELLE 

 BODY:
Since the 1950's, state governments have lured corporations with expensive incentives such as free factories, canceled property taxes, low-interest loans, free access roads and special tax credits. Now in the 1990's, the competition among states and even Mexico to attract companies has spawned a new incentive, one strikingly uncharacteristic for a free market economy: wage rebates.
Wage rebates allow companies to lower their labor costs through taxpayer-financed subsidies. For each job created by a relocated or existing company, a state reimburses the company for part of the wages paid. These subsidies, offered by only 8 states in 1989, are now offered by 21 states, mostly in the South and Midwest, according to the Council of State Governments, a research group financed by the states. 
 Consider Whirlpool, which opened a stove factory in Tulsa, Okla., two years ago and hired more than 1,100 workers. For 10 years, it will get back 4.5 cents of every dollar paid in wages to those workers.
In all, nearly one million jobs appear to be covered by the rebates, judging from the few states that report new jobs. In some states, including Oklahoma and Ohio, the wage subsidy has become the single most expensive corporate lure. It is costing Ohio taxpayers more than $25 million a year. In other states, including New Jersey, North Carolina and Maine, it is the fastest-growing corporate incentive.
When wage rebates began to spread in the mid-1990's, the unemployment rate was higher than it is today, and states were struggling to generate new jobs. Now, a robust economy is generating millions of new jobs, pushing the unemployment rate to its lowest level in decades. That is raising questions about the value of taxpayer-financed wage rebates, which increasingly reward companies for creating jobs they would have created anyway.
"The real issue is whether, in a tight labor market, these rebates have turned into a windfall for the companies," said Van Doorn Ooms, research director of the Committee for Economic Development, a research group supported by business. "In a high-unemployment situation, wage rebates are useful as a stimulus for creating jobs. In a tight labor market, they are more likely to simply pass on some of the cost of labor to the taxpayer from the employer."
Mitchell Gold shares that view, although he does not put it that bluntly. The Mitchell Gold Company, which he owns, makes upholstered furniture in Taylorsville, N.C. -- furniture sold through Pottery Barn and Crate and Barrel stores. With business thriving, Mr. Gold decided to expand a year ago. He looked into the incentives available from North Carolina and found that his company qualified for a wage rebate.
So for the 80 workers being added to the company's 250-member work force, Mitchell Gold will get back a portion of the state income taxes withheld from each employee's check for four years. The rebate is equal to roughly 2 percent of the typical worker's annual pay.
"Frankly I would have stayed in North Carolina and expanded without the wage rebate," Mr. Gold said, "but in a competitive, labor-intensive business, every little bit helps."
The subsidies are almost always restricted to manufacturers and high-end service companies that bring "good jobs"; that is, jobs paying more than $7.50 an hour. The Oklahoma rebate law, for example, applies only to jobs that pay at least $9 an hour and carry health insurance benefits. Temporary workers are ruled out. So are people who move to the state for the new jobs.
Such rules let the states alter the marketplace in a form of industrial policy much criticized by those who advocate a reduced role for government. "We are becoming more regulated at the state level even as we become less so at the Federal level," said John Bishop, a Cornell University labor economist.
As Joseph Kramer, vice president for economic development of the Greater Cincinnati Chamber of Commerce, sees it: "Wage rebates have become a very important modern-era incentive for companies. And they are pay as you go, much more than other incentives. A company does not get the rebate until after the new worker is actually on the payroll."
Mimicry plays a big role in the spread of wage subsidies. The Maryland Legislature, for example, enacted a subsidy in 1996 and expanded it last year to cover more industries because neighboring Virginia had such a subsidy. Similarly, the Ohio Legislature quickly followed Kentucky's lead in 1992, prodded by the Greater Cincinnati Chamber, which feared that companies would choose to build in Cincinnati's suburbs on the Kentucky side of the Ohio River.
Ohio will soon have 100,000 jobs covered by wage rebates, state officials say. And Kentucky is moving up quickly, having recently agreed to rebate a portion of the wages for 6,000 jobs that United Parcel Service is creating at a distribution hub being built in Louisville. U.P.S. officials have pointed to the wage credits, totaling $3.5 million a year for 10 years, as a key reason for choosing Kentucky for the new hub. And such thinking pops up frequently.
"Not to have a wage-reimbursement program today is a terrible thing," said Jerry Wade, a research economist at the Department of Business and Economic Development in Maryland. "When Virginia adopted a wage subsidy next door, we found ourselves telling companies that we would have one, too. The perception was that Virginia, because of its subsidy, had a better overall business climate than we did."
Mexico also looms in the equation. Oklahoma's subsidy, lowering the cost of labor, led Whirlpool to put its stove factory in Tulsa rather than in another state or in northern Mexico, where the company already has factories.
"We had four states and Mexico under consideration, and Oklahoma gave us the Quality Jobs Act," as the wage-rebate legislation is known, said Thomas Vining, a Whirlpool vice president. "That incentive, along with another incentive, were the tie-breakers." The second incentive was a diversion of the county sales tax revenue for a year to pay for construction of the Whirlpool factory.
The wage reimbursements take several forms. Some states, like Ohio, offer a credit against corporate income taxes, and if the corporate tax is not sufficient, they send out checks to cover the difference. Other states cap the reimbursement. The state income tax provides the other most common way of handling the rebates. In this version, states return to the company a portion of the taxes withheld from qualified employees at the end of each year.
Whatever the mechanism, officials in states with the rebates increasingly argue that they are the most efficient incentive in creating jobs. Unlike the other incentives -- investment tax credits, for example, or state-financed factory construction -- no taxpayer money goes for wage rebates until the jobs exist. Even then, the jobs must last for a certain number of years or the companies must give back the rebates.
In many states, a company must create 25 jobs a year to qualify for a rebate. Maryland has set the minimum at 60, pointedly undercutting the 100-job requirement in Virginia.
"We view wage reimbursement as revenue neutral," said Lisa Cruz, spokeswoman for the Department of Commerce and Economic Development in New Jersey, the only state in the New York metropolitan area that has adopted the rebates. In the two years since New Jersey began to provide rebates, some 30,000 new jobs have qualified for the credit, which goes as high as $3,800 a year for a single $75,000-a-year employee. "These workers," Ms. Cruz said, "generate sales taxes and corporate income taxes that would not otherwise have existed."
Such big corporations as Raytheon, Hewlett-Packard and Bristol-Myers Squibb, having put new operations in New Jersey over the last two years, are now receiving wage rebates for more than 1,700 of their employees, all of them earning the minimum of $7.73 an hour required by New Jersey law, or 150 percent of the Federal minimum wage.
Competition with nearby Maryland played a role in Gov. Christine Todd Whitman's decision to ask the Legislature for a wage rebate program. "Our strategy has been to tie state-funded incentives directly to the creation of good jobs," said Gil Medina, Secretary of the Department of Commerce and Economic Development in New Jersey.
Wage subsidies have existed for years in a different form, as part of a social welfare program. In these programs, companies receive wage rebates to create jobs in inner cities and other areas of high unemployment or hire people on welfare, ex-felons and others who have trouble finding work. More than 40 states offer such wage rebates, usually in the form of a tax credit, as does the Federal Government. The programs aim to help the disadvantaged, who would otherwise not have jobs, even in tight labor markets.
California, New York and Connecticut have such programs, arguing in effect that taxpayer-financed wage subsidies should be aimed at encouraging employment of the needy and not employment of people who are already sufficiently skilled to be attractive to corporations. The legislatures of these three states have never enacted wage rebates for high-skilled, high-wage jobs.
"We have not had to take that step," said Chris Holben, an under secretary of trade and commerce in California. "Yes, we are constantly told by companies considering California that other states will give them a wage rebate, and why not us. We believe the package of incentives that we do offer is sufficient. And we have a strategic advantage: We serve the Pacific Rim and the Mexican market."
At the national level, Congress enacted a broad wage rebate program in 1976, like those now proliferating among the states. The program was intended to stimulate job creation in the wake of the mid-1970's recession. To qualify, a company had to increase its employment by 2 percent in a single year. If it did, it received a corporate income tax credit equal to half of the first $4,200 of each new worker's wages.
The program did generate jobs, according to a study done by Mr. Bishop of Cornell. But it was phased out after two years as too expensive, having cost $4.5 billion in 1978 alone.
The wage rebates and all the other incentives used by states to entice companies face a similar criticism today. "We are funneling tens of billions of dollars into shifting jobs from one state to another," said Charles Horn, a Republican State Senator in Ohio. "That money should be going to schools and roads and other public outlays that would make states truly more competitive."
The House of Representatives has before it a bill, introduced by David Minge, Democrat of Minnesota, that would force corporations to declare as income all the state incentive payments they receive each year. These would then be taxed at the Federal level. Arthur Rolnick, research director at the Federal Reserve Bank of Minneapolis, supports the measure, and even goes a step further. He wants state incentive payments outlawed as illegal obstacles to interstate commerce.
"Congress has the authority," he said, "under the commerce clause of the Constitution to end this war between the states."

HEADLINE: THE MEDIA BUSINESS;
A Man of OutsizedActs and Spending

BYLINE: By BRUCE WEBER 

 BODY:
Garth H. Drabinsky, the Canadian showman whose flamboyant rise to prominence on Broadway has apparently come to a halt, was a man who inspired both admiration and resentment from his colleagues in the staid business of live theater.
Mr. Drabinsky, ousted yesterday as chief creative director of Livent Inc., the theater company he helped found, was known for outspending rival producers for actors' salaries, stage sets and advertising. As a result, he was long the subject of suspicion among those who could not figure out how he made the numbers add up. 
 At the same time, many of his loudest critics gave him credit for his accomplishments: the lush and lovely revival of "Show Boat," which ran for two years at the Gershwin Theater and recouped its cost, though at $10 million it was very likely the most expensive musical revival of all time; the construction, on time and on budget, of the Ford Center for the Performing Arts on West 42d Street, a nearly universally praised building that, with musical theater houses in short supply, Broadway and New York City needed, and the original musical "Ragtime," which won four Tony Awards and is virtually selling out at the Ford Center eight times a week.
"I admired his passion and commitment to his goal, which was the production of quality theater that would appeal to and reach worldwide audiences," said John F. Breglio, an entertainment lawyer who has had wide dealings with Mr. Drabinsky. "But as an outside observer, I was confounded by certain business decisions, namely the production and advertising costs, which seemed to contradict good economic sense."
Mr. Drabinsky, 48, is known as a man with expensive tastes, considerable self-regard and no lack of confidence. The profile of a man who would spend lavishly, perhaps recklessly, to support and sell his artistic vision is in sync with Mr. Drabinsky's reputation for arrogance and hubris. And he has been cut down before.
In 1979, he founded Cineplex Odeon, the movie theater concern, building it over a decade from an 18-screen complex in Toronto to an 1,800-screen chain throughout the United States and Canada. But in his expansion plans, which included film production and distribution and forays into live theater, he ran afoul of MCA, the partner he had taken on in 1986 to avert bankruptcy. MCA dismissed him in 1989.
As severance, he took with him the company's live entertainment division, consisting of two assets: the newly renovated Pantages Theater in Toronto, and the right to present in it the Andrew Lloyd Webber musical "The Phantom of the Opera." That was the foundation of Livent.
Now, having once again taken on partners to avert financial disaster, history has repeated itself, as he has again been dismissed from the company he created.
Since Livent was revamped in April, Mr. Drabinsky's position has been widely speculated to be precarious, but yesterday's announcement was nonetheless surprising.
"I'm surprised and I'm sad, because our experience with Livent under Garth's direction has been excellent," said Cora Cahan, president of the New 42d Street, a nonprofit development agency that is effectively Livent's landlord for the Ford Center and that signed an agreement with Livent last week to take over the Times Square Theater, the last empty theater on 42d Street. (Livent has proposed to create within the current building a 500-seat house for plays and small musicals, a restaurant and offices.)
"We have other men who own theaters," Ms. Cahan said. "We don't have too many with such vivid dreams. It's sad what's happened to him."

HEADLINE: State Dept. Halts a Pioneering Boeing-Russian Space Venture

BYLINE: By WILLIAM J. BROAD 

 BODY:
Worried that sensitive aerospace data were being transferred overseas, the State Department has suspended all work between the Boeing Company and its Russian and Ukrainian partners in a pioneering venture meant to fire rockets into space from a floating platform at sea.
A State Department official said the department was working with the Defense Department and was passing along the results to the Customs and Justice Departments, which are looking into whether Boeing's transfers broke any American laws. 
 Neither Boeing nor the Government would spell out the nature of the offense that prompted the suspension, and it was unclear whether the trouble was more procedural than substantial.
The Boeing-led venture, Sea Launch, seeks to adapt Ukrainian and Russian rocket technologies to tap an emerging market for the lofting of hundreds of communication satellites into orbit.
Boeing characterizes the work as turning swords into plowshares. Its Ukrainian partner, the Yuzhnoye design bureau and Yuzhmash production plant, once made the Soviet Union's deadliest missile, the SS-18.
A recent investigation in Washington over whether American aerospace companies aided Chinese rocket makers has brought the Boeing venture and similar endeavors under close scrutiny.
The suspension took place on July 27 and forced up to 40 Russian and Ukrainian engineers to leave the venture's home base in Long Beach, Calif., Timothy L. Dolan, a Boeing spokesman, said yesterday. Mr. Dolan had no estimate of how long the suspension might last or whether it would delay the sea rocket's inaugural launching.
The rocket's rise with a communication satellite from a floating platform in the Pacific would be a space-age first.
"We're putting all our efforts into working with State to get these matters resolved," he said. "We want the suspension to be as brief as possible."
But a Government official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity, said: "This is a big project. We would not suspend it unless there were serious concerns."
Mr. Dolan said Sea Launch was responsible for about 10,000 jobs in the Ukraine and Russia.
"It's very important from that standpoint," he said. "It's very good for economic stability in that region. And it's a program for which there was no existing template. Few of us have walked this way before."
The suspension was done without public announcement and was first reported on Saturday in The Washington Post.
The State Departmentsuspended Boeing's technical assistance agreement, a Federal official said yesterday. This plan, agreed to by Boeing and the Government in April 1995, spelled out the rules by which the company would work with foreigners while protecting sensitive data.
A new plan is being worked out, Boeing and Federal officials said .
Space experts said the incident appeared to be part of a pattern of tightening in matters of national security, prompted mainly by the Chinese disclosures.
"Over the past few years, the climate has been to try to make these joint ventures work, with only secondary emphasis on concerns about technology transfer," said John M. Logsdon, director of the Space Policy Institute at George Washington University. "Now the pendulum is swinging back to more of a balance between economic and security interests."
The mystery in this case is that Russians and Ukrainians are highly regarded as rocket makers, their work at times considered superior to that of the United States, especially their efficient engines. In contrast, Chinese rocketry is considered inferior.
Charles P. Vick, a rocket expert at the Federation of American Scientists, a private group in Washington, said the trouble might have arisen because of integration problems in Sea Launch's rocket, the Zenit.
Mr. Vick said the Ukrainian rocket had flown out of Russia in a version with two stages but never with three, which is how Sea Launch wants it to fly for greater lifting power. Boeing's mistake, he said, may have been in supplying information to help tie an additional stage to the existing Zenit, a process that can be technically daunting. Boeing is an expert integrator.
"The security for these kinds of things has increased dramatically," Mr. Vick said. "The question is how far this goes before we start hurting ourselves" with broken promises and missed opportunities.
The team's Zenit rocket was originally scheduled for its first launching in October, Mr. Dolan said, but that date was recently pushed back to early 1999 by the satellite customer in a delay unrelated to the current investigation.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BRIEFS;
Earnings Rise59% At British Airways

BYLINE: Bridge News 

 BODY:
British Airways P.L.C., Europe's largest airline, said yesterday that its pretax profit for the three months that ended on June 30 rose 59 percent, excluding a one-time gain a year earlier. The airline earned a pretax profit of 145 million ($236 million), up from 91 million a year earlier after excluding a one-time profit of 129 million recorded from the sale of a stake in U S Airways Group Inc.
The carrier said, however, that it had lower passenger loads compared with a year earlier because of a "less strong economic situation in the U.K. and the Far East." The American depository receipts of British Airways fell yesterday, dropping $4.8125 each, to $91.4375, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: As Vacation Begins for Congress, Problems Follow the G.O.P. Home

BYLINE: By ALISON MITCHELL 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 10

 BODY:
Republicans in Congress left last week for their summer vacation deeply divided, fighting themselves as hard as they fought Democrats and unable to fill the policy vacuum left by the hobbled Clinton Presidency.
With only one month left in the Congressional session before mid-term elections that will decide control of the House and Senate, Republicans in both chambers have been unable to agree on a budget. They are squabbling over tax cuts. They have yet to send the White House one of the 13 spending bills needed to keep the Government running when the new fiscal year begins in October. 
 House Republicans now say they may not move forward with their own scaled-back antismoking bill, which they promised when the Senate legislation to regulate tobacco died.
"Trying to craft a bill that will garner a majority has been elusive," said Representative John A. Boehner of Ohio, the chairman of the House Republican Conference.
Across the board, the divisions among social conservatives, moderates and the party's business wing have resulted in prominent broken promises and stalled spending bills.
Even tax cuts no longer seem to be the unifying force that they once were for Republicans.
Speaker Newt Gingrich sent his rank and file home with instructions to gin up a public outcry in August in favor of a House Republican plan to devote $700 billion of a projected $1.5 trillion Federal surplus over the next decade to tax cuts and dedicate the remaining surplus to Social Security.
But the tactic seemed as much about putting pressure on Senate Republicans who balk at the proposal as it was about staking out ground against the Democrats for the midterm election.
"When the American people learn about the size of the surplus," Mr. Gingrich said on Friday, "when the American people learn about the power of economic growth to save Social Security, when the American people learn about what we're proposing to do, I am confident that by September you will see virtually all of the senators on the Republican side in favor."
Senate leaders adamantly oppose tax cuts of such magnitude this year, and since the first days of the 1995 Republican revolution, the Republican-led Senate has usually been wary of the sweeping changes sought by the Republican-led House. Mr. Gingrich has conceded to other House members that, partly because of this stance, the House may end up getting only about $70 billion in tax cuts this year.
In some ways, the problems facing the Republicans are endemic to Congressional parties without a President to articulate an overarching message. Making matters worse for the Republicans is Mr. Clinton's skill at stealing their rhetoric, leaving them flummoxed with little to oppose. And not only do the Republicans lack one dominant figure, their Congressional leadership is hampered by one of the smallest House majorities this century.
Mr. Boehner, the fourth-ranking Republican in the House leadership, justifies the gap in policy making as the inevitable consequence of a natural pause between the set of domestic concerns that ended last summer with the balanced budget agreement with President Clinton and a new set of issues that he calls "not quite ready for prime time."
Those new concerns include the search for a way to make Social Security and Medicare solvent for the baby boom generation and the Republican push for tax cuts of historic magnitude in a new era of Federal budget surpluses.
"So there was by nature this vacuum that we were going to have to deal with this year," Mr. Boehner said.
Other Republicans say the party lost the unifying ideas that allowed the disparate elements of the party to unite in the past -- anti-Communism and the battle to erase the Federal budget deficit.
And so elements of the party check, or perhaps checkmate, each other.
The Senate has stalled legislation sought by social conservatives but opposed by business that would require sanctions against nations that persecute religion.
And despite Mr. Gingrich's pledge to business groups that he would push in July for financing for the International Monetary Fund, the House abruptly put the issue off until September, with Representative Dick Armey of Texas, Mr. Gingrich's second in command, leading the battle against the money.
In an odd pose for a party that once projected itself as internationalist, Mr. Armey recently took pride in his lack of interest in foreign travel. "I've been to Europe once," he said. "I don't have to go again."
Senator Chuck Hagel of Nebraska recently called the split between his party's business and social conservative wings "terribly dangerous."
"It could undermine our party," Mr. Hagel said. "It could defeat us in 2000 if we don't put our party back together."
The Democrats, accusing the Republicans of running a "do-nothing Congress," are hoping the Republican infighting can be turned to their advantage in their struggle to retake the House. And they underscore the lack of action constantly.
"This is a Bart Simpson Congress: underachievers and proud of it," Representative Richard A. Gephardt of Missouri, the minority leader, said as the House left for August. "Instead of working to address the real challenges, which most American families face, the Republicans continue to run out the clock."
But voters, when asked which party they would prefer to lead Congress, have put the two at a tie for months. And Democrats say surveys earlier this year by two White House pollsters, Mark Penn and Douglas Schoen, found that the public did not necessarily think a do-nothing Congress was bad -- as long as the economy was good.
So the Democrats are trying to highlight particular issues to show voters what it means to them if Congress has a scaled-back agenda. Their list of legislation left undone includes an antitobacco measure, regulation of health maintenance organizations, overhaul of the campaign finance system and higher spending on education.
Last week, House Republicans and Democrats each seemed to be spoiling for precisely the political confrontation that most scares Senate Republicans, a debate over whether the Republicans' proposal for a large tax cut would risk the long-term health of Social Security.
That allows each party to play to its traditional strengths.
"We will fight together to make sure Republicans don't betray our obligation to Social Security and the American people," Mr. Gephardt said. "If that's what they want to run on, that's good. Let's engage."
Mr. Gingrich, anticipating the Democratic line of attack, said that under current economic projections of the surplus, a tax cut of $700 billion would still leave $761 billion over 11 years to be set aside for Social Security.
"They want to keep all the money in Washington, frankly so they can spend it," the Speaker said.
The entire political mood could change in the fall, depending on the investigation of Whitewater and Mr. Clinton's relationship with Monica S. Lewinsky by Kenneth W. Starr, the Whitewater independent counsel. That in turn could affect whether Mr. Clinton and the Congress hurtle to another Government shutdown instead of reaching an agreement on tax cuts and spending.
After receiving a veto threat from the White House on seven spending bills, Republicans last week preemptively began accusing the Administration of seeking such a confrontation as a diversion from Mr. Clinton's troubles.
Mr. Gingrich himself was cautious about predicting the session's outcome.
"In my judgment," he said, "we'll get something done this fall unless the whole place melts down."

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

With Investors Defensive, Small-Cap Stocks Skid
After last week's stock market rout, investors seemed defensive and uncertain. Drug company shares rose, but financial stocks were weak, as the Dow industrials gave up 23.17 points, to close at 8,674.85.
After rallying late last week, small-company shares faltered, leaving the Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks below its level of a week earlier. The index fell 4.16 points, or 1 percent, to 411.64. Page D8.
 
Treasury bond yields fell to one-month lows on expectations that Asian financial turmoil would bolster demand at the Treasury's $37 billion quarterly debt sale this week. The benchmark 30-year bond rose 2/32 , or 67.5 cents per $1,000 bond, to 1076/32 , nudging its yield down a basis point to 5.62 percent. D8.
 
Wall Street passed a preliminary test of its computer readiness for the year 2000 "with flying colors," the Securities Industry Association said. D7.
 
H.M.O.'s Said to Overbill Medicare
Health maintenance organizations have been receiving more than $1 billion a year in overpayments from the Medicare trust fund because they bill the Government for administrative costs attributable to their private customers as well as their Medicare patients, Federal investigators said. A14.
 
A New State Lure: Wage Rebates
The competition among states and even Mexico to attract companies has spawned a new incentive, one strikingly uncharacteristic for a market economy: wage rebates. For example, Whirlpool will get back 4.5 cents of every dollar paid in wages to the 1,100 workers it hired for a stove factory in Tulsa, Okla. A1.
 
Ford Cutting Prices for 1999
Ford Motor, for the first time in over 30 years, cut the average price of its 1999 model cars and trucks. The decrease averages three-tenths of 1 percent, or about $61, from comparably equipped 1998 models. The prices of Ford's highest-volume cars, the Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable, will fall by $1,000 to $1,800. D2.
 
Oxford Pressed on New York Plan
The New York State Insurance Department has asked Oxford Health Plans to increase its reserves for its New York plan by $152 million to insure that it has sufficient funds to pay medical claims over the next year. B6.
 
Bell Atlantic Strike Is Felt
The strike by Bell Atlantic workers affected customers from Maine to Virginia who were unable to get a telephone line installed or repaired or reach directory assistance. B1.
 
China's Firm Stance on the Yuan
Asian markets have seesawed as traders play on concerns that China, like the Asian nations roiled by financial crisis, will reduce the value of its currency, the yuan. But China's leaders have repeatedly promised they will not, and the traders overlook the fact that China responds more to politics than to market pressure. News Analysis. D4.
 
New Editors for Glamour and Cosmo
Ruth Whitney is retiring after more than three decades as editor of Glamour, just 18 months after Helen Gurley Brown left Cosmopolitan. Succeeding the leaders whose sensibilities defined the two women's magazines for a generation are to be Bonnie Fuller, Cosmo editor, at Glamour, and Kate White, editor of Redbook, at Cosmo. Advertising. D6.
 
A Free Fix for Vulnerable E-Mail
Sendmail, whose software routes electronic mail, plans to announce a simple and free fix for a security flaw found in Microsoft and Netscape E-mail programs. D5.
 
 
The Fortune Rubin Left Behind
When Robert E. Rubin left Goldman, Sachs, where he held one of the largest ownership stakes, in late 1992 to join the Government, he may have left a half-billion dollars -- or even $1.5 billion -- on the table. As Treasury Secretary, he earns $99,500 a year. D7.

 CORRECTION:

HEADLINE: What's Good for G.M. Is Good for Its Workers

 BODY:

To the Editor:
In "General Motors Plans to Build New, Efficient Assembly Plants" (front page, Aug. 6), you note that the United Automobile Workers is concerned that the plants will need fewer workers. Both G.M. and the U.A.W. are missing the obvious. If labor-saving devices were used for their legitimate purpose -- to reduce work time without a cut in pay -- the number of jobs would be maintained. 
 Managers and union leaders alike would have widespread support for such an approach. According to a U.S. News & World Report poll, 65 percent of Americans think that a movement to shorten the workweek is a good idea, while 62 percent of managers say shorter work hours would give employees an incentive to be more productive and would have little effect on living standards.
 
DAN ARONSON
Somerville, N.J., Aug. 7, 1998
 
The writer is an associate professor of economics at Raritan Valley Community College.

HEADLINE: Strikes and Asian Crisis Are Factors in U.S. Productivity Drop

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
The productivity of United States workers fell in the second quarter, the Government said today, the first such drop in three years, as Asia's economic crisis and strikes at General Motors plants took a toll.
Productivity -- a measure of the time and effort of providing goods and services -- fell in the second quarter at an annual rate of two-tenths of 1 percent after surging at a 3.5 percent pace in the first three months of the year. 
 Still, second-quarter nonfarm productivity was 1.9 percent higher than it was in the corresponding three-month period a year ago and near the 2.4 percent year-over-year increase posted for the first quarter.
As economic growth picks up in the second half of the year, productivity should rise, too, analysts said.
"Even with this setback in the second quarter, the trend in productivity growth is pretty solid," said Mark Vitner, an economist with the First Union Corporation in Charlotte, N.C. "Productivity is decent enough that inflation concerns aren't likely to intensify."
The slower rate of productivity growth in the second quarter comes as no surprise to Federal Reserve policy makers. The chairman of the Federal Reserve, Alan Greenspan, told Congress last month that a slowdown in second-quarter gross domestic product growth would likely result in weaker productivity for the period.
The drop in productivity in the second quarter was the first since the first quarter of 1995, when productivity fell at an annual rate of four-tenths of 1 percent. Analysts said productivity was depressed by two strikes against the General Motors Corporation in Flint, Mich., which shut down nearly all the company's North American plants.
"The G.M. strike cut into output growth," said Carol Stone, an economist with Nomura Securities Inc. in New York. "Cutting out 30 percent of the nation's auto industry is a problem." Additionally, the productivity slowdown to a certain extent was an effort on the part of manufacturers to reduce inventories, she said.
Fed policy makers are counting on productivity gains to compensate for the rising cost of workers.

HEADLINE: Adobe Systems Warns Loss Is Possible inThird Quarter

BYLINE: By LAWRENCE M. FISHER 

DATELINE: SAN FRANCISCO, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Adobe Systems Inc. warned today that its third-quarter revenue would fall below analysts' expectations, resulting in a potential loss. Adobe also announced the departure of three senior executives and a reduction of 240 to 300 jobs, or 13 percent of its work force.
Shares of Adobe fell $1.375, to $30.8125, on Nasdaq before trading was halted for the company's announcement late in the afternoon. 
 Adobe, based in San Jose, Calif., is a leading maker of software programs used in publishing, including Photoshop, Illustrator, Pagemaker and the Postscript language used in printers. Although Adobe has modified many of its programs to take advantage of the Internet, and many are used to create Web sites, analysts said the company had run into difficulty exploiting the transition to electronic publishing.
"Adobe is a tremendously successful company in the print world, but they haven't really figured out the right products and strategy for making money and being successful on the Web," said Christopher J. Galvin, an analyst with Hambrecht & Quist.
Adobe also said in its announcement today that business continued to be hurt by Japan's recession. The company said that cost-cutting efforts, including the reduction of jobs, would lower expenses by as much as $60 million a year.
The company said revenue for the quarter that will end Aug. 28 was likely to be $220 million to $225 million, compared with $230 million in the quarter a year earlier.
After a one-time reorganization charge and other nonrecurring expenses, Adobe said, net income may break even or be a loss, compared with net income of $53.4 million in the quarter a year earlier. Analysts had expected Adobe to earn 52 cents a diluted share, according to First Call, which tracks company earnings.
Adobe also said today that three top executives, P. Jackson Bell, executive vice president and chief administrative officer; Robert Roblin, executive vice president for marketing, and Ross Bott, executive vice president for product divisions, had resigned.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
As the Yen Falls, Markets Fear Japanese Savers Will Look Elsewhere

BYLINE: By STEPHANIE STROM 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 11

 BODY:
As the yen falls to new lows against the dollar, ordinary investors are fleeing to other currencies, heightening concern that a fundamental shift in sentiment is under way against the yen.
Among the factors mentioned by currency traders as immediate causes of the yen's fall are the faltering stock market, doubts about the new Government's commitment to dealing with problems in the banking sector and the possibility that China might devalue its currency. 
 Such concerns pushed the yen down to a rate of 147.63 to the dollar in London trading early today, an eight-year low, and to 147.35 in New York later. The benchmark Nikkei index of 225 stocks fell for a seventh consecutive trading day, closing down 219.40 points, or 1.4 percent, at 15,406.99. In Hong Kong, the main stock index fell 3.6 percent, to 6,779.95. Most other Asian markets were also lower.
The biggest worry among currency traders is that the yen is reaching a level where Japanese housewives, who control the family purse strings and thus a vast pool of savings, are swapping their yen for dollars, German marks and pounds sterling.
"That's the main worry for me," said Steven Barrow, a currency strategist at Bear Stearns International in London. "The key here is what's happening to Japanese savings and the fear that ordinary Japanese are looking to send their cash abroad in droves."
The yen's slow erosion over the last few months has contributed to a surge in the Government's already large surplus in the current account, which measures the difference between income from foreign sources and foreign obligations payable, excluding net capital investment.
Few have been paying attention, however, to the even larger outflows from capital and investment accounts since last spring, a strong indication that Japanese households are beginning to seek higher returns and less volatility in other currencies.
Mr. Barrow noted that while the current account surplus has been running at one trillion to 1.5 trillion yen a month, according to Government figures issued in July, Japan's capital and investment accounts are running deficits of 2 to 2.5 trillion yen a month, reflecting a net outflow of money.
"While they're earning more foreign currency from trade, it seems they're only too willing to see even greater sums flowing back out to take advantage of higher yields elsewhere," he said.
One of the biggest factors in the decision last month by Moody's Investors Service, the credit-rating agency, to put Japan's triple-A rating on review for a possible downgrading was concern that the household sector had joined the flight to other currencies.
"Of particular concern is the potential for volatile portfolio shifts into foreign currency assets by Japanese residents in the post-Big Bang environment," Moody's said in its news release, referring to sweeping financial reform measures that went into effect on April 1.
And traders worry that the Government statistics fail to fully capture the flight from yen to dollars or other currencies. A shift of individual savings out of yen and into other currencies may not show up in the Government numbers because the money may never leave the country. Instead, it may sit in a foreign currency account at the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi, Citibank, Sumitomo Bank and other banks that offer such accounts.
It is difficult to get a read on how big that shift is, however, since most banks refuse to disclose breakdowns of foreign-currency deposit accounts and yen deposit accounts.
Japanese bank officials contend that April's financial reform measures did not really enhance the ability of Japanese depositors to shift their savings into dollars and other currencies, but they do concede a marked uptick in demand for foreign-currency accounts since then.
Until this spring, the Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi was almost the only Japanese bank to promote foreign-currency accounts aggressively. Katsumi Tsuiji, a Bank of Tokyo-Mitsubishi spokesman, said the demand for those accounts had accelerated since April, although the increase was somewhat modest because the bank already had a significant part of the foreign-currency deposit market.
Mr. Tsuiji declined, however, to disclose the amount in foreign-currency deposits, as did a spokesman for Citibank.
Sumitomo Bank began offering foreign-currency deposit accounts in five different currencies last year, in advance of the financial reforms. A spokesman said that from March until the end of July, the amount of deposits held in foreign-currency accounts had increased 150 percent.
Few believe the Government is prepared to step in and try to stem that tide. In the past, intervention has taken place only in advance of a significant policy development, and there is no new policy in sight.
Indeed, various senior officials of the ruling party have expressed dissatisfaction with the yen's direction in recent days, but to no avail. Today, Finance Minister Kiichi Miyazawa hinted obliquely that the Government might move to prop up the yen, and Eisuke Sakakibara, Vice Minister of Finance for international affairs, suggested that the Group of Seven industrial nations would join in support of the Japanese currency.
Mr. Miyazawa, noting the negative impact that the slide in the yen is having on other Asian currencies, said, "I couldn't speak of specific levels, but it is necessary to intervene if the market is not moving in an orderly fashion."
The markets assume that as the yen weakens, Japanese exports become more competitive with those of other Asian countries, and concern is mounting that the Chinese will be forced to devalue their currency, the yuan, in spite of pledges not to do so.
A report today in The Financial Times said the Chinese Government was selling yen, in a major shift in its foreign-currency portfolio.
"The next key point is 150" yen to the dollar, said Hiroshi Sakuma, a foreign-exchange trader at Barclays Bank in Tokyo. "That's the target point for a lot of investors and speculators because that's the point that many think the Chinese will have to devalue."
Some economists and strategists suggest that allowing the yen to weaken is, in fact, the Government's newest plan to reinvigorate the deteriorating Japanese economy, in spite of the stern tone of disapproval emanating from the Ministry of Finance.
Economists like Paul Krugman have argued that Japan should deliberately unleash inflation, which would encourage consumers and companies to spend rather than save in fear that their purchasing power would be diluted in the future.
Craig Chudler, chief strategist at Salomon Smith Barney in Tokyo. said: "This could be the economic policy they're after. If they allow the currency to depreciate, it should be inflationary by making imports more expensive, and many economists believe Japan desperately needs inflation to get the economy going again."

HEADLINE: Business Travel;
Northwest Is Pressured To Reduce Some Fares

BYLINE: By EDWIN McDOWELL 

 BODY:
Bowing to pressure from North Dakota politicians and local airport managers, Northwest Airlines said yesterday that it would cut business fares to and from the state as part of a six-month trial to stimulate passenger traffic. The fares, discounted as much as 60 percent on connecting flights and 42 percent on nonstop flights, are available immediately for travel from Sept. 14 through March 31, 1999.
The new discounts come against the backdrop of mounting political pressures in state legislatures and in Congress to rein in rising business fares. Just this Monday, a Democratic candidate for Attorney General of Minnesota said that if elected, he would summon a task force to recommend ways of increasing airline competition in the state and would also investigate whether Northwest had violated antitrust laws -- a suggestion the carrier denies. 
 Reacting to yesterday's decision, Senator Byron L. Dorgan, a Democrat from North Dakota, said: "Community representatives and our airport managers have been in ongoing discussions with Northwest on the issue of reducing fares since last October. Northwest is responding to our analysis and concerns that the current business fares are inhibiting some North Dakota travelers."
Last May, in what it said was an effort to spur economic development in the nine-county greater Des Moines area, UAL's United Airlines cut fares between Des Moines and other Midwest cities by 34 percent, to $249 each way. It also cut 50 percent off 14-day advance fares that do not require a Saturday night stay. And by deploying bigger planes between Des Moines and Chicago, it added 812 seats each week during the summer.
Kevin Mitchell, chairman of the Business Travel Coalition, said that both the United and Northwest decisions were directly related to the increasing business, government and news media pressure on the airlines. Yesterday's cuts, he said, "underscore the usefulness of Federal Government leadership on the competition issue in providing local communities with impartial data and analysis."
Nevertheless, Northwest does not seem prepared to lose revenue indefinitely on its North Dakota experiment. "A substantial increase in the unrestricted business fare traffic will be required to maintain these fares after the test period," the carrier said in a statement. "For example on many routes, passengers in the business fare category will have to double their current level just to maintain present revenue levels for Northwest."
During the test period, one-way fares between Bismarck, N.D., and Chicago, for example, will fall to $195 from $460, between Bismarck and Washington to $325 from $680 and between Minot, N.D., and Chicago to $195 from $484. Reductions on flights from both Bismarck and Minot to Minneapolis-St. Paul will range between 36 and 42 percent.
Northwest said it would support its lower business fares with increased marketing, advertising and by including the rates on its World Wide Web site. Test results will be reported by early January 1999, and a final evaluation will be released about mid-June.
 
Cheap Seats to Hong Kong
From now through the end of the month, Cathay Pacific is offering round-trip flights to Hong Kong from New York and Los Angeles for $399 plus taxes and fees. Seats are limited and tickets -- nonrefundable even in the event of illness -- are valid for travel between Sept. 1 and Nov. 30, among other restrictions. Moreover, the fare is available only via the Internet, although there is no charge for registration (www.cathay-usa.com/hop) and it takes only a few minutes.
 
Traveling With Laptops
An American Express survey of business travelers has found that 65 percent of respondents always or almost always use a laptop computer on overnight trips. Those travelers will probably be pleased to learn that the new security gates at United Airlines' Terminal 7 at Los Angeles International airport, scheduled to open in early September, will allow passengers to go through without switching on their computers.
Security-minded laptop owners may be glad to know that Port Inc., which already offers a motion-sensitive system for notebook-computer carrying cases, has developed a remote control security system. When motion is detected, an electronic sensor triggers an alarm that activates a siren, which sounds for up to 30 seconds. A key chain remote control, usable up to 40 feet, has a panic button that signals an immediate alarm to find a lost carrying case or to signal an alert if a thief grabs the case.

HEADLINE: ABOUT NEW YORK;
Brothers Land On Their Side Of the Divide

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
SHRIEKS and squeals filled the yellow school bus as it bounced and bumped over the potholes along the factory-lined streets of the East Williamsburg Industrial Park. They subsided, only to be replaced by the bouncy beats of a hip-hop song on the radio. Bear Mountain was still an hour away, but the children from St. Barbara's Day Camp were getting psyched for the summer's final outing on Monday.
"I'd rather have bus music," one child shouted. "She'll be coming 'round the mountain when she comes. Yee-haw! She'll be coming 'round the mountain when she comes. Yee-haw!" 
Brother Rick Dixon, the camp's director, savored the exuberant scene, speaking up only a few times to quiet the group when the yee-haws reached rodeo riot levels. He did so reluctantly, at that, since he knew this was a big day for youngsters who feel cooped up in their Bushwick neighborhood.
"With a group like this, the more ordered and controlled it is, the easier it is for us," Brother Rick said. "At the same time, it's not good for human relations. I'm continually struggling with that balance."
The bus trip was a breeze compared with the demands of his own spiritual journey as a member of the Little Brothers of the Gospel, a tiny Roman Catholic order that practices prayer and contemplation in neighborhoods that are poor, violent and sometimes raucous. Odder yet to some of their neighbors, their mission is not to build schools or hospitals, but to offer simple acts of constant companionship. With the income gap between the rich and poor widening, Brother Rick said the hardest part of his mission was to convince others that money may help, but it doesn't heal.
"In our consumer-oriented culture, there is so much pressure," he said. "The only things kids see is this drive for money, exploitative love and sex. It's almost like we've forgotten that profound friendship is love, too."
Brother Rick and his confreres didn't need any studies to tell them how rich and poor were diverging more and more. Good economic times forced them to move to Bushwick two years ago from their longtime home on the Lower East Side. Four of them had lived in an apartment just steps off the Bowery on East Fourth Street until skid row gave way to sidewalk cafes, pricey apartments and clubs of the moment. Most of the poor families they had known over the years had gradually been scattered to other parts of the city.
"The Lower East Side is a better community because it attracts tourists," Brother Giorgio Gonella said. "But in recent years we felt like guests and the neighborhood belonged to the people who went to restaurants and theaters."
What had once been a struggling community, he said, began to feel more and more like a no man's land of urban individualism. What Bushwick lacked in material wealth, they discovered soon after their arrival two years ago this month, was offset by what it had in human bonds. And while their neighbors first thought they were undercover police officers, little by little they became friends with the people they saw each day sitting outside on stoops, chatting in bodegas or worshiping at church.
A previous generation once measured success by the mile, equating it with how far they could move from the neighborhood. Jackie Gracie, a day camp counselor, credits people like Brother Rick for reminding others how they can work to improve the block.
"He's willing to listen," Mr. Gracie said. "He may be a Brother, but he's really like a brother from a different mother."
THE Little Brothers call the neighborhood a little village, even if the curses that filter into the small chapel in their apartment would make it appear that this was hardly a place for contemplation. Quite the opposite, they said.
"When survival is a daily challenge, somehow there is something beautifully naked," Brother Giorgio said. "The dialogue always comes down to the basic questions. Why life? Why death? Why poverty? The more middle-class you are, the more expert you are in the art of hiding from the real questions. Living in a poor neighborhood, your contemplative life is enriched by the tragedies which oblige you to be truthful."
It all adds up to a richness of life that Brother Giorgio didn't see being replaced anytime soon by cafe society.
"You don't come here unless you belong here," he said. "So far, we don't have any yuppies moving here. They're all going to Williamsburg."

HEADLINE: Drifting to a New Iraq Policy

 BODY:
These first days of August have brought a disquieting retreat by the Clinton Administration on Iraq. Without saying as much, the White House seems on the verge of altering seven years of American policy by letting Saddam Hussein slip free of the international effort to prevent him from developing a new arsenal of biological and chemical weapons. That would be a grave mistake.
The change of tone and direction have been striking in the week since Mr. Hussein ended Iraqi cooperation with United Nations weapons inspectors, breaking the agreement he reached earlier this year with Kofi Annan, the Secretary General of the U.N. Instead of warning Mr. Hussein that his resistance was no more acceptable now than it was before, and would be met with military force if necessary, the Administration has deliberately downplayed the defiance. Mr. Annan, for his part, has urged the Security Council to review the inspection system and accompanying economic sanctions that have been in place since the end of the Persian Gulf war in 1991. 
 This is just the kind of equivocating performance Mr. Hussein has been hoping to provoke. A relaxation of sanctions and reliance on less intrusive inspections might be in order if Iraq had complied with the Security Council requirement that it dismantle all weapons of mass destruction and make no effort to rebuild them. But Iraq has resisted inspection at every turn, leaving inspectors convinced it retains the ambition and means to develop biological and chemical weapons.
Mr. Hussein has repeatedly demonstrated his willingness to attack his neighbors, even his countrymen. Allowing him to replenish his stockpile of biological and chemical weapons would threaten the Persian Gulf region and its oilfields, as well as Israel. Few developments would so directly endanger American security interests.
There should be no illusions in Washington about the difficulty of keeping Mr. Hussein in check. The Security Council is wobbly, with Russia and France eager to ease inspections and sanctions. Mr. Annan's resolve seems in doubt. Many Americans question the need to maintain pressure on Baghdad and would oppose the use of force.
But the threat is too great to give ground to Mr. Hussein. The cost to the world and to the United States of dealing with a belligerent Iraq armed with biological weapons would be far greater than the cost of preventing Baghdad from rearming.
Without a clear and consistent message from Washington that it is prepared to enforce the inspection system, Iraq's weapons programs cannot be reliably contained. Unless Mr. Annan insists that Baghdad fully honor its agreement with him, increasingly bold Iraqi challenges to U.N. authority are certain to come.

HEADLINE: A Budget Balance in Congress

 BODY:
With Congress in recess, Washington is filled with threats of another government shutdown over the budget in October. Underneath the surface, however, a fragile majority of moderate Democrats and Republicans is emerging in both the Senate and House that could set a less confrontational tone when lawmakers return in September. On budget issues, moderate Republicans are warning sensibly against big new tax cuts and spending reductions in essential areas. It would be healthy for Republican leaders to pay attention.
Passage of the Shays-Meehan campaign finance legislation owed much to independent-minded Republicans in the House this year. In that vote, more than 60 Republicans ignored Speaker Newt Gingrich and voted with the Democrats. An equally large bloc of Republican moderates voted with House Democrats recently to save the National Endowment for the Arts and defeat a gay-bashing amendment pushed by social and religious conservatives. Moderates in the Senate, especially veterans of past budget battles like Pete Domenici and William Roth, refuse to go along with the big tax cuts advocated by the budget-cutters in the House. 
 Fights between Republican moderates and conservatives have so tied up the budget this year that none of the 13 appropriations bills financing the Government after the end of September have been passed by both houses of Congress and sent to President Clinton. Congressional Republicans could not even agree on an overall budget resolution. Meanwhile, moderates in the Senate support full funding for the International Monetary Fund to help it deal with the Asian economic collapse. House conservatives seem more in the thrall of the isolationism of Dick Armey, who recently commented: "I've been to Europe once. I don't have to go again."
The White House may be in crisis but can count on the country rallying against another budget siege by Republicans, shutting down the Government as they did in 1995. Last week, when some House Republicans were saying that this time they could reap political gains from a shutdown, it was Mr. Gingrich's turn to cringe. The title of his recent book, after all, is "Lessons Learned the Hard Way." The paradox of this moment is that while the conservatives brought Mr. Gingrich to power, the moderates are the ones who learned the lessons.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKES & BONDS;
Treasury Securities Gain As Investors Seek Havens

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities made modest price gains yesterday as investors sought a haven from the stock market and from overseas markets.
The demand for Treasuries pushed down the long bond's yield, which falls as prices rise, close to its all-time low. One reason for the demand was that the dollar surged to an eight-year high against the Japanese yen, and investors grew concerned that Russia might default on debt repayments. A strong dollar makes dollar-denominated investments like Treasury securities more attractive to foreign investors, not only for the return but also for the potential gains from currency trans lations. 
 By late in the day the 30-year benchmark issue was up 11/32, to a price of 107 17/32, and its yield fell to 5.60 percent, from 5.62 percent on Monday.
At the Treasury's $16 billion, five-year-note auction yesterday, part of its quarterly sale of notes and bonds, the yield came in at 5.327 percent, a little worse than expected, although not surprising considering bonds were rallying at the time. Usually dealers will raise yield levels ahead of an auction to attract investors, but the rally may have cut into that pre-auction preparation.
Today, the Government will auction $11 billion of 10-year notes by reopening the 5.625 percent issue due May 15, 2008, and tomorrow, it will sell $10 billion of a new 30-year bond. In when-issued trading, the 10-year note was being offered at a price to yield 5.36 percent and the 30-year bond at a price to yield 5.52 percent.
Hugh Whelan, vice president and portfolio manager at Aeltus Investment Management, said the bond market's strength came from two sources yesterday, primarily from the so called flight to quality from other assets like emerging markets and stocks. The second source of strength, he said, was "from people beginning to wonder if Federal Reserve chairman Alan Greenspan would entertain the idea of an ease in interest rates to offset some of the global weakness that seems to be deteriorating further."
Toward the close of the New York market, bond yields came off their best levels of the day, in response, Mr. Whelan said, "to a stabilizing stock market and a mediocre five-year note auction, which I thought was affected by the rally in Treasuries."
Even strong economic data yesterday were overwhelmed by events in overseas markets and in domestic stock markets.
Thomas E. Donne, vice president and senior portfolio manager at Banc One Investment Advisors in Columbus, Ohio, said: "Clearly the stock market decline is an indication of an asset reallocation play going on. There is a question now being asked: What is the most desireable asset? People are rethinking their positions, but it does not reflect any change in fundamentals in the market., The economy has not changed except to slow slightly."
The following are the results of yesterday's Treasury auction of five-year notes:

HEADLINE: Colleges Agree to Share Chores, But Without Uttering the M-Word

BYLINE: By WILLIAM H. HONAN 

 BODY:
Four years ago, LeBron Fairbanks, the president of a small, distinctively Christian liberal arts college in Mount Vernon, Ohio, had an inspiration. Budget cuts were threatening his institution, but, he figured, he could save "bushels of money" by combining resources with neighboring colleges.
The idea was daring for an institution like Mount Vernon Nazarene College, which is committed to its religious traditions and wary of blurring its identity. 
 Nevertheless, Mr. Fairbanks came up with a proposal in which Mount Vernon and five other Ohio colleges would seek ways to combine administrative tasks. He found a receptive ear for his experiment at the Teagle Foundation, a midsize private philanthropy that was just then shopping for a way to make a significant contribution to higher education. Teagle so liked the idea (and trusted Mr. Fairbanks, as an earlier grant recipient) that it set up the Collaborative Ventures Program and has issued more than $4 million in grants to help colleges set up money-saving collaborations.
While only a handful of such consortiums existed in 1995, today there are at least 21 representing more than 125 colleges and universities. They range from the elite Five Colleges Inc. (Amherst, Hampshire, Mount Holyoke, Smith and the University of Massachusetts at Amherst) to the Montana Consortium of American Indian tribal colleges (Rocky Mountain, Salish Kootenai, Little Big Horn and Fort Peck Community College).
The appeal for Five Colleges was not just to save money but also to enrich academic programs. Specialized courses like Arabic, early music and astronomy rotate among the Five Colleges campuses, which individually might not be able to afford such unusual offerings. Students are encouraged to register for the shared courses at member institutions for no additional fees, and free intercollege bus service is provided.
Five Colleges is now trying to consolidate programs in American ethnic studies. A $135,000 Teagle grant will help pay for a new ethnic studies teacher who will shuttle from campus to campus this fall.
In contrast, the colleges in the Montana Consortium are too far apart for shuttle buses, so they are creating an on-line university using distance-learning techniques, with a shared curriculum and faculty exchanges.
"A great many of these small institutions are being caught in a squeeze," said Richard W. Kimball, president of Teagle. "On the one hand, their costs are going up because education is labor-intensive, and on the other they can no longer continue to raise tuition faster than the rate of inflation because the public won't stand for it. They've got no alternative but to reduce costs."
When he was approached by Mr. Fairbanks, Mr. Kimball said he was aware that some collaborative efforts in the past had failed. But he recalled thinking, "If a very conservative school like Mount Vernon Nazarene College is interested in this, maybe the time is right nationally."
The idea of consortiums is not entirely new. The Associated Colleges of the Twin Cities, an organization of five colleges in the Minneapolis-St. Paul area, has shared academic programs for about two decades. It is expanding its collaborations and is now working on a plan to share security services.
"The future will require higher-education leadership to reach out to others where there are administrative overlaps and academic programs which can be combined," said Larry Osnes, president of Hamline University in St. Paul, a Twin Cities institution.
Some of the most striking efforts involve institutions that have strong religious ties. A consortium of seminaries around Columbus, Ohio, is linking libraries and requiring students of each institution to take at least one course at another consortium member.
"We're fairly avant-garde in this," said Norman E. Dewire, president of the Methodist Theological School in Ohio, part of the consortium. "But we realize we can't live in a world apart."
College administrators are not unmindful of the risks. "Of course we have to be careful," said Mr. Fairbanks of Mount Vernon Nazarene College, which is now in league with five diverse institutions, including Ohio Dominican College, a Roman Catholic institution, and Wilmington College, which is affiliated with the Religious Society of Friends, the Quakers. Teagle awarded $560,000 to the consortium.
"People have a fierce loyalty to these institutions," Mr. Fairbanks said. "If you talk to the alumni about mergers, changing the name or losing your identity you're looking for another job."
Lorna M. Peterson, the coordinator of Five Colleges Inc., also expressed the need to proceed with caution. "We don't want this to become a threat to the distinctiveness or autonomy of the members," Ms. Peterson said. "The whole is smaller than the sum of its parts."
Mr. Kimball said Teagle did not use the word "merger." "If we use that word, we're dead," he said with a smile. "We don't want them to loose their identity, but does that mean they all need to cut their own grass?"

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

British Petroleum to Buy Amoco in $48.2 Billion Deal
British Petroleum announced that it would acquire Amoco, the big oil company, for $48.2 billion in stock. The deal is the largest oil industry merger ever, as well as the largest foreign takeover of an American company.
If approved by regulators and shareholders of both companies, BP Amoco, as the company is to be known, will be the world's third-largest multinational oil company in terms of net income after Exxon and the Royal Dutch/Shell Group of Companies. Page A1. 

Russian Markets Plunge
Russian stocks fell 9.11 percent, nearly as great a decline as on Monday. Government bonds tumbled to their lowest prices ever, as rates on the Russian equivalent of United States Treasury bills approached 80 percent for three-month maturities and 140 percent for nine-month maturities. "It's a collapse in confidence about the Russian Government's ability to fund itself," a former World Bank official said. A3.
 
The Belarussian ruble -- called the zaichik, or bunny, after the engraving that is its main feature -- has lost half its worth in five months, and the Belarus Government will no longer accept it as payment for exports. A3.
 
Bell Atlantic Workers End Strike
Ending a two-day-old strike against Bell Atlantic, members of the Communications Workers of America declared victory and returned to work. They reached a tentative agreement with management that insures that jobs in the company's high-technology growth areas will go to union employees. A1.
 
The Yen's Fall From Favor
With the yen trading at eight-year lows -- 147.35 yen to the dollar in New York -- currency traders fear a fundamental shift in sentiment is under way against the yen. Housewives, who control vast savings, are moving into dollars, pounds and marks. D5.
 
Second-Quarter Productivity Off
Workers' productivity fell at an annual rate of two-tenths of 1 percent in the second quarter, the first such drop in three years, as Asia's economic crisis and strikes at General Motors plants took a toll. D3.
 
Long Bond's Yield Near Low
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond fell to 5.62 percent, near its all-time low, as investors seeking a haven from stocks and overseas markets pushed up bond prices. D7.
 
Wal-Mart Profit Exceeds Forecasts
Wal-Mart Stores said that its quarterly earnings rose 30 percent, to $1.03 billion, or 46 cents a diluted share, 3 cents above analysts' forecasts. Profit surged almost fivefold at its international stores. D3.
 
Geocities' Successful I.P.O.
Investors clamored to buy the stock of Geocities, which gives its 2 million members pages on the World Wide Web to display pictures of their kids, their pets and their bottle-top collections -- a business on which it has not proved it can make money. Shares closed at $37.31, more than double the offering price of $17, in a day the market tumbled. D6.
 
Adobe Issues Warning on Revenue
Adobe Systems warned that revenue would fall below analysts' expectations, possibly resulting in a third-quarter loss, and that three senior executives would leave. Adobe is cutting 240 to 300 jobs. D2.
 
Associates First to Buy Avco
Associates First Capital, the finance company spun off by Ford Motor, will buy Avco Financial Services for $3.9 billion. D2.
 
Bad Shows for Investors
Announcing enforcement actions, Federal regulators said that fraudulent entertainment-industry investment schemes had cost investors $100 million in recent years. D3.
 
Viacom Sells Its Music Stores
Viacom Inc. sold its disappointing chain of Blockbuster Music stores to Wherehouse Entertainment for $115 million in cash. D2.

HEADLINE: The German Consensus

 BODY:
Gerhard Schroder, the German Social Democrat who may put an end to Helmut Kohl's chancellorship in elections next month, came to Washington last week to see and be seen with President Clinton. Along with trying to assure Germany that strong ties to America will continue, Mr. Schroder is reinforcing parallels with a politician he admires. He paints himself as a tough and energetic reformer running against a stodgy incumbent.
The comparison of himself to Mr. Clinton is misleading. Germany has rejected the kinds of economic reforms now taken as gospel in Britain and America. The generosity of the German welfare state sometimes verges on parody. But Germans strongly believe society should take care of all its members. Even after 16 years of the conservative Mr. Kohl, benefit deductions average 42 percent of workers' salaries, a record. Employers have won more flexible work hours, but labor costs remain among Europe's highest. 
 At 54, Mr. Schroder may be relatively young and energetic, but he is unlikely to depart from the German consensus. With unemployment at 10.7 percent, slightly down from a postwar high, Mr. Schroder's main issue is job creation. But his ideas are vague and contradictory. What he could do depends on the coalition the Social Democrats could form -- and on the party's chairman, Oskar Lafontaine, who advocates wage hikes. Mr. Schroder, who favors a tax cut, also wants the Government to pick up some expensive benefits now paid by employers. He wants to turn low-wage temporary jobs into "real" jobs, which could exacerbate unemployment. While he is one of the most pro-business members of a party with a union base, he advocates little that the unions could oppose.
Mr. Kohl was the architect of German unification and is now the chief advocate of European integration. Mr. Schroder, once a skeptic about Europe's single currency, now says that even if he governs with the Green Party, there will be no change in any major aspect of foreign policy.
It is still very possible that Helmut Kohl will win a fifth term as Chancellor. But it is a mark of Mr. Kohl's influence on modern Germany that even if he loses, his policies are likely to live on.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE MARKETS -- Market Place;
Less U.S. Ability This Time To Halt Falling Yen's Damage

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
With the Japanese yen falling to eight-year lows, helping to pull down financial markets around the world, the United States finds itself with few options.
It can intervene in the currency markets to support the yen's value, as it did in June, or jawbone the Japanese Government into stimulating its economy. Yet neither tactic is likely to be very effective in the absence of drastic measures by Japan, a point repeatedly made by Secretary of the Treasury Robert E. Rubin. 
 In June, the United States had the element of surprise when it worked in concert with Japan to prop up the yen, which had then traded as low at 146.78 to the dollar.
The move was intended to give the Japanese some breathing room to carry out bold policy changes -- changes that have not yet materialized. Timed just before President Clinton's trip to China, the intervention was also intended to placate the Chinese, who had been sending signals that a further decline in the yen might force them to devalue their currency, the yuan.
A Chinese devaluation would deepen the financial crisis in Asia and reverberate through other other international markets, perhaps setting off more devaluations.
After the joint intervention, the yen briefly rallied, at first to a rate of 136.75 to the dollar. China reassured the President that it would not devalue its currency.
The move also helped calm worried financial markets. After the June 17 intervention, the Dow Jones industrial average started a 7.8 percent run-up to a record high of 9,337.97 about a month later.
And foreign stock markets got a lift, albeit a smaller one. Hong Kong rose, and Mexico, which has suffered sharp losses this year, rallied for a time. Canadian stocks got a boost, as well, though they are now down 19 percent from their high to date this year.
But currency traders view the intervention as a one-time success.
What the United States can hope is that the yen does not fall precipitously, but grinds down slowly, said Richard Medley, president of Medley Global Advisers, which gives advice to institutions and hedge funds. To achieve this, he said, the United States and Japan might be forced to intervene again.
But a second intervention, he warned, would be less effective. For one thing, traders are expecting it now and have positioned themselves accordingly.
In addition, the new Japanese Government has not convinced investors that it will take the necessary steps, like tax cuts and banking reform, to revive the economy.
"We are telling investors to buy the dollar," Mr. Medley said. "You may get some smoothing intervention, but don't expect it to be an effort to reverse the trend."
For now, the falling yen has become a sell signal on the world equity markets. How much further can it fall? It will not be hard for the yen to reach 150 to the dollar, analysts said yesterday. And in New York trading, it dropped eight-tenths of a percent to settle at 147.35, its lowest level in eight years. Some year-end forecasts have the yen as far down as 180 to the dollar. In Asian trading on Wednesday, the dollar was quoted at 146.10 yen.
"There are no fundamentals supporting the yen," said Carl Weinberg, chief economist at High Frequency Economics in Valhalla, N.Y.
This could spell a stormy end of summer for the financial markets as investors grapple with a still-uncertain outlook for Asia and its impact.
Yesterday and Monday, the weakening yen -- and the fear of a Chinese currency devaluation -- was blamed for sharp declines in stock and currency markets around the world.
A devaluation by the Chinese would make their exports cheaper, taking sales away from other Asian nations that are fighting back from economic collapse.
And it would cut into American corporate earnings in two ways: American export sales would drop further as the Chinese and other Asian nations lose purchasing power, and goods brought into this country would be cheaper, putting downward pressure on the prices charged by American competitors.
Stocks slumped yesterday in the United States after a rout overnight in Asia. In Latin America, where, it is feared, a Chinese devaluation would set off currency declines there, the main Brazilian stock index dropped 5.6 percent in two days and the Mexican market fell 6.8 percent. The Mexican peso dropped to a low against the dollar, a rate of 9.19.
In Europe, the French CAC 40 index was off 2.37 percent yesterday, while in London, the Financial Times 100-stock index fell 2.77 percent, and the German DAX index declined 3.2 percent.
Commodity prices are also following the yen's lead. Oil and copper prices fell yesterday on concern that consumption in Asia would slow.
What is complicating the situation for American policy makers is that investors fear a further decline in the yen's rate will set off a Chinese devaluation -- repeated Chinese denials of such plans notwithstanding. Not too long ago, a level of 150 yen to the dollar appeared to be the line in the sand to hold off the Chinese.
Many economists, however, argue that there is little direct correlation between the two currencies. The Japanese and the Chinese do not compete very much in terms of exports. In addition, the benefit to China in making its exports cheaper is not sufficient to offset the political and social costs of a devaluation on the giant domestic economy, Mr. Weinberg argued.
Mr. Medley considers the Chinese trade surplus a more important gauge than the yen. He said that if the surplus fell to zero -- it was $20 billion for the first half of the year -- China would have to devalue because such a trade deficit would threaten its huge foreign-currency reserves.
"We recommend keeping your eyes on this number for the next few months, rather than news wire headlines," he told clients.
But thoughts of a Japanese-Chinese currency link have taken hold, in part because the June intervention was seen as a response to complaints from Beijing.
"There are portfolio managers we speak to who have set sell orders on their emerging market portfolios that are linked to the level of the yen," said Jeremy P. Fand, senior foreign-exchange strategist at BankBoston. While he does not think the link is appropriate, he said a lot of those orders were bunched at 150 yen to the dollar. Or, as Mr. Weinberg of High Frequency Economics said, "The perception is more important than the reality."
This means that a weakening yen could become more disruptive to financial markets, even if China does not feel compelled to devalue its currency, because even if there is no yen-yuan link, the markets see it that way for now.
"China, Japan and the United States are connected in every trader's mind," Mr. Fand said.
But the United States Treasury and the Federal Reserve, which would conduct any future intervention, cannot afford to become "the policemen of world financial markets," he said. Alan Greenspan, the Fed chairman, he said, "doesn't even want to be responsible for the fate of the Dow."
