HEADLINE: A Brooklyn Race Pits Two Former Friends and Allies

BYLINE: By JONATHAN P. HICKS 

 BODY:
They were not merely up-and-coming officials from the same Brooklyn neighborhood, but kindred politicians close enough to have been the best of friends for years. Over nightcaps in neighborhood bars, they planned their political futures. They worked on each other's campaigns. They went to family reunions together and even, at times, vacationed together.
But now, in one of the odd twists that are often part of politics, Assemblyman Darryl C. Towns and City Councilman Martin Malave Dilan have become political adversaries. 
 Mr. Towns, 37, is in a heated Democratic primary for re-election to a seat he won in 1992, representing the northern Brooklyn neighborhoods of Bushwick and Cypress Hills. Mr. Dilan, 47, who was elected to the Council in 1991, is running against him. It is a race in which Mr. Towns has had to defend his record, presenting himself as a vigilant advocate for his district as Mr. Dilan has offered a dissenting view and the promise of "a more active presence in Albany and in the district."
"The current Assemblyman has been an absentee Assemblyman," Mr. Dilan said of his former confidant. "Many of the people in the district, if they were to see his face, would not know who he is. In fact, I think he has been in a holding pattern waiting for Daddy to retire."
He was referring to Mr. Towns's father, Representative Edolphus Towns. The Congressman's relationship with the Democratic Party organization in Brooklyn adds another layer of complexity to the race for the Democratic nomination for the Assembly seat. The contest between Mr. Dilan and Mr. Towns is widely seen as an extension of a feud between Assemblyman Clarence Norman Jr., the Brooklyn Democratic chairman, and Congressman Towns.
Mr. Norman and the elder Mr. Towns, once close friends themselves, have become bitter political adversaries, a result of disagreements over endorsements. When Congressman Towns decided to support Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, a Republican, in last year's mayoral contest, Mr. Norman announced that the Democratic organization would no longer support the Congressman.
Earlier this year, Mr. Dilan had planned to run for Congress, against Representative Nydia M. Velazquez, a fellow Democrat. But last month, Mr. Dilan, a close ally of Mr. Norman, announced that he could not raise enough money to topple the popular Congresswoman. Instead, he announced for the Assembly seat held by the younger Mr. Towns.
Both Mr. Norman and Mr. Dilan say they are not involved in any plan to injure the Towns family. "One might have that perception," Mr. Norman said. "But I want to make it perfectly clear that the county organization is neutral. Despite the fact that I have some differences with the father, it has nothing to do with my relationship with the son. There is no backdoor support to Darryl's opponent."
Not all are convinced, however. "He's neutral against an incumbent?" Congressman Towns asked. "I find that strange, because the incumbent usually enjoys the Democratic organization's support."
The Congressman added that Mr. Dilan also endorsed the Mayor but was not attacked for it by Mr. Norman. "I think that Clarence is being vindictive," Congressman Towns said. "Instead of dealing with me, he wants to deal with my son, and that's unfortunate."
Mr. Dilan, too, accuses Mr. Towns and his father of disloyalty. "When I decided to run against Nydia, I expected they would be supportive, or at least neutral," he said. "But they supported her. The Congressman was vicious, and worked hard to reverse the decisions of the people who supported me. They had no pity and mercy."
The race in the 54th Assembly District is also marked by ethnic issues. Mr. Towns, who is black, and Mr. Dilan, who is Puerto Rican, are running in a district that is predominantly Hispanic. And one of Mr. Dilan's campaign themes is that it is time for the district to send a Hispanic Assemblyman to Albany.
The 1990 census showed the Assembly district as 66 percent Hispanic, 24 percent black, 5 percent white and 3 percent Asian, and demographers say the Hispanic population is now more than 70 percent.
For his part, Mr. Towns says he has been vehement in his efforts to enhance economic development in his district, which includes working-class and low-income residents.
"I've been a strong voice in Albany," Mr. Towns said. "Even through a time where resources have been cut drastically, I've still been able to address the issues of concern to all of my constituents."
Mr. Towns is likely to benefit from the power of incumbency and a network of support from his years of work among community organizations, not to mention assistance from his father and from Ms. Velazquez. Mr. Towns has been able to win the nomination consistently with more than one Hispanic opponent.
Mr. Dilan, a Democratic district leader, also has a broad network of community support based on years as an elected official. "Darryl Towns could be in trouble, simply because of the demographics," said Michael D. Nieves, a political consultant.
But Mr. Nieves said that Mr. Dilan, too, may have some difficulty because of his longstanding campaigning on behalf of the Townses.
"For years, the alliance between him and the Townses has been so strong," Mr. Nieves said. "He has been telling people why Darryl Towns was good for the community. He now has to convince those same people to vote for him. And he has to give a reason other than the fact that they don't get along anymore."

Diplomatic Posts Are Shut In Response to Threats
Several American diplomatic posts have been temporarily closed in response to threats made after the terrorist attacks on the embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, State Department officials said. A1
 
Federal agents began reconstructing hundreds of pieces of vehicles blown apart in the attack in Nairobi, in an attempt to identify the pickup truck that carried the explosives. A8

Belarus to Refuse Its Currency
The Belarussian ruble has lost half its worth in five months. Now, the Government has announced that starting next week, Belarus will no longer accept its own currency as payment for exports. A3
 
Russia's stocks and bonds fell to near-historic lows. Some analysts questioned whether the Russians, already embarked on an all-out effort to avert bankruptcy, would be able to rebuild the confidence of world financial markets. A3

Israel announced that it would not block the next step in a United Nations effort to draft an international treaty that would halt the production of the materials used to make nuclear weapons. Caribbean Secession Defeated
A majority of voters on the Caribbean island of Nevis supported secession from St. Kitts in a referendum but fell short of the two-thirds majority needed, officials announced. If the measure had been approved, Nevis would have become one of the smallest nations in the world. Leaders in St. Kitts and Nevis said they would try to work out differences between the islands, which constitute the smallest nation in the Western Hemisphere. A4

HEADLINE: BOMBINGS IN EAST AFRICA: THE SECURITY ISSUE;
U.S. CLOSES DOWN SOME OPERATIONS IN FOREIGN POSTS

BYLINE: By PHILIP SHENON 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Several American embassies and other diplomatic installations have temporarily closed down routine operations in response to threats made after the terrorist attacks on the embassies in Kenya and Tanzania, State Department officials said today.
The officials, speaking on condition that they not be identified, said the embassies affected include those in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, and Kampala, Uganda. 
 The embassy in Mbabane, Swaziland, was evacuated for several hours today after a bomb threat. In West Africa, the American Embassy in the Ivory Coast said it had cut back its business hours while security was reinforced.
The Cairo office of the Agency for International Development was also shuttered and its employees moved into the well-fortified American Embassy.
The State Department also said today that it had received information about possible threats to American targets in Egypt, Malaysia and Yemen. "This could include attacks on buildings," the department said. The embassies in those places were continuing to operate, though in some cases at reduced levels.
The department said Americans in those countries "should exercise caution" but it did not issue travel alerts.
Officials said they could not recall a similar instance in recent years in which several American diplomatic installations, which often get threats of violence, had suspended operations simultaneously.
The United States has announced a worldwide alert for embassies and other diplomatic installations after the terrorist attacks last week. The State Department and Congress have faced criticism since the attacks that they failed to provide sufficient security for embassies abroad.
Many American diplomatic missions were not given the upgraded security recommended by an independent commission after the bombing of the American Embassy and Marine barracks in Beirut, Lebanon, in 1983.
Patrick F. Kennedy, the Assistant Secretary of State for Administration, said that since the bombings last week, the Department and its overseas posts had received between one dozen and two dozen threats, including some considered "copy cat" threats of terrorist attacks mimicking those in Kenya and Tanzania.
"We are not leaving," he said. "We are taking, in effect, a brief time-out in order to make the security adjustments that are necessary to be responsive to a threat."
Another State Department official, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said that, "where prudent, we're reducing staff, we're moving from one building to another, we're reducing hours."
But he insisted that Americans living or traveling abroad would be able to obtain emergency services from all embassies, regardless of threats. "You will always be able to get an operator at the embassy and be connected to a duty officer -- 24 hours a day," he said.
The department refused to provide a formal list of the shuttered embassies out of concern that it might be used by terrorists to identify targets for attack.
"I'd prefer not to go into identifying specific embassies," Mr. Kennedy said at a news conference. "I think that just probably leads to more copycat calls." The suspended operations, he said, had occurred in "several regions" of the world.
He said the embassy operations had been curtailed at the request of ambassadors or, in their absence, the highest-ranking local American diplomat.
"We have always said to our chiefs of mission that they are responsible to protect the lives and safety of personnel overseas," Mr. Kennedy said.
"If the chief of mission feels that there is information available to him or her that says, 'I must take a particular step, including potentially briefly suspending operations until adjustments to the security posture can be made,' then we feel that is absolutely the right thing to do."
He did not describe the threats that had prompted the decision to cut back operations, but he said all were being taken seriously.
"When a call comes in or whatever it is," he said, "each call is analyzed and measured and then the post, the ambassador, the regional security officer, the emergency action committee at the post does what is appropriate."
An American official at the United States Embassy in Kuala Lumpur, speaking on condition that he not be identified, said the embassy closed its iron gates today for all but emergency services for American citizens. The official said it would remain closed Wednesday in order for the compound to be "hardened" against a possible terrorist attack.
"No one thinks of Kuala Lumpur as a terrorist target, but we want to take every precaution to keep our people safe," the official said. "I think you'll see additional barricades outside the embassy later this week, some more barbed wire."
State Department officials said the American Embassy in Uganda, which borders both Kenya and Tanzania, was closed today but was expected to reopen Wednesday, with security measures tightened.
The attack on the embassy in Nairobi, Kenya, has hindered the conduct of American diplomacy not just in Kenya but across much of East Africa.
The embassy there effectively functioned as a regional headquarters for the State Department and other Government agencies.

HEADLINE: Drought in Texas and Oklahoma Stunting Crops and Economies

BYLINE: By RICK LYMAN 

DATELINE: HOUSTON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
Figuring out how far Lynn Bartlett's erector-set grid of sprinklers can reach as they pivot around his sun-cracked cotton fields along the Salt Fork of the Red River is really not much of a chore.
The plants within the irrigation perimeter stand three or four feet high, thick and bristling with moist green bolls of healthy cotton, some of them as big as an apricot. Just beyond the water's reach, though, the plants slouch only a foot above the scaly soil and most have just two or three dusty bolls, none bigger than a Ping-Pong ball. 
 "This is basically burnt-up cotton," Mr. Bartlett said. "We had a good planting rain back in May, then a week or so later the tap just shut off and it's been off ever since."
While many parts of the country, including the Northeast, are suffering through dry months verging on drought, the situation is particularly severe in Texas and Oklahoma. Just two years after a drought ravaged large swaths of the rich agricultural region, both states are in the midst of a dry spell that officials say shows signs of developing into the costliest and most devastating the region has seen since the Dust Bowl years.
There is not a corner of Texas that is not laboring under severe or extreme drought conditions. President Clinton has declared each of the state's 254 counties a Federal disaster area, making farmers eligible for low-interest loans. "The crops have been lost, the livestock has been liquidated and there's really no relief in sight," said the Texas Agriculture Commissioner, Rick Perry. "I am starting to hear reports that this is the worst ever."
During crucial growing weeks from April through June, Texas received little measurable rainfall at all. South Texas, which has been hit hardest by the drought, received only 8 percent of its normal precipitation, the citrus ranchlands of the Rio Grande Valley only 4 percent.
Oklahoma received only two-thirds of its normal rainfall from June 1 to Aug. 1, and the southwestern corner of the state received less than a third. Adding to the problems is the extreme heat throughout the region this summer, taking away the last bits of moisture in already dry fields.
The United States Agriculture Secretary, Dan Glickman, recently declared 66 of Oklahoma's 77 counties Federal disaster areas, and state officials are hearing the same sort of dire reports about the drought's effects.
"All of agribusiness is very much affected," said Oklahoma's Agriculture Commissioner, Dennis Howard. "The ag dollar goes around Main Street six, seven, eight times, but it's not going around now, because it's not there. Small-town Oklahoma is really hurting."
But Texas and Oklahoma have changed a great deal since the Dust Bowl years of the 1930's, growing more urban and more economically diverse, particularly in the last two decades. So even though the drought could have a ruinous effect on farmers, cattle ranchers, small towns and agriculture-related businesses, the region's overall economy could well be cushioned.
On Wednesday in Washington, the Agriculture Department will release its monthly crop report, estimating how many of the country's planted acres will be worth harvesting and what their expected production.
The news is not expected to be good for Texas or Oklahoma.
Already, officials in Texas have estimated that the drought will cost farmers and ranchers $1.8 billion and will result in a $4.9 billion drain on the state's economy. In Oklahoma, officials last week predicted a total statewide cost of $2 billion.
But both Jared Hazelton, director of the Center for Business and Economic Analysis at Texas A&M University, and Bernard Weinstein, director of the Center for Economic Development at the University of North Texas, have said the drought will not have as dire an effect as some are predicting.
That, they say, is because agriculture accounts for only about 1 percent of Texas's $641 billion economy, even though Texas ranks third in the nation in net farm income, behind California and Iowa.
"The wonderful thing about the growth in the 90's is it isn't tied to a single-sector economy," Mr. Hazelton said. "There is no dominant industry."
Even in Oklahoma, where agriculture remains the state's leading industry, the economy has thus far been able to withstand the drought's impact.
"Now, thank goodness, Oklahoma's economy is more diversified than it was," Mr. Howard said. "The whole state isn't being impacted like it was during the drought in 1982, when we really went into a nosedive."
Even without such a nosedive this year, agriculture officials say, the drought will still be crushing to those corners of the region where agriculture remains at the center of life. In rural Texas and small-town Oklahoma, they say, businesses will close, tens of thousands of jobs will be lost, cattle herds will be affected for years to come, and nervous bankers will refuse to lend money to more and more struggling farmers.
"In metropolitan cities, the impact will be felt in consumer prices and in those businesses connected to agriculture," said Carl Anderson, an agricultural economist at Texas A&M. "But the real impact will be felt in smaller farm communities, and it's going to be devastating. They're going to have problems collecting taxes to keep open their schools. It's going to speed up the drying up of these small, rural communities."
Economists say that while the drought will inevitably affect prices at supermarkets all over the country, it is too early to say which products will be affected and by how much.
A $500 million Federal aid package is in a House-Senate conference committee, but agriculture officials in Texas and Oklahoma are complaining because half of that money is earmarked for farmers in the Dakotas and Minnesota. Mr. Glickman told officials in his recent swing through the region that he wanted the total raised to $1 billion, maybe more. He spoke to farmers and officials again today about Federal drought-relief efforts.
Last Friday, Gov. Frank Keating of Oklahoma organized a Plains States Rural Crisis Summit meeting in Oklahoma City, where he and the Governors of three other states concerned about the drought -- South Dakota, North Dakota and Nebraska -- adopted 22 emergency and long-term recommendations, including urging President Clinton and Congress to act more quickly to pump drought relief into the region.
Mr. Perry, the Texas Agriculture Commissioner, is pushing a plan to use some of Texas's budget surplus for a fund to provide aid in natural disasters. But the Texas Legislature, which meets biannually, is not scheduled to meet this year, so such a law could not be passed until 1999 at the earliest.
"God forbid this drought will still be going on then," Mr. Perry said.
Truman Zybach raises cattle on 1,700 acres in southwestern Oklahoma and across the Texas line. On his 900-acre ranch in Oklahoma, Mr. Zybach said, he would normally have 700 head of cattle at this time of year. But last Friday, with no grass in the fields for the cattle to eat and little hay available in the markets, he packed up four truckloads and sold them off, leaving him with only 50 or 60 cows.
"There's no green grass at all," Mr. Zybach said. "We're plum out of green grass."
Jack Feagley, manager of the Farmers Cooperative Society No. 1 in Wellington, Tex., said conditions were as bad in the Panhandle as he had ever seen them.
Most of Mr. Feagley's business comes from the co-op's two cotton gins. But this year, business has been so bad that the co-op is trying to sell one gin. The co-op also provides a weighing service for trucks full of cattle on their way to be sold.
"Normally, you'd start getting the cattle trucks in September," Mr. Feagley said. "But the ranchers are all out of grass out there, so they're selling early. They have to. I weighed 12 trucks already today."
Ernie Davis, an economist at the Texas Agricultural Extension Service, estimates that Texas cattle ranchers have already lost more than $450 million from being forced to sell off their herds early and from buying expensive feed in a vain effort to keep the herds going. If there are no rains in August, the year's loss figures could double, said Larry Boleman, a cattle specialist at Texas A&M.
In Oklahoma, the story is similar.
"Dry-land cotton is gone," Mr. Howard said. "Irrigated cotton is very stressed. Much of it won't make it. The watermelon crop is three-fourths off. The pecans, they're pretty well wiped out. Hay crop is 70 or 80 percent off. The horticulture industry is feeling it. People aren't buying shrubs and trees. If we don't get rain very quickly, we are not going to have any wheat pasture this fall. Corn is 80 or 90 percent gone. Soybeans are something like 70 percent gone. My dairy farmers tell me that because of the heat the cows are just off their feed, off their milk and production is down a third or a half. I know how the cows feel."
Mr. Bartlett walked through his field near the Salt and watched a neighbor's tractor kick up reddish dust. "I've heard of these droughts, but I've never been through one," he said.
On his own dry land, Mr. Bartlett said, he would normally expect to get 300 to 400 pounds of cotton per acre. This year, he will get only 50 to 100.
"The irrigated cotton is close to normal," he said, "but it's costing me $50 more an acre in watering. That's an expensive crop I've got in the ground."
If all goes well from now until the harvest, he expects to lose about half of what he would have earned on a normal crop.
"There may well be a few less farmers around here next season," Mr. Bartlett said. "Who knows? I may be one of them." He tossed a shriveled cotton boll back into a crusty furrow. "No, I don't really think so. I'll make it. But it all depends on how understanding your banker is. The bankers have their rules and regulations, too, I suppose. It's just life, I guess."

HEADLINE: COMPANY NEWS;
INTERNATIONAL PAPER EXPECTS TO TRIM ABOUT $100 MILLION

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

 BODY:
The International Paper Company expects to close about 25 plants and cut about $100 million in operating costs as a result of consolidating its $263 million acquisition of the Mead Corporation's Zellerbach distribution unit. International Paper said yesterday that it had completed the purchase of Zellerbach and would merge the unit with its Xpedx distribution business. The merger will add $1.2 billion to existing Xpedx sales, bringing combined annual sales at the unit to about $6 billion. The deal will expand Xpedx into seven new markets. Xpedx, based in Covington, Ky., distributes printing, packaging, industrial and graphic arts supplies and equipment. Shares of International Paper dropped $1.4375, to $42.625.

HEADLINE: Health Care Solution Is Over the Border

 BODY:

To the Editor:
It is extraordinary that the number of medically uninsured Americans has risen to 41 million while the national economy has never been better (front page, Aug. 9). Children are particularly hard hit. 
 Over the past decade there has been a steady trend of dropping children from employer-provided health care plans and a growing number of children eligible for, but not enrolled in, Medicaid. Urged on by President Clinton, Congress last year passed legislation to expand child health insurance coverage, which may bring three million to five million uninsured children into the system over the next five years.
But if employers keep dropping those already in private plans and confusion around key aspects of welfare reform continues to erode enrollment in Medicaid, there is a danger that net gains in coverage from the new legislation may be dramatically reduced.
 
IRWIN REDLENER, M.D.
New York, Aug. 10, 1998

HEADLINE: Health Care Solution Is Over the Border

 BODY:

To the Editor:
Forty-one million Americans cannot afford health insurance in this time of global capitalism (front page, Aug. 9). At the same time nine insurance executives earned more than $10 million each last year, according to a recent study. 
 This has escaped most news organizations' attention while they work to bring us news most of the public does not want -- trivial sex scandals, for instance. Political corruption may be at an all-time American high. If this is the celebrated triumph of capitalism over other forms of economic organization, what exactly did we win? Have we gained the world at the cost of our souls?
 
JASON REYNOLDS
Portland, Ore., Aug. 9, 1998
 
The writer is executive director of the Oregon Consumer League.

SECTION: Section D; Page 1; Column 2; Business/Financial Desk

LENGTH: 1847 words

HEADLINE: Medicine at the Click of a Mouse;
On-Line Health Files Are Convenient. Are They Private?

BYLINE: By MILT FREUDENHEIM

 BODY:
Guy Yarden, a musician who lives in Brooklyn, recently received a letter from a doctor asking him to press his health plan to pay an outstanding bill. By going to the insurer's World Wide Web site, Mr. Yarden could review the payments to his doctors, saving time on the phone for both himself and the health plan.
Propelled by the soaring popularity of the Internet plus the shifting economics of health care, the medical industry is rapidly going on line. 
 The Internet is already a popular place to search for general information about medicines and treatments, but now a growing number of insurers and doctors are also using it to provide members and patients with personal medical information, from lab results to payment records.
"A potential revolution" is brewing in "how the consumer interacts with the health plan and, down the road in a different way, with the providers of care," said Jim Hudak, a managing partner with Andersen Consulting.
And Mr. Yarden, who describes himself as a "big on-line user," said he hoped that what was available now would be only the beginning. "They should be offering a lot more information," he said, "like the doctor's diagnosis and prognosis."
All this has the potential to be a huge benefit for consumers, doctors and insurance company employees, who can become bogged down in mountains of paperwork and, when seeking information, often face clogged phone lines.
But it also raises serious questions about the privacy of such highly personal information wafting about the digital world. A person with AIDS, for instance, might not want his employer to know, and a politician or an executive up for a promotion might want to keep a serious illness secret.
The issue thus fits squarely into the broader debate about privacy and security on the Internet, whether it involves protecting credit card numbers or keeping children from offensive information.
For while the variety of Internet offerings has exploded, privacy has limped far behind. Medical privacy was a factor recently when the White House backed away from the idea of assigning every American a medical identification number. The notion was shelved, the Administration said, until Congress passes legislation to protect patient privacy. The current version of that bill has faced criticism for not going far enough.
Mr. Yarden said the privacy issue "doesn't worry me," adding, "I change my passwords regularly."
Carol Haberman, who works at the National Library of Medicine, noted, "If you pay a doctor on your credit card, your privacy is gone right there."
But Dr. Donald J. Palmisano, a trustee of the American Medical Association, is skeptical. "If vandals can break into a C.I.A. Web site," he said, "it doesn't make the A.M.A. feel real secure that some vandals won't break into a health plan."
Managed-care companies say that they are eager to safeguard members' privacy and that their security systems can protect the electronic information, sometimes more effectively than with paper records.
One Blue Cross plan even invites subscribers to dial in tips when they suspect fraud.
In California, the Kaiser Permanente health plan says it will provide laboratory results next year to patients over the Internet using a personal identification number. Oxford Health Plans has similar safeguards.
"We are continually walking a very fine line" between preserving the confidentiality of patient records and using the information to improve care, said Richard Huber, chief executive of Aetna Inc.
Its Aetna U.S. Healthcare subsidiary says it hopes to have "a significant percentage" of information for consumers on the Internet soon, including benefits data, the status of claims and a way to get approval for referrals to specialists.
The United Healthcare Corporation said it also planned to test an Internet project in October, though it gave no details.
Doctors, for their part, are starting to exchange messages, typically about nonurgent matters, with patients in remote areas and computer-savvy patients everywhere who are willing to risk having some hacker eavesdrop on their cholesterol reports.
Dr. Paul Tang, an internist and researcher at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, said he often received E-mail from patients telling how their blood pressure or allergy medicine was working or describing symptoms and asking whether they should come to the office. "One hundred percent of my patients would rather have communications with me any time of day or night," he said, "than worry about the small risk that someone would intercept any message."
Physicians at Columbia University are testing an electronic program that will allow patients with chronic diseases like asthma and diabetes to see and add to their medical records. Patients type in an identification number displayed on a card that resembles a smarter version of an A.T.M. card. A machine receives and automatically verifies the number, which changes every 60 seconds.
"We're trying to prove that there are big benefits" to the patients by involving them more deeply in their treatment, said Paul Clayton, chairman of the department dealing with computerized medical information at Columbia.
Half the respondents to a survey in Boston said they would be interested in communicating with their doctors by E-mail.
This could pose hazards for the doctor. Michael Ackerman, who directs computer research contracts for the National Library of Medicine, said he had heard warnings from "malpractice insurance persons that a written document by a doctor might show up in a court and bite you." But he noted that the same could be said of a tape of a doctor's advice by telephone. "How far are you going to push this stupidity?" he said, expressing exasperation at the intrusion of litigation.
Harvard Pilgrim Health Care, a Massachusetts-based health plan, said it was planning "a secure Web site" in response to members' requests for Internet programs to get lab results, doctors' appointments and prescription drug renewals.
Dr. David Cochran, an associate medical director at Harvard Pilgrim, agreed that "computers have both benefits and risks." He added that "we're not going to jump into" on-line services to patients until other plans get more experience.
Harvard Pilgrim was severely criticized three years ago when it became known that the records of members with mental health problems were widely available to general practitioners. "We learned a lot about patient confidentiality from that," Dr. Cochran said.
Most health plans already have Web pages that provide lists of doctors and hospitals in their networks, and information about staying well. But some began to require a password to look at their lists after they learned rival insurers were snooping and recruiting their doctors.
Blue Cross and Blue Shield of New Jersey even provides street maps showing the primary-care doctor closest to the member. Members of all Blue Cross plans can dial up a list of participating hospitals in 80 countries.
A few plans, like Health Partners in Minnesota and Blue Shield of California, let employers and insurance agents enroll members over the Internet. Blue Shield also has contracts with 18 California companies with 9,000 employees who can select their type of coverage and physicians over an encryption-protected Internet line.
"There's a big difference between security and confidentiality," said A. G. Breitenstein, director of the Health Law Institute, a private nonprofit research center in Boston. "The salient question is: How many people other than the Kaiser member have access to that lab result?"
Information about prescription drugs that may indicate that a patient has the virus that causes AIDS or suffers from depression or male impotence is "bought, sold, disseminated and researched on, all without the patient's consent or knowledge," she said.
The American Medical Association says patients have a basic right to the privacy of their medical information and records, a right that "should be honored unless waived by the patient," Dr. Palmisano said.
It is common for individuals worried about privacy to avoid seeing a doctor who would take notes on their condition. Others pay out of their own pocket for psychotherapy, for example, rather than risk having their insurers or employers know of their problem.
On the other hand, a rigorous requirement for individual consent could cripple the work of epidemiological researchers, who scan thousands of patient records seeking patterns to explain diseases like cancer.
"Privacy is always an issue," said Jay Silverstein, chief marketing officer of Oxford. "We're not in the business of collecting medical records."
Aetna said that in a test over several months, experts from the International Computer Security Association had tried unsuccessfully to breach its privacy safeguards.
Tim Kieschnick, a strategic development manager at Kaiser, said his employees were using industry standards similar to those used in on-line banking to encrypt exchanges between Kaiser and the member. "We are satisfied with it and still improving it," he said, though adding that there was always more to improve.
Part of the fear is that the Internet, which attracts millions of curious cybersurfers every day, could be a breeding ground for horror stories similar to those involving computerized medical records at hospitals and insurance companies.
Tammy Wynette, the country singer, was outraged to find her medical records from the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center reported in two supermarket tabloids. She sued the papers, The National Enquirer and The Star, for invasion of privacy, and the case was settled -- no terms were disclosed -- shortly before she died in April.
Paul Tsongas, the late Massachusetts Senator, complained before he died last year that an insurer had used his computerized medical records without his permission in a training program.
And Nydia M. Velazquez, a Brooklyn Congresswoman, testified at a Senate hearing that records of her treatment several years ago at St. Clare's Hospital in Manhattan, following a suicide attempt, were leaked to newspapers.
"There is a long history of bribing hospital employees to get to the records," said Alan F. Westin, a legal scholar and privacy expert. Even before electronic communication, he said, such records had been misused by blackmailers to discredit rival executives for promotions and by neighbors in personal vendettas.
"We don't yet have adequate security for access to Internet technology," he said.
A number of experts on privacy issues warned that a determined hacker could probably get into protected records. But several privacy specialists said that most interlopers would have little interest in medical insurance claims.
The economic payoff from breaking into health care records is "a lot less than for banks," said Dr. Clayton of Columbia. "A hacker in Holland probably wouldn't gain any economic benefit from knowing that my syphilis test was positive," he said.

HEADLINE: British Petroleum Is Buying Amoco in $48.2 Billion Deal

BYLINE: By YOUSSEF M. IBRAHIM

DATELINE: LONDON, Aug. 11

 BODY:
British Petroleum P.L.C. announced today that it would acquire the American oil giant Amoco for $48.2 billion in stock in the largest oil industry merger ever.
The deal would also be the largest takeover of an American company by a foreign concern. 
 If approved by regulators and by shareholders of both companies, BP Amoco, as the company is to be known, would be the world's third-largest multinational oil company in terms of net income after the Exxon Corporation and the Royal Dutch/ Shell Group of Companies.
Consumers in the United States are unlikely to feel any immediate effects of the deal. Prices at gas pumps are mostly dependent on world oil supplies, which are currently plentiful. And while the consolidation of gasoline outlets may slightly decrease retail competition, the combined exploration prowess of the companies could eventually result in larger supplies of crude oil.
Executives at other oil companies said that the deal benefited both B.P. and Amoco. The main strength of British Petroleum, they said, is in looking for and finding oil reserves. But the company is weak in the business of refining oil into products and chemicals and distributing it to consumers, operations at which Amoco excels.
"The strength of Amoco is in areas that are lacking at B.P. such as the natural gas reserves which it possesses and petrochemicals," Andrew Avramides, an oil consultant in London, said. "The merger brings these assets into a larger, far more comprehensive structure, making BP Amoco a true giant with enhanced structures."
The merger will allow the companies to consolidate their spending on exploration, which would exceed that of Exxon and Royal Dutch/Shell. In addition, officials of both companies said the deal would allow them to become more competitive in regions like the former Soviet Union, China and Latin America, where competition has increased as companies seek new sources of revenue.
Analysts and deal makers alike said the announcement could set off a wave of consolidation in oil companies not unlike that seen in the financial services and telecommunications industries. Until now, the major players in the oil industry have relied on joint ventures, rather than comprehensive acquisitions, to increase profitability.
Companies that might consider moves now are the Mobil Corporation, the Chevron Corporation and Texaco Inc., all of which saw their stocks rise today despite a general downdraft in the American stock markets.
People close to the talks said that the chief executive of British Petroleum, Sir John Browne, approached the chairman of Amoco, H. Laurance Fuller, in late spring about a possible merger. Sir John believed that consolidation was inevitiable and, an executive close to the deal said, "Both of these guys said if we don't pick a partner, we are going to be last."
It is expected that the merger will take months to be approved by regulators, although there are no obvious impediments to the deal's structure.
A Justice Department spokesman said: "A merger of this magnitude has to come under review. We will be looking at it."
The two companies employ a total of 99,450 workers worldwide. Amoco, with 43,450 total employees, expects to cut 5,000 to 6,000 jobs, but none in its Chicago headquarters, Dan Dietsch, the company's media relations adviser, said. A spokesman for B.P. said the company planned to cut about 1,000 jobs in Cleveland when refining and marketing operations there are moved to Chicago. Other cuts are expected at Amoco's research offices in Houston.
Amoco and B.P. said that Chicago would be the headquarters for the new company's North American operations in refining, marketing and transportation, "and, in due course, the worldwide chemicals business." Amoco is the fourth-largest company in the Chicago area.
Today's merger announcement coincided with another significant drop in oil prices on world markets, which are flooded with supplies. Producers have been hurt by the economic slowdown in Asian economies, a mild winter and overproduction by the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries.
As the deal was announced in London this afternoon, the average oil price around the world hit a 10-year low at about $10 a barrel, which, adjusted for inflation, is lower than the price of oil 25 years ago.
Senior oil executives and analysts alike stressed that the move by British Petroleum must be looked at as a strategic decision transcending the fluctuations in the price of what remains one of the world's most essential commodities and a vital element of economic growth worldwide. Mr. Avramides said that today's low oil prices were "not a permanent condition."
David Mayhew of Cazenove & Company, a London brokerage firm, said that no company could ignore current oil prices, but added that "this move provides considerable economic and financial benefits in the long run; it makes a great deal of sense."
Sir John, who will head the new company as its chief executive, said the merger was forced by the need for economies of scale and by increasing competition in a global economy.
"International competition in the industry is already fierce and will grow more acute as new players emerge," Sir John said at a news conference today. "In such a climate the best investment opportunities will go increasingly to companies that have the size and financial strength to take on those large-scale projects that offer a truly distinctive return."
In an interview later, he added: "People always ask me if such mergers are good for consumers. Competition always is good for consumers. It is also exciting and challenging. This deal moves us into the super-league and provides the prospect of real competition for those already in it."
Sir John said that the merger would bring some $2 billion in savings as the companies eliminated redundancies and consolidated divisions.
The merger ranks as the world's largest combination of industrial companies, surpassing the $36 billion acquisition of the Chrysler Corporation by Daimler-Benz A.G. of Germany announced in May, and it is the sixth-largest merger of any type.
Both parties in the merger descend at least in part from John D. Rockefeller's Standard Oil empire, which was split up in the early part of this century by the United States Supreme Court. BP America was the former Standard Oil of Ohio Company, and Amoco was created from Standard Oil of Indiana.
A senior oil executive in Kuwait, a country that holds about 7 percent of B.P.'s shares, hailed the deal. "Over the past decade they have gone through a major rationalization process cutting costs, staffing, increasing their reserves of oil worldwide and their efficiency," the Kuwait official, who insisted on anonymity, said in an interview in London.
B.P. will exchange American depository receipts equivalent to 3.97 of its shares for each Amoco share. B.P. closed Monday at 7.73, making the value of the deal $50.15 for each Amoco share, or $48.2 billion based on 964,406 million Amoco shares outstanding.
By the close of trading today, B.P. shares had increased 22 pence in London, to 7.95, raising the value of the takeover to $49.7 billion. Shares of Amoco, which had closed at $41 on Monday, climbed as high as $52.125 in early trading before closing today at $46.875 on the New York Stock Exchange.
The board of the new company, which will be based in London, will have 13 B.P. directors and 9 from Amoco. Amoco must pay $950 million if it breaks the agreement; B.P. will have to pay $1 billion if it backs out. Although both companies strove today to represent the deal as a merger, analysts tended to look at it as an acquisition by B.P., which will control 60 percent of the new company. British Petroleum will also assume $4.86 billion in long-term Amoco debt.
The combined company will have 9.2 billion barrels of crude oil in reserves. Amoco has been struggling recently to refocus its growth overseas in an effort to move away from the saturated American market. The company sold about one-third of its domestic oil and natural gas properties last year. By buying Amoco, B.P. also acquires 9,300 retail gasoline outlets. The new company will also be the largest natural gas producer in North America. If completed, the merger would make B.P. the largest company in Britain, supplanting the pharmaceutical manufacturer Glaxo Wellcome.
For the first six months of the year, Amoco's net income fell to $673 million from $1.3 billion a year ago and revenues dropped to $15.4 billion from $17.6 billion.
Share prices of United States oil companies have been battered this year because of overproduction by world oil producers and falling demand from Southeast Asian countries. Amoco's stock, which was split earlier this year, is down 12 percent from a year earlier.
British Petroleum was advised by J. P. Morgan & Company and the law firm of Sullivan & Cromwell. Amoco was advised by Morgan Stanley Dean Witter and the Wachtell Lipton Rosen & Katz law firm.

HEADLINE: THE MARKET TURMOIL: THE OVERVIEW;
Asia Crisis Takes Toll On U.S. Stocks

BYLINE: By GRETCHEN MORGENSON

 BODY:
Stocks buckled yesterday as investors grew increasingly fearful that sickly Asian economies would drive down corporate earnings at United States companies in the second half of the year.
The Dow Jones industrial average lost 1.3 percent on the day, closing at 8,462.85. That puts the average 9.3 percent below its July 17 high of 9,337.97 and within shouting distance of a 10 percent correction. 
 Unlike last Tuesday's 300-point decline, which came on a day with little in the way of news, yesterday's drop came amid a raft of fresh and frightening world developments. First was an indication that the Asian typhoon appeared to be gathering speed. Japan's Economic Planning Agency said in a monthly report that the country's worst slump since World War II was deepening; this sent the Japanese yen plunging to 147.35 to the dollar, setting an eight-year low.
The yen is crucial to world markets because the further it falls, the greater the fear that China will devalue its currency, causing another round of devaluations across the Pacific Rim. Japan's Nikkei 225 index fell 219.43 points yesterday, or 1.4 percent, and in Hong Kong, the Hang Seng index lost 3.6 percent. Malaysia's stock index fell to its lowest level in 10 years.
 Asian markets were steadier on Wednesday. The Nikkei was virtually unchanged in afternoon trading, while the Hang Seng was up six-tenths of 1 percent at midday.
The situation in Russia worsened as well yesterday as investors, concerned that the Russian Government would not be able to meet its debt payments this year, fled the country's stocks and bonds. Latin American stocks reeled as well.
By the time all this news had registered with United States investors -- around 10:30 A.M. -- the Dow was down 220 points. At its low point, it had lost 254 points, or almost 3 percent. By the end of the day, a buying spree in oil stocks brought the average back a bit to close down 112 points.
Once again, smaller stocks took bigger hits yesterday than their large-capitalization brethren. The Nasdaq composite index lost 46.51 points, or 2.53 percent.
By all accounts, investors seemed to watch the day's events warily but without panicking. Several mutual fund companies reported that the heaviest selling took place in the morning. According to John Woerth, a spokesman for the Vanguard Group, buyers began returning to equity funds shortly after noon.
But not everybody was willing to buy on this particular market dip. One stockbroker in St. Louis reported a distinct mood change among his clients. Last Tuesday, when the Dow dipped nearly 300 points, the bargain hunters came out in force. But they were on the sidelines yesterday.
In any case, the consensus du jour among Wall Street analysts -- that a bear market cannot begin unless interest rates rise or a recession looms -- lost much of its credibility yesterday. "The earnings side of the stock market is really starting to deteriorate rapidly," said Richard Bernstein, chief quantitative strategist at Merrill Lynch in New York. "We are in a profit recession where we will have zero or minus 10 percent earnings growth this year. That's what we think the market is seeing here."
Indeed, three elements began to sink into the investor psyche yesterday. One was that the continuing deterioration in Asia means corporate earnings among American companies in the second half will not bounce back as Wall Street's Pollyanna analysts continue to claim. Although hard data to support this belief will not be available for quite some time, anecdotes about declining sales at a variety of American companies are spreading. The stock market is picking up this buzz.
Yesterday's developments in Russia also seemed to show that investors are increasingly skeptical about governments' ability to stem currency devaluations. Back in June, when the United States Treasury joined the Japanese Government in defending the yen, it was an attempt to stop the Asian contagion dead in its tracks. So much for that idea: the yen is seven-tenths of 1 percent below where it was when the two Governments intervened.
The $22.6 billion bailout of Russia by the International Monetary Fund in mid-July was another line in the sand drawn by Robert E. Rubin, Secretary of the Treasury, and the International Monetary Fund. The bailout was given an initial chance of success by investors hoping to see fiscal reforms across Russia. But Charles A. Peabody, an analyst at Mitchell Securities, said: "The markets are starting to wonder why Secretary Rubin and the I.M.F. have not been successful. The markets fear that they are failing."
But the most troubling view that crept onto investors' radar screens yesterday was that for all the Federal Reserve's concerns about inflation, it could be deflation that ultimately undoes the United States stock market. As investors absorb the possibility of another round of Asian devaluations, so too do they begin to comprehend what a deflationary spiral could bring.
Deflation is disastrous for an economy, as Japan is discovering, because as the prices of goods fall, consumer spending grinds to a halt. People simply wait to buy goods until they feel that the prices will fall no further. What this kind of behavior does to earnings is obvious.
E. Han Kim is professor of finance and international business and director of the Mitsui Financial Research Center at the University of Michigan Business school. Mr. Kim also acted as a financial adviser during the debt negotiations with the Korean Government earlier this year and is a specialist in Asian finance and economies. While last year's devaluations actually benefited the United States economy by keeping prices of foreign goods down and inflation low, he said, American companies would find another devaluation less pleasant.
"Right now we have virtually zero inflation," he said. "So the next thing could be deflation. The chance of a deflationary spiral is greater now. It was really slim before, but is a real danger now."
One reason why even the whiff of deflation scares the daylights out of the stock market is that it is a virtual unknown. The United States economy has not experienced deflation since the 1930's, so few investors know what to expect or how to measure it. "What scares people the most is the unknown," Mr. Kim said.
Economists do know that deflation plays out slowly and insidiously and that the Federal Reserve Board chairman, Alan Greenspan, has little in his arsenal to counteract it. While Mr. Greenspan can curb inflation by slamming on the monetary brakes and raising interest rates, in a deflationary environment the Fed has few levers to pull. The only way to get out of a deflationary period is to contract the supply of goods. This means shutting plants, laying off workers -- anything that will remove excess supply from the economy and restore companies' ability to raise prices of their goods.
So what are the chances that China will devalue its currency? Better and better with each fall of the yen, say market watchers.
Richard Babson, chairman and president of Babson United Inc., an investment advisory firm with $2 billion under management, said: "We expect the Chinese to devalue and unpeg the Hong Kong dollar in the first quarter of next year. If it's a choice between maintaining an international system by not devaluing and having riots in the streets of Beijing, they'll devalue."

HEADLINE: THE CANADIAN BUCK STOPS AT THE BORDER;
Towns in North Country Feel the Pinch Of Their Neighbors' Weak Currency

BYLINE: By IVER PETERSON

DATELINE: OGDENSBURG, N.Y.

 BODY:
It is high summer in the North Country, with the back-to-school shopping season fast approaching. Time for local business people to reminisce about the days not so long ago when the Canadians flocked across the border at this time of year as dependably as the swallows to Capistrano.
"They would show up with empty suitcases and literally no spare clothes, and they would do all their clothes shopping in one afternoon," said Norman V. Garrelts, the president of Hacketts, a local department store here, recalling another North Country store he once managed. "At the end of the day, the parking lot would be covered with empty shopping bags." 
 Lou Williams, the owner of two motels here, remembered: "They would come over on Friday and, basically, party hearty all night and spend all day Saturday shopping. Then they'd shop a little more on Sunday and go home."
Now, the Canadians are staying away. The Canadian dollar has fallen to its lowest level in modern times, and the commercial fortunes of dozens of towns along the border have fallen with it.
It is as if half the people around here had suddenly moved away. Along almost all of the United States-Canada border, the Canadian side is much more populous, and shopping by Canadians, who were drawn across the border by lower sales taxes, longer shopping hours and often more choices, has formed an important part of local markets on the American side.
Since the Canadian dollar began to plummet, however, trips by Canadians to New York State, by far the biggest destination for Canadians, declined by 9.3 percent, to 2.4 million trips in 1997 from 2.6 million in 1996, according to Statistics Canada, a Government agency. Canadian spending in the United States has declined for each of the three consecutive quarters ending in March, the latest figures available.
In the small towns of northernmost New York State, the decline has been even more acute.
"We have three shopping centers, and one is derelict, one is struggling and the third is half-full," Mr. Garrelts said. "We were just over-stored, and it was all based on getting the Canadian dollar."
And if that was not bad enough, Mr. Garrelts suspects that his own American customers, lured by Canadian advertising in newspapers on this side of the border, are beginning to venture north.
"The Canadians aren't dumb," he said. "Now they're advertising in our papers for our customers."
The effects of the Canadian dollar's drop have been felt all along the snaking border, from the Pacific to the Atlantic.
At the Bellisfair Mall in Bellingham, Wash., business is down 5 to 10 percent, said John Bucksbaum, the executive vice president at General Growth Properties, which owns the mall. And Blaine, Wash., which sits right on the Canadian border, seems to be hurting even more.
"Being a border town, we kind of took for granted that all the Canadians would come down," said Anne Fournier, the coordinator for the Blaine Visitors Information Center.
Mickie Blazicevic, a supervisor at Cost Cutters in Blaine -- which Ms. Fournier described as "where Canadians used to go" -- said that even with the discount outlet's lower prices there were fewer Canadians going across the border regularly to buy groceries. And several gas stations in the area have closed.
In Maine, towns that had refashioned themselves as French Canadian tourist destinations, complete with signs in French, are also feeling the pinch, said Vaughn Stinson, the executive director of the Maine Publicity Bureau. "It's really been very, very soft," he said. "They have just not come in the numbers this year."
For most Americans, the decline in Canadian spending in the United States may mean little more than a drop in the number of Canadian quarters, pennies and dimes that show up in their pocket change.
But people in the North Country, as the four New York counties that border the St. Lawrence River are known, are connected to Canada as much as or more than they are to the rest of the state. And they have been that way since before Gov. Daniel Tompkins, in 1808, sent the New York militia to defend the customs house at Ogdensburg from irate smugglers on both sides of the river.
After all, Syracuse, the closest American city, is three and a half hours away by car, while Albany is four and a half hours, and New York City, nine. But Ottawa, with a million residents, is less than one hour from the river, and Montreal, a little more than two.
"We are oriented toward Canada, absolutely," said Ram L. Chugh (pronounced choodge), a professor of economics and director of the Rural Services Institute at the State University College at Potsdam. "Our commercial relations are not only with Canada, but our major cultural, sophisticated and important urban areas are Ottawa and Montreal. We even go to Ottawa when we want to fly to the U.S.A."
Per-capita income in the four New York counties bordering the St. Lawrence River -- Jefferson, St. Lawrence, Franklin and Clinton -- is among the lowest in the state, averaging $14,700 a year, compared with $24,900 for the entire state. The average unemployment rate in 1997 was 8.1 percent, compared with 5.5 percent for the whole state, although the impact of lost Canadian trade on employment has been offset in the far north by state prison construction and Federal military base spending in recent years.
Not surprisingly, people here follow the value of the Canadian dollar the way farmers watch the weather. And what they have seen has been troubling.
Driven down by the low worldwide demand for Canadian commodities, which is partly a function of the Asian economic crisis, the value of the Canadian dollar has fallen from a high of 89.3 cents in American money in 1990 to 66 cents, a loss of 26 percent of the Canadian dollar's purchasing power in the United States.
Traffic on the Ogdensburg Bridge to Canada reflects the widening disparity between the two dollars. Bridge crossings hit a peak of 866,000 in 1991-92, when the Canadian dollar could still hold its own, but has declined without interruption each year since, to 517,000 crossings both ways in 1997.
"First it was a 10 percent difference and then it was 20 percent, and it just got harder and harder to market to the Canadians," said Mr. Williams, the motel owner who is also president of the Ogdensburg Chamber of Commerce. When times were good, Mr. Williams said, 30 to 40 percent of his customers were Canadians, and American wedding receptions had to clear out of his restaurant by 6 P.M. to make way for the Canadians. Now, he said, perhaps 5 percent of his trade is with Canadians, and newlyweds can linger at their parties.
For a while, as the Canadian dollar slid, American businesses tried to keep their Canadian customers by giving them, in effect, a discount. Signs saying, "Canadian at par," offered equal value for both currencies at many stores. Informal discounts are still common -- Mr. Williams gives Canadian customers 75 cents for their dollar, instead of the market's 66 cents -- but the advantage has clearly moved across the river: "$1.00 U.S. = $1.50 Canadian," says an advertisement for Young's clothing store in Prescott, Ontario, that ran in local American papers.
The loss of so much of Mr. Williams's business is not just a theoretical problem for Ron Dashnow, a handyman who often works for him. For one thing, Mr. Dashnow's wife, Sue, lost her job at a Canadian paper goods plant in Ogdensburg when the plant moved back across the border a year ago, chased home by the rising cost of paying employees in American dollars, Mr. Dashnow said. And Mr. Dashnow is no longer sure Mr. Williams will need him to put a new roof on one of his motels.
"If Lou doesn't get the trade, I'm not going to get a job putting that roof on -- it just goes down the line," he said.
Do not blame Bobbie White, an 18-year old from Wallpole, Ontario, who was on the American side the other day not to shop, but to hunt for a job that pays in American dollars. "To me, the way the dollar has gone means 'Stay on the Canadian side,' " Ms. White said. "Everybody used to come over here to shop all the time -- there were these long lines at the border going back -- but not anymore."
"Now you need that almighty American dollar," her father, Robert, a police officer, said with rueful good cheer.
Ms. White's first stop in job-hunting was at a sparkling, 500,000-square-foot mall built in Massena, 35 miles east of here, to capture Canadian business. The St. Lawrence Centre -- even the spelling is Canadian -- opened in 1990, when the Canadian dollar stood at nearly 90 cents in American money and as the Canadian Government was about to impose the widely detested 7 percent national sales tax, the Goods and Services Tax.
"Because of all of those factors, the Canadians were basically flocking to the U.S.," said Ron Patnode, director of marketing for the mall. "Our license plate count showed that 40 to 50 percent of our shoppers were Canadian, but then it began to decline."
The mall's license plate census hit 10 percent Canadians in 1995, Mr. Patnode said, but it has come back some to about 20 to 22 percent. "They're still coming, but it's not like it was before," he said.
"I used to go the Massena mall," said Rosa Spagnola, a Canadian from Prescott who recently graduated from Clarkson College in Potsdam. "It was new, it was American -- that was definitely part of the psychology. But I pretty much shop on the other side now -- a loyal Canadian."

SECTION: Section F; Page 8; Column 1; House & Home/Style Desk

HEADLINE: DESIGN NOTEBOOK;
Barbecue Pits for Those With Money to Burn

BYLINE: By Donna Paul 

 BODY:
SMOKE gets in their eyes -- and that's only part of the attraction. Once man cooked over an open fire in a cave. Some time later came the 1950's backyard grill, a mammoth creation etched on the landscape in brick or stone. In the 60's, more mobile chefs, or those without backyards, swore by their portable hibachis and Weber kettle grills. And then came the 80's and the portable gas-fired grills that turned summer cookery into something as romantic as, say, lighting the kitchen range.
And now? After two decades of growth, the American economy has brought a return to the backyard barbecue. Fire-hungry homeowners who want to keep up with the Dow Joneses are moving beyond rusty iron grills to a new generation of built-ins. They want fish baskets, wood-fired pizza and bread ovens, smokers and rotisseries. They may even want a designer fire pit. 
 That's because the experience of cooking over wood or charcoal is powerful. "The mingling of the fragrances with the air, the unique quality of the smoke and the aroma of charcoal is very healing and purifying," said Barrie Kavasch, a Native American food historian who maintains that fire is "emotionally magnetic."
Whether it's done in a primitive oven in a hole in the ground or in a rooted-in-stone artisanal outdoor command post of the sort that is becoming popular today, cooking over fire is in fact booming. Steven Raichlen, author of "The Barbecue! Bible" (Workman, 1998), says he believes that the "grill mania" sweeping the country is a reaction to the high-tech lives people are living. "Grilling has a timelessness about it," he said. "It appeals to a primal yearning for fire-cooked food."
In Hamilton, Mass., a seaside town north of Boston, a tall stone fireplace has a shiny stainless-steel grill and a fancy rotisserie. Its owner, Frank McClelland, a chef in Boston, lives in a new house, built a year ago, along with the outdoor hearth. "I wanted to experience the great pleasure of cooking outside during the spring, summer and fall months," Mr. McClelland said.
Frank Martin, the owner of Martin Grill and Oven Works, in Providence, R.I., recently made a fish basket for Mr. McClelland that attaches to the rotisserie. Mr. Martin said that the demand for expensive outdoor cooking areas is increasing and that outdoor ovens for the home have risen to 20 percent of his business, from 5 percent five years ago.
Alice Ross, a food historian who has taught courses in historical cookery in Smithtown, N.Y., for 20 years, noticed the change about two years ago. "All of a sudden there was an interest specifically in building brick ovens and learning how to bake and cook in them," Ms. Ross said. The demand was so great that she has added a course on the subject.
When Mr. McClelland and his family moved to Hamilton from an apartment above his Boston restaurant, L'Espalier, he hired Peter Giordano, who describes himself as a muratore. (The word is Italian for mason.) Mr. Giordano, born in Palermo, Sicily, has been building with stone since he was 14. Now 53, he and his son Peter Jr., 26, built a fireplace for Mr. McClelland that is an update of a traditional design.
The fireplace is made primarily of local field stone. The stone chimney and grill area are built on a brick base; counters and the grill are standard height, 36 inches. High-quality iron spot bricks, which cost $1.35 apiece as against 40 cents for standard bricks, was chosen. The top of the chimney is made of the same bluestone as the surrounding terrace, and a food preparation area is also made of bluestone.
Although the design is simple and timeless, it includes modern modifications, particularly inside the fireplace. For the walls, the masons used cement blocks rather than solid stone. "If we would have built this using the ancient method, we would have had 12- to 16-inch solid walls on both sides," Peter Giordano Sr. said. Instead they determined that stone veneer over cement blocks would be more efficient and less expensive. Yet, the cost for the fireplace still ran about $5,000, or $35 a square foot.
Worth it, Mr. McClelland said. "When I cook at home, I love to let my hair down," he said. "The idea of coming out here when the weather is cool and roasting game or meat is fantastic."
In Austin, Tex., June and Mark Chandler purchased a house four years ago and found a crumbling outdoor fireplace held together by little more than ivy. They hired Gardens, a local landscape design and construction concern, to recreate and embellish an outdoor cooking area where one had been built 70 years earlier.
Bill Bauer, an architectural designer at Gardens, was inspired by traditional Italian stone techniques to create a new oven, entertainment area, grill and terrace. He said his emphasis was on using stone the way it is supposed to be used. "There is nothing fancy here," he said. "We used the simplest materials: limestone, galvanized metal and pea gravel. What this is really about it is how it is executed."
Using blocks of white Texas limestone measuring 24 by 12 by 6 inches, Mr. Bauer made the walls of the oven tower 12 inches thick. "Stone is meant to be heavy and big and support itself," he said. "In today's world, stone is often used as a veneer. In our construction, all of our stone becomes load-bearing walls."
When the quarry stone arrived, it was in a rough rectangular shape; stonemasons reworked each block by hand to make certain the corners were crisp and straight.
The limestone blocks in the Chandlers' original terrace had been pushed up by tree roots. The masons were able to recycle the blocks for the new terrace; pea gravel was used to fill in where the roots were intruding.
The $2,500 wood-fired pizza oven the Chandlers selected came from Italy in terra-cotta sections. Although they fit together tightly, Mr. Bauer had stonemasons seal the oven entirely with a layer of cement.
The tower that houses the oven looks like a folly sitting in a Tuscan garden. It is 10 feet high with a standing-seam metal roof. Ivy climbs its walls, and the whole thing looks as if it had been on this spot for years.
The terrace is 30 feet square, including the area for the barbecue grill, storage cabinets and galvanized metal counter tops, which won't rust, set along a 19-foot-long limestone wall. Cabinet doors are made of teak and wire mesh. The total cost was about $38,000.
When Donald and Virginia Sohn were renovating a 60-foot-long terrace behind their home in Beverly Farms, Mass., "it seemed to need a fireplace," Mrs. Sohn said. What she had in mind was quite different from what her architect, John Pears, drew for her. Mr. Pears, who was born in South Africa, presented a hybrid of several different fireplaces he had seen in Africa.
"Particularly in Malawi, they don't do structures," he said. "They make a pit in the ground. Here the sunken terrace that already existed became like the pit."
Stone walls surrounded the area, and would provide seating. It was the congeniality of a circle around a fire that inspired Mr. Pears. "Everyone faces inward and looks at each other across this event, while people cook together," he explained. In the end, he adapted an African concept to fit an American life style.
The fireplace consists of a 48-inch circular drum, built with bricks recycled from a chimney in a nearby carriage house. Firewood is stored on a bluestone cap above the drum. The firebox is a conical steel structure that contains the fire. Topping that is a 42-inch rotating steel grill. The grill gently spirals up and down, so food can be raised high when the fire is hot and lowered as it cools. Mr. Pears also designed a circular steel ledge, at counter height, to hold implements, plates and drinks.
Custom fabrication added to the costs. With the architect's design fee, the tab for the Sohns' grill was nearly $15,000. But it was an instant success.
"The first party we had was in October, and the night was brisk," Ms. Sohn said. "As the evening drew on, the crowd sat on the walls around the fireplace."
Whether a fire pit, a pizza oven or a fish basket added to a fireplace well anchored to the land, the new accouterments have attracted fans of entertaining outdoors. "If you are cooking your very chic buffalo burgers on a very chic outdoor grill," said Ms. Kavasch, the food historian, "they do taste better."
 
The Fire Bearers
 
AN outdoor oven is usually dome-shaped and gets as hot as 600 to 700 degrees. Wood is set inside and fired up, and afterward the coals are raked out. Baking is done directly on the oven floor.
"Correct dimensions when building an oven are critical," said Frank Martin, owner of Martin Grill and Oven Works in Providence, R.I. "The door height should be no more than 65 percent of the height to the top of the oven."
Outdoor ovens begin at $5,000. Sources for them include Mr. Martin's company, at (401) 724-1491; Peter Giordano of Gloucester, Mass., (508) 283-2793, and Gardens in Austin, Tex., (512) 467-9934.

People sit around the fire on stone walls when Mrs. Sohn enter tains, as at far left, where she is shown with her son-in-law, Rob Carlson, and his daughter Gillie; MEGA -- Grill -- Frank McCelland workd up the blaze outside Boston (Photographs by Donna Paul for The New York Times)
