PUB-DATE: August 13, 1998

SECTION: Section G; Page 1; Column 1; Circuits 

LENGTH: 2417 words

HEADLINE: Braindump on the Blue Badge: A Guide to Microspeak

BYLINE: By STEVEN GREENHOUSE 

 BODY:
DETROIT and Hollywood have invented scores of words and phrases that have become part of America's speech and psyche. Tail fin, mini-series and sitcom quickly come to mind.
Now that role falls to Microsoft. The company that has shaped the way hundreds of millions of people use computers is helping to shape the way people talk as well, with words like facemail and self-toast and new meanings for terms like dog food and ask. 
 Microspeak is a slangy company jargon made up of dozens of words and phrases commonly used at Microsoft. This Microjargon, which includes word usages unique to Microsoft as well as usages from elsewhere in the high-tech and low-tech worlds, has been documented in an informal lexicon written by current and former workers at the company, based in Redmond, Wash.
At Microsoft, "dog food" means software not fit for public consumption but good enough for internal purposes. "Code warrior" refers to a developer who writes code for software. The workers at the Redmond campus now utter sentences like, "It's kind of a klugey solution, but we don't have the cycles to clean it up."
More than a dozen current and former Microsoft blue badges (permanent Microsoft employees) and orange badges (temporary workers and independent contractors) are among the contributors to the lexicon of Microspeak, which can be seen on the Web at cinepad. com/mslex.htm. Ken Barnes, the principal compiler and editor of the lexicon, was editor of Microsoft's Music Central site when he left the company in June; he gave Circuits permission to reprint some of the definitions.
While the lexicon began life as a semi-underground enterprise, it eventually won some kind of company sanction. The company's corporate newsletter, Micro News, ran a story on it, and it was posted on Microsoft's company Web site in all its irreverence -- around the time that the company, Mr. Barnes said, began creating a similar list of its own. This may prove two things: not only that the lexicon is a good read but also that language is the ultimate software.
 
 
Adminisphere -- Organizationally speaking, the levels starting directly above you, characterized by their general cluelessness about issues you're well versed in and tendencies to make policy decisions that ignore your expert input.
 
Ask -- Used as a noun, preceded by "the," as in, "What's the ask?" which basically means, "What are you asking?" or, "What's the question?"
Bandwidth -- A cumbersome synonym for "time," as in, "I don't have the bandwidth to deal with that issue," but with implications beyond the merely temporal, encompassing the larger issue of mental resources or capacity.
 
Binary problem -- A method of paring down a complex issue to a two-possible-solutions scenario (yes or no, 1 or 0). Described by a resident Microsoft philosopher as "classic MS reductivism" and "clearly an economical way of thinking since it eliminates all need to consider the vast gray area that occupies the psychic space of most issues and problems."
 
Bitstorm -- A volume of traffic on a service high enough to cause the digital equivalent of gridlock.
 
Black hole -- A project requiring infinite amounts of work.
 
Bleeding edge -- Synonym for "cutting edge," with an added implication of the pioneer's vulnerability. Example: "We're really on the bleeding edge with this product. Hope it sells through."
 
Bloatware -- Software that takes up a huge amount of space on your hard drive. Synonym: spacehog.
 
Blue badge -- (Sometimes, slightly derogatorily, blue badger.) Synonym for full-time Microsoft employees, the Brahmins of the deeply ingrained Microsoft caste system, whose card keys have a blue background rather than the orange used for contractors and green for vendors. Derivative terms include "turn blue," meaning to earn full-time status.
 
BOOP -- One of at least 10,000 peculiar-to-Microsoft acronyms. There are so many casually-tossed-off acronyms (most of three letters, like OOF, for Out of Facility) in daily use that there is even an acronym for the concept itself: T.L.A. (three-letter acronym). This particular four-letter acronym is especially disarming; it stands for "Bill and the Office of the President," meaning Bill Gates and his three top honchos. After a reorganization on Dec. 3, 1996, BOOP was replaced by the less-endearing Executive Committee.
 
Bouncing -- Cybernetic equivalent of going off the air for repairs, a new app or other internal tinkering. "The system is bouncing at 4:30 and should be up in 20 minutes."
 
Braindump -- A process by which a departing Microsoft employee or contractor imparts the essential information vital to performing his or her job to the designated replacement. The process normally consumes no more than five minutes immediately prior to the incumbent's departure from the company, nevermore to return.
 
Bug -- All-purpose term for mistake, error, glitch. Despite its universal acceptance, the term is deliberately avoided by Microsoft technical support personnel when referring to Microsoft software. Employed instead are such euphemisms as "issue" or more highly evolved doublespeak terms like "undocumented feature," "challenge" or "design side effect." Company loyalists insist, however, that one reason for this circumlocution is that in Microspeak, "bug" has the all-inclusive definition of any problem or complaint filed about a product, whether valid or not, as opposed to the general usage, which refers only to actual problems.
 
Build -- The drive to complete a project or new version of a product. "The IE 4.0 build is eating up all our dev resources."
Bump -- Synonym for "push back," i.e., readdress an issue after an unsatisfactory or dilatory response. As in "You'll need to bump legal again on the permissions issue."
 
Buttoned down -- Compliment, meaning tightly reasoned, clear, concise, etc. Not often heard of late.
 
Buyoff -- Approval from above; green light. "We need BOOP's buyoff before this project's a go."
C.L.M. -- Three-Letter Acronym for "career-limiting move." Badmouthing adminispheric dictates, no matter how ill-considered, can be a C.L.M.
Context-switch -- A verb, unbelievably, meaning "change subjects." Example: "Enough about outsourcing issues. Let's context-switch to planning the rollout."
 
Crisp -- Well-reasoned, precisely reasoned. Opposite of random.
 
Cycles -- Another approximate synonym for "time," as in, "There aren't enough cycles in the day to drive this issue." Often used in tandem with the verb "burn," as in, "He's really burning a lot of cycles trying to resolve those U.I. issues."
 
Death march -- The long, lingering final countdown to a ship date, involving 16- to 25-hour days, catnaps on couches and plenty of "flat food" (food, mostly from vending machines, that you can slip under people's doors so they can keep working).
 
Disambiguate -- A remarkably unclear way to say "clarify."
 
Drive -- To push; to captain the initiative on a particular issue or project. "Ed is driving the HTML issue for the product."
 
E.O.D. -- Endemic T.L.A. (three-letter acronym) meaning "end of day." Example: "I need your take-away from the off-site by E.O.D. tomorrow."
 
Eye candy -- A commonly used term denoting visually attractive material, analogous to "ear candy" in the music business.
 
Facemail -- Technologically backward means of communication, clearly inferior to voice mail or E-mail. Involves actually walking to someone's office and speaking to him or her face to face. Considered highly inefficient and declasse.
 
Feature -- Euphemism for bug. Dysfunctional attributes in a product are often "explained" away by apologists with the phrase, "It's not a bug, it's a feature." As a result, "it's a feature" became synonymous with "it's a bummer."
 
Feewall -- A barrier of demarcation for financial responsibility. "Does this project fall on our side of the feewall?" translates directly as, "Do we have to pay for this?"
 
Fiber media -- Material published on the hopelessly archaic medium of paper. Example: "Yeah, I used to be a writer in fiber media, but now I'm a content provider in cybermedia."
 
Freeze -- Point in a project's times pan after which no more changes can be permitted. Or, as Cityspeak Dictionary puts it, "Point in product development after which the answer to all great new ideas is no."
 
Generating content -- Writing. "We'll need to hire some content providers to generate content by Milestone 1."
 
Global fix -- A programmatic trick to correct all instances of a recurring error. "Ed's working on a global fix to turn all the commas in the CD-ROM into semicolons."
 
Granular -- Generally used in tandem with the verb "to get," as in, "We need to get granular on this issue," meaning to examine the fine details.
 
Gronk -- The sound of a computer embroiled in bandwidth issues. "I tried to reboot, but my computer just sat there gronking until I had to call Help Desk."
 
Issue -- All-purpose term for practically anything relating to a product, from a particular characteristic or bug to a delicate diplomatic initiative.
 
Klugey -- (Also kludgey; pronounced CLUE-gee.) Clunky, inefficient, inelegant. "It's kind of a klugey solution, but we don't have the cycles to clean it up." Also used in noun form as kluge or kludge.
 
Live -- Odd biomorphic usage, sort of an electronic half-life. "Where will this data live?" means, "Where will this data be located?"
 
Mapping -- Targeting. "Mapping a user group" is synonymous with "targeting an audience."
 
Media -- Content that isn't words. Media can include photos, song clips, illustrations.
 
N.D.A. -- For Nondisclosure Agreement, meaning Keep Your Mouth Shut. A legal document, invoked by Microsoft lawyers for anything more sensitive than setting a lunch date, that allows them to crucify anyone who reveals confidential information.
 
Net -- Summarize. "Ed really knows how to net a presentation." Related command: Net it out, meaning boil it down.
 
New paradigm -- Pompous way of essentially saying "unique": "This Web site establishes a new paradigm on the Net."
Nonlinear -- Becoming nonlinear means becoming irrationally angry. "When he found out the R.T.M. date was slipping, Ed went totally nonlinear."
 
Offline -- A synonym for "in private" or "confidentially"; "Let's take this offline" equals "let's talk about this in private." Often used as a semipolite way of saying, "Shut up about that, you impolitic idiot."
 
OOF -- A T.L.A. (three-letter acronym) that has turned into a word of its own. Stands for "out of office." Historians tell us that OOF originally meant "out of facility." Occasionally used, rather irritatingly, in conversation: "I'm OOF next Friday; you'll have to drive on it."
 
Open the kimono -- A marvelous phrase of non-Microsoft origin, probably stemming from the rash of Japanese acquisitions of American enterprises in the 80's, that has been adopted into the Microspeak marketing lexicon. Basically a somewhat sexist synonym for "open the books," it means to reveal the inner workings of a project or company to a prospective new partner.
Orange badge -- Contractor, temp. From the background color of the photo ID badge-card key used for temporary workers.
 
Own -- To take responsibility for an issue. Ownership is even more serious than drivership; you can drive an issue without owning it, but it's unlikely that you would own it without also driving it.
 
Ping -- A reminder, or (used as a verb, which is slightly more common) to remind: "I need to ping my program manager to get some more test help."
 
Quality bar -- The remarkably flexible level of acceptability in a product. Tends inexorably to drop as the pressure of an impending milestone or other deadline builds.
 
Random -- A pejorative term to describe poorly reasoned analysis. Antonym: crisp.
Randomize -- To distract or throw off track by constantly changing course or emphasizing irrelevant details. "Marketing randomized him by shifting the goalposts every week."
 
Reality distortion field -- When a team deludes itself that it can achieve impossibly tight milestones and solve insurmountable tech problems.
 
Self-toast -- To fatally contradict yourself. Extension of the widespread mainstream usage of "toast" as "history," "dead," "burned out."
 
Showstopper -- A function, object or issue important enough to jeopardize a ship date. In other words, a really big bug.
 
Spec -- Used as both noun and verb: as verb, to analyze a field of information prior to the commencement of a project; as noun, the analysis of that information. Also, a preliminary plan or prospectus. "Ed will spec the song clips to see which ones we need to swap out"; "Ed, have you finished the song-clip spec yet?"
 
Take-away -- Not, as might be suspected, food to go, but impressions gleaned from a meeting or message. "My take-away from his E-mail was that he wasn't ready to drill down yet."
 
Taxonomy of options -- A greatly murkier (and therefore infinitely preferable) way of saying "range of choices."
 
T.L.A. -- Three-letter acronym. A widespread general term in computer-speak, but refined to a way of life (if not a metalanguage) at Microsoft.
 
Touch skin -- Same basic meaning as facemail or face time. A meeting arranged to counter the austerity of communicating in cyberspace. "We flew that guy to Redmond just so we could touch skin."
 
Truline -- (From screenwriting jargon.) One-sentence summary of a project's projected appeal or purpose.
 
Uninstalled -- Fired, canned, dismissed.
 
Vaporware -- A Microsoft classic, dating back to at least the early 90's) and now escaped into the world at large. Software that was conceived (and probably promoted and advertised) but never came to fruition; by extension, a foolish or fanciful conceit.
 
Weasel text -- A message on a Microsoft Web site explaining why a popular feature or option has been discontinued.
 
Weasel user -- What the outside world has learned to label "computer nerd." Specifically, a buyer of a Microsoft product who bombards P.S.S. (the company's customer support apparatus) with constant and generally ludicrous technical complaints.
 
Zero-bug release -- Not, as you might suspect, a version of a software product that's error-free, but a release with the major bugs eliminated, retaining plenty of less significant problems.

GRAPHIC: Photo: Ken Barnes, compiler of a lexicon of slang that Microsoft built, at home in Seattle. (Robert Sorbo for The New York Times)(pg. G9)

HEADLINE: In America;
Don't Flunk the Future

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

 BODY:
The press is drawn irresistibly to that which is loud and destructive. This seems especially true when it comes to leadership in the black community. Persistent, quiet, dedicated work generates little in the way of headlines or air time. But if someone starts making outrageous comments and playing the fool, the reporters will come running.
Hugh Price, President of the National Urban League, is not a noisy man. But he is saying some things that need to be heard. "The data tell us loud and clear," said Mr. Price, "that our children are decaying academically. We say our children equal our destiny. But what destiny awaits us if nearly 80 percent of our youngsters in Denver fail the fourth-grade reading tests, as they did last year?" 
 Delivering the keynote address at the annual Urban League conference, which was held in Philadelphia last week, Mr. Price warned: "The achievement deficits facing our children will be our undoing if we don't reverse them."
His words echoed those of retired Gen. Colin Powell, who said at the N.A.A.C.P. conference in Atlanta last month that there would be no point in preserving affirmative action programs if black youngsters were not prepared academically or socially to take advantage of them.
Both men stressed that a vast field of opportunity is now open to black youngsters in the U.S. But only catastrophe will result if the black community fails to do a better job at what Mr. Price calls "the urgent matter of preparation."
The basic preparation begins long before conception. "We must make certain that our youngsters don't start out behind the eight ball," said Mr. Price. "Yet that's exactly what we do by bringing infants into this world before their parents are mature enough to nurture and provide for them."
He told his audience that at a minimum, just to avoid the scourge of poverty, "There are three things black parents must persuade their teen-agers to do. First, get their high school diploma. Second, get married before having their first child. Third, hold off on having their first child until after they turn 20 themselves."
He said: "Only about 8 percent of children raised in households that follow these rules experience poverty. By contrast, 80 percent of the youngsters in households that ignore these rules end up poor."
Mr. Price was blunt at times in his speech and in a recent interview, but he was not pessimistic. He cited a number of encouraging trends, including the birth rate for unmarried black women, which has reached a 40-year low, and the high school graduation rate of black youngsters, which now equals that of whites.
Still, too many black youngsters are in serious trouble academically, including a large percentage of those who are graduating. And Mr. Price seemed astounded by what he described as the "blase" attitude toward this continuing academic failure.
"We say we want our youngsters to do well in school," he said, "but how involved are we in making certain that actually happens? Blase is the word. There's no other way to describe why we tolerate the lackadaisical attitude of many of our children and the lousy performance of the schools they attend."
He said: "I know I'm butting into other people's personal business. But this is no time for politeness, obliqueness or complacency. There's too much at stake and time is running out -- for our children and, thus, for our people."
Despite the myriad problems that continue to plague African-Americans, Mr. Price believes that the current conditions in the United States offer blacks the "best shot we have ever had to shove ourselves the rest of the way into the American mainstream."
He said: "With unemployment so low, employers are gobbling up almost every willing and able worker with a pulse. Shame on us if we don't seize this historic opening in the economy."
Racial discrimination? It must be fought wherever it still exists, said Mr. Price. But he suggested that the most egregious forms are, in fact, abating. He said, "I think we are moving rapidly toward the day when if you've got something to put on the table, employers aren't going to care what color you are."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: BONDS;
Lower Dollar andSteadier Stocks Hurt Treasuries

BYLINE: By ROBERT HURTADO 

 BODY:
Treasury securities turned slightly lower yesterday, as the dollar fell against the yen before steadying, making dollar-denominated investments like Government securities less attractive to foreign investors.
Also putting some pressure on bonds was the Treasury's $11 billion auction of new 10-year notes, which followed a disappointing auction of five-year notes on Tuesday. Yesterday's auction results turned out to be not as good as hoped. 
 A third factor was that the stock market showed signs of recovery, easing the flight to bonds. Still, bonds held fast after a manufacturing report from the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta suggested the nation's economic growth was slowing and inflation was subdued.
By late in the day, the 30-year bond was down 2/32, to a price of 107 15/32, while the yield was unchanged at 5.60 percent.
Dealers and traders expect the market to remain uncertain through the Treasury auctions this week as investors may be wary, not only of the 10-year note yesterday but also the 30-year bond today, since everything is currently on the high side of the recent price range.
As a result, even though many people believe the dollar will strengthen again and the Asian markets will get worse before they get better, the 10-year issue was awarded at a price to yield 5.428 percent, a little behind what was hoped for, traders said.
Doug Burtnick, managing analyst with Thomson Global Markets, said yesterday's auction, because it was a reopening of an existing issue of 10-year notes, was considered a dealer-driven event, rather than one for smaller investors. "It was better for those wanting to buy large amounts without moving the market," he said.
"The market behaved well late in day because of a rumor that the Russian ruble might be devalued, which spurred a late flight to quality into Treasuries," he said. "Regarding tomorrow's auction of 30-year bonds, the closer we get to a yield of 5.50 percent on the long bond, the harder it is to sell. Dealers might have to cheapen the issue to make it more attractive."
In when-issued trading, the 30-year bond was being offered at a price to yield 5.55 percent.

HEADLINE: Economic Scene;
Rich nation, poor nation. Is anyone even looking for a cure?

BYLINE: By Peter Passell; This is Peter Passell's final Economic Scene column. He is leaving the staff of The New York Times to become editor of the public policy quarterly for the Milken Institute.

 BODY:
MOST economists are most comfortable thinking and writing about what is, or will be. Would cutting the capital gains tax to 15 percent transform couch potatoes into software entrepreneurs? Would 4 percent unemployment lead to inflation? Just ask you friendly, neighborhood Ph.D.
And, truth be known, most economists have a weakness for clever fixes that exploit free markets. Want to prevent the overfishing of coastal waters? Privatize the rights to fish. Want to curb global warming for a fraction of the cost of conserving energy at home? Let Western consumers pay the Chinese and Russians to cut their emissions. 
 But efficiency isn't an end in itself: making more stuff for less gets you only part of the way to the economist's nirvana. And maybe, just maybe, economists -- and other Americans -- are worrying too little about dividing up the spoils.
America's economic system does work better than the obvious alternatives. After all, the socialist utopias collapsed under the cumulative weight of their internal contradictions. Asia's crony capitalism has proved that it isn't ready for prime time. Europe's mixed economies perch on a powder keg of 20 percent youth unemployment -- and can't think of any way out, save for the risky strategy of following the advice of Alexander Hamilton and adopting a common currency.
But the celebration may be getting out of hand. For while the American system is doing many things right, most economists would agree that it is doing one big thing wrong: for the last quarter century, virtually all the bounty of growth has gone to the educated, enterprising and already-affluent.
Not so long ago, growth was seen as the solution to all problems. Competitive markets, the not-so-dismal scientists reminded us, had insured that two-thirds of all income had gone to wages as far back as the division between capital and labor could be measured. Hence, a growing, fully employed economy would mean rising living standards for all.
But since the 1970's, economists have learned that a very nasty devil lurks in the details. While labor still captures about two-thirds of national income, only skilled workers have benefited. And even within this elite, the phenomenon of "winner take all" has increased the gaps between the successful and the also-rans in occupations as diverse as law, plumbing and basketball.
Defenders of business-as-usual argue that the consequences are less than meet the eye. Inequality of consumption, they note, is less extreme than inequality of wages or incomes. Social mobility allows some of the poor to make the leap to the comfortable middle. The earned-income tax credit -- a negative income tax for the working poor -- has offset some of the wage decline of the unskilled. And the elderly, the people traditionally at greatest risk, are generally shielded from poverty by Social Security and Medicare.
But such rationalizations get you only so far in an economy that has grown steadily less egalitarian over the last quarter century. The most comprehensive estimate of income distribution, by Lynn Karoly of the Rand Corporation, shows that the real income of the bottom 10th of American families fell by 13 percent between 1973 and 1995. And Brooks Pierce, an economist at the Bureau of Labor Statistics, has found this growing inequality has been magnified by the decline of company-wide medical and pension benefits.
What could be done to right the imbalance without damaging the engine of economic growth? Probably plenty.
The earned-income tax credit could be expanded. State and Federal tax systems could be tilted, effectively eliminating taxes on the bottom third of the income distribution and making up the lost revenue with modest increases on the top third. Government could take some of the sting out of private income inequality by increasing outlays for communal services -- day care, early childhood education, mass transit, recreation.
What is being done? Precious little. Virtually all recent tax changes have had the effect of allowing the rich to keep more of their earnings. President Clinton's acclaimed effort to make college affordable has funneled the greatest share of the tax breaks to the middle class.
Surprising the skeptics, welfare reform has been successful in cutting dependence. But it is safe to say that tough love gets you only so far. Even its most optimistic supporters concede that the social infrastructure of day care and medical benefits is sorely lacking -- and that roughly one-third of the welfare caseload is hopelessly unprepared for gainful employment.
A decade hence, will hindsight show that American capitalism, too, was drifting toward the ashcan of history? Probably not. But history rarely looks kindly on societies that trumpet their virtues and ignore their failings.

HEADLINE: Boeing to Shift Some Jet Output to Long Beach to Ease Strain

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
Aiming to ease the strain on one of its most troubled production lines in Seattle, the Boeing company plans to announce today that it will begin building some of its single-aisle 737 jets in Long Beach, Calif., beginning next year.
The decision, which has been highly anticipated for months, is good news for workers at the former McDonnell Douglas operations in California, who have seen three of the four airplanes currently built there canceled by Boeing since it bought McDonnell Douglas last year for $16.3 billion. 
 But Boeing executives and union officials acknowledged that the move would only restore about 600 jobs, a fraction of the number that will be lost when production on the discontinued Douglas jets stops in 2000.
Boeing is expected to say that it will start building three of the best-selling 737's a month in Long Beach starting in the second half of next year, possibly rising to as many as five a month after that, said executives who spoke on the condition of anonymity.
The announcement is part of changes to an overall consolidation plan that Boeing first announced in March.
The company is also expected to say that it will transfer some of its satellite operations to California and will make St. Louis the headquarters of all future production of fighter planes.
Neither move will result in the transfer of many jobs. But the St. Louis decision could be significant if Boeing wins the competition to produce the Pentagon's new Joint Strike Fighter.
The company has said that it expects to eliminate between 18,000 and 28,000 of its 238,000 jobs by 2000 but today's announcement is not expected to provide more details on how those targets will be reached.
Boeing officials declined to comment. The move was reported yesterday by The Seattle Times.
The 737 move has been opposed by the International Association of Machinists, who represent 39,000 hourly Boeing workers in the Puget Sound area. Though Boeing now has more orders for the 737 than it can handle and has paid heavy penalties to airlines for missing delivery dates, workers fear that they will lose their jobs if orders dry up in the future.
The machinists' contract is set to expire next year, and Boeing is eager to avoid a strike like the one it suffered in 1995. The situation is complicated by the fact that the machinists' union and the United Automobile Workers union, which represents 7,600 hourly workers at Long Beach and is just as eager to get the new work as the machinists are worried about losing it, are set to merge in the next few years.
An eight-member joint committee led by Frederick C. Mitchell, the Boeing executive in charge of commercial airplane production, and Bill Johnson, the president of the union local, has been meeting in recent weeks to reach some sort of an accord.
One executive who requested anonymity said that the two sides were close to an agreement yesterday but that talks were still being held. Boeing was willing to limit production in California to five planes a month and offer some assurances that there would be no layoffs as a result of the new production line, he added.
The machinists' union did not respond to inquiries yesterday.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS;
Interest Rates Favor U.S. Borrowers

BYLINE: By SHARON R. KING 

 BODY:
One side effect of the financial crisis in Asia is incredibly low interest rates for American consumers.
Because of the region's malaise, demand for computers and their components and a variety of other products is dwindling, putting downward pressure on the earnings of many American companies. But that very damper on growth has made inflation a distant worry and kept interest rates attractive. 
 Long-term interest rates have reached historic lows in recent days, and consumers can largely expect more of the same, according to economists and market analysts.
On Tuesday, the yield on the 30-year Treasury bond touched 5.55 percent, its lowest level since the Treasury Department began issuing bonds on a regular basis in 1977.
Yields fall when investors clamor for bonds and push up their prices. That is what happened on Tuesday as fears increased that Japan's economic recession would worsen and investors fled worldwide equity markets for the relative safety of bonds backed by the United States Government. Yesterday the yield on the 30-year bond was down 2/32 , to a price of 10715/32 , while the yield was unchanged at 5.60 percent.
"The general feeling is that interest rates will remain good and there's not a lot of economic news out there to steer us otherwise," said Greg Lumsden, a managing director of loan originations at Countrywide Credit Industries, one of the nation's largest mortgage loan providers.
Already, home mortgage refinancings have hit their highest levels in years and are expected to continue at a strong pace. The average interest rate on a 30-year mortgage, which started the year at 7.05 percent, is now 6.9 percent, and has been below 7 percent for eight weeks, the longest stretch since 1993, according to Fannie Mae, the nation's largest mortgage provider. Rates are expected to remain in that range through the end of the year, said Robert Barr, a senior economist at Fannie Mae.
If Asia's economic crisis continues to worsen, "our forecast may be a little too conservative," Mr. Barr said, suggesting that rates could fall even further.
Fannie Mae forecasts that $1.33 trillion in mortgages, for home purchases and refinancings, will be made in 1998, up from $834 billion last year. The record was $1.2 trillion in 1993.
The yield on the 10-year Treasury note, increasingly used as a gauge for mortgage rates, rose six basis points, to 5.43 percent yesterday, but remains near its June low of 5.35 percent, also its lowest level since 1993.
Declines in rates for other types of consumer borrowing are even more striking.
Four-year new-car loans are now available from banks at an average rate of 9.05 percent, down from 9.21 percent at the beginning of the year and 9.36 percent a year ago, according to The Bank Rate Monitor.
And bank-issued credit cards offer fixed rates almost two percentage points lower than where they were at the beginning of the year. At this time last year, the average rate was 16.85 percent and it remained at 16.82 at the beginning of this year. At the current rate of about 15.06 percent, a consumer carrying a card with a $1,000 balance who switches to the lower rate from the rate of a year ago could save $200 a year in interest payments.
"The rates for people with good credit continue to go down," Bill Anderson, president of The Bank Rate Monitor, said.
A stellar credit history may qualify consumers for a credit card with a 9.90 percent fixed rate that Capital One Financial began in April or a similar card at 9.99 percent from First USA Inc.
Declining interest rates and fierce competition have also pushed some introductory "teaser" rates for new card holders to as low as zero, from the recent average of about 5.9 percent to 6.9 percent, said Robert B. McKinley, president of Cardweb Inc., a Gettysburg, Pa., research firm that tracks the card industry.
While rates are unlikely to fall much more, credit card rates for consumers with a less-than-rosy credit history are actually wending higher as lenders become more concerned about their own risks in a weakening economic environment, Mr. McKinley said. Credit card issuers are also imposing more stringent restrictions on customers. One late payment, for example, can cause a customer to forfeit a low introductory rate, and late payment fees are rising, he said.
In what is known as the subprime card market, which caters to consumers with low incomes, poor credit or no credit history, rates now run 18 percent to 21 percent, said Spencer Nilson, publisher of The Nilson Report, an industry newsletter.
Low rates on everything from mortgages to auto loans raise a note of caution from some economists.
If the economy slows drastically, consumers may find themselves overextended after taking advantage of today's favorable rates to borrow, Robert Brusca, chief economist at Nikko Securities Company International, said.
"People have called this the Goldilocks economy, but maybe we're getting to the part where Goldilocks meets the three bears," Mr. Brusca said.

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Cautious Buyers,Prowling for Bargains, Lift Dow 90.11

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Once again, the bargain hunters tiptoed back into the stock market yesterday, picking up some of the issues battered the previous day.
This buying of small-company, oil, semiconductor and other beleaguered stocks repeated the pattern that led the stock market to rebound at the end of last week, after the Dow Jones industrial average plunged 299.43 points on Aug. 4, its third-worst point decline in history. 
 But there were also signs of renewed interest in the big-name stocks that have performed well all year, in part because investors viewed earnings reliability as a haven in an uncertain market. This buying helped lift the Dow Jones industrial average by more than 100 points during the day. And it held most of the gains, ending up 90.11 points, or 1.1 percent, at 8,552.96.
Analysts, however, do not seem ready to say the market is out of danger yet. And they point out that much of the market -- especially small-company stocks -- is already in a bear market, having fallen more than 20 percent in value.
"It is too much to expect the market to reach the bottom on this leg," said Byron R. Wien, United States investment strategist at Morgan Stanley Dean Witter. "First you have a frightening down leg, a recovery from that, a relaxation of investor fears, and then another down leg." That, he concluded, means there could be more trouble in October, the time of last year's record one-day point decline in the Dow. His forecast for the Dow at year-end is 8,000.
Jeffrey M. Applegate at Lehman Brothers is more optimistic, forecasting the Dow at 9,900 at year's end, which would give the Dow an unprecedented four years in a row of double-digit gains.
Still, he said, the market faces trouble ahead, in part because Japan has yet to prove that it can get its economy back on track. "You can't say we are out of this rolling correction yet," he said.
The Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks rose 15.24 points, or 1.4 percent, to 1,084.22. Although both the Dow and the S.& P. regained most of their Tuesday losses, they are still down 8.4 percent and 8.6 percent, respectively, from their July highs.
As has been the case in the few days of recovery recently, the Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks and the Nasdaq index, with many high-technology stocks, outperformed the marquee indexes. The Russell rose 7.95 points, or 2 percent, to 408.55, while the Nasdaq climbed 32.83 points, or 1.8 percent, to 1,825.53. They are 16.9 percent and 9.4 percent, respectively, below their highs.
The buying yesterday was prompted in part by a reversal in the Japanese yen, which rallied against the dollar after hitting an eight-year low on Monday. This led to a mixed day for stocks in Asia -- which was better than usual -- and a rally in Europe before Wall Street opened.
"Just any day tell me what the dollar-yen is doing, and I will tell you what U.S. equities are doing," said Mr. Applegate of Lehman Brothers.
But Latin American stocks continued to plunge, despite the yen's rally. The Bovespa index in Brazil fell 4.4 percent and the Mexican Bolsa index dropped 1.9 percent. Both markets were rattled by growing fears that Russia would be forced to devalue the ruble, adding to the pressure on other emerging market currencies.
World markets have been following the movements of the yen recently because it is a signal of the continued weakness of the Japanese economy. American officials say Japan must turn its economy around to lead Asia out of it year-old economic crisis. Only then will Asia's drag on the American economy and corporate earnings be eased.
In addition, the weak yen has focused attention on the possibility of a devaluation by China, a move that would deepen the Asian crisis.
The yen, which finished in New York at 146.44, rallied after Japanese officials indicated overnight that the Government was prepared to intervene in the currency market to support the yen if its decline accelerated. On Tuesday, the yen fell to 147.35 to the dollar, surpassing the 146.78 low it hit before the surprise intervention to support the yen by the United States and Japan in June.
This kind of official jawboning can slow a decline temporarily. But currency traders do not seem overly concerned. Japan's intervention alone to support the yen this spring had almost no lasting impact. And the surprise intervention with the United States on June 17, while effective at the time, did not support the yen for long because Japan did not take the policy actions investors think are needed to deal with the nation's banking problems and to stimulate the economy.
General Electric and Wal-Mart Stores led the Dow higher. G.E., off 11.6 percent after the Dow hit its record high of 9,337.97 on July 17, rose 2 1/16, to 89 3/8. Wal-Mart, which announced a 30 percent surge in earnings on Tuesday, jumped 2, to 66.
And then some stocks have just continued to rise, bucking the market's trend. Apple Computer, whose stock is up 205 percent this year, rose 1 1/16 yesterday, to 40 1/16; it had risen 8.6 percent since the Dow began to plunge.
The performance of American Express yesterday was another indication of how hard it is to rebound in the current environment. It has been one of the best-performing stocks in the Dow this year, although only a middling performer when included among the stocks in the S.& P. 500.
It announced last week that the crisis in Asia would cut into its revenue in the second half of the year, and the stock dropped 6.8 percent in one day. Since hitting a high for the year of 117 7/8 on July 14, American Express had plunged 16.4 percent through Tuesday. Yesterday, it jumped as much as 2 3/4, or 2.8 percent, to 101 1/4. But by the end of the day it had given up most of its gain, rising just 1/8, to 98 5/8.

HEADLINE: Investigating Disappearance, Police Seek Man For Questioning

BYLINE: By MICHAEL COOPER 

 BODY:
Detectives trying to untangle the case of the Upper East Side widow who vanished last month are now focusing on trying to track down a traveling companion of the prime suspects in the case, Sante and Kenneth Kimes.
The police said yesterday that they hoped the man, Jose Antonio Alvarez, 24, would be able to shed light on the disappearance of the widow, Irene Silverman, 82, who was last seen on July 5 and is presumed dead. 
 Mr. Alvarez, who immigrated to the United States from Cuba in 1994, apparently met the Kimeses on about May 14 in West Palm Beach, Fla., and drove with them to New York, Police Commissioner Howard Safir said.
"It is not unusual, based on the information we've developed," Mr. Safir said, "for the Kimeses to attach themselves to various people who are either unemployed or down on their luck."
Mr. Safir said that Mr. Alvarez and the Kimeses arrived in New York on June 14, and that Mr. Alvarez was later seen in Mr. Kimes's apartment in Mrs. Silverman's town house and at dinner at the Pierre Hotel with the Kimeses. Mr. Safir emphasized that Mr. Alvarez was wanted for questioning as a witness, not as a suspect.
Detective Tom Clark, of the Police Department in Manalapan, Fla., near West Palm Beach, said Mr. Alvarez had a residence in another nearby town, Belle Glades, and had been doing various odd jobs when he began keeping company with Mr. Kimes and his mother.
Detective Clark said the Florida authorities believe that Mr. Alvarez may have helped the Kimeses buy an $80,000 mobile home with bad checks. The Kimeses made an appointment to buy the 36-foot-long mobile home with certified checks on a Friday afternoon at the Ritz-Carlton Hotel in West Palm Beach. By the time the checks bounced on Monday, Detective Clark said, the Kimeses had a 72-hour head start in their new vehicle.
The Kimeses are being held in New York on charges of credit card fraud and passing a bad check in Utah to buy a Lincoln Town Car, which Mr. Safir said investigators believe the Kimeses and Mr. Alvarez drove to New York. Those charges are unrelated to Mrs. Silverman's disappearance.
Detectives and prosecutors have said they suspect that the Kimeses killed Mrs. Silverman as part of a scheme to swindle her out of her town house on East 65th Street. But building a case against them has been difficult because no body has been found and neither of the Kimeses has talked with investigators.
Mr. Safir said that although Mr. Alvarez has not been seen since June 22, the police have no reason to believe he has been the victim of foul play. "He may be able to provide valuable information about the Kimeses' activities here in New York," he said, urging anyone with information on Mr. Alvarez's whereabouts to call the police confidential phone line, (800) 577-TIPS.
Mel A. Sachs, a lawyer representing Kenneth Kimes, said he hoped Mr. Alvarez is found soon. "When this individual, Jose Antonio Alvarez, is located," he said, "it will clearly show that Sante and Kenneth Kimes had absolutely nothing to do with the disappearance of Mrs. Silverman."

HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: Market Place;
Amid Market Turmoil, Small Investor Is Steadfast

BYLINE: By DAVID BARBOZA 

 BODY:
The selling was furious early Tuesday. By 1:30 P.M., the Dow Jones industrial average was down 257 points. And while stocks recovered late in the day, the session, the fifth busiest on record, came after a week that had the second- and third-heaviest trading days on record. This surge in activity raises a question: Who exactly is moving the market this summer?
The answer: institutional investors, the same powerful group that sold aggressively last October, when the Dow tumbled 554 points, or 7.2 percent, in a single day. And the same big-time players who have soured repeatedly on the bull market, only to jump back in later, after smaller investors have quietly affirmed their faith. 
 "The institutions are busy -- they're real busy, there's no question about it," said Bill Allyn, director of listed trading at Jefferies & Company in New York, which handles large institutional trades. "There's a lot of blood being spilled."
At the same time, small individual investors have continued to open new brokerage accounts and to buy beaten-down shares, according to executives at mutual fund companies, discount brokerage firms and market analysts.
So this summer, when most investors would be expected to be lounging on a beach somewhere, professional traders and portfolio managers are selling aggressively, presumably on fears about slowing profit growth at home and economic turmoil in Asia. They are also shaking up their portfolios, trying to find ways to beat the leading stock indexes, and engaging in huge program trades, which are growing as a percentage of all trades, according to the New York Stock Exchange.
In fact, in recent weeks computer-driven program trades have accounted for nearly 18 percent of all Big Board volume, up from 10.7 percent just eight years ago. (A program trade consists of a trade of 15 stocks worth at least $1 million).
The statistics may help explain why volume is so heavy this summer, but also why the market may not tumble in October-like fashion: because a huge majority of smaller investors have apparently not yet jumped onto the frenzied selling bandwagon by aggressively redeeming shares at mutual funds.
Of course, reliable statistics about trading activity are inexact and difficult to come by because the identity of most trading is largely secret. But there is a trickle of information that exists about who is trading, and it suggests that institutions (hedge funds, mutual fund companies and brokerage houses) have done the bulk of the selling for the last few weeks, creating a big downdraft in the markets.
Small, individual investors -- while also jittery about corporate earnings and the Asian economic crisis -- have been holding steady, just as they did last October.
"The great majority of small investors have done nothing," said Tracey Gordon, a spokeswoman for Charles Schwab & Company, one of the nation's largest discount brokerage firms. "They stick to the market like Velcro."
Concern among smaller investors has certainly been heightened this summer because of market volatility. But brokers say that investors are showing few signs of panic.
"We've seen a lot more rational behavior than we've seen in the past," said Kathy Levinson, chief operating officer of E-trade, a fast-growing on-line brokerage firm. "So while the market has been going down, people have not been panicking."
The idea that institutional investors have been less bullish in these last few weeks is borne out in a study conducted this week by Birinyi Associates, a market research firm in Greenwich, Conn. In the period between July 24 and Aug. 11, large institutions have been more aggressive sellers of stocks than smaller investors, according to a study of stock money flows into the New York Stock Exchange.
Analysts at Birinyi Associates did this by tracking large block trades -- those of 10,000 shares or more -- against smaller trades of fewer than 10,000 shares, which include, for example, an investor's purchase of 100 shares of I.B.M. Through Tuesday, the study showed, retail trades created about $731 million in net buying on the Big Board, while block trades accounted for $3.47 billion in selling. The bottom line: institutions sold and smaller investors bought.
"The key to this market is the retail investor," said Jeffrey Rubin, an analyst at Birinyi Associates. "The retail investors are the ones who have been really correct about this market. And the institutions haven't been right."
A survey of several brokerage firms this week concluded that smaller investors were nervous after the Dow tumbled 299 points on Aug. 4, and then fell 257 points in the first hours of Tuesday's session. But investors did not aggressively trade so much as inquire.
"We've seen an increase in call volume, but most of the calls are more service-related," said Beth Basilio at the Dreyfus Corporation, noting that people often inquired about the market's recent performance.
And at a Schwab branch office in Manhattan, the week has been anything but tumultuous. Even during Tuesday's steep decline, the office consisted of just a few stragglers, investors checking quotes at a computer bank and cheering on the market as it reversed course. "It's going up; it's going up," said one investor, who refused to give his name. "We've gone up 100 points in 10 minutes."
Mo Kraushar, a 42-year-old computer expert, said he wasn't planning on selling stock. "I'm not moved one way or another," he said tapping away at a computer to check quotes. "I'm a fundamental kind of guy. I just kind of chuckle at it all. It's like a sporting event."
Another measure of individual investor sentiment lies in the on-line trading arena, where about 20 to 25 percent of all retail trading occurs, according to Bill Burnham, an electronic commerce analyst with Credit Suisse First Boston.
On-line trading has more than doubled in the last year, to about 15 million shares a day, but on-line trading executives say that trading activity has not been unusually high this month.
"The on-line firms are contributing, but their contribution is being overshadowed by the huge volume coming out of hedge funds and other professional market speculators," Mr. Burnham said. "Ultimately, the retail investor can have an impact on the margins, but at a macro level, nothing has the power to move the market like arbitragers and hedge funds."
Last October's huge selloff was much more serious, many analysts say, and it created much more activity, even though average trading volume is actually heavier this month -- about 744 million shares a day, up from about 610 million last October.
Joe Ricketts, chief executive of Ameritrade Holdings, an on-line brokerage firm based in Omaha, said investors continued to open accounts at a steady pace this summer, and that on the day after the Aug. 4 selloff, they were eagerly buying shares using Ameritrade's on-line system.
"We were really busy," Mr. Ricketts said. "The individual investors stepped in to buy that day."
If smaller buyers are active in the market, though, much of that activity may be coming from day traders, individuals who trade professionally and actively each day, and usually close out their positions at the end of the day.
Like many other professional traders, day traders thrive on market volatility, hoping to make large profits in price swings. And with market volatility on the rise -- as a result of concerns about the strength of the bull market -- day traders have been more aggressive than usual, driving up electronic trading volume by about 30 percent, according to James Lee, president of the Electronic Traders Association.
"If there's nothing going on, we won't initiate it, but if there's activity, we'll jump in," said Harvey I. Houtkin, founder of the All-Tech Investment Group in Montvale, N.J., a professional day-trading firm. "If it's an active day, we'll make it even more active."

HEADLINE: Editors' Note

 BODY:
An article last Aug. 20 described the operations of the European Union Bank, an offshore institution based in Antigua. The article said two of the bank's original directors, Aleksandr P. Konanikhin and Mikhail B. Khodorovsky, were officers of the Menatep Bank of Moscow. It quoted unidentified British and American officials who said Menatep had links to Russian organized crime.
In fairness, The Times should have sought a response from Menatep, Mr. Khodorovsky and Mr. Ko nanikhin.
Mr. Khodorovsky has since said the allegations about Menatep were "baseless" and "entirely false." He said last fall that Menatep had earned a B+ rating from Thomson Bank Watch, an international rating service, and had recently gained approval from the Securities and Exchange Commission to sell stock in the United States. He added that the bank had ties to the World Bank and was a "respected, reputable financial institution."
Mr. Khodorovsky said he withdrew as a director of the European Union Bank in 1994, a week after its registration, and played no role in its operations before then.
Mr. Konanikhin said the allegations against him, including an arrest in the United States, visa violations and Russian charges of having embezzled $8 million, resulted from "disinformation" by Russian intelligence, which influenced or duped officials at the United States Department of Justice.
This editors' note was delayed pending the outcome of a lawsuit in London against The International Herald Tribune over the article. The Times was not sued, and the suit has now been settled.

HEADLINE: Text of Solicitation Letter For Legal Expense Trust

BYLINE: By The New York Times 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
Following is the solicitation letter sent to supporters of the President and Mrs. Clinton under the signature of former Senator David Pryor, Democrat of Arkansas, as provided by the Clinton Legal Expense Trust. Those receiving the letter also get a certificate for donors to sign and return with their checks.
 
Letter
In today's political climate, public service can exact a disturbing price. There is perhaps no better example than the financial crisis now facing President and Mrs. Clinton. 
 News reports reflect that to conduct his four-year investigation of the Clintons, the independent counsel already has spent more than $40 million of taxpayer money. And supporters of Paula Jones continue to fund her case on appeal.
Since entering the White House, President and Mrs. Clinton have accumulated almost $5 million in legal expenses -- an amount far beyond the President's total compensation or the first family's net worth. They are personally liable for these bills.
The Clinton Legal Expense Trust has been established to enable supporters of the first family throughout America to help defray these enormous costs. Because you are a supporter of the President, we are writing to ask for your help.
Contributions to the trust can be made by any United States citizen who is not a lobbyist or an employee of the executive branch of the Federal Government.
Contributions from PAC's, corporations or labor organizations are not permitted, and no individual can contribute more than $10,000 per year.
All of us should be concerned when the financial burden of public service becomes so great as to discourage good men and women from seeking office. Our President deserves the chance to do his job and serve our nation unburdened by the prospect of a huge personal debt.
Few Americans would deny that President and Mrs. Clinton have worked tirelessly for the benefit of our nation. Their work has helped produce economic prosperity, lower crime and most importantly a new optimism about America and our future.
Their dedication and their achievement deserve our thanks and our generosity.
I have known the President for more than 30 years, and I'm sure that your help will be deeply appreciated by the first family. Please join other friends of the Clintons in contributing to the trust. Your contribution will make a big difference.
P.S.: If you are disturbed by the way politics is conducted today, then what better response than to make your own gesture of decency and generosity. I know that it will be enormous comfort to the first family to know that so many Americans appreciate their work and have come to their aid. Thank you so much for any contribution you send.
 
Certificate
To the trustees: In connection to my contribution to the Clinton Legal Expense Trust, I hereby certify that:
*I'm a citizen of the United States;
*I've made my contribution voluntarily and with my own personal funds;
*I'm not a lobbyist registered with the Federal Government;
*I'm not employed by the executive branch of the United States Government;
*Including this contribution, I've not contributed more than $10,000 this calendar year to the Clinton Legal Expense Trust;
*I understand that my name, city, state and the amount of my contribution will be publicly disclosed;
*I understand that my contribution is not tax-deductible.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Text

HEADLINE: BUSINESS DIGEST

 BODY:

Asian Malaise Brings Low Rates to Americans
In the complex chain of global economic events, the malaise that has brought pain and suffering to Asians has given American consumers low interest rates -- a trend economists expect to continue.
One result is that home mortgage refinancings have hit their highest levels in years. The average interest rate on a 30-year mortgage, which started the year at 7.05 percent, is now 6.9 percent. Page D7.
 
Treasury prices slipped, as the dollar fell against the yen before steadying. D7. 

Boeing to Build 737's in California
Boeing plans to announce today that it will build some of its single-aisle 737 jets in Long Beach, Calif. -- a decision welcomed by workers at the former McDonnell Douglas operations there, where 600 jobs will be restored. D2.
 
Britons Buy MCI Stake in Venture
British Telecommunications agreed to acquire MCI's 24.9 percent stake in Concert, the companies' international joint venture, for $1 billion in cash. D4.
 
Sunbeam in Deal With Shareholder
Sunbeam granted one of its largest shareholders, Ronald O. Perelman's MacAndrews & Forbes Holdings, the right to increase its stake for attractive terms in exchange for guarantees not to sue the troubled appliance maker. D5.
 
Calenergy to Buy a Utility
Calenergy, an international developer of power plants based in Omaha, said it would buy MidAmerican Energy Holdings, Iowa's largest utility, for $2.6 billion in cash. D3.
 
Archer Executive Testifies
An executive with Archer Daniels Midland testified that he and another senior executive had participated in a global conspiracy with competitors to fix the price of citric acid. D2.
 
Daimler Options Pass Muster
A German court rejected a professor's challenge to the way Daimler-Benz rewards 1,600 of its executives with stock options. Now Daimler can tackle the differences between its executives' pay and executive pay at Chrysler, which it plans to acquire. Daimler's chief executive, Jurgen Schrempp, left, is thought to receive $1.1 million to $1.5 million a year, plus the returns on Daimler stock options. The News Corporation said its fourth-quarter earnings more than doubled, buoyed by large gains in its United States television businesses and a return to profit of its film division. D3.

Detroit gave Americans words like tailfin, while Hollywood contributed sitcom. The latest lingo comes from Redland, Wash., where current and former Microsoft workers have compiled a lexicon of company's jargon: "opening the kimono" means to reveal the inner workings of a project or company to a prospective new partner, while a "bitstorm" causes the digital equivalent of gridlock. HEADLINE: Giuliani to Stump for G.O.P. Around U.S.

BYLINE: By DAN BARRY 

 BODY:
Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani will be traveling to several states in the next few weeks to present himself as a Republican visionary whose ideas about governance and politics have national applicability. But those visits will not be limited to the exchange of ideas; he will also be raising money for various Republican candidates along the way.
Mr. Giuliani is tentatively scheduled to attend a fund-raising event for the Wisconsin Republican Party in Milwaukee on Aug. 25. The next day, he will swing through Iowa, stopping along the way to help raise money for Representative James A. Leach, the chairman of the House Banking and Financial Services Committee, deliver a speech to a group of law enforcement officials, and attend a fund-raising event for Jim Ross Lightfoot, Iowa's Republican candidate for governor. 
 A week later, Mr. Giuliani is to travel to South Carolina for a "Victory '98" dinner being held by the Republican State Committee. In mid-October, he will make several appearances in New Hampshire, including one before the Nashua Federated Republican Women's Club. And his aides are working out details for possible visits to other states, including California and Rhode Island.
Both the Iowa caucus and the New Hampshire primary figure prominently in Presidential races. But aides to the Mayor were quick to say that his visits to those states did not suggest any Presidential ambition.
"The purpose of the trips is to tell people the story of the successes in New York City and to help influence the Republican Party to accept his views on economic and social issues," said John H. Gross, the Mayor's longtime campaign treasurer. "It is also to try to help those candidates who share the same values that he does."
Nevertheless, Keith Fortmann, the executive director of the Republican Central Committee of Iowa, said visits by prominent out-of-state politicians always carry that undercurrent of ambition. "I know the assumption is that if someone is coming to Iowa, it automatically means he's running for President," he said, adding, "I'm looking forward to seeing what Rudy says, like everybody else."
The trips will mark the first out-of-state political visits that the Mayor has made since addressing a gathering of Republican National Committee members in New York City last month, during which he maintained that the party's future success depended on its ability to be more inclusive. It was an appeal that many read to be as much personal as ideological. Mr. Giuliani, who is interested in higher office, favors abortion rights and is for gay rights and gun control -- positions that are anathema to the party's strong conservative segment.
The Mayor's new-found beneficence on behalf of the Republican Party has not been limited to out-of-state visits. Next week, for example, he is serving as the host of fund-raising events for Linda Lingle, a gubernatorial candidate in Hawaii, and J. D. Hayworth, a conservative Congressman from Arizona. He has already held functions in New York for Jeb Bush, a gubernatorial candidate in Florida; Gary Franks, a Connecticut candidate for the United States Senate, and Representative Robert L. Livingston of Louisiana, the chairman of the House Appropriations Committee.
All this Republican-related effort by Mr. Giuliani comes at a time when New York City has a shot at becoming the host to the Republican National Convention in 2000; the city has traditionally been perceived as too liberal for mainstream Republicans to bless it with their presence. But the administration's hopes were bolstered this week when the national committee announced that New York was one of five finalists. A choice will be made before the end of the year.
Cristyne F. Lategano, the Mayor's communications director, said some of the reasoning behind Mr. Giuliani's peregrinations was to eliminate any lingering impressions of New York City as crime-ridden, drug-infested and otherwise unsafe.
"New York City is one of the safest large cities in America," she said. "Getting that message around is very helpful for New York, especially in luring large conventions."

HEADLINE: For Afghans, Full Circle

BYLINE: By JOHN F. BURNS 

DATELINE: NEW DELHI, Aug. 12

 BODY:
A quarter of a century after the overthrow of the monarchy cast Afghanistan on a downward spiral into fratricide and destruction, the Islamic hard-liners of the Taliban movement appear to be on the brink of re-unifying the country and imposing their vision of a purist Islamic society.
In a month-long offensive, Taliban forces have overwhelmed the so-called northern alliance, which defied the Islamic militants for two years by holding on to much of the territory north of the Himalayan peaks of the Hindu Kush. 
 With a rush of victories in the last week, the Taliban now hold at least three quarters of Afghanistan, and seem poised to surround the last remnants of the alliance forces in two remaining redoubts, in the Bamiyan region of the central mountains and in the Panjshir valley of the northeast.
The Taliban thus appear to be on the verge of doing something that neither the Soviet invaders in the 1980's nor the American-backed guerrillas who ousted them were unable to do: Bringing peace to a weary, demoralized and underfed country of between 15 million and 20 million people.
While Taliban forces continue to push forward against the scattered and retreating alliance forces, which surrendered 14 northern cities and towns in recent days with only token resistance, the historic significance of the moment was proclaimed by the Taliban's representative at the United Nations in New York, Noorullah Zadran.
"After 25 years of struggle, it seems to us that we have finally come to the end of the struggle," Mr. Zadran said in a television interview today with the BBC.
If so, the outcome is full of tragic irony for a nation that seemed set on a completely opposite course in 1973, when King Zahir Shah, the last representative of the Durrani Dynasty that had ruled the country for 250 years, was ousted in a coup mounted by his cousin, Mohammed Daoud.
As President, Mohammed Daoud proclaimed himself a modernizer but lasted barely five years before he was killed in April 1978 in a coup staged by the Soviet-backed Communist Party, which proclaimed a still more radical modernization program.
The Communists' program aimed at uprooting the pervasive influence of Muslim clerics, whose support of the Durranis had consigned Afghanistan to a social and economic backwardness.
Within hours of seizing the Arg Palace in Kabul, the Afghan capital, the Communists vowed to emancipate Afghan women, achieve universal literacy, and move the country beyond its bullock-cart economy.
But the bid to force compliance with the Communist program, especially in the arch-conservative world of the Afghan village, triggered a civil war that drew in Soviet forces in December 1979.
This in turn prompted President Jimmy Carter and later Ronald Reagan, to commit the United States to backing the Afghan mujahideen, the self-styled Muslim holy warriors, who drove out the Russians in February 1989.
The American effort, backed by other Western countries and by Saudi Arabia, turned Afghanistan into one of the most dramatic confrontations of the cold war.
By the time the Kremlin withdrew its forces, the Soviet Union was barely three and a half years away from collapse.
But Afghanistan was virtually obliterated as a functioning state, with thousands of villages in rubble, at least a million people dead, and another five million living abroad as refugees, mostly in Iran and Pakistan.
When the Taliban first appeared, in 1995, many in the West were dismayed.
The movement was rooted in the ancient ways of the Afghan village, with its insistence on strict forms of purdah for women and summary executions or amputations for adulterers, blasphemers and thieves. But to many Afghans, the Taliban's rise seemed like an inevitable consequence of the conflict in which modern weapons, poured in with scant consideration for the civilian population, had reduced an ancient society to rubble.
With destruction of many of the attributes of modern civilization -- schools, hospitals and highways -- the way was cleared for a band of village clerics to offer their own brand of salvation.
While educated Afghans recoiled, many others in a country that is overwhelmingly rural accommodated quickly to the Taliban's social strictures. To villagers, and to many city-dwellers, too, what mattered most was that the Taliban held out the prospect of ending a civil war in which most of the factions have long since become little more than warlords, sustaining their rule by banditry, pillage and rape.
Now, the Taliban seem likely to be faced with a continuing resistance from the two remaining opposition forces, the Hezbe-i-Wahdat of Abdul Khalili in the mountainous redoubt of Bamiyan, and the Jamaat-Islami of Ahmed Shah Massoud in the Panjshir Valley.
Mr. Massoud, the most effective guerrilla commander during the war with Soviet forces, seems likely to pose the biggest obstacle to the Taliban. But now that the Taliban have virtually surrounded Mr. Massoud's forces, even his wily battle tactics may not be enough.
Meanwhile Taliban spokesmen have renewed demands for international recognition. So far, only Pakistan, Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates have recognized the Taliban. Internationally, disapproval remains great for the Taliban's social policies, under which most women are banned from working, girls are denied education and dancing, television, kite-flying, bird-keeping and even the trimming of beards are banned.
So far, the Taliban -- the name is taken from an Arabic term meaning seekers after truth -- have played cat-and-mouse with Western Governments and international aid agencies, hinting that harsh policies against women might be relaxed in return for diplomatic recognition.
In the BBC interview today, Mr. Zadran suggested changes were possible, but just as quickly entered what seemed to be a disqualifying condition. "We will never compromise on our religion, Islam," he said.
In recent months, tightening Taliban strictures, including rules that virtually eliminated any direct international assistance for Afghan women, have prompted most aid organizations to suspend operations in Kabul, Kandahar and Herat, as well in Mazar-i-Sharif, the pivotal northern city the Taliban seized last weekend.
With a harsh Afghan winter approaching, there have been fears for the survival of the poorest city-dwellers, including at least 400,000 people in Kabul, the capital, who have relied on Western aid for food.
Russia has led a chorus of dismay at the threat of a Taliban-ruled Afghanistan spreading Islamic militancy.
"Russia considers the stepped-up military activities by the Taliban in northern Afghanistan as a real threat to the commonwealth's southern borders," a Russian Foreign Ministry statement on Tuesday said, referring to the Commonwealth of Independent States, the former Soviet republics that includes the Muslim states of Turkmenistan, Uzbekistan and Tajikistan.
Iran has joined the outcry, leaving Pakistan, alone among Afghanistan's neighbors, as a supporter of the Taliban.
But the Taliban's main challenge seems likely to lie at home, among millions of Afghans who yearn for peace, but not for the harsh life vouchsafed by the Taliban.
For these people, the prospect now is for years of living in a society not much different in its political, religious and social rigors from the Afghanistan of the distant past. So far, the signs have been that Western pressure for greater tolerance may not only be ineffective, but a stir that pushes the Muslim clerics who control the Taliban to adopt still harsher constraints.

Map of Afghanistan showing location of Mazar-i-Sharif: The Taliban capture of Mazar-i-Sharif was a major victory. (pg. A9)
