HEADLINE: If the Shoe Fits, Click It

BYLINE: By ANNE EISENBERG 

 BODY:
MADE-TO-MEASURE" refers to a tailor-made shirt, suit or gown, something that was once available only to the wealthy few. In time, that custom fit may be readily available to the average mall shopper as well, thanks to three-dimensional body scans. Within a year or so, experts say, some consumers are likely to find such computer scans available at a handful of locations ranging from the Mall of America to Fifth Avenue.
Technology being developed in the fashion industry in the United States and abroad is likely to make so-called mass customization a reality rather than an oxymoron. "We have the capability," said Stephen Gray, head of the Computer Clothing Research Center at Nottingham Trent University in England. "If people have been through our body scanners, we can have their data on a smart card that gives the retailer all the information necessary to fit the individuals, who can, in turn, use the Internet to look at fabrics and position the garment on a personalized mannequin of their body type." 
 Right now, body scanners can be found mainly at a few research sites and special effects studios. While clothing manufacturers and retailers are intensely interested in the new technology, they are aware of the many roadblocks on the way to consumer acceptance.
One problem is what Dick Yardley, a manufacturing technology specialist at the American Apparel Manufacturers Association, calls the modesty factor: "Some people don't want everyone to see what they look like in a skintight body stocking." There are, too, the inevitable glitches that will occur when consumers trust the same technology to design their clothes that has created a new meaning for the word "bug" and threatens worldwide disruptions in 2000.
"The technology is amazing," said Andree Conrad, editor of Apparel Industry Magazine, "but inevitably problems will occur. And, granted that the fit is far better than off-the-rack, will consumers be willing to pay for it? The American public is so price-conscious that it has pushed the cost of garments way down. Is it actually going to say, 'I'm willing to pay 20 percent more for a good fit?' Right now, what they're willing to do is take 40 garments into the waiting room and try them all on -- and then say how much they hate to shop when they get home."
Eric Blackwood, a vice president at J. C. Penney, the nationwide chain of department stores, agrees that price is the defining issue for the American market. "Europeans are willing to spend more for their clothing than Americans," he said. "When you customize, the cost is higher. We think the scanners have tremendous potential, but it's not going to happen tomorrow for us. We have to refine the process to get the scanning and manufacturing costs down to what the customer is willing to pay and shrink the scanners, too. The amount of square footage they take up is not economical."
Still, problems and all, manufacturers and retailers, many of them in the high-end office-clothes market, are starting to come forward to embrace the body scanner, bulky though it may be, although few have yet bought. Homi Patel, president and chief operating officer of the Hartmarx Corporation -- which includes Hart, Schaffner & Marx, a major manufacturer of men's clothing in the United States -- is working with a research and training operation in Cary, N.C., that has developed its own scanner. That organization, called TC 2 (for the Textile/Clothing Technology Corporation; it is pronounced tee cee squared) involves more than 100 clothing manufacturers, including J. C. Penney.
"Probably we'll work with department stores to have scanning equipment available and then connected directly into our management information systems to develop custom garments at quick speeds," Mr. Patel said. "True, the scanning machines won't have the charm of a good salesman, but people will get acclimatized. Young people will have no trouble; older people will need more time."
Even if body scanning is slow to spread to mass markets, accurate information on body shape could have a profound effect on the clothing industry. "Even in the shops," Mr. Gray said, "fit is going to be better as we acquire more accurate data about our body shapes."
Those interested in the new technology of digital fashion include Edith Gazzuolo, who expects to operate her scanner at the Mall of America, near Minneapolis; Kathryn Chase, a chemical engineer and ardent seamstress who hopes to open her own scanning parlor at an Atlanta shopping center, and Brooks Brothers, the home of the button-down shirt.
Brooks Brothers has had striking success in the past year with its fledgling computer-assisted shirt-customization program, which began last August. Joe Dixon, a senior vice president for manufacturing at Brooks Brothers, said, "If you have the ability to give people exactly what they want, it's a differentiator."
For now, customers for custom shirts are fitted the traditional way, with a tape measure. Then software adapts the standard Brooks Brothers pattern to specific measurements -- for example, making one sleeve longer than the other -- before the material is cut and sewn. Delivery is promised in about two to three weeks; prices start at $75.
"We were pleasantly surprised by the level of business we've generated," Mr. Dixon said. "We started with a catalogue announcement, and only recently rolled the program out to all the stores. We are already seeing a nice uptake." He said he expected the special-order business to grow. "We're working with a couple of companies on body scanners," Mr. Dixon said, "and when we think it's right for us, we'll go ahead. There's no doubt scanning works for made-to-measure. We just need to make sure that when a customer comes in and has to strip to underwear that the customer really wants to do that."
Levi Strauss, the jeans maker, has had a custom-fit program for women's jeans for several years, using measurements taken by employees. Ike Behar, a high-end shirt company that has boutiques in Neiman Marcus, Bergdorf Goodman and many other stores, does about 20 percent of its business in custom-fitted shirts but does not use scanners yet. Alan Behar, president of the company, said: "Body scanning is going to become a necessity. The shirt is the closest thing to the body. The shoulder, chest and arm holes are particularly difficult to measure for comfort." He said that his customers were exercising more and that the shirt's fit had to reflect this. He is not worried about customer reaction to scanners, he said.
Neither is Ms. Chase, who is searching for capital to open her Atlanta scanning center and a related Web site. Describing her test of a scanner, she said: "It's almost like a carnival ride. The equipment is draped in black theatrical cloth to keep out the light. You go in, get down to your underwear, put your feet on the white marks and press the button. Lights flash, music plays -- it only takes a few seconds -- and you have all the data the pattern-making software needs for a custom fit."
Ms. Chase got the idea for her business in part from observing her two daughters. "They both have the same measurements -- waist, hips, bust -- but there are very few items that they can trade back and forth," she said. "They don't look good in the same clothes. With 3-D, we'll have a better way of knowing how we actually look in the clothes we want to buy."
Body scanners are crucial to made-to-measure clothing for the masses; the technology takes measurements so patterns can be altered for individual customers.
"Traditionally, tailors have taken these measurements for their own pattern-altering methods," said David Bruner, manager of research and development at TC 2 , "but when you compare one tailor's measurements to another, it turns out each is making an educated guess; in fact, it's all guesswork -- the measurements are notoriously inconsistent."
Both two- and three-dimensional scanners are being used for the body measurements that are the basis for mass customization. In England, the Computer Clothing Research unit at Nottingham Trent University has measured more than 8,000 people. The center uses a system of side profiles and front outlines that is less expensive than point-to-point three-dimensional scanning.
"We were concerned that larger ladies, say size 32, would be unwilling to expose themselves in their underwear," Mr. Gray said. "But when we ran a piece on local radio two years ago, we had women queuing at the door. They said, 'No one understands our clothing problems.' They were glad to volunteer."
Full-color three-dimensional scanning of the entire body is being used by the United States Air Force. After all, pilots wear clothing, too, and helmets. "Everyone is interested," said Kathleen M. Robinette, an anthropologist and mathematician at Wright-Patterson Air Force Base in Ohio who is managing a program called Caesar, for Civilian American and European Surface Anthropometry Resource, the first large-scale whole-body three-dimensional scanning project ever done. "Now that 3-D is here," she said, "We can measure bodies quickly and accurately in a way that tape measures could never accomplish. The technology will be applied in ways that haven't even been imagined yet." Caesar will measure 10,800 men and women of varying weights and ages, 4,000 of them in the United States and 6,800 in Europe.
"We're going to learn for the first time what we're shaped like," said Ms. Robinette, manager of engineering anthropometry, the study of human body measurements, for the Air Force. "The data will help us create realistic computer mannequins to build made-to-measure garments on. It will yield many software tools for the design and production of customized clothing. But it's also going to help for better-fitting clothing in general. Right now, there are many errors as we go from the person to a flat pattern. We'll finally take away the guesswork. It may even lead to consistent sizes across brands."
The United States military has been interested in body measurement since the 1930's because of its responsibility for uniforms and gear that must fit properly, like helmets and gas masks. "By 1980, we agreed there had to be a better way than tape measures," Ms. Robinette said. "We were disposed to 3-D automated scanning methods."
In 1987, Wright-Patterson Air Force Base bought a head-scanning system and developed software for it.
"The scanner was being used for a 'Star Trek' movie," Ms. Robinette said. "The studio was concerned with artistry, but we wanted accuracy. So we developed software not only to drive the scanner and analyze the data but for applications related to apparel."
The data became the basis for things like tight-fitting fighter pilot helmets, oxygen masks and night vision goggles. "Now we're moving on, from head scans to full-body ones," Ms. Robinette said. "Our last full-scale survey was done in 1939, and a lot has changed since then: people's bodies, even our concept of fit."
Mr. Gray, of Nottingham Trent, agrees. "Human size and shape have changed in the McDonald's years," he said.
He credits a small part of the change to undergarments. "Lycra holds things in, but not with the supportive properties of whalebone, so nipples are about five inches lower," he explained. "But there's also the rest of us. Men are more round-shouldered, and almost every person we surveyed has a stomach sticking out. In general, we're not only taller than our parents -- we are fatter."
Mr. Gray says virtual reality software would be only one of many benefits from body scanning. "The advantages will come as well from understanding the size of people and making patterns better," he said. "As the body grows, different bits grow at different rates. Gravity alone means a bigger bust is lower than a smaller one. The stomach protrudes around the sides as well as the front. People want clothing to disguise the bad and emphasize the good; we need good data on body shape to do that."
The Caesar project is expected to yield data useful across industries. Its partners include not only apparel companies, like Lee, Levi Strauss and Vanity Fair, but also other companies with an interest in body shapes and how they are changing, like Boeing and Caterpillar. Gary Pollack of the Society of Automotive Engineers, which is coordinating many administrative functions for the huge project, said there had been no lack of volunteers to be scanned so far. "Everyone has the experience of sitting in a car or airplane seat that is too small," he said. "People want their dimensions looked at and used."
Digital fashion may one day provide not only physical benefits, like clothes that fit better, but also psychological benefits: shoppers may be able to to try on clothes without specifying their size or weight, which many are reluctant to do.
"We hate to say our size," said Linda Freedman, vice president for marketing at Modacad, a Los Angeles company that produces software for electronic commerce. "And everyone -- well, nearly everyone -- lies about their weight. Don't you on your driver's license?"
Starting this August, Modacad will offer a CD-ROM intended to let young women shop for clothes by using 3-D models of different body types to try on their selections. "We ask them to choose a shape, but we don't use words like 'pear-shaped' or any other expressions like that. I'm a pear, myself, but I don't want to be called one," Ms. Freedman said.
So far, digital fashion has produced Kevlar-lined suit jackets that don't rub a bodyguard's chest and snug-fitting helmets and gas masks that would please even Darth Vader. As to whether scanning and virtual try-ons will transform cabbage leaves into Cary Grants -- given a technology that routinely messes up our monthly bills and crashes when loaded with too many Web sites -- it's entirely possible we'll end up looking more like Charlie Chaplin than the Prince of Wales.

HEADLINE: Decline of 24% In Cotton Crop Is Seen for U.S.

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 12

 BODY:
The prolonged Southern drought and other weather problems will cut the nation's cotton crop by 24 percent this year from last year's, the Agriculture Department projected today.
Ideal weather elsewhere means the fall soybean harvest remains on track to set a record, the corn crop figures to be the second-largest ever and wheat yields are forecast to reach an all-time high. 
 Such big yields this year and the decrease in foreign demand because of the Asian financial crisis are almost certain to keep down the prices that farmers receive, though that is likely to be somewhat offset by higher yields per acre.
Less cotton had already been planted by farmers because of a three-year decline in prices. But drought and extreme heat in Texas, by far the top cotton-producing state, have reduced this year's expected harvest there by 40 percent, or more than two million 480-pound bales.
About 1.9 million acres of cotton have been abandoned in Texas, or about 37 percent of the acres planted this year.
In the No. 2 cotton state, California, the problem has been prolonged wet weather that triggered soil fungus disease. That state's cotton crop is forecast at 1.8 million bales, down 32 percent from a year earlier.
Coming in conjunction with floods in China's prime growing region, the decline in the harvest could mean higher prices of cotton goods like T-shirts by the middle of next year.
In an effort to ease farmers' troubles, President Clinton signed legislation today to speed $5.5 billion to thousands of farmers.
The law will ease the cash crunch by allowing farmers to receive certain transition payments at the start of the new fiscal year, Oct. 1, instead of waiting until later in the year. Thepayments are intended to wean farmers off crop subsidies.
Agriculture Secretary Dan Glickman said today's crop estimates would be used to determine the extent of drought losses and how much more emergency aid was needed above the $500 million in a Senate spending bill.

HEADLINE: BOMBINGS IN EAST AFRICA: THE AMERICAN AMBASSADOR;
The 'Devastated' Envoy Now Faces Kenyans' Ire

BYLINE: By JAMES C. McKINLEY Jr. 

DATELINE: NAIROBI, Kenya, Aug. 12

 BODY:
This has been an agonizing time for the United States Ambassador to Kenya, Prudence Bushnell.
Her embassy was destroyed in a terrorist bombing on Friday that injured her and took the lives of three dozen American and Kenyan colleagues, many of them close friends. 
She has had to set up her mission in temporary quarters while overseeing a chaotic rescue operation and arranging to evacuate dozens of wounded officials and employees.
To make matters harder, she has also become the focus of anger among many Kenyans who believe the United States did too little to help save the people trapped under the rubble of a building next door to the embassy.
"I feel like that building over there -- devastated," Ms. Bushnell said today during a ceremony for rescue workers, pointing at the demolished Ufundi Cooperative House, where more than 100 Kenyans died.
Embassy officials say the bombing was particularly painful for Ms. Bushnell because she had been complaining privately to her superiors in Washington for more than a year about the poor security in Nairobi.
She had argued that the embassy should be moved, but a decision was made in Washington to renovate the existing building instead.
She has a reputation as an effective manager -- indeed, her background was in administration within the State Department. Within two hours of the explosion, a bandaged Ms. Bushnell walked into a temporary command center set up at another building housing the United States Agency for International Development and took charge.
She immediately ordered a secretary to take down a list of priorities: determine who was missing, establish a central control room, set up communications because the local telephones were jammed.
Until last Friday, Kenya was considered a safe foreign posting, a lovely country where diplomats enjoyed safaris and the biggest threat to security was the occasional political riot by students downtown or a spate of carjackings.
That changed drastically when a pickup truck loaded with explosives blew up at the entrance of the embassy's underground parking garage at the rear of the building.
The explosion gutted the mission, demolished the seven-story Ufundi building and killed at least 247 people.
The explosion caught Ambassador Bushnell on the 18th floor of the Cooperative Bank Building next door to the Ufundi building, where she was meeting with the Kenyan Trade Minister.
She was badly cut by flying glass and had to descend on foot through floor after floor of destruction and chaos before being led into a scene of carnage outside.
"Everybody was bleeding," she recalled at an emotional news conference on Saturday. "The banister was wet with blood."
The Ambassador has taken the tragedy personally, friends said. She had prided herself that during a three-year tenure as a Deputy Assistant Secretary of State for Africa -- a time when there was genocide in Rwanda and several other dangerous crises on the continent -- no Americans were killed.
"One thing that really upset her was that the whole time she was the Deputy Assistant Secretary in Washington, she never lost an American," one aide said. "Today she's saying, 'Now look what's happened, and it's my fault.' That's what's hurting her most."
Ms. Bushnell was born in Washington to the diplomat's life, the daughter of a career Foreign Service officer. She was raised abroad, in Germany, France, Pakistan and Iran. She speaks fluent French.
After graduating from Russell Sage College in Troy, N.Y., she worked as a management consultant in Texas before joining the Foreign Service in 1981.
She served as the general services officer in Bombay, and then as the Deputy Chief of Mission in Dakar, Senegal, under George E. Moose, who later became an Assistant Secretary of State and took Ms. Bushnell with him to Washington in 1993.
Like her father, she was on the administrative track in the State Department, which seldom leads to an ambassadorial appointment. But in 1996 President Clinton nominated her to become the Ambassador to Kenya, with the strong support of Mr. Moose.
She is married to a retired lawyer and playwright, Richard Buckley, and has five stepchildren.
In her two years in Kenya, she has been a persistent critic of President Daniel arap Moi's Government, pushing Kenya to live up to its 1992 promise to establish a full-fledged Western-style democracy.
She has also hammered the Moi administration again and again for being slow to clean up corruption, which is a tremendous drag on the economy.
But this week she found herself on the defensive, facing allegations from Kenyan journalists and people in the street that United States marines should have allowed local rescuers to enter the embassy in the hours immediately after the bombing to carry out wounded people. Instead, the marines turned away crowds of good Samaritans.
This evening Ms. Bushnell defended the marines on state television, saying they had been trying not only to protect the crime scene but also to keep self-appointed rescuers from being hurt.
There was a gas tank behind the building that might have exploded, she pointed out. "The effort was to keep everybody out because we didn't know if the gas was going to explode and we didn't know if the building was sound," she said.
Ms. Bushnell also tried to defuse public anger in diplomatic terms. "I feel tremendous anger and frankly it is that anger that helps me keep going," she said.
Embassy officials said Ms. Bushnell had been functioning well on the job, running staff meetings with her usual mix of humor and intensity.
"She's done remarkably well considering that she was almost killed in the explosion," one official said.

HEADLINE: SWISS BANKS REACH HOLOCAUST ACCORD

BYLINE: By JOSEPH P. FRIED 

 BODY:
Representatives of Swiss commercial banks and Holocaust survivors announced a settlement yesterday in which the banks agreed to pay $1.25 billion in restitution to victims of the Nazi era.
The agreement, intended to settle the claims of tens of thousands of survivors whose families lost assets in World War II, was hailed by Jewish groups and elected officials as providing long-delayed justice for the victims. 
 "I am tremendously pleased and gratified to announce that we've reached a historic agreement," said Senator Alfonse M. D'Amato, who led the move to pressure the Swiss banks into providing money for a settlement. The settlement "will allow us to turn to healing the wounds here and in Switzerland," he added.
The banks involved are UBS, recently formed by the merger of Union Bank of Switzerland and Swiss Bank, and Credit Suisse.
As part of the settlement the plaintiffs agreed to drop a major suit against the Government-owned Swiss National Bank. Clinton Administration officials said the deal was also contingent on state and local governments agreeing to drop plans for sanctions against the Swiss.
The deal was announced in front of Federal District Court in Brooklyn, where three suits filed over the last two years had been consolidated into one class-action suit. The suits had accused the banks of retaining the assets of Holocaust victims -- assets the plaintiffs' lawyers said had either been deposited in the banks by the victims or had been looted by the Nazis and stored in Swiss banks.
The litigation had been part of a growing effort to force the banks to scour their records to identify dormant accounts and the proceeds of Nazi plunder, and to return the assets to the elderly and frail victims and their heirs.
The effort galvanized many of the victims and stirred bitterness in Switzerland. But animosity was replaced by expressions of good will yesterday, as Mr. D'Amato spoke before a battery of microphones and cameras in downtown Brooklyn. The lawyers and representatives of the two sides were joined by two people who added a moving touch to the discussions of litigation and vast amounts of money to right historical injustices.
One of the two was Estelle Sapir, 73, of Queens, a concentration camp victim who is among the plaintiffs.
"I'm very happy," Ms. Sapir said in a barely audible voice. "I think this should have happened long ago. People need the money. They're getting very old, and this is not charity."
The second person was Christoph Meili, 30, a former night watchman at a Swiss bank who was fired and subjected to death threats and police interrogation in Switzerland for saving Holocaust-era bank documents from a shredder. Mr. Meili is now living in New Jersey and working as a guard at an office building in Manhattan.
"It's a great day," he said. "We move a big step forward. I'm happy. I'm glad to help the survivors."
In a statement, the banks said the settlement "represents a major milestone in our longstanding efforts to insure that justice is served." Banks officials also praised Senator D'Amato and Judge Edward R. Korman for their roles in working out the deal.
Besides direct reimbursement for survivors or heirs who can prove ownership of dormant bank accounts, the settlement envisions a "rough justice" fund to be distributed among Holocaust survivors.
But many details of how to pay the money and who would qualify remain to be worked out. The payments are to be made in four installments over three years, with the first installment, $250 million, not very likely for nine months to a year because of the work needed to start the plan, lawyers for both sides said. The work would include devising a plan to distribute the money to victims with claims who live in the United States and abroad, they said.
A number of states and cities, including New York City and New York State, had threatened to impose sanctions on the Swiss banks if they did not agree to an acceptable settlement. The threat had outraged the Swiss Government, and the sanctions were also opposed by the United States Government, which feared that the threats could complicate efforts at a settlement.
Under Secretary of State Stuart E. Eizenstat said in an interview that the deal was contingent on the officials, led by New York City Comptroller Alan G. Hevesi, agreeing to drop the proposed sanctions.
The calls for sanctions intensified after a settlement agreement fell apart in June, and New York officials planned to phase in a series of penalties beginning on Sept. 1. The steps ranged from barring city and state funds from overnight deposits in Swiss banks to eventually selling off the stock of Swiss companies held by pension funds.
Mr. McCall and Mr. Hevesi declined to comment last night.
Under the settlement, the plaintiffs agreed to drop a suit against the Swiss National Bank, which along with the Swiss Government had refused to negotiate with the plaintiffs, and to indemnify the bank and other Swiss companies against further claims by the plaintiffs.
Mr. Eizenstat said the National Bank's role in processing gold that it knew had been looted was not in contention, but that taking the bank out of the case was a necessary condition to reach a settlement.
"We didn't want to make the perfect the enemy of the good," he said. "I think additional monetary claims by the U.S. Government and by the private sector will not likely be forthcoming." He and lawyers for the banks said neither the Swiss Government nor the Swiss National Bank were contributing to the settlement.
"Nothing can compensate for the destruction of six million Jews," said Rabbi Hertz Frankel, of the World Council of Orthodox Jewish Communities, one of the plaintiffs. "While this is a day of satisfaction, it is not a day of celebration."

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 35; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk

LENGTH: 4751 words

HEADLINE: Art Guide

 BODY:

 Here is a selective listing by critics of The Times of new or noteworthy art, design and photography exhibitions at New York City museums and art galleries this weekend. Addresses, unless otherwise noted, are in Manhattan. Summer hours vary for galleries and should be checked by telephone. Gallery admission is free. * denotes a highly recommended show.
 
Museums
 
 "THE ACADEMY AND AMERICAN ART: HISTORY AND HIGHLIGHTS," National Academy Museum, 1083 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 369-4880 (through Aug. 23). A good, economical selection of works from the museum's collection, including a pair of over-inflated allegories by the Hudson River School painter Asher B. Durand, a couple of dark seascapes by Albert Pinkham Ryder, two lovely still lifes, by William Merrit Chase (a sparkling silver ewer and a Chinese teapot) and John La Farge (a lush magnolia blossom in a purple glass), and a sharp, faux-folk portrait carved in wood by Anne Arnold. Hours: Wednesdays, Thursdays, Saturdays and Sundays, noon to 5 P.M.; Fridays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M. Admission: $5; $3.50, students and the elderly. (Ken Johnson) 

 * "THE ART OF THE MOTORCYCLE," Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum, 1071 Fifth Avenue, at 89th Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 20). Yes, it is weird to see motorcycles in the Guggenheim, but American art museums have always shown objects of design, and if there's a certain peril in taking this curious show altogether seriously, on one level that's fitting because motorcycles are frivolous to begin with. The exhibition covers the ground between an 1868 French velocipede with a steam engine beneath the seat (ouch!) and a sleek 1998 MV Agusta. The show is way too big, but many of the bikes really are great to look at, and to like them you don't have to have a tattoo or know what a single-overhead-cam valve gear with enclosed rockers is. Frank O. Gehry's installation of shiny stainless-steel panels covering the rotunda side of Wright's ramp miraculously dematerialize the rotunda and makes the inside of the museum resemble a machine, an apt metaphor. Hours: Sundays through Wednesdays, 10 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays and Saturdays, 10 A.M. to 8 P.M. Admission: $12; $7 students and the elderly (Michael Kimmelman).
 
 * "BOCCIONI AND WOMEN," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Oct. 18). A key member of the Italian Futurist group at its height, from 1909 to 1916, Umberto Boccioni (1882-1916) worked toward an art that reflected the speed and dynamism of 20th-century civilization. This small show of drawings, prints and one sculpture relating to women conveys the important shifts in Boccioni's style from 1905 until his death while serving in World War I. Unlike, say, Picasso or de Kooning, Boccioni used the women in his life -- his mother, sisters, neighbors and mistress -- to explore artistic strategies rather than his own psyche. In this show, his mother appears to be his favorite model, and the most powerful work is a sculptured head of her that is remarkable for its melding of soft, fleshy contours with Cubistic angles and planes that create a surface as roughed up as a New York City street. This show only hints at Boccioni's real achievements, but it whets the appetite for a retrospective. Hours: Fridays and Saturdays, 9:30 A.M. to 8:45 P.M.; Sundays, and Tuesdays through Thursdays, 9:30 A.M. to 5:15 P.M. Suggested admission: $8 for adults; $4 for students and the elderly (Grace Glueck).
 
 * "BONNARD," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Oct. 13). Don't miss this exhibition. Americans still don't appreciate Pierre Bonnard enough. He doesn't fit comfortably into the history of modernism, so he tends to be regarded as an anachronism, an Impressionist after Impressionism was dead. But his best art deserves to be ranked with Matisse's and Picasso's, and if you doubt this, spend time in the last rooms of the show. It ends with the paintings of Bonnard's wife, Marthe, in the bath -- mysterious elegies of love -- and with his self-portraits, which are unequaled, and that's not forgetting Rembrandt, van Gogh or anyone else. Hours: Saturdays through Tuesdays, and Thursdays, 10:30 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Fridays, 10:30 A.M. to 8:30 P.M. Admission: $12.50; $9.50, students and the elderly (Kimmelman).
 
 * "COMPARATIVE CONCEPTS," Photographs by August Sander, Karl Blossfeldt, Albert Renger-Patzsch and Bernd and Hilla Becher, International Center of Photography, 1130 Fifth Avenue, at 94th Street, (212) 860-1777 (through Sept. 13). A quietly stunning exhibition that brings together the work of three photographers and one husband-and-wife team, all German, whose work spans most of the century. Each devised and carried out an immense documentary project, built one carefully thought-out image at a time. Sander made a collective portrait of the German people. In exquisite photographs of plants, Blossfeldt traced decorative motifs back to their sources in nature. And Renger-Patzsch and the Bechers recorded the grand forms of industrial architecture according to their very different sensibilities. The show makes palpable the urge to order and thus to understand what motivates so much human endeavor, as well as the order already in place. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Tuesdays, to 8 P.M. Admission: $5.50; $4, students and the elderly (Roberta Smith).
 
 * "DEEP STORAGE: COLLECTING, STORING AND ARCHIVING IN ART P.S.1," P.S. 1 Contemporary Art Center, 22-25 Jackson Avenue, at 46th Avenue, Long Island City, Queens, (718) 784-2084 (through Aug. 30). This ambitious show documents the urge to document in recent art, a tendency broadened in the 1970's by Performance and Conceptual Art. With Duchamp's "Green Box," which documents his masterpiece "The Large Glass," among its jumping-off points, the show ranges through five decades of mostly American and German art that amasses and orders large quantities of things -- be they objects, materials, images or bits of information. Joseph Cornell, On Kawara, Hanne Darboven and Bernd and Hilla Becher fill in the older generations. Representing the younger are Louise Lawler's deadpan photographs of museum storage rooms, an enormous installation piece (in a box) by Jason Rhoades and the portrait-lined pantheons of the painter David Deutsch. Of particular interest from Germany is Karsten Bott's "One of Each," a manically methodical accumulation of everyday objects, and "Detonation Deutschland," a video installation by Piero Steinle and Julian Rosenfeldt that orchestrates images and sounds of old German buildings being blown up, to mesmerizing, ineffably sad effect. Hours: Wednesdays through Sundays, noon to 6 P.M. Admission: $4; $2 for students and the elderly (Smith).
 
 "DAVID GOLDBLATT: PHOTOGRAPHS FROM SOUTH AFRICA," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Oct. 6). This exhibition of 46 photographs of South Africa under apartheid is a dispassionate inventory of churches, monuments, shantytowns, apartment houses, graveyards, toilet seats, billboards, hedges and house trimmings. Mr. Goldblatt practices social iconography, photographing ordinary objects packed with historical and sociological meaning. He was drawn "to the quiet and commonplace, where nothing 'happened' and yet all was contained and immanent." But all is not contained and immanent in these images. Many of the pictures cry out for explanation, and their cry is answered with a torrent of text. Sometimes the words help, turning uninflected pictures into illustrations of the twisted social relations and hideous inequalities of apartheid. Sometimes, though, the text is just a tidal wave of words in which the crucial information drowns. Hours: See above. Admission: $9.50; $6.50, students and the elderly (Sarah Boxer).
 
 "IMAGE AND TEXT: ORIENTALIST WORKS ON PAPER," Dahesh Museum, 601 Fifth Avenue, at 49th Street, (212) 759-0606 (through Sept. 5). Orientalism, or the European cult of Near Eastern exoticism, has been a loaded topic for ideologically minded historians. Avoiding theory, this show presents prints depicting costumes, architecture and anecdotal narratives made by various 18th- and 19th-century Europeans for travel books. The most compelling technically and the most incorrect politically are the salacious photogravures of the French academician Jean-Leon Gerome. Hours: Tuesdays through Saturdays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. Free (Johnson).
 
 SHIKO MUNAKATA, Japan Society, 333 East 47th Street, (212) 832-1155 (through Sept. 27). Munakata (1903-1975) was one of Japan's most celebrated 20th-century printmakers. First inspired by van Gogh reproductions to become a painter, he turned to the woodcut and achieved a radical marriage of the most vital possibilities of Eastern traditionalism and Western modernism. Using children's chisels that could be thrown away when dull, he gouged and hacked away at the wood instinctively, producing expressionistic images of deities, saints, fauna and flora in black and white and hand-colored compositions that at best have great decorative vitality. This show presents about 60 works from the Japan Society's own collection. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 5 P.M. Suggested donation: $3 (Johnson).
 
 * FABRIZIO PLESSI, Guggenheim Museum SoHo, 575 Broadway at Prince Street, (212) 423-3500 (through Sept. 13). Well-known in Europe for his large-scale video installations, Mr. Plessi weighs in for the first time in New York with four room-size works. The common theme is the clever theatrical play of video imagery with down-to-earth substances and situations: water, stone, metal, architectural elements and the like. In short, he mixes the virtual with the real, as in the show's most impressive piece, "Baroque Cathodic Movements" (1996), in which three ominious-looking wooden structures, painted black and echoing 17th-century architectural motifs, gyrate slowly from the ceiling. Each resembles a sort of furnace whose maw contains amazingly real-looking video flames that appear to be consuming the ancient architecture with a fierce roar. Ultra-theatrical, a ballet in themselves, they suggest coffins for the past while conveying a shivery sense of hellfire and brimstone. Hours and admission: See above (Glueck).
 
 ALEKSANDR RODCHENKO, Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9400 (through Oct. 6). By turns illuminating, tragic and chilling, this fascinating exhibition details the work of an artist who spent much of his career on the cutting edge of art and history, a position that did not leave him unscathed. For a few short years in the early 1920's, Russian Constructivism was an artistic revolution in step with a political one, and Rodchenko was its most diversely innovative representative. He made paintings and sculptures that presaged Minimalism and photographs and graphic designs that were similarly ahead of their time, while also serving the needs of the new Soviet state. With Stalin, that state brutally switched its allegiance to Socialist Realism, dismissing, imprisoning and sometimes killing avant-garde artists, or requiring humiliating "reconstructions." This was the path chosen by Rodchenko, as attested by the photo-journalistic images that give this exhibition such a sad conclusion. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
 * "TONY SMITH: ARCHITECT, PAINTER, SCULPTOR," Museum of Modern Art, 11 West 53d Street, (212) 708-9480 (through Sept. 22). Tony Smith's works work, when they do, by causing you to look carefully, as Smith did, at the way geometric forms can be combined into abstract shapes that seem to shift as you move around them. Change, the idea that the same forms can keep mutating in provocative ways, is Smith's constant. A virtue of the Modern's intelligent, not too large retrospective is that it brings together the three aspects of his career -- architecture, painting and sculpture -- so that we can see, for example, how Smith's approach to form had as much to do with Frank Lloyd Wright, Le Corbusier and Mies van der Rohe as with Barnett Newman and Clyfford Still, and more to do with Newman and Still than with Donald Judd. When it's not good, Smith's work suggests a certain anonymous and chilly indifference because he brought an architect's mentality to everything; he planned what he often let others complete. At the same time, he spent a lifetime trying to endow geometry with feeling, to distill emotion from indifferent forms; and there was a sense of wonderment in the way he kept discovering new shapes in these forms. Hours and admission: See above (Kimmelman).
 
 * "LOUIS COMFORT TIFFANY AT THE METROPOLITAN MUSEUM OF ART," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Jan. 31). This austere exhibition, drawn almost entirely from the Met's collection, outlines Tiffany's varied production in the exquisite detail for which he is justifiably known. The opulent sensuousness comes across in small doses, sometimes kitschy, sometimes innovative. Included are examples of furniture, jewelry, ceramics, enameled objects, paintings and design studies, stained-glass windows and lamps, and the Favrile glass vases that are his most lasting achievement. Hours and admission: See above (Smith).
 
 * "THE UNICORN TAPESTRIES," Metropolitan Museum of Art, Fifth Avenue at 82d Street, (212) 535-7710 (through Sept. 6). The Unicorn Tapesteries are among the most famous works housed at the Cloisters, the Metropolitan's upper Manhattan branch devoted to medieval art. But this year they're spending the summer downtown at the museum's main headquarters on Fifth Avenue. Who commissioned them, where they were made and what their images are all about are still matters for speculation. But they've had a fascinating history -- including a stint protecting potatoes against frost after the French Revolution -- and they are absolutely exquisite. Dense with flowers, animals and courtly hunters, with the unicorn himself at the center, playing the part of a captivated lover or perhaps the suffering Christ, they have a tumultuous vivacity and suggest the flavor of a medieval world in which every detail of life was exactingly recorded and everything was more than it seemed. Hours and admission: See above (Holland Cotter).
 
 "UNKNOWN TERRAIN: THE LANDSCAPES OF ANDREW WYETH," Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, (212) 570-3600 (through Aug. 30). The first exhibition to concentrate on the artist's landscapes and to show his watercolors in profusion makes the most convincing case for his strange talent. The obsessively textured tempera paintings are best, especially in the 1940's, when Mr. Wyeth portrayed nature as active and fecund and used abrupt shifts in scale to create dizzyingly Spiel bergian experiences of space. And the dry-brush watercolors, similar in fineness to the temperas, are often technically dazzling. But after the first two galleries, the exhibition offers a disturbing psychological portrait of an artist progressively shutting down, eliminating color, warmth and emotional complexity. A more conventional realism prevails, overly indebted to artists like Durer and Eakins, but hollow in its virtuosity and calculated in its portrayal of the world as a bleak, hard-bitten place, devoid of sun or joy. Hours: Wednesdays, and Fridays through Sundays, 11 A.M. to 6 P.M.; Thursdays, 1 to 8 P.M. Admission: $8; $7 for students and the elderly; free on Thursdays, 6 to 8 P.M. (Smith).
 
 * "MARY ANN WILLSON: ARTIST MAID," Museum of American Folk Art, 2 Lincoln Square, Columbus Avenue at 65th Street, Manhattan, (212) 595-9533 (through Sept. 27). This small show by a little-known American folk artist who worked in upstate New York around 1800 to 1825 has its charms. Biblical sources, Pennsylvania German decorative art, popular prints and personal fantasies went into her creations, which are distinguished by bright colors, sometimes abstract patterning and a happy lightness of touch. "Three Angel Heads," a trio of seraphic women's faces topped by elaborate coiffures and sprouting wings is one of the best, a lovely apparition. Hours: Tuesdays through Sundays, 11:30 A.M. to 7:30 P.M. Free admission (Glueck).
 
Galleries: Uptown
 
 JAMES LEE BYARS, Michael Werner, 21 East 67th Street, (212) 988-1623 (through Sept. 5). Four large black-and-white works on paper never before exhibited, by one of the more singular conceptualists of the last 25 years. Made around 1960 while Byars (1932-1997) was living in Japan, these black ink abstractions fill the page with large rounded shapes, creating compositions that suggest Ellsworth Kelly with an Eastern twist. There's also a prone ladderlike construction called "The Black Figure" that calls to mind Louise Bourgeois (Johnson).
 
 "A FLOWER IS TO THE SUMMER SWEET," Hirschl & Adler Galleries, 21 East 70th Street, (212) 535-8810 (through Sept. 25). This lavish bouquet of a show includes the work of more than 40 painters who celebrated flowers, among them John James Audubon (1785-1851), Martin Johnson Heade (1819-1904), Fairfield Porter (1907-1975) and many less known. One standout is "Still Life of Flowers and Fruit," a fresh, fetching arrangment of morning glories, lilies, primula and iris done in the early 1870's by one of the greats of American flower painting, Severin Roesen (1816-1872). Another is "Victoria Regia, or the Great Water Lily of America," a stunning group of four-color lithographs done in 1854 by William Sharp that traces this regal flower from bud to blossom in brilliant botanical detail. All in all, a fine garden to browse in on a steamy day outside (Glueck).
 
 "PORTRAITS OBSCURED," Gagosian Gallery, 980 Madison Avenue, at 76th Street, (212) 744-2313 (through Sept. 12). This oppressively museumlike show presents one work each by seven famous male heavyweights, living and dead. The title is loosely relevant: there's a camouflaged self-portrait by Andy Warhol and a big collage of expressionistic ancestral portraits by Anselm Kiefer. A gloomy, gray, abstracted woman by Picasso could portray a lover. But works by Jean-Michel Basquiat (a nice one), David Smith, Willem de Kooning and Francesco Clemente don't look like portraits at all (Johnson).
 
 "SHIP/SHAPE," Keith de Lellis, 47 East 68th Street, (212) 327-1482 (through Aug. 29). The shapes of ships, from ocean liners to rowboats, from purely architectural studies to romantic visions, is the substance of this show. It includes some 70 prints by more than 30 photographers, from 1914 to the mid-60's. Celebrated talents like Edward Steichen, Weegee and Margaret Bourke-White share wall space with lesser-known photographers like the future Edward VIII when he was the Prince of Wales. Among the more striking images are Herbert Matter's 1938 close-up of a pair of worn, weathered sails in full rig, James Doolittle's 1930 study of a sturdy anchor chain dropped from the skyscraper prow of a huge ocean liner, and Gordon Coster's "Untitled (Sky)" (1929), a view of a big, cloudy sky with the cabin and masts of a ship just visible on the horizon line. The show is a beguiling way to spend an hour at sea (Glueck).
 
Galleries: 57th Street
 
 SHIRLEY GOLDFARB, 41 East 57th Street, (212) 752-1223 (through Sept. 4). Ms. Goldfarb's paintings from the 1960's and 70's look good enough to make you wonder why you've never heard of her. She was born in Altoona, Pa., in 1925, and lived in Paris from 1954 until her death in 1980. During the 60's she began using a palette knife to create allover fields of little squares. Some are monochromatic, some multicolored; "Chartres" has the bejeweled luminosity of stained glass (Johnson).
 
 YASUHIKO TSUCHIDA, Yoshii Gallery, 20 West 57th Street, (212) 265-8876 (through Aug. 31). A dozen lovely cups by a young Japanese-born glassmaker who lives and works in Italy. Each handleless cup has a slightly wobbly, irregular form and appears to have been made by fusing separate facets, resulting in loose grid or checkerboard patterns. They're not great art, but the jewel-like colors and the humble, slightly comical forms are irresistible (Johnson).
 
Galleries: SoHo
 
 "ANONYMOUS," the Work Space, 96 Spring Street, SoHo, (212) 219-2790, (through Sept. 12). More photography about photography and truth. This show focuses on the human figure, which appears anonymous because, in most cases, it's so blurry. Tanya Marcuse's small, fragmentary shots of bridal lingerie and skin are sexy; Jon Naiman's large picture of a corpulent fellow with feet and head cut off by a paper floor and ceiling is funny. But too much of the show is caught up in uninteresting technical manipulations (Johnson).
 
 BRIAN CLARKE, "The Glass Wall (Dedicated to Linda McCartney)," Tony Shafrazi Gallery, 119 Wooster Street, (212) 274-9300 (through Sept. 12). Taking as his leitmotif the heraldic fleur-de-lis, the English artist Brian Clarke -- in recent years noted for large-scale stained-glass collaborations with architects all over the world -- has produced a mammoth eight-panel wall that curves across the space of the gallery. A tour de force of contemporary stained glass, its brilliantly nuanced colors range from nearly transparent white to rose and sparkling blue. Big fleurs-de-lis, sometimes easily readable in bold color, sometimes so pale you can barely tease them out from their shimmering grounds, dominate the panels, each gridded with 35 squares of leaded glass. Thanks to Mr. Clarke's extraordinary sense of color and architectural design, expressed in an entirely appropriate scale, "The Glass Wall" is a very impressive work (Glueck).
 
 KENNETH GOLDSMITH, Printed Matter, 77 Wooster Street, (212) 925-0325 (through Sept. 4). Mr. Goldsmith is an artist whose primary medium is language. Some of his avant-gardist prose on view in book form is amusing, some tedious. The main attraction is a set of 13 paper suits imprinted with a transcript of a performance called "Fidget," in which he verbalized every movement of his body during one 13-hour period last year; you don't have to read much to get the idea (Johnson).
 
 "HOLLYWOOD BACK LOTS AND CANTEENS," Georges Schreiber and Fred Shane, Susan Teller Gallery, 568 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 941-7335 (through Aug. 27). Schreiber (1904-1977) and Shane (1906-1990) were both American Regionalists and skillful illustrators who, at different times, made watercolors and drawings based on visits to Hollywood. Shane's paintings of movie props or a whole simulated village in ruins have a brisk immediacy. Schreiber's vivid watercolor of lunching directors and stars steals the show: look for Carole Lombard, Humphrey Bogart and Hedda Hopper (Johnson).
 
 ANN LOVETT, Dorsky Gallery, 379 West Broadway, near Broome Street, (212) 966-6170 (through Aug. 28). In "Conundrum," a neatly composed installation combining photographs of antique medical books, pictures of her own naked body printed on loose, sheer fabric and a room-circulating line of text that reads, "Neglect me, absolve me, ignore me, want me, consume me" and so on, Ann Lovett evokes familiar connections between ideology and the body. The didactic tends to override the poetic (Johnson).
 
 "MAPS," Paul Kasmin Gallery, 74 Grand Street, (212) 219-3219 (through Aug. 28). Don't expect conventional cartography in this group of maps by six artists, each of whom has his own interpretation of the word. The broadest is James Turrell's grand-scale topographical drawing for his "Roden Crater" project, the reshaping of an extinct volcano rim north of Flagstaff, Ariz. The most "mappish" is Buckminster Fuller's "Dymaxion Air-Ocean World Map" of 1980, said to be the least distorted layout of the Earth's surface in cartographic history. Other views of the world, or particular pieces of it, are offered by Andy Warhol, Jasper Johns, Donald Baechler and the Italian team of Alighiero e Boetti, whose flat, colorfully embroidered rendition of the globe delineates each country in terms of its national flag. Move over, Rand McNally (Glueck).
 
 "NEIGHBORHOOD WATCH," Julie Saul Gallery, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, (212) 431-0747 (through Sept. 5). This well-chosen group show presents nine photographers who study suburbia from ironic or quietly surrealistic perspectives. Todd Hido's nocturnal pictures of ordinary houses taken from the street have a suspenseful, cinematic hyper-reality; Tracey Baran's large staged shot of a sunbathing girl nagged by her mother in the backyard of a seedy house is darkly comic, and Andrew Bordwin's soft-focus view of a house through blades of grass is dreamy (Johnson).
 
 "WHITE," Mitchell Algus, 25 Thompson Street, SoHo, (212) 966-1758 (through Aug. 21). Everything in this small, eccentric selection of works mostly from the 1960's and early 70's is white, creating a dialogue between the ethereal and the material. In a painting called "Winter's Silver," Carol Haerer evokes an opalescent, vaporous space; up close, the paint has a buttery sensuality. Walter Redinger suggests a play between purity and grossness in a molded fiberglass box that morphs into a giant tongue (Johnson).
 
Galleries: Chelsea
 
 RINALDO HOPF, "Golden Queers," Wessel & O'Connor, 242 West 26th Street, (212) 242-8811 (through Aug. 28). A celebratory installation of 69 Warhol-style portraits of famous gay (or supposedly gay) people by this German artist. Each photo-based canvas is silk-screened in black on white, and the figure's skin is gold-leafed. Subjects include Allen Ginsberg, Sophocles and Eugene Delacroix. The whole-wall grid has a nice decorative impact, but the pictures are too mechanical. Warhol himself would have done it with more stylish sensuality (Johnson).
 
 "SENSAROUND," Pamela Auchincloss, 601 West 26th Street, (212) 727-2845 (through Sept 19; by appointment in August). More conceptual than sensual, this six-person show presents variously clever and/or oblique approaches to the five doorways of perception. It includes Alyosha Blau and Thorsten Tenberken's potted plant equipped with a little speaker making jungle noises; a picture by Spencer Finch called "Mist," which consists of sheer white fabric on white stretchers, and Erik Hanson's abstract representations of perfume in clay, photography and needlepoint (Johnson).
 
Other Galleries
 
 "NO BOUNDARIES," Trans Hudson Gallery, 416 West 13th Street, West Village, (212) 242-3232 (through Aug. 23) A show of seven artists from Korea, the United States, Costa Rica and Brazil. The title alludes to the crossing of esthetic as well as geographical boundaries, as the artists mix traditional categories. The work ranges from the unstretched, Schnabel-like canvases of Theodore Cantrell to gridded variations on the square by Malvina Sammarone to Paula Stuttman's neat conceptualist kits for making American flags (Johnson).
 
Last Chance
 
 "AN EXPRESSIONIST IN PARIS: THE PAINTINGS OF CHAIM SOUTINE," Jewish Museum, 1109 Fifth Avenue, at 92d Street, (212) 423-3230 (through Sunday). This exhibition is an exciting gantlet, a bombardment of 56 canvases thick with extravagantly manipulated paint, resonant colors and an aura of intense emotional involvement, all painted by Soutine (1893-1943) from 1916 to 1920. It departs provocatively from the retrospective format, playing down Soutine's chronological development to illuminate the way different critics have defined his role, as savage outsider, as savior of traditional French painting and finally, in the United States, as the prophet of Abstract Expressionism. It proves that much more than just beauty is in the eye of the beholder. Hours: Sundays through Thursdays, 11 A.M. to 5:45 P.M.; Tuesdays, until 8 P.M. Admission: $7, with $2 surcharge for Soutine; students and the elderly, $5; children under 12, free (Smith).
 
 ALEKSANDR RODCHENKO, Howard Schickler, 560 Broadway, at Prince Street, SoHo (212) 431-6363 (through today). Fans for whom the big show at the Museum of Modern Art wasn't enough might want to check out this small exhibition focusing on the revolutionary designer's work for books, including endpapers bearing a pattern of military tank silhouettes, a couple of his surrealistic photomontages and a selection of original books. Also, there are some vivid portraits of the artist and his associates (Johnson).

SECTION: Section E; Part 2; Page 33; Column 1; Leisure/Weekend Desk 

LENGTH: 1117 words

HEADLINE: ART REVIEW;
Images Shimmer Upon Screens, Installed in the Imagination

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
Installation pieces involving moving images, whether film or video, are prominent among art's current staples, and the number of women pursuing the medium is on the rise. So it barely bends the law of averages to find two such installations at the Whitney Museum of American Art: "Swoon" by Janine Antoni and "Blind Side" by Liisa Roberts. And it's not so surprising that they play off each other in revealing ways.
Ms. Antoni's work has been performance-oriented, usually hammering home points about "women's work" and various female compulsions, especially those to be clean, thin and well turned out. She also often puns on male-dominated art styles. In "Gnaw," she lampooned Minimalist perfection and dramatized various cravings with a man-size cube of chocolate, a substance thought to be a female aphrodisiac, that was noticeably chewed around the edges. 
 She has made drawings by fluttering her mascara-laden lashes across sheets of paper. And in an especially well-known performance piece, she scrubbed the floor with her own hair dipped in black dye, creating a kind of cleaning-day Pollock.
But as with nearly every performance artist before her, Ms. Antoni may have grown weary of putting her body on the line and realized that she had to move on. "Swoon" is her first large work in which the viewer does not see or sense the artist's physical involvement, and it represents a big, largely successful step.
Originally seen last summer at the Capp Street Project in San Francisco, "Swoon" pursues the familiar theme of beauty and its cost, but it abandons the domestic realm to concentrate on art, specifically ballet. The viewer enters the piece through a darkened rawly finished corridor accompanied by strange, slightly disturbing sounds: heavy breathing, straining grunts and light thuds that can make one think of sex or sports.
Inside, in a darkened gallery, the source of these sounds is revealed. Beneath a beautiful red velvet curtain that is lowered almost to the ground, the bottom of a glowing screen is visible, and on it are the dancing feet of a ballerina and her partner. As they proceed through their steps, turns and lifts unaccompanied by music, her toe shoes make sharp little thuds, the stays of her costume creak, and the dancers' breath becomes increasingly labored.
In all, it's an audible account of the work, discipline and suffering behind ballet's breathtaking illusion. The image is doubled by a wall-size mirror opposite the screen, so that the viewer's shadowy reflection becomes part of the image, adding another layer of reality.
One can walk around the screen to view its "backstage" side, where the dancers are fully visible, along with the installation's inner workings: the projection booth and video tracking numbers on the screen. Yet more in the way of beauty, narrative and emotion is also conveyed: the ballerina's white feathered costume suggests "Swan Lake"; the dancers are performing the ballet's famously sad, seductive final pas de deux, in which the lovers repeatedly seem overwhelmed by feeling.
Suddenly, Tchaikovsky's music for the ballet fills the gallery, masking the sounds of effort, lifting dancer and viewer alike, making one feel slightly swoonish. But the music lasts only a few exhilarating moments before the sounds of reality take over again.
Nothing quite so dramatic happens in Ms. Roberts's "Blind Side," a Structuralist effort that also uses a two-sided screen and a mirror. In this case, a film of a well-appointed salon -- complete with formal antique furniture and oriental rugs and punctuated by three big French windows -- is projected through a translucent glass screen and reflected on a wall-size mirror on the opposite end of the gallery. Entering this gallery, viewers are thus sandwiched between mirroring life-size images, one that reflects them, one that doesn't.
The camera never moves, but the scene changes; the light outside moves from day to night and back again, in a 24-hour exposure accelerated to less than 6 minutes. As the sky darkens, the room disappears and only the windows remain, luminous rectangles through which a busy city comes into sharper focus: the lights of buildings, streets and cars speeding across an elevated highway emphasize a fast, gritty urban world far removed from the quiet unchanging formality of the room itself.
This piece is a considerable improvement over Ms. Roberts's debut last year at the Lehman Maupin Gallery in SoHo, a pointlessly busy installation involving images of statues. "Blind Side" has economy and understatement in its favor, although it may be almost too stripped down.
It seems to make deliberate reference to one of the landmarks of Structuralist film, Michael Snow's "Wavelength" of 1967. In this movie, the scene is a TriBeCa loft; the action consists of the camera's executing a 45-minute zoom slowly and inexorably toward the center point of a three-windowed wall. The light changes into a series of lurid Warholian colors (achieved with filters); the sounds of unseen street traffic intrude. Just as the camera seems about to hit the wall, the zoom shot comes to an end, centimeters from a postcard-size image of the ocean.
It is almost as if Ms. Roberts set out to rearrange the components of Mr. Snow's film: in her work the light, and its changes, are natural; the traffic is visible, the grungy loft, an industrial space redolent of old-style manufacturing, has been traded for a more genteel but equally old-fashioned setting, one whose stillness contrasts with the industrious scene outside. As day turns to night and the room fades into total darkness (like a theater), the three windows come to resemble narrow movie screens and the racing traffic the movement of film through the projector.
"Blind Side" might almost be said to out-structure the structuralism of "Wavelength." Ms. Roberts touches on the basics of film -- time, light and movement -- using reality in a more straighforward manner, and she tolerates even less narrative than Mr. Snow, who teasingly created a fragment of traditional suspense by having a couple walk past the camera talking about finding a corpse in the loft. The only figures in "Blind Side" are the shadows and reflections of the viewers (an effect, however, that evokes the work of one of Mr. Snow's contemporaries, Paul Sharits.) A problem is that too much of the work's interest lies in its dialogue with its precedent, which limits its power for viewers not familiar with Mr. Snow's film.
 Janine Antoni's "Swoon" remains at the Whitney Museum of American Art, 945 Madison Avenue, at 75th Street, through Nov. 15 and Liisa Roberts's "Blind Side" through Oct. 4.

GRAPHIC: Photos: In Janine Antoni's "Swoon," the viewer sees dancers' feet on one side . . .; . . . While their entire figures are visible on the other side of the screen. (Photographs from the Whitney Museum of American Art)

HEADLINE: Earnings at Kmart and Gap Are Better ThanExpected

BYLINE: By Bloomberg News 

 BODY:
The Kmart Corporation and Gap Inc., two big retailers, reported quarterly earnings yesterday that were better than expected, aided by the strong economy and a return to the basic fashions favored by their mainstay customers.
Profit before a charge tripled at Kmart, the nation's second-biggest discount retailer. Net income almost doubled at Gap, the third-biggest clothing chain. 
 At a third retailer, Saks Holdings Inc., the quarterly loss narrowed as shoppers splurged on designer clothes and accessories at the Saks Fifth Avenue luxury department stores.
The economy is helping retailers of all stripes turn in surprisingly strong results for the latest quarter. "It's a good retail environment right now," said John Cabell, a portfolio manager who follows retailers at USAA Investment Management. "If you've got the merchandise, the consumer will come."
Of the 80 retailers that have reported for the quarter so far, 89 percent beat or met analysts' earnings expectations, led by the nation's biggest retailer, Wal-Mart Stores Inc.; the Abercrombie & Fitch Company, and Federated Department Stores Inc., according to the First Call Corporation. That has given retail stocks a boost.
With unemployment near a 30-year low and consumer confidence high, shoppers continue to spend money. Still, some retailers are struggling. The catalogue retailer Lands' End Inc. said yesterday that slow sales resulted in an unexpected loss for the second quarter.
In its earnings report yesterday, Kmart said profit before a charge rose to $93 million, or 19 cents a share, in the quarter ended July 29, its fiscal second quarter. That was up from net income of $31 million, or 6 cents a share, a year earlier and exceeded analysts' expectations by 2 cents a share. But Kmart's stock fell 87.5 cents, to $17.8125, on the New York Stock Exchange.
The discounter brought back elastic-waisted pants and added more larger-sized clothes to replace the hot pants and tight, cropped shirts that had been shunned by middle-aged mothers, its primary shoppers. Strong demand for the new fashions helped the retailer avoid the steep markdowns that ate into profits last year.
Revenue for Kmart, which is based in Troy, Mich., rose 3.4 percent, to $8.12 billion from $7.85 billion.
In the latest quarter, a charge of $13 million, or 3 cents a share, for costs of an early-retirement program resulted in net income of $80 million, or 16 cents a share. There were no special items in the quarter a year ago.
At Gap, net income in the second quarter ended Aug. 1 rose to $136.9 million, or 34 cents a share, from $69.5 million, or 17 cents a share, a year earlier. That beat forecasts by 3 cents a share.
Gap fell $3.625, or 5.8 percent, to $63.50, on the New York Stock Exchange. The shares, which are up about 54 percent over the last six months, gained 6.5 percent on Wednesday in anticipation of better-than-expected earnings.
The company, whose chains include Old Navy, Gap Kids and Banana Republic, has been adding more inventory and widening its selection of basic styles like T-shirts. Its ads for jeans and khaki pants featuring celebrities and young people dancing have helped make it the place to shop for those items, analysts said.
The San Francisco-based retailer's revenue rose 42 percent, to $1.91 billion from $1.35 billion.
The return to basic fashions is helping Gap sell more items at full price.
At Saks, the loss before a charge narrowed in the quarter ended Aug. 1 to $7.29 million, or 11 cents a diluted share, from $8.6 million, or 14 cents a share, a year earlier. The results matched estimates, and the shares closed unchanged, at $26.75, on the New York exchange.
The New York-based retailer's revenue rose 12 percent, to $509.6 million from $454.7 million.
Strong demand for name-brand clothes, jewelry and cosmetics bodes well for Proffitt's Inc., which last month agreed to buy Saks.
In the most recent quarter, the net loss was $11.1 million, or 17 cents a share. A year earlier, it was $14.2 million, or 22 cents a share.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Japan's Trade Surplus Falls; Asian Slump Slows Exports

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: TOKYO, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Japan's current account surplus fell in June from May, the ninth decline in the last 13 months, as exports to other Asian nations slowed and imports rebounded from a two-and-a-half-year low.
The surplus in the current account, the broadest measure of goods and services flowing in and out of a country, fell by a seasonally adjusted 2.4 percent, to 1.465 trillion yen, or about $10 billion, the Finance Ministry said. That was more than the 1.2495 trillion yen forecast by economists, and came as exports rose 1.7 percent and imports expanded 11.4 percent. 
 The surplus fell in part because soccer fans traveled to France to see Japan's national team play in the World Cup. "Lots of people left Japan with lots of money to spend overseas," said Yasukazu Shimizu, an economist at Nippon Credit Bank Research Institute.
Japanese companies shipped fewer goods to Asian customers in June. Merchandise trade makes up three-quarters of the overall current account, and recessions in Asia, where Japan ships 35 percent of its exports, contributed to the decrease.
Companies and governments throughout the region are ordering fewer Japanese trucks, tractors and television sets as they try to reverse shortages of foreign-currency reserves used to pay for imports. That has hurt companies like Hitachi, Fujitsu and NEC.
While imports rose in June, the Finance Ministry said that might not continue because of Japan's stagnant economy. "It's too early to say whether imports will keep rising," said Masaki Omura of the ministry's international finance division.
For the first six months of the year, the Japanese current account surplus rose 52.9 percent from the corresponding period in 1997, to 7.573 trillion yen, or $51.7 billion. That was the third straight half-year rise and the biggest surplus in five years for a first half. Overall exports rose 1.5 percent, and imports dropped 10.9 percent in the half.
The semiannual figures do not include a breakdown of trade and services by country. Trade figures released separately last month showed that Japan's merchandise surplus -- not including services and income -- with the United States, its largest trading partner, rose 37.7 percent from the first half of 1997. That has increased tension with Washington, which has accused the Japanese of relying on exports for growth and not doing enough to increase consumer spending at home.
Japanese exporters have increased sales to the United States and Europe to offset the tumbling Asian sales. Japan's surplus with other Asian nations, not including services and income, fell 26.8 percent in the first half, according to figures released last month.

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
I.M.F.'s Japan Report Warns of Lower Yen

BYLINE: Reuters 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
The International Monetary Fund warned today of an even weaker yen unless Japan took bolder steps to revive its moribund economy and repair its troubled banking system.
The I.M.F.'s report, issued two weeks after Prime Minister Keizo Obuchi took office, said intervention by the United States and Japan to support the yen in June had helped stabilize the currency "for the time being." But it added, "Failure to follow through with supporting policy actions could trigger further downward pressures on the yen." 
 In the report, completed on Aug. 5, the I.M.F. complained that Tokyo had so far not done enough to restore its economy, the world's second largest, saying Japanese economic health was critical to all of Asia.
"While the Government has taken a number of welcome initiatives," the fund said in its annual review of Japan's economy, "the overall response thus far has fallen short of the timely, comprehensive and forceful program that is required, given the seriousness of the present situation."
It added that Japanese short-term interest rates were at appropriate levels for now, but a few directors said a rate cut might be needed later in the year if Mr. Obuchi's planned tax cuts and other measures failed to stem economic decline.
The I.M.F. said it expected the Japanese economy to shrink 1.7 percent in 1998, a change from the fund's April forecast of zero growth this year. But it also said the economy could start to recover late in the year, bolstered by tax cuts.

HEADLINE: Boeing in Deal With Union On the 737

BYLINE: By LAURENCE ZUCKERMAN 

 BODY:
The Boeing Company and its biggest union announced an agreement yesterday that paves the way for Boeing to produce the 737 commercial jet at the former McDonnell Douglas complex in Long Beach, Calif.
But while the deal was designed to allay union fears of job losses, Boeing also said yesterday that it planned to cut even more employees than it had indicated last month. 
 As part of the deal, Boeing agreed that assembly of most of the single-aisle jets would remain outside Seattle and that the major parts, such as the fuselage and wings, would continue to be produced at their current locations. The company also pledged that it would not lay off any union workers as a result of the move.
It is the first time the International Association of Machinists, which represents 39,000 Boeing workers, and the company have a deal apart from the union's regular four-year contract.
"This is a step into the future," said Bill Johnson, president of the machinists' local for Boeing. "There are a lot of issues that when we sit down and work together everybody can win."
But the deal does not prevent Boeing from following through on its goal of eliminating between 18,000 and 28,000 of the company's 238,000 jobs by the end of 1999. Indeed, the company said yesterday that even more cuts will come after 2000.
Boeing has provided few details about where the initial job reductions will be made. A Boeing spokesman declined to elaborate on the additional cuts, saying that details would not be disclosed until next year.
The new production line will require between 600 and 1,000 workers, saving only a fraction of the 6,200 Long Beach jobs set to be lost when production of three McDonnell Douglas models is scheduled to stop in 2000. Boeing bought McDonnell Douglas last year.
The company also said yesterday that it would further consolidate the operations of its fighter, satellite, space transportation, information and communications and military transport businesses. By the end of the decade, the moves will reduce the company's overall office, warehouse and manufacturing space by 21 million square feet -- three million square feet more than Boeing first announced in March.
Boeing will begin assembling a few 737's in Long Beach later this year, bringing the rate up to three a month by the second quarter of 1999. The agreement with the machinists caps production at the plant at five planes a month.
And in a move that is rich with symbolism for the former McDonnell Douglas employees, Boeing said that it would drop the remnant of the acquired company's name and call the complex the Long Beach division. It is now called the Douglas products division.
Moving production to California will help relieve the strain at Boeing, which has been struggling to fill hundreds of orders for the best-selling 737. The company will use Long Beach to make the most varied versions of the 737 -- a business version of the jet and a combination passenger and cargo version commissioned by the Pentagon -- so that its main assembly lines outside Seattle can focus on stamping out similar types for the world's airlines.
Shares of Boeing closed down $1.6875, at $37.1875, on the New York Stock Exchange.

HEADLINE: Retail Sales Fell in July, U.S. Reports

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
Retail sales fell four-tenths of 1 percent in July, reflecting the General Motors strikes, the Commerce Department said today. Excluding automobiles, sales rose for the sixth time in seven months.
Although July's decline was the first in nine months, it was smaller than the eight-tenths of 1 percent that analysts had expected. Sales increased one-tenth of 1 percent in June. 
 Excluding automobiles, retail sales rose half a percent in July after having fallen one-tenth of 1 percent in June. Previously, June's sales outside the automobile industry had been reported as increasing one-tenth of 1 percent.
"In general, what you have is a situation where consumers have the money to spend and are more than glad to spend it," said Joel Naroff, chief bank economist at the First Union Corporation in Philadelphia. "Given that prices are rising so slowly, these are really, really strong consumption numbers."
Also today, the Labor Department reported an unexpected decrease of 7,000, to a seasonally adjusted 301,000, in the number of first-time jobless claims that were filed last week. The data suggested that the cooling economy was not slowing the robust labor market.
The four-week moving average for jobless claims, which is less volatile than the weekly report, fell to a seasonally adjusted 306,500 last week from 315,500 the previous week. That was the lowest since the week ended April 11, when the average stood at 306,000.
Last week's decline showed "the labor market has a lot of vitality," said Cary Leahey, chief United States economist at High Frequency Economics Ltd. in Valhalla, N.Y.
The July retail sales report showed that sales of big-ticket goods, including automobiles, appliances and furniture, fell 1.4 percent. Orders for nondurable goods, ranging from groceries to clothing, rose four-tenths of 1 percent.
Sales at automotive dealers slumped 3 percent in July, the largest decrease since a 3.3 percent decline in April 1997. In addition to the impact on sales of the strike -- General Motors sales fell 38 percent during July, the company's worst performance in nearly three decades -- sales of cars and light trucks were hurt because auto makers ended incentive and discount programs.
Outside of automobiles, though, retail sales gains were broad based. Sales at furniture and home furnishing stores increased 1.2 percent, and sales of building materials and hardware rose 1.1 percent.
Sales by apparel and accessories stores rose seven-tenths of 1 percent in July, in contrast to June's decline of 1.1 percent.
Low interest rates, the thriving job market, steady incomes and high consumer confidence have proved a fruitful combination for retailers even as weak results from Asian operations pour in. Still, if the stock market begins an extended decline, consumer spending could suffer.

GRAPHIC: Graph: "Retail Sales" shows total retail sales, from Feb. 1997 through July 1998. (Source: Commerce Department)
