HEADLINE: Too Late to Say 'Extinct' In Ubykh, Eyak or Ona;
Thousands of Languages Are Endangered

BYLINE: By PAUL LEWIS

 BODY:
As the legend goes, when the Turkish sultan first heard of Ubykh, the bizarre-sounding language spoken by Muslims who had emigrated from the northwestern Caucasus in the mid-19th century, he dispatched a servant to learn more.
When the servant returned, he described what a language with 83 consonants and one vowel sounded like by taking out a bag of pebbles and pouring them on the sultan's marble floor. "Listen to these sounds," he said. "Foreigners can gain no greater understanding of Ubykh speech." 
 Today, if people are curious about Ubykh, they can listen to a recording instead of a handful of tumbling stones, but they can't hear it spoken in person. The last Ubykh speaker, Tevfik Esenc, died in Turkey at the age of 88 in 1992.
Ubykh is one of hundreds of languages that are either dead or dying; thousands more are expected to disappear over the next century. For linguists, the growing number of vanishing languages is a looming disaster that threatens to diminish the world's cultural diversity and erase a monumental human achievement. "Languages are more than grammar," Ken Hale, a linguist at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology, said. "They are cultures, ways of thinking about ourselves and our surroundings. When we lose one it's like losing the Louvre."
The disappearances are no less alarming, they argue, than the threat the earth's biological diversity faces from industrial pollution and population growth. "Surely we linguists know and the general public can sense that any language is a supreme achievement of a uniquely human collective genius, as divine and endless a mystery as a living organism," Michael Krauss, a linguist at the University of Alaska, has written. "Should we mourn the loss of Eyak," an Alaskan language, "or Ubykh less than the loss of the panda or the California condor?"
According to the latest and most authoritative survey of the world's tongues -- Ethnologue, published in 1996 by the Summer Institute of Linguistics in Dallas -- 336 languages are "nearly extinct," meaning that parents no longer teach them to their children. Among the recent disappearances, say linguists, are Northern Pomo, a Californian Indian language; Sirenik Eskimo; Quinault, spoken by Indians in Washington State; Kasabe, spoken in the Adamawa province of Cameroon, and Ona, spoken in Tierra del Fuego in southern Argentina. Eyak is down to one speaker.
Mr. Krauss brought attention to the erosion of the world's language diversity in 1992, when he predicted that at least half the world's roughly 6,500 languages would become extinct over the next century.
Many languages have already died out, including those of major civilizations, like Sumerian, Assyrian, Babylonian and Latin. But in today's more technologically connected world, that process is hastening. English and a handful of other major languages that increasingly dominate the world are widely seen as passports to education and a brighter economic future.
Roughly half the world speaks one of 10 mega-languages as a primary, or mother, tongue. Mandarin Chinese is spoken by 16 percent of the world's population, followed by English and Spanish at 5 percent each; varieties of Arabic, 4 percent; Hindi, Portuguese, Bengali and Russian, 3 percent each, and French and Japanese, 2 percent each, Ethnologue reports.
Meanwhile, 60 percent of existing languages have 10,000 speakers or fewer, said David Harmon, who analyzed the 'Ethnologue survey and is a member of Terralingua, a society dedicated to language preservation. Languages with so few speakers are highly vulnerable to disruption.
Nancy C. Dorian, a Gaelic languages expert at Bryn Mawr College, said that "when small linguistic communities become economically unviable, for instance, they break up and the language dies out."
For example, after Russia drove the roughly 50,000 Ubykh speakers from their homes on the Black Sea into Turkey in the 1860's, the refugees eventually decided that the dominant Turkish, Abkhaz or Circassian languages would be more useful. Over time they stopped teaching their children their own ferociously difficult tongue.
"From what we know it was simply a decision by the Ubykh elders not to teach Ubykh to the next generation," said George Hewitt, a professor of Caucasian languages at London University. "It seemed more sensible to concentrate on languages they would need. But it was a tragedy all the same because when a language dies, a culture dies with it."
Bert Vaux, an expert on Turkish languages at Harvard University, agreed. "Every language offers a unique insight into the nature of speech and thought," he said. Ubykh, along with other northwestern Caucasian languages, for example, has a unique system of agreement between subject, verb, object and indirect object, Mr. Vaux said. "It shows that humans have a greater cognitive capacity than we thought," he said, "because the average person would never think it possible to keep track of so many agreements within a single sentence."
Nor is cultural diversity the only loss. Luisa Maffi of Terralingua said indigenous languages could play a role in environmental preservation because they often reflect valuable ecological knowledge that enable speakers to preserve their habitats.
Today, Spanish is killing Indian tongues in Latin America while French wipes out languages in its former colonies in Africa. In southeastern Alaska, parents have stopped teaching native languages to children, Nora Marks Dauenhauer and Richard Dauenhauer write in "Endangered Languages: Language Loss and Community Response" (Cambridge University Press, 1998).
English, it turns out, is the biggest language slayer. It was the language of the Industrial Revolution and remains the language of the world's biggest economy and remaining superpower. "It was always in the right place at the right time," said David Crystal, a retired linguistics professor from Reading University in Britain and author of "English as a Global Language" (Cambridge University Press, 1997).
Mr. Crystal estimated that 343 million people speak English as a mother tongue; another 235 million to 350 million speak it well as a second language because they learned it in a country like India, where it has official status. Estimates of those who are learning English as a foreign language vary wildly, from 100 million to one billion. Nonetheless, Mr. Crystal figures that the number of "fluent to reasonably competent"English speakers is 1.2 billion to 1.5 billion, compared with 1.1 billion Chinese speakers.
English seems set to spread even further because it is the most-taught foreign language in more than 100 countries, including Russia, China, Germany, Spain, Egypt and Brazil, sometimes displacing the study of other languages in the process, Mr. Crystal said. In 1996, for example, Algeria replaced French with English as the chief foreign language in its schools.
"It may be," he concluded, "that English, in some form or another, will find itself in the service of the world forever."
As concern grows over the loss of languages, efforts to record and revitalize endangered tongues are intensifying. Before he died, Mr. Esenc, the last Ubykh speaker, allowed linguists to take X-rays of his speech organs while he demonstrated the vocal gymnastics necessary to produce those 83 distinct consonant sounds. He also helped scholars compile an Ubykh dictionary and grammar guide.
In the United States, Congress passed legislation in 1990 and 1992 encouraging the preservation of American Indian languages. And a privately financed Endangered Languages Fund, which awards grants for the preservation and recording of threatened tongues, has been set up at Yale University.
Abroad, Tokyo University has created an International Clearinghouse for Endangered Languages and Unesco is cataloguing languages around the world. British linguists have established a Foundation for Endangered Languages that also provides grants for preservation and documentation.
In Britain and Ireland, minor revivals are under way in such endangered tongues as Breton, Provencal and Welsh, Irish and Scottish Gaelic. Bilingual inhabitants of the Isle of Skye off the western coast of Scotland, for example, are writing English subtitles for Gaelic television programs. In Belfast a group is trying to found an Irish-speaking community by buying houses in the same street. And over 200 people are now fluent in Cornish although the last mother-tongue speaker died at the end of the 18th century.
Ms. Dorian pointed out that the collapse of the Yugoslav federation had strengthened the position of Slovenian by making it the official language of an independent nation, while Croats and Bosnian Muslims are trying to create separate languages for themselves out of the Serbo-Croatian they speak along with Serbs.
In some cases "new" languages are gaining popularity. In Papua New Guinea, Tok Pisin, originally a form of pidgin English, is becoming a language in its own right. Yet as it does, it is replacing some of the country's other 800 languages.
Organizations interested in preserving indigenous languages, including Terralingua and International PEN, which represents writers and translators, want to add a Universal Declaration of Linguistic Rights -- creating a right to be educated in one's native tongue -- to the Universal Declaration of Human Rights that the United Nations adopted in 1948.
But many argue that the disappearance of languages is inevitable. Peter Ladefoged of the University of California at Los Angeles has argued that linguists should record languages before they disappear but not necessarily try to save them. Preserving languages, he said, can impose political and economic costs by weakening unity and encouraging tribalism. It can also absorb scarce resources that might otherwise be used for development. Tanzania, he pointed out, promotes Swahili at the expense of tribal languages in the hope of creating a sense of nationhood in an ethnically diverse country.
The loss of indigenous language and culture can be the price of entering the modern world, Mr. Ladefoged said. He remembered a speaker of Dahalo, an almost extinct Cushitic language in rural Kenya, who smilingly revealed that his sons spoke only Swahili. "He was proud his sons had been to school and knew things he did not. Who am I to say he was wrong?"

HEADLINE: About New York;
A Salesman Who Paid Attention

BYLINE: By DAVID GONZALEZ 

 BODY:
ZARA GRAUER still remembers her first date with Howard Bardach. He stepped aside to let her board a bus, then sat beside her and suggested they share some coffee and conversation. Walking home afterward, he asked her not to walk so fast.
"Don't you feel well?" she replied. 
 "No," he said. "I want it to last longer."
Such sentimentality. It figured, since he fancied himself a ladies' man. Such salesmanship, too, since he was just as likely to approach strangers on the street and ask if they wanted to buy or sell his roach-killing paint, hand warmers or special light bulbs whose rays rivaled "sunshine on a June day."
Those who got beyond the product pitch would learn that Mr. Bardach, 80, had once been a Yale man, a Navy man and the owner of a packaging business. They were also told that he had moved to Hell's Kitchen after one of his sons committed suicide and his wife divorced him. Despite those setbacks, he reinvented himself, convinced that riches still waited for him.
"He came to this neighborhood to get away from it all," said Sylvie Pappis, a friend. "And he did."
Too much so. Starting about a year ago, he grew thin and quiet. He stopped writing the wacky, hyperkinetic letters hawking his products and solutions to the world's ills. He stopped being a salesman. On July 27, he hanged himself. His death seemed as impenetrable as the successes and sorrows of his very life.
"Let's face it," said Roger Starr, a former city official who worked on the Yale Literary Magazine with him and received his bizarre letters over the years, "there's sort of a gap between being eccentric and being insane. I'm not sure what side of that gap he fell on."
His letters and phone calls would make you think he was on the wrong side. What kind of person would call a reporter at 4 A.M. and urgently insist that he leave his ink-stained cocoon to embrace the world of wealth by selling those special light bulbs?
Then again, John Waldo Adams, his best friend, knew him as the only person who ever threw him a birthday party in his 90 years on this earth. The two met around 20 years ago when Mr. Bardach stopped him on the street and tried to sell him a chemical with amazing gunk-removal powers. When he discovered that Mr. Adams was a poet, he volunteered to type up his writings, offering free editorial advice.
"He wanted me to get more fun and laughter into my poems," Mr. Adams said. "I was writing about the condition of the world, the economy, the psychological, the sociological. Sometimes he said it was too serious."
He often stopped by Ms. Pappis's hat shop on West 54th Street, sometimes with lady friends as possible customers. "He had a good eye for colors," she said. "He was always attentive. He wasn't like a lot of men who pass by the store and don't notice. He paid attention."
She suspected something was amiss last year, when he would walk past the store with only a nod. Some of his friends said he had cancer, though he would never talk about what was going on. He always had lunch at a nearby senior center, but the people there knew even less.
"I think he was a tortured soul," said Sharon Beard, who works at the center. "But he carried himself without a scintilla of self-pity. He was a classy man."
While his friends in Hell's Kitchen wondered what was wrong, Ms. Grauer explained simply that he had had an epiphany about a year ago when she fell ill. He took care of her, she said, and grew caring and calmer. But she suspected that he was disappointed by his fizzled business plans.
"I think it must have been difficult when the Yale magazine would arrive and he saw this one was a C.E.O. and that one had a home in Montauk, and he hadn't accomplished," she said. "That's what got to him."
THAT didn't matter to the dreamers and buddies who met him during his last years. They recalled a man whose hard life never diminished the fast talk. To them, he was Howie Bardach, salesman and friend. They only wish he had let them in a little closer a little longer.
"He was essentially a salesman," Ms. Grauer said. "It was like 'Death of a Salesman,' when the wife said, 'Attention must be paid.' I always thought of that because I did pay attention. The first time we sat on the couch, I put a pillow behind him. I don't think anybody had ever done that for him before."

HEADLINE: Russia's Markets Rally as Western Powers Discuss Rescue

BYLINE: By MICHAEL WINES 

DATELINE: MOSCOW, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Russia's financial markets rallied today after the Kremlin and the major Western powers indicated that they were working on another round of plans to end the nation's economic crisis.
But with banks still shaky and the memory of Thursday's panic still fresh, brokers and analysts said they were not so much optimistic about a solution as relieved that today's markets had not completed the collapse that began the day before. 
 After losing almost 6.5 percent of their value on Thursday, Russian blue-chip stocks regained about 4 percent today. Nine-month Government bonds were yielding about 150 percent, well under the 200-percent-plus yields of Thursday.
President Boris N. Yeltsin, breaking his summer vacation today to inspect a meat-processing factory in the ancient city of Novgorod, insisted that there would be no devaluation of the ruble -- "that's firm and definite."
"That would signify that there was a disaster and that everything was collapsing," he said. "On the contrary, everything is going as it should."
The Kremlin said Mr. Yeltsin had a lengthy telephone conversation with President Clinton this afternoon.
 In Washington, the White House press secretary, Michael D. McCurry, said today that Mr. Clinton and Mr. Yeltsin did not discuss whether a new aid package from the West would be needed.
 "This was not a phone call about money. It was a phone call about doing the things necessary" to stabilize the struggling economy, Mr. McCurry said.
 "They discussed some of the steps that will be necessary to, over the long term, assure economic stability in Russia," he added.
The banking system, which became the focus of Thursday's panic after it became clear that some major banks were unable to repay major loans, remained solvent, if short of foreign currency. Moscow banks were open today, although many refused to sell their customers dollars. The city's hundreds of hole-in-the-wall currency exchanges were selling dollars, sometimes at exorbitant rates, but many had posted "No dollar" signs by day's end.
The Central Bank was trading currency at the rate of about 6.3 rubles per dollar. But at some currency exchanges, the rate approached 7 rubles per dollar. "It looks as though they avoided a run on the banks, which was the nightmare we were staring at this morning," said Tom Adshead, co-director of research for Moscow's United Financial Group. "The foreign-exchange market dried up. But fortunately, nobody's clamoring for their money."
For the moment, the critical question is whether the banks will do as well next week. Thursday's crisis was rooted in months of speculating by some banks in high-yield Government bonds and currency "forwards" -- contracts to buy or sell currencies at specified future dates. The banks had bet that the ruble would remain stable and that the bond prices would not collapse -- and when their bets soured, they were unable to cover their losses.
More currency contracts will fall due next week, and the ruble's weak status means that some banks may have to absorb large trading losses. As occurred this week, other banks that put up Government bonds as collateral for loans could be asked to produce more money now that the bonds have lost much of their value, a practice known as a margin call.
But Russia's Central Bank has begun pumping money into some of the least liquid banks, and analysts said it was spending still more money to keep the value of the ruble from deteriorating further. That pleased investors, but it is uncertain how long the Central Bank, which has but $17 billion in reserves, can continue without outside help.
Russia's leaders continued to reject calls to devalue the ruble, a move that would reduce the nation's debt, but would also ignite inflation, destroy investors' confidence and provoke a political showdown with Communists and nationalists.
Mr. Yeltsin made a point of noting that he had not even broken his summer vacation to return to Moscow, but instead had directed Prime Minister Sergei Kiriyenko to press ahead with an overhaul of tax and budget policies that is seen as critical if the Government is to remain solvent.
Mr. Yeltsin also summoned the Communist-controlled lower house of Parliament into emergency session to address the fiscal crisis. Because the Duma has refused to meet, Mr. Yeltsin has been forced to issue a series of legally dubious decrees ordering the measures Mr. Kiriyenko is undertaking.
But today the Communists, apparently struck by the seriousness of the collapse, grudgingly agreed to convene, still insisting that they will have nothing to do with tax increases and other controversial provisions of the plan. Russian officials said that finance ministers of the major Western industrial powers were already talking about how they might mount another loan package or other assistance to steer Russia away from bankruptcy.

HEADLINE: Strikes Cost G.M. $1.65 Billion

BYLINE: Dow Jones 

DATELINE: DETROIT, Aug. 14

 BODY:
The General Motors Corporation estimated the third-quarter production losses as a result of work stoppages from labor strikes in Flint, Mich., cost it $1.65 billion after taxes, the company said today in a Federal securities filing.
The total includes a loss of $1.3 billion for G.M.'s North American operations and another $350 million for G.M.'s Delphi Automotive Systems unit, the auto maker said in its quarterly report for the second quarter, which was filed today with the Securities and Exchange Commission. 
 In the section reviewing G.M.'s North American operations, the company estimated the strike-related production loss for the third quarter totaled 318,000 vehicles from the start of the quarter until full production resumed.
G.M. said the estimates did not take into account the effect of possible recoveries that may occur through production increases in future periods.

HEADLINE: Conrail Strikers Ordered Back to Work

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: PHILADELPHIA, Aug. 14

 BODY:
A Federal judge ordered 3,400 striking Conrail employees to return to work today just hours after the track maintenance workers walked out, shutting down the freight railroad's operations.
Judge James T. Giles of the Federal District Court here issued the temporary restraining order pending a full hearing Aug. 27 on Conrail's contention that the strike is illegal. 
 The ruling came hours after 3,400 workers walked out over Conrail's use of outside contractors to build tracks in Marysville, Ohio. The union, the Brotherhood of Maintenance of Way Employees, said Conrail had promised in writing not to contract out the work.
The strike shut down all movement by Conrail, the nation's fifth-largest freight rail company. It moves about 7 percent of the nation's freight volume.
The strike also affected some passenger service. Amtrak service was disrupted in western Pennsylvania, Michigan and New York, where four Amtrak trains had to stop short of their destinations because they could not operate on Conrail's tracks, a railroad spokesman said. One train heading from Toronto to New York was stopped in Niagara Falls, N.Y. and two trains heading from the city to Niagara Falls stopped in Schenectady, N.Y.

HEADLINE: Big Brokerage Plans to Build Near Times Sq.

BYLINE: By CHARLES V. BAGLI 

 BODY:
Morgan Stanley Dean Witter has signed an agreement to move into a new one-million-square-foot office tower on Seventh Avenue between 49th and 50th Streets, according to real estate executives.
If completed, the deal would represent the latest in a series of expansion moves by the city's big investment houses, whose growth has helped fuel New York City's economic resurgence in the last few years. It also would add another piece to a building boom in the Times Square area driven largely by media and financial companies. 
 After many months of on-again, off-again negotiations, Morgan Stanley signed a letter of intent on Tuesday with the Rockefeller Group Development Corporation to build and occupy a proposed 33-story glass tower on what is now a parking lot and a rare development site in midtown Manhattan, according to the executives, who spoke on condition of anonymity.
The site, known as Rockefeller Plaza West, was a victim of the recession in the early 1990's and sat fallow for nine years. But with rents soaring and little vacant space available in midtown, the land has become very valuable, although at least two companies in the last year have tried and failed to come to terms with the owner, the Rockefeller Group, which is a subsidiary of the Mitsubishi Estate Company.
The Rockefeller Group's plans for the Seventh Avenue tower are now going through the city's land use review process. According to documents filed with the Planning Commission, the 33-story skyscraper would include an atrium at the corner of Seventh Avenue and 49th Street with an entrance to the subway as well as the vast underground concourse beneath Rockefeller Center to the east.
Morgan Stanley's letter of intent gives the investment bank exclusive rights to complete a deal at Rock West within a specified time, one real estate executive said.
If a final deal is struck this time, the new office tower would be Morgan Stanley's third building in the area and its latest step in creating a corporate campus at the northern end of Times Square. The Rock West site is across the street from Morgan Stanley's building at 750 Seventh Avenue. And both buildings are only a block north of the investment bank's 43-story headquarters at 1585 Broadway, between 47th and 48th Streets.
Morgan Stanley, like many of the largest investment banks, moved to midtown during the 1970's from lower Manhattan, the city's traditional financial center. In 1995, the investment bank decamped to a newly resurgent Times Square, suddenly rife with financial and media and entertainment companies like Disney, Viacom, Bertelsmann A.G., Proskauer Rose and, soon, Skadden, Arps, Slate, Meagher & Flom.
Morgan Stanley and other major financial institutions are expanding. According to the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics, the number of jobs in the securities industry in New York City hit a record of 164,300 in June, surpassing the previous peak of 163,000 for the first time in 11 years. Goldman, Sachs & Company and Merrill Lynch & Company are both scouring the metropolitan area for more office space, while Bear Stearns & Company is building a new headquarters on Madison Avenue between 46th and 47th Streets.
Morgan Stanley declined comment yesterday, as did the company's broker, Colliers ABR. Jonathan D. Green, president of Rockefeller Group Development, was no more forthcoming, nor was his broker, Cushman & Wakefield. But word of the tentative deal, which was shrouded by confidentiality agreements, spread quickly through the real estate industry.
"This continues the trend of large financial companies devouring whatever space is available in the city today," said Howard L. Michaels, chairman of the Carlton Group, a real estate advisory firm. "As the Wall Street boom continues, the space requirements for the investment banks grow ever larger."
In this year's first four months, financial service companies accounted for nearly 11 percent of all commercial leasing in the city, according to a recent report from the office of State Comptroller H. Carl McCall.
Goldman, Sachs is putting together its own corporate campus downtown, where the investment bank recently leased 660,000 square feet of space at 180 Maiden Lane and 520,000 square feet at 10 Hanover Square. The company, which is based nearby at 85 Broad Street and One New York Plaza, is back in the market looking for more space, according to real estate brokers.
Merrill Lynch, which bought a 780,000-square-foot tower at 222 Broadway last year, is now hunting for a million more square feet and will probably end up finding space in Jersey City, brokers said.
Aside from real estate, Wall Street has fueled budget surpluses for the city and the state and accounted for an astounding 56 percent of the increase in inflation-adjusted earnings in New York City between 1992 and 1997, while representing only 5 percent of the jobs. But financial analysts have warned of the dangers that the city's economy is so dependent on the fortunes of Wall Street.
"While good times on Wall Street pour unprecedented personal and business tax revenue into the city and the state, the flow of income from this single area poses some risks," Mr. McCall said Thursday. "A market downturn, or worse, a broader economic recession, would result in job losses and the loss of a significant source of funds for the city and the state."
Despite a robust stock market and record profits among Wall Street companies, the American and New York Stock Exchanges, the commodity exchanges and the investment banks have demanded hundreds of millions of dollars in tax breaks to remain in the city. Morgan Stanley, which received a $100 million tax subsidy in the early 1990's, is expected to go back to the city for more if a deal is struck at Rock West.
The tower would be something of a victory for Mitsubishi Estate, which lost a billion-dollar investment in the historic Rockefeller Center complex during the recession. The site itself has served as a barometer of the New York real estate market.
Mr. Green began buying the parcels that make up the site at the start of the last real estate boom in 1980. But by the time he had demolished the existing buildings and obtained city approval in 1990 for a 55-story, 1.3 million square foot limestone tower, a recession had devastated the New York real estate market. In 1994, the Rockefeller Group turned it into a parking lot.
Last month, the Rockefeller Group nearly struck a deal with Morgan Stanley for the property, but it ultimately balked at the suggestion of turning over the property to Morgan Stanley's developer, Gerald Hines. According to one executive who knows of the deal, Morgan Stanley returned to the negotiating table recently, agreeing to lease the land for 99 years, pay the Rockefeller Group a development fee and still use Mr. Hines to build the project.

SECTION: Section A; Page 12; Column 1; Editorial Desk 

LENGTH: 511 words

HEADLINE: Canada's Noble Gift

 BODY:
Canada's decision last week to give the Nisga'a Indians control of their ancient tribal lands in British Columbia was an overdue but honorable gesture, born partly of guilt for past injustices and partly from a belief that tribal sovereignty will lead to economic self-sufficiency. But the Government in Ottawa must make sure its trust is not abused. In particular, it must hold the tribe to national laws, especially those protecting the environment, even if that limits what the Indians hope to do.
The United States' experience with Indian sovereignty might be helpful to the Canadians, who in fact have come rather late to the idea -- more than two centuries behind America, which granted self-government to 371 separate tribes between 1778 and 1871. The treaties struck between Congress and the tribes gave the Indians tribal homelands and freedom from state control. But they remained subordinate to the will of Congress, becoming, in effect, nations within a nation, levying their own taxes and enforcing their own laws but always subject to a higher power. 
 This is essentially the same arrangement that the Canadian Government has struck with the Nisga'a tribe. The tribe will be encouraged to engage in forestry, mining, fishing and other activities to sustain its independence. At the same time it will be asked to obey national laws, including strict environmental regulations -- a vital point since the land to which the Nisga'a will be taking title, with its extensive pine forests and pristine streams, is not only visually stunning but also ecologically fragile.
But this "nation-within-a-nation" architecture, however clean it looks on paper, has not prevented conflicts in the United States between tribes and local and state interests. Some of these conflicts involve money -- whether, for example, non-Indians who run businesses on reservations should pay taxes to the tribe or to the state. Many disputes involve the environment.
In New Mexico, for example, the Isleta Pueblo tribe forced the city of Albuquerque to spend $300 million to clean up a nearby river. A Federal court ruled that the Indians were well within their rights under the Federal Clean Water Act. Conversely, the Goshutes, a tribe in central Utah, decided last year to lease part of their reservation as a storage ground for high-level civilian nuclear waste. The Goshutes said they were simply invoking their sovereign powers to make themselves self-sufficient. Their neighbors, quite rightly, were horrified.
Ultimately, this dispute will have to be resolved by the authorities in Washington, which is just where it ought to be settled. As the senior partner in the treaties, the Federal Government must juggle two obligations. One is to protect tribal interests, the other to assert the national interest when tribes overreach. So will it be in Canada, where neighbors of the Nisga'a in British Columbia are already complaining that the deal gives the tribe unfair advantages. Having made the gift of sovereignty, Ottawa must now control its consequences.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

TYPE: Editorial

HEADLINE: Now It's Grapevines Climbing the Rockies;
Small Wineries Gaining Footholds In Many Unlikely U.S. Locales

BYLINE: By WILLIAM R. LONG 

DATELINE: PALISADE, Colo.

 BODY:
Parker and Mary Carlson have an unpretentious attitude about making and marketing their wine.
"We're not the swirl, sniff and spit crowd," Mr. Carlson said. "Our wines are just meant to be enjoyed. They're light and fruity, easy drinking." 
 Their Carlson Vineyards labels have playful names like Prairie Dog Blush, Tyrannosaurus Red and Gewurzasaurus. And they are made from Colorado grapes. Hundreds of acres of cabernet, merlot, chardonnay and gewurzstraminer are thriving on the western slopes of the Rocky Mountains.
It is a process being repeated in many states without long wine-making traditions.
The number of American wineries doubled to 1,817 between 1980 and 1995, the last year for which data are available, according to the American Vintners Association in Washington. More than half of the new wineries are outside California. Except for Alaska, North Dakota and Wyoming, every state has at least one winery. The trade association said New York, Oregon, Washington and Virginia had a combined total of 379 wineries, up from 138 in 1980. Pennsylvania, Ohio, Missouri, Texas, Michigan, New Jersey, Indiana and New Mexico each had 20 or more.
But many of those wineries operate on a fine line between a pastime and a small business.
"The wine industry outside of California, Washington, Oregon and New York tends to be a very small, cottage industry, almost a home industry, one step beyond a hobby," said Louis Perdue, who publishes an Internet newsletter called Wine Investment News. "The problem is that they don't make a great deal of wine, and if you don't make a great deal of wine, it's hard to make a great deal of money."
Vic Motto, a partner in Motto, Kryla & Fisher of St. Helena, Calif., which provides consultants and accountants for the wine industry, says vineyards and wineries are capital intensive. A winery that grows its own fruit typically has assets of $4 to $5 for each dollar of annual sales, Mr. Motto said, compared with $1 or less in assets per dollar of sales for a manufacturing company.
 But many small wine makers are motivated primarily by a love of wine and a desire to combine agriculture with an art that has existed for thousands of years.
"There's a certain romance to it," Mr. Motto said. "You're growing some fruit that you're going to convert into a product that has a certain amount of mystique to it and charm."
The winery operations in most states are still dwarfed by California's labels. Eric Sims, an economist with Motto, Kryla, estimated that California wines accounted for 90 to 95 percent of the $16 billion in sales of American-made wines in 1997. Most of the rest came from New York and Washington, he said.
 But Simon Siegl, president of the American Vintners Association, said advances in scientific knowledge had helped spread commercial vineyards into new regions. New tools and techniques include more effective fungicide applications, better water management and improved ways of dealing with severe cold weather, which is not a problem in California's grape-growing regions.
"In years past, the growers just didn't have the tools to win out against nature," Mr. Siegl said. "As more and more research delivers better tools to the wine maker, it's more feasible for wine to be produced in some of these regions."
Colorado's tiny emerging wine industry is an example of how wine making is proliferating throughout the United States.
At 4,700 to 6,400 feet above sea level, the Colorado vineyards are among the highest in the world, but the area's radiant summer days and cool nights are great for grapes, and improved vineyard management techniques are helping to solve problems of long, cold winters.
In 1980, the state had two commercial wineries. Now, there are 21, according to the Colorado Wine Industry Development Board. Five new Colorado wineries received licenses in 1997.
Carlson Vineyards, south of Palisade in the Grand Valley of the Colorado River, is typical of the recent trends.
The winery has three acres of its own vineyard and buys "seven acres' worth" of grapes from other growers in the area, to make about 15,000 gallons of wine a year. Mr. Carlson, 52, said he expected to sell about $350,000 worth of wine this year.
The Carlsons started their winery in 1988. "We were home wine makers for about 10 or 15 years before that, so it's just a hobby that got out of control," Mr. Carlson said.
For the first four years, Mr. Carlson also continued working at his supervisory job at a Coors ceramics plant in nearby Grand Junction. He has taken short wine-making courses at the University of California at Davis, the American mecca of viniculture education, and some of his wines -- including the 1995 Gewurzasaurus -- have won medals in national competitions.
Like other vintners interviewed in the area, Mr. Carlson was reluctant to talk about profits. He said that the winery produced a taxable income, "but it's all going back into the business."
Douglas and Susan Phillips have a cabinet full of medals in the tasting room of their Plum Creek Winery beside U.S. 6 in Palisade. The prize they are most proud of is a gold medal from the 1992 San Francisco Fair for their 1990 Grand Mesa, a blend of merlot and cabernet franc.
Susan Phillips said people at the California competition, whose knowledge of Colorado's fledgling wineries was sketchy at best, were dumbfounded. " 'Who are these guys?' -- that's what they were saying about us," Mrs. Phillips said.
The Phillipses are both lawyers in Denver, three hours over the Rockies from Palisade. But the couple spends more than 40 extended weekends a year working at their winery and 55 acres of vineyards, helped by a dozen full-time employees and as many seasonal workers. They opened the winery in 1984 and Mr. Phillips estimated that they had invested "considerably more than $2 million" in the venture, first breaking even after seven years.
This year, he predicted, total sales of grapes and wine will be $800,000 to $900,000, but he declined to discuss profits or losses for the privately held company.
The Colorado Wine Industry Development Board expects 1998 sales of 79,000 gallons for all micro-vintners in the state, which amounts to less than 1 percent of the Colorado retail wine market, according to John Lowey, the group's executive director. The board's long-term goal is for Colorado wines to win 10 percent of the state's nine-million-gallon market.
Total sales of all wine in the United States increased from 449 million gallons in 1993 to 508 million gallons in 1996, according to the American Vintners Association.
Mr. Siegl, the president of the association, said the improving quality of wines made throughout the country had contributed to the growth of wineries by giving consumers more confidence in what they buy.
"They're getting better and better wine every time they turn around," Mr. Siegl said.
For example, in western Colorado, viniculturists say, a dry climate helps prevent vine disease; intense summer sunlight gives grapes good color and flavor, and low nighttime temperatures promote acid-retention, which is regarded as a key to premium wine making. But potential problems in Colorado include severe winter cold, which can damage vines, and late spring frosts, which can abort the budding process.
The Colorado wine board, which is financed with a small share of state taxes on wine, pays for a research station and experimental vineyard operated near Palisade by Colorado State University. Growers and wine makers say Richard A. Hamman Jr., a viniculturist who operates the research station, has helped improve the area's grape crops and wines.
Mr. Hamman said that many local wines were still mediocre. But he said the industry had the potential to expand in western Colorado, with up to 3,500 acres suitable for vineyards.
"It's not ever going to be a Napa in terms of size," he said. "But the quality -- we can make just as good a grape here as they can in California, for most varieties."
Mr. Hamman has experimented with different varieties of grapevines to find those that adapt well to the Colorado climate, and many do. But no variety resisted a cold wave in February 1989 that dropped temperatures to 23 degrees below zero and damaged most vine tissue above ground level. Colorado produced almost no grapes that year.
In seminars for growers on how to reduce winter damage, he teaches such techniques as reducing water to vines in the late summer to hasten their winter acclimation process and delaying pruning until late in the winter to leave more dormant buds in case some are damaged by winter freezing.
Many growers have installed electric wind machines, huge fans that dissipate low layers of frosty air. And Mr. Hamman is also working on an experimental spray of water, sugar and an acid taken from ground seaweed that can postpone the time when buds pop out, a precaution against late spring frosts.
Richard and Padte Turley operate Colorado's oldest and largest winery. The Turleys bought a fruit farm near Palisade in 1977 and converted orchards to vineyards in 1985. They sold grapes to Colorado Mountain vineyard, a pioneering Colorado winery that was operating in the red. In 1989, they bought the winery from its absentee owners.
"The reason I bought it is they weren't making any money, so they couldn't buy my grapes any more," Mr. Turley said.
Despite the grape crop busts in 1989 and 1991, the Turleys managed to keep the winery alive by importing grapes from California. Now called Colorado Cellars Ltd., its sales have been growing at about 10 percent a year, reaching $630,000 in 1997. The winery makes about 25,000 gallons a year, although Mr. Turley declined to discuss the company's earnings in detail.
One problem Colorado wineries have struggled with is getting Denver-based distributors interested in their wines. Mr. Turley, who worked as a distributor before buying the winery, tackled the problem by hiring a sales manager and buying a van to deliver his wine throughout Colorado. He says Colorado Cellars wines are sold at about 3,500 restaurants and liquor stores, more than half of the licensed outlets in the state.
"We're selling everything we make," he said.

HEADLINE: Religious Groups Mount a Campaign To Support Pact on Global Warming

BYLINE: By JOHN H. CUSHMAN Jr. 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 13

 BODY:
The political debate on global warming, long dominated by arguments over science and economics, is spilling over into pulpits and pews as religious organizations speak out about morality, faith and the Kyoto Protocol.
Major church groups in the United States are mounting an unusually broad and active campaign to persuade the Senate to approve the protocol, an international agreement to fight climate change that was negotiated in Japan last year, leaders of the effort say. 
 Many Protestant, Greek Orthodox and Jewish groups, including black churches and some evangelicals, have joined the campaign, although Roman Catholic bishops are still considering their stance on global warming and some of the nation's more conservative Christian groups, like the Southern Baptist Convention, are not participating.
In a letter to President Clinton and the senators, 22 member churches of the National Council of Churches pledged to work for approval of the Kyoto Protocol, calling it "an important move toward protecting God's children and God's creation."
The Kyoto treaty calls on developed countries to make deep cuts in emissions of heat-trapping gases like the carbon dioxide that comes from burning fossil fuels, with the United States reducing 1990 levels by 7 percent over the next 10 to 15 years.
The Rev. Joan Brown Campbell, the council's general secretary, said the group wanted the climate issue to be "a litmus test for the faith community." Ms. Brown said the churches would demand that the United States lead the way on fighting global warming without requiring actions by the developing world, a condition the Senate has already set.
And in an unusual grass-roots campaign, an interfaith coalition, the National Religious Partnership for the Environment, plans to have members of the clergy and lay lobbyists focus on senators from nine states that stretch from Appalachia across the Midwest.
The states include West Virginia and Michigan, where the coal and auto industries are powerful opponents of the treaty. Some of the region's senators, like Richard G. Lugar of Indiana and Chuck Hagel of Nebraska, both Republicans, are considered especially influential in the climate debate.
In October, the churches will bring together about 100 people in Columbus, Ohio, to coordinate the advocacy work in congregations across the region, organizers say.
"This is two parts ground swell and one part mobilization," said Paul Gorman, the executive director of the religious partnership. "This is really about the future of religious life itself."
Kim Winchell of Freeland, Mich., a medical laboratory technician who coordinates about 32 Michigan Lutheran congregations on environmental issues, said, "I plan to network, network, network and pray a lot."
Susan Harlow of Indianapolis, a seminarian who works with youth groups through the Church of Christ, said she was called to environmental causes during a course in prophetic ministry, which she defined as "speaking the hard truth, speaking out on issues that people would rather not deal with."
The Rev. Christopher Bender of the Assumption Greek Orthodox Church in Morgantown, W.Va., said his efforts on climate change "really have a long way to go."
"Given the fact that we live in West Virginia, the first step is just to get the subject on the table," Father Bender said. "Perhaps over the course of time we can also change hearts and minds."
The campaign on climate issues reflects a determination among churches in the past decade to involve the faithful more directly in matters like the disproportionate effects of pollution on poor people or the need to save endangered species.
When Pope John Paul II delivered his "Ecological Crisis" message in 1989, he said industrial nations could not demand that the third world set restrictive environmental standards without doing so first themselves.
Like other religious leaders, Catholic officials said they viewed global warming as a moral issue with profound importance for the world's poor, who stand to suffer most from disruptions to the climate. But they said it would take time for American bishops to consider where they stand on the treaty's specifics. Two committees are considering the issue.
John Carr, secretary of the department of social development at the United States Catholic Conference, said the bishops "understand there is a lot at stake here, and want to think our way through this."
At times, the convergence of religion and environmentalism has cast secular environmentalists and believers in unfamiliar roles.
At a conference last year in Santa Barbara, Calif., it was hard to say which was more notable: the pronouncement by Ecumenical Patriarch Bartholomew, the Eastern Orthodox Christian leader, that polluting was a sin, or the public apology by Carl Pope, the executive director of the Sierra Club, for the rejection of religion by his generation of environmentalists.
Some participants said they expected resistance to the injection of morality into the climate debate.
"I don't believe that there is a consensus in the country that it is a moral issue," said Mark Jacobs, director of the Coalition on the Environment and Jewish Life. The coalition, which brings together 26 national Jewish organizations spanning the spectrum from Reform to Orthodox, is participating in the campaign.
"Many people don't believe we have an obligation to curtail our life style to protect future generations," Mr. Jacobs said.
The discussion in religious circles on global warming can be just as complex as the parallel debates in economic and scientific circles.
"There is considerable debate in the scientific community on the whole issue of global warming, enough to learn that working scientists are not monolithic on the question," said William Merrell, a spokesman for the Southern Baptist Convention. "The convention itself has not taken a position, and in view of the unsettled science, it seems unlikely that we will take such a position."
The National Association of Evangelicals has also largely stayed away from environmental issues, although it is planning a conference to discuss them next March.

HEADLINE: Robert M. Luby, 88, Founder Of Regional Cafeteria Chain

BYLINE: By ROBERT McG. THOMAS Jr. 

 BODY:
Robert M. Luby, a restaurateur who had such a down-home devotion to quality and such an accommodating string of unemployed relatives that he helped turn a small Texas cafeteria business into a $500 million chain with more than 200 restaurants in 11 states, died on Thursday at a hospital near his summer home in Colorado Springs. He was 88 and had retired as president of Luby's Cafeterias Inc. in 1971.
To say that Mr. Luby grew up on cafeteria food would be something of an understatement. Within a year after he was born in Mansfield, Mo., in 1910, his father, Harry, an Illinois-born entrepreneur who operated a men's clothing store in Springfield, had made a fateful business trip to Chicago and returned fired by the possibilities of a strange new food establishment he had encountered there. 
 Copying the Chicago operation from its name to its menu he daringly opened the New England Dairy Lunch in Springfield and promptly discovered that people there had been hankering for bargain-priced boiled vegetable dinners served buffet style from a 12-foot counter.
A family operation from the beginning (Mr. Luby's mother, Julia, planned meals and helped cook even with a toddler underfoot), the original short-counter cafeteria was so successful that a second one was opened in Springfield in 1912 and Mr. Luby's father embarked on a novel path of incremental improvements.
Concerned that patrons would resent changes, even those that improved operations, the elder Mr. Luby began the practice of selling one cafeteria, usually retaining a minority interest, while opening a new, improved version in a different town. The result was the creation of what was not so much a chain as a dotted line of a dozen cafeterias stretching from Missouri through Oklahoma, Texas and Louisiana.
By the time the family and the family business reached San Antonio in 1927, Harry Luby had done well enough to retire at 39, leaving his teen-age son with a near obsession for the business he had grown up in.
During his high school years Mr. Luby did every facet of cafeteria work from serving food to washing dishes and while studying business administration at the University of Texas in Austin he took a couple of years off to open and operate a cafeteria in Corpus Christi, Tex.
After his graduation in 1934, Mr. Luby indulged in a short burst of wanderlust, opening a cafeteria in San Francisco. The city's Depression-era maritime union problems helped doom the business but not before it had brought Mr. Luby two important assets, an especially satisfied customer named Georgina Wenglein, who became his wife, and her brother, George, who was persuaded to return to Texas with Mr. Luby and join him in the cafeteria business.
By 1940 Mr. Luby had opened several cafeterias in Texas, but after the outbreak of World War II he sold out and joined the Army Air Corps, typically spending his years as an intelligence officer stationed in California and dreaming of creating a chain of cafeterias.
Teaming up with a cousin, Charles R. Johnston, he founded the modern Luby's chain in San Antonio in 1947 and began an expansion using Mr. Wenglein and other relatives as trusted managers.
When he ran out of relatives, Mr. Luby, recruited investor-managers whose 40 percent share of the profits assured that they would be as concerned about quality and efficiency as Mr. Luby was.
Although there were several long-established cafeteria chains in the South, where an appetite for a hearty, home-style meal that doesn't cost an arm and a leg is not considered as declasse as it is elsewhere, Mr. Luby's insistence on quality and attention to detail helped assure a steady expansion.
Initially operated as Cafeterias Inc., the company sold stock to the public in 1973, changed its name to Luby's Cafeterias Inc. in 1981 and gained a listing on the New York Stock Exchange in 1982, the year Mr. Luby stepped down as chairman of the board.
Since then, as the company he founded continued to flourish and expand (its 231 cafeterias specializing in regional favorites from grits to tamales stretch from Arizona to Florida) Mr. Luby, who became a multimillionaire providing low-cost food that even now averages just above $5 a meal, devoted himself to civic work, travel, hunting and fishing, golf and -- gourmet cooking.
Mr. Luby, twice a widower, is survived by his wife, Kathleen; a daughter from his first marriage, Martha Lahana of Littleton, Colo.; a stepdaughter, Elizabeth Rogers of San Antonio, and two stepgrandchildren.

HEADLINE: Boaters' Paradise in the Bronx;
A Marina Thrives Where Warehouses Cast Shadows

SERIES: RITES OF SUMMER: On the Water

BYLINE: By DAVID M. HALBFINGER 

 BODY:
Along a narrow creek that divides a sooty Bronx industrial park from the whooshing traffic on the Hutchinson River Parkway, where the setting sun casts shadows of warehouses and tractor-trailers, exists a seagoing community like no other.
There is Francois Guillet, the weather-beaten owner of this unlikely marina, who speaks English laden with the diction of the French Alps and dreams of retiring here. And Daniel Torrez, a former Greenwich Village shopkeeper who has built an art studio inside a ramshackle houseboat and arranges orchids on the foredeck. And "Uncle Bob," a disabled jail guard who eases his pain with beer and companionship on the deck of his motorboat, the Golden Girl.
What unites them all is a love of the water, and a willingness to see past their immediate surroundings. 
 Where some might be put off by the speeding cars on the parkway -- the nearest lane of traffic cannot be more than 250 feet from the dock -- Mr. Torrez says he tunes out the noise. "Sometimes, at night, there's hardly anyone on the highway, and you can hear the birds," he said.
Besides, the parkway's proximity has its advantages. Directly opposite the marina is a rest stop, with a gas station and a McDonald's. So boaters in need of a refill, or hungry for a hamburger and fries, simply have to paddle a rowboat a few yards across Westchester Creek.
The Bronx, the only borough of New York City that is part of the mainland United States, actually has a wealth of marinas and boaters. In addition to the dozen or so boatyards on City Island, there are several on Eastchester Bay near Throgs Neck, and one hidden away on the Hudson in Riverdale.
Mr. Guillet's 30-slip marina on Westchester Creek, Metro Marine, was built in 1957 by the late Jerry Conroy, a retired tugboat captain, said Mr. Guillet, who bought it from him 11 years ago. Even at the time, the location south of Westchester Square was an odd choice. The path of Westchester Creek was shifted slightly in the 1930's to make way for the parkway. It might have been filled in and paved over then, but for a fuel company that needed to continue receiving oil shipments by barge. So the Army Corps of Engineers dug a new path for the creek along Commerce Avenue, Mr. Guillet said.
Today, oil barges still inch up the waterway once a month or so, twice a week in winter. But over time, despite the growth of an industrial park alongside it, the creek has become more of a refuge than a commercial artery, a sort of maritime version of the community gardens, or casitas, that have sprouted on vacant lots in many neighborhoods in the Bronx.
For years, the marina has drawn police officers, schoolteachers and other working people unable or unwilling to pay the rent at more fashionable boatyards. Some are new boaters, like the criminal lawyer who received his boat, the Bandolero, as payment from a client, though a few have been coming here for more than a decade. A number live nearby, or once did.
Abraham Aviles, a self-employed insurance broker in the Morrisania section of the South Bronx, comes here after work a few days a week to go fishing for the plentiful bluefish and striped bass to be had in Long Island Sound.
"Sometimes I come at 2 or 3 in the afternoon, depending on the tides," he said. "There's nothing better. You get off work, co, the Sunrise Marina on Eastchester Bay, in 1968. His wife, Gail, was the marina's secretary. They were married in 1977.
"Fifteen years ago, boating was good," he said. "It was easier to borrow money from the bank for a boat than a car. I had a waiting list. I had to refuse customers."
So Mr. Guillet bought the marina on Westchester Creek as a low-rent option for his overflow business. (The seasonal rent now is about $800 for a 25-foot boat, less than half what some marinas charge on City Island.) But the recession of the late 1980's and early 1990's dropped the bottom out of the boating business, he said. Today, he supplements his scant profits from the two boatyards with his earnings as a barge captain, providing a floating crane that is used in bridge inspections throughout the metropolitan area.
Soon, he says, he will sell the Sunrise Marina. He and his wife are making a home of an old three-story building that overlooks the marina on Westchester Creek. Although his wife, who was raised in the Bronx, says she has been begging to leave the borough for years, Mr. Guillet says they will retire here.
"I love it," he says, his face lighting up through sweat and filth and a full gray beard. "I don't see a building in front of me here. I'm not blocked in. I'm never crowded, like those people who live in those apartment buildings, on top of each other, in New York.
"Nobody wants to buy this," he added. "There's not that much income. It's a way of life -- like a fisherman, or a farmer. Every boat is like a cow, you know? You pull the boats like cows."
As the sun sets, Mr. Guillet takes up a blowtorch and sets to work on the steel frame for his second-story deck. His son, 7-year-old Pierre, fishes for horseshoe crabs under the dock.
At the other end of the boatyard, Mr. Guillet's right-hand-man, the ever-barechested Bonifacio Santos, has ended his day of repairs and maintenance. Mr. Santos, a Spaniard from the Canary Islands who was a dynamiter before coming to the Bronx in 1988, retreats to the trailer where he and his young wife, Tamika, live with their two sons. Their infant, naked in her arms, watches as three young puppies romp among the stray pieces of outboard motors and battered hulls.
Amid all this, the untimely cock-a-doodle-doo of a rooster hunting for food -- its feathers resplendent in red, gold and blue -- hardly seems unusual. Three hungry hens, in fact, plainly ignore it.
 
Rites of Summer
 
Previous articles in this series have looked at the emerging motorcycle culture in Manhattan, visiting day at a sleepaway camp, the West Indian sport of netball and a religious tent revival in Queens.

HEADLINE: TRACKING BAGHDAD'S ARSENAL: THE DIPLOMACY;
U.S. Urged Arms Monitor to Back Off From Clash With Iraq

BYLINE: By STEVEN ERLANGER 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
The United States and Britain urged Richard Butler, the chairman of the United Nations arms inspectors, not to have a confrontation with Iraq by trying to hold a surprise inspection after Baghdad suspended cooperation with the inspectors earlier this month, senior American and British officials said today.
The officials were responding to a Washington Post report today about private American discussions with Mr. Butler and his decision to drop plans for the inspections. 
 Until Baghdad broke off cooperation with inspectors on Aug. 3, these officials said, they had supported Mr. Butler's plans to hold surprise inspections at two sites that promised new information about Iraq's chemical, biological and missile programs. Mr. Butler had brought the necessary inspectors to Iraq when he arrived on Aug. 2, intending to go ahead with the inspections.
But on Aug. 3, once Iraq broke its February agreement with the Security Council and the Secretary General, Kofi Annan, to cooperate fully with the inspectors, the officials said, they did urge caution on Mr. Butler. Secretary of State Madeleine K. Albright sent word to Mr. Butler that she wished to speak to him. After leaving Baghdad, Mr. Butler traveled to Bahrain, where he could talk to her on a secure line in the American Embassy.
The officials said that they were not eager to rush into a "precipitate confrontation" with Iraq that would focus on Mr. Butler instead of Iraq's breach of its promise to the Security Council and Mr. Annan. Nor did they want another military crisis with Iraq on Baghdad's timetable, before Washington could prepare the political and diplomatic ground.
"A confrontation on the ground in Iraq may prove a point, but it doesn't get you closer to what you want to accomplish, which is to help Unscom do what it needs to do," a senior Administration official said, referring to the United Nations Special Commission on arms inspections. "By keeping the focus on what Iraq has done, which is to suspend inspections, rather than on what Butler does, allows no country on the Security Council to contend, as some have done over the last six months, that Unscom and Butler have provoked Iraq."
At a news conference today, Ms. Albright denied reports that she had been urging Mr. Butler, the chairman of the commission, for months to avoid confrontations with Iraq.
"We have had no change in our policy," said Ms. Albright. "We support Unscom in its inspections and fully support Unscom's right to decide where, when and how it conducts its inspections." She added: "I do not tell Chairman Butler what to do. There should be absolutely no doubt that the United States wants to see Unscom succeed."
She was responding to news reports, also broadcast on NBC Nightly News on Thursday night, that Washington and London had tried, over a period of months, to dissuade Mr. Butler from carrying out surprise inspections in Iraq in order to avoid a new crisis with Baghdad. The reports cited officials concerned that Washington and London were undermining Unscom and arms control, a concern expressed regularly by some Unscom officials.
The White House spokesman, Michael D. McCurry, emphasized that although Mr. Butler takes advice from the Security Council, he makes all operational decisions on whether to make an inspection or not.
"That is not our role," Mr. McCurry said. Asked whether American officials had suggested that certain inspections be delayed or stopped, Mr. McCurry said: "We consulted with them about the best way to conduct their mission -- timing, outcomes, best way of achieving their mission. But we don't order them not to conduct missions."
Unscom itself issued a news release saying "the allegations are false." The statement denied that Mr. Butler "has been given or accepted external direction with respect to operational activities" of the commission and said he would "find it invidious were any attempt made to direct his operational decisions or to micromanage the day-to-day work of the Special Commission."
According to the Post account, sometime in mid-July Mr. Butler met with Peter Burleigh, the second-ranking American delegate to the United Nations. Mr. Burleigh read Mr. Butler a list of American questions about the planned raids. While Mr. Burleigh stressed that the decision was Mr. Butler's, he left Mr. Butler, the Post said, "with the plain understanding that the United States did not support his plan."
A senior American official, after having read the guidance Mr. Burleigh read to Mr. Butler, disputed the account, saying that the questions had sought information about what Mr. Butler planned, and that Mr. Burleigh had begun and ended the meeting with a statement of support for Mr. Butler and his work.
Mr. Butler intended to go ahead with the inspections, British, American and United Nations officials said today. It was only after Baghdad "pulled the plug" on Aug. 3 that Washington and London suggested that he avoid new inspections that Baghdad was going to block anyway, and that he take up Iraq's breaking of its promises with the Security Council first.
Mr. Butler then made the tactical decision to pull out the inspectors, the officials insisted. One senior official said that Washington had expected Iraq to pull the plug on Mr. Butler closer to October, when economic sanctions are up for review. One reason, the official suggested, might have been leaks to Baghdad about Mr. Butler's inspection plans.
Today, Representative Benjamin Gilman, the New York Republican chairman of the House International Relations Committee, wrote Ms. Albright to ask for a copy of Mr. Burleigh's talking points, "as well as similar talking points used by other Administration officials," including herself, in talks with Mr. Butler.
Senator John McCain, the Arizona Republican, wrote Mr. Clinton urging him to clarify Iraq policy and reaffirm his commitment to eradicating Iraqi weapons.
The officials insisted that Unscom had been making progress and had held as many as 10 surprise inspections, which included one at Air Force headquarters that produced a document leading to the discovery of Iraq's production of VX nerve gas for missiles, which Iraq had denied. "We have been the most consistent and forceful proponent of Unscom's right to conduct challenge inspections and to have full access when and where it chooses," a senior American official said.
The officials said the burden was now on Mr. Annan and the Security Council to get Iraq to keep its word. "The fault here clearly lies with Baghdad and not with Butler," one official said. "There's only one place to point the finger. It strengthens our hand in the Security Council, it shows the region that Washington is flexible and not eager to strike militarily at Iraq, and it lays the foundation for military action if necessary, while giving Saddam a chance to fold first in the face of a truly united Security Council."

HEADLINE: In July, Industrial Production Fell for2d Consecutive Month

BYLINE: Bloomberg News 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Industrial production declined in July for the second consecutive month as manufacturers struggled to overcome sluggish Asian demand and the General Motors strikes cut auto and truck output by 20 percent. Inflation remained tame at the producer level.
The Federal Reserve said today that production at the nation's factories, mines and utilities fell six-tenths of 1 percent in July, on the heels of a 1.1 percent drop in June. However, excluding the output of automobiles and auto parts, production rose one-tenth of 1 percent last month, in contrast to a decrease of four-tenths of 1 percent in June. 
 Analysts said the decline in total production would probably be short-lived. "In the second half of the year, a less severe Asian impact and an end to the G.M. strike should place production back on a healthy growth path," said Greg Jones, an economist at Briefing.com in Jackson, Wyo.
In a second economic report today, the Labor Department said producer prices rose two-tenths of 1 percent in July after having fallen one-tenth of 1 percent in June. Prices were pushed higher last month by the end of sales incentives offered by auto makers and a jump in electricity prices during the nation's recent heat wave. Producer prices are the prices that manufacturers and farmers charge for the products they sell to retailers, distributors or other buyers.
Other indicators released today showed the automobile industry's impact on the economy in recent months. A 3 percent decline in retail stocks of autos during June, when auto companies reported record sales, held business inventories to an increase of one-tenth of 1 percent in the month, the Commerce Department said. In May, there had been no change in the level of inventories.
And the University of Michigan's preliminary index of consumer sentiment fell to 104.5 this month from 105.2 in July.
The strikes, which started June 5 and were settled at the end of July, took an expected toll on industrial production. Production at factories alone fell seven-tenths of 1 percent last month.
Production of durable goods apart from automobiles and parts increased 1.1 percent in July, following a 1.3 percent decline in June. Output of computers and office equipment rose 3.1 percent.
With the walkouts over, manufacturing activity is likely to rebound in August and September. General Motors, the world's largest auto maker, has stepped up production.
"We're going to see a big bounce back as G.M. comes back onstream," said Elliott Platt, chief economist at the Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette Securities Corporation in New York.
That does not necessarily mean a return to the robust growth of earlier this year, however. Although the shutdown of most General Motors assembly plants, and the closing of many of their suppliers, was the main reason for the slowdown in industrial production, the output of clothing, chemicals and paper was also sluggish because of weak Asian demand.
The Fed also reported that the plant-use rate, which measures the amount of industrial capacity in use, fell to 80.5 percent in July from 81.2 percent during June. While the General Mortors strikes accounted for some of the decline, it was also a sign of slack demand and a signal of slower growth ahead, said Gordon Richards, an economist with the National Association of Manufacturers.
That fits the expectation of Federal Reserve policy makers, who meet next week to discuss whether to adjust interest rates. Slower growth would reduce the chance of an acceleration in inflation.
The producer price report raised no inflation warning flags, analysts said. The core producer price rate, which strips out volatile food and energy costs, rose one-tenth of 1 percent in July, following an increase of two-tenths of 1 percent in June.
The end of sales incentives pushed auto prices up eight-tenths of 1 percent in July. Analysts had expected the increase and dismissed its impact on the economy.
There were some isolated trouble spots in the price report. Energy prices rose three-tenths of 1 percent, bolstered by a 1.1 percent gain in residential electric power costs and a gain of four-tenths of 1 percent in the price of residential natural gas.

HEADLINE: HORSE RACING;
Yearling Market Booms At Auction at Saratoga

BYLINE: By JOSEPH DURSO 

DATELINE: SARATOGA SPRINGS, N.Y., Aug. 14

 BODY:
Leaders of the troubled racing industry, gathering today for their midsummer Round Table conference here, were greeted by news that at least one market was thriving: the market for young horses.
At the annual Saratoga auction of selected yearlings this week, the average price reached $211,395, a gain of 15 percent over last year. The sales grossed $34 million, a gain of 24 percent over last year. And the highest price paid for a horse this week was $1.7 million for a Storm Cat filly, the fourth-highest price for a filly in the history of the Fasig-Tipton auction house. 
 "Despite whatever jitters there may be in the equities market," said D. G. Van Clief Jr., chairman of Fasig-Tipton, "the market for good thoroughbreds is solid."
The president of the auction house, Walt Robinson, said a gain had been expected. "Right now, our world is good, and the game was here," he said. "I'd hoped for a $200,000 average. I think we had better horses and a better market."
The pricey filly was sold last Tuesday, the opening night of the auction, when the first of the yearlings was led into the sales ring and the auctioneer began prompting bids in the time-honored chant used by old-fashioned tobacco auctioneers. It was apparent that the slump of the early years of the decade was a thing of the past, and that money from England, the Middle East and Japan was still funneling into the market despite economic troubles in many parts of the world. The Storm Cat filly who fetched the week's highest price was bought by Prince Ahmed Salman of Saudi Arabia.
On closing night, Thursday, nobody surpassed the week's high bid, but a Summer Squall colt out of a Gulch mare brought the session's top price of $835,000. The buyer was Mrs. Milton J. Dance, the seller Lane's End Farm. The underbidder was Rick Pitino, coach of the Boston Celtics, who is active in horse racing.
The horse market began slumping about 10 years ago, when the excesses and record prices of the 1980's were deflated chiefly by changes in the tax laws that adversely affected the breeding business. But as the American economy grew stronger, racing purses grew bigger and foreign money started pouring into the breeding market, notably from Saudi Arabian and Japanese investors seeking to strengthen their bloodstock lines.
The turnaround took hold, gained major momentum in July when the Keeneland sale of select 2-year-olds set records and carried over this week to Saratoga.
 
FINISH LINES
Auntie Mame, a 4-year-old Theatrical filly, won her second straight stakes and her ninth race in 14 starts over all when she took the Glens Falls Handicap by seven lengths. The filly, trained by ANGEL PENNA JR., stalked the leaders into the homestretch, when she made her move. The French filly Yvecrique ran second, Makethemostofit third and Schemozzle, fifth. The winner ran the mile and three-eighths on the turf in 2:13 and paid $4.60 for a $2 bet to win. . . . Nine horses were entered in the $1 million Pacific Classic at Del Mar in California on Saturday, all carrying 124 pounds. They do not include Skip Away or Silver Charm, but do include Gentlemen and Puerto Madero, an entry trained by RICHARD MANDELLA, and Free House and Touch Gold, two stars of last year's Triple Crown series.
