HEADLINE: THE MARKETS: STOCKS;
Treasury Rally Surges Ahead While Stocks Continue Slump

BYLINE: By JONATHAN FUERBRINGER 

 BODY:
Long-term Treasury rates fell to their lowest level in 30 years yesterday, but the stock market's increasingly painful slide continued.
The drop in yields and the decline in stocks could both be traced to the economic crisis in Asia and the financial turmoil in Russia, and the uncertainty they have fostered among American investors. 
 With yesterday's slump, the Standard & Poor's index of 500 stocks is now down more than 10 percent from its high, the Wall Street definition of a correction. The Nasdaq composite index, which is dominated by technology stocks, and the Russell index of 2,000 smaller-company stocks have already fallen more than 10 percent. And the Dow Jones industrial average is just points away.
But even the weak performance reflected in these indexes hides the damage in the broader market and the pain that many investors have been feeling. According to Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, the stocks that trade on the New York Stock Exchange and the Nasdaq market are down an average of 35 percent from their 52-week highs. Twenty-five percent of the stocks are down 50 percent or more.
"When you look at the troops instead of the generals, you are in a bear market," said Thomas M. Galvin, Donaldson, Lufkin's chief investment officer and an analyst who expects the market to recover in the fall. "And the question is how long will it persist."
While stocks are tumbling, the Treasury market is rallying, and for some that is not a positive signal. For most of the last three and half years, the bond market and the stock market have moved in the same direction, responding to the positives of low inflation and strong earnings.
"When you see stocks down and bonds up, the message is there is a problem ahead for the economy," said Hugh Johnson, chief investment officer at the First Albany Corporation.
Stocks have been hurt as the economic drag from Asia reduces the corporate earnings that investors watch so closely. And each new company that now warns of lower earnings, as the Ciena Corporation did yesterday, has a bigger impact.
Asia is also slowing growth here and around the world. In addition, the drop in demand for important commodities like oil and copper is helping keep inflation low. Both of these trends -- and the millions of investors who are looking for a haven for their money -- is helping bonds and is likely to push long-term rates even lower in the months ahead, several analysts said.
"The predominant underlying fundamentals of a slowing world economy and lower inflation are the real drivers that are going to be here next month and the month after that," said Dan Lokoszka, portfolio manager, global fixed income, at Wells Capital Management in Los Angeles.
The yield on the 30-year Treasury bond finished at 5.54 percent, down from 5.59 percent on Thursday and down from the previous low of 5.58 percent on June 15. The price, which moves in the opposite direction from the yield, rose 29/32 , to 99 15/32 . The yield on the 10-year note, which is a benchmark for mortgages, fell to 5.39, from 5.44 on Thursday, but it is still above its low of 5.35 percent on June 15. The interest rate on 30-year mortgages has been below 7 percent for eight weeks.
The trend toward slower growth because of Asia, said Mickey D. Levy, chief economist at Nationsbanc Montgomery Securities, should keep Federal Reserve policy makers on hold when they meet next week.
Robert V. DiClemente, chief United States economist at Salomon Smith Barney, said he was working on scaling down his growth forecast for the second half of the year. "Big pockets of the world economy are deteriorating around us," he said, adding that the yield on the 30-year bond could now move into a range of 5 percent to 5.5 percent.
In the stock market, the Dow fell 34.50 points, or four-tenths of 1 percent, to 8,425, and is just 20 points away from a 10 percent correction. The Dow had shot up almost 100 points at the opening, in part because of a small rebound in the Russian markets and talks between Russian officials and the United States and other countries about more aid.
In addition, Hong Kong officials announced they had bought stocks to shore up that country's troubled market. Rumors of the announcement, which was made after the market closed, helped send the Hang Seng index up 8.5 percent.
But the Dow lost its gains in the afternoon and would have been down even more except that the stock of J. P. Morgan, which was once again the subject of new takeover speculation, jumped 8.2 percent, adding about 38 points to the Dow.
The S.& P. index dropped 12.16 points, or 1.1 percent, to 1,062.75 and is now down 10.4 percent from its high of 1,186.75. The Nasdaq index fell 12.35 points, or seven-tenths of 1 percent, to 1,790.19 and is off 11.1 percent from its high. The Russell index fell 1.04 points, or three-tenths of 1 percent, to 402.79. It is down 18 percent from its high and is off 7.8 percent for the year. The other major indexes are still up for the year: the Dow, 6.5 percent; the S.& P., 9.5 percent, and the Nasdaq, 14 percent.
The question now is will and when the retail investor, who has kept the bull market going in past downturns by buying on the dips, step in again. Abby Joseph Cohen, the co-chairwoman of the investment policy committee at Goldman, Sachs & Company, said investors are "having a hard time looking to September," when she thinks that the outlook for earnings and the economy will look much better than it does now.
Asia and the Clinton investigation are "dominating out lives right now," Mr. Galvin said. "Speculation is rampant and the only news is bad news."

HEADLINE: Cloudy Blue Skies

BYLINE: By SYLVIA NASAR 

 BODY:
With Russia facing financial turmoil, Asia sinking deeper into recession, the President fighting for his political life and the stock market swooning, the blindingly bright economic picture of the last couple of years suddenly looks murkier.
What makes things a bit scary is that the economy has already shifted into slower gear, and slowdowns -- which make it harder for businesses and consumers to shrug off random blows -- have a way of turning into recessions. "Things can pile up," said June O'Neill, director of the Congressional Budget Office. "They can unravel as quickly as they materialize." 
 But the economy is not likely to unravel anytime soon. Forecasters are counting on low inflation, falling interest rates and confident consumers to keep growth going in the year's second half. They are taking in stride last month's news about a slide in everything from industrial production to retail sales -- all made worse by the General Motors strike.
In fact, a slowdown, they say, is just what the doctor ordered. "The domestic economy is still very sound," said Mickey Levy, chief economist at NationsBanc Montgomery Securities. "I see it moderating from a robust to a sustainable pace."
The Blue Chip consensus of 50 economic forecasters sees growth just shy of a 2.4 percent annual rate for the second half of the year and more of the same next year. That would not be as heady as the average 4 percent growth rate of last year and earlier this year. But it is considered fast enough to keep unemployment near its 28-year low of 4.5 percent, without being so fast as to intensify inflationary pressures or invite interest rate increases by the Federal Reserve.
Not a single Blue Chip economist sees a recession beginning in the second half. "Asia has slowed the economy," said Bruce Steinberg, chief economist at Merrill Lynch, "but its only intrinsic problem is a shortage of workers."
Still, the risks to this essentially benign outlook are numerous and real, economists acknowledge. A disaster in one area or a combination of mini- disasters could darken the economic picture. Apart from bolts from the blue like a military confrontation with Iraq or natural disasters, Asia's woes could worsen sharply, reducing United States exports still further, deepening the downturn in manufacturing and hammering corporate profits.
The political crisis surrounding the Presidency could sap the economy, just as, in some analysts' eyes, Watergate may have deepened and prolonged the severe recession of 1973-75. Finally, a stock market rout could shake consumers' confidence and wreak havoc on household balance sheets, causing spending to collapse and inventories to pile up. In 1990 Saddam Hussein's attack on Kuwait and surging oil prices frightened consumers badly enough to tip the economy into recession.
Like the special effects in the movie "Armageddon," the nasty hypothetical possibilities are so palpable that it is easy to forget the economy's strengths. Momentum, for example. Sturdy consumer and business spending will probably offset a further deterioration in the trade deficit, a decline already built into most forecasts for the second half. The side effects of the Asian crisis -- the stronger dollar, lower interest rates and cheaper raw materials -- are actually bolstering the purchasing power of American consumers and businesses and lifting the profits of many companies in finance, transportation, services and consumer goods.
Analogies between President Clinton's troubles and Watergate fail to take into account the impact of Richard M. Nixon's economic policies and his bad economic luck, as Lawrence Kudlow, the chief economist at the American Skandia Life Assurance Corporation, points out. Long before Mr. Nixon resigned the Presidency in August 1974, inflation was spiraling out of control, the dollar was sliding and oil prices were soaring.
While a sudden, sharp stock market decline -- two or three times the 10 percent drop that several indexes have now taken from their recent highs -- would almost certainly affect consumers, there is no reason to believe they would head for the hills, especially since the Federal Reserve would surely push interest rates down to cushion the blow and encourage spending.
Though the fallout from the recently settled G.M. strike has made it hard to see clearly, consumers and businesses are still spending at a steady pace.
Business investment, which surged at a 26 percent annual rate in the year's first half, is bound to slow, but not necessarily to a crawl. Total corporate profits have flattened in recent quarters as companies in such fields as high technology, energy and machinery have seen sharp declines. Still, many companies in the service sector are still enjoying double-digit gains. Overall profit margins remain close to historic highs. Productivity is up nearly 2 percent from a year ago, and wage costs, while drifting higher, show no signs of taking off. Cash flow -- a measure of businesses' ability to finance capital spending -- is strong. "The fundamentals for capital spending are still pretty good," said Richard Rippe, chief economist at Prudential Securities.
Barring a sudden collapse in demand, there is little reason to expect that business will stop replenishing inventories. Stockpiles look fairly lean relative to sales. Much of last winter's big pileup, when inventory accumulation hit a record $91 billion, has already been whittled away.
As with business spending, consumer spending, which spurted at a torrid 6 percent annual rate in the first half, is bound to moderate. But the latest readings from the nation's malls show that sales of big-ticket items other than cars were up smartly in June. Consumers are not stinting on services either; so many consumers are traveling that airlines are once again raising fares, for example.
With consumer net worth $12 trillion higher than just four years ago, courtesy of the stock market, and consumers more willing to use their capital gains than ever before, consumers have been spending virtually everything they make and saving almost nothing. But newfound wealth has not been the main prop of spending; jobs are still plentiful and incomes are rising much faster than inflation.
So far, consumers have not been spooked by the latest stock market gyrations. Confidence, which is close to historic highs, seems to depend more on such factors as inflation, interest rates and, most of all, job growth, says Richard Curtin, director of the surveys of consumers at the University of Michigan. To the extent that consumers worry about the Asian crisis, he said, it is because they fear that it will result in layoffs.
Besides, the long run-up in stock prices has dwarfed the recent declines, leaving consumers with strong gains.
"Consumers will impart a degree of stability to the economy that wouldn't be there if they reacted like traders," Mr. Curtin said.
At the end of the day, a lot of economists' confidence in the economy reflects today's low inflation and zero budget deficits, which leave policy makers considerable maneuvering room.
"In a low-inflation environment, you have great flexibility for the Federal Reserve to counter an excessively weak economy," points out Mr. Rippe of Prudential Securities. During the economic slowdown in 1995, for example, the Fed eased three times, and the economy rebounded.

HEADLINE: Cottage Tenants Settle With Developers

BYLINE: By TRACIE ROZHON 

 BODY:
The cottagers are leaving their cottages.
Five elderly tenants who have battled developers' efforts to build a 31-story condominium tower on the site of their Regency-style one-bedroom apartments have agreed to accept a settlement and move out of their Upper East Side enclave by the end of the month. 
 The parties to the settlement have signed a confidentiality agreement, and declined to disclose the amount paid by the developers, a joint venture of Davis & Partners and RFR Holding. But Leslie L. Youngblood, one of the tenants of the so-called Cottages -- a snatch of countryside in the midst of Manhattan, along Third Avenue between 77th and 78th Streets -- called the settlement "sizable."
A year ago, Mr. Youngblood, a 78-year-old retired lieutenant commander in the Navy, said that if the developers wanted to settle, it would take "a lot more money than they think it will."
"And it did," he said Wednesday night.
In April, he had said that if the developers offered a million dollars to each renter, and paid moving expenses, "it would be silly to say I'd never take the money."
"But I'll be perfectly frank," he said the other night. "I don't give a damn how much money they had offered us. None of us would ever have left if our lawyer hadn't told us our chances of stopping this development were almost nil."
While they pack, the legal drama drags on.
Just this week, a judge refused to grant a group of tenants at 177 East 77th Street -- a rental building that overlooks the courtyard of the Cottages and is owned by the same developers -- a temporary restraining order to block development pending the outcome of a lawsuit the group filed this week against the city. The suit seeks to force the city's Landmarks Preservation Commission to hold a public hearing on preserving the Cottages. The commission has brought the matter before its designation committee -- consisting of commissioners and staff members -- five times in three mayoral administrations and has decided each time against holding a hearing.
The 77th Street group and hundreds of supporters, known as the Coalition to Save the Cottages and Garden, are also waiting to see what the New York State Division of Housing and Community Renewal will do about an application by the developers that would allow them to alter the area of the courtyard garden to build their tower. The tenants are fighting the application, contending that the garden is part of what they pay rent for and that the developers will reduce its size. The developers maintain that they will merely reconfigure the stone paths and greenery.
Though either battle could conceivably stop the project, several of the participants say privately that each effort is a long shot. In his remarks in denying the temporary restraining order, Judge Franklin R. Weissberg told the coalition's lawyer, Richard D. Emery, that he had "a hard row to hoe."
Even Deborah Valcourt, a spokeswoman for the coalition, who lives at 177 East 77th Street, said she had heard that the odds were against stopping construction.
"But, hey, something often comes from the most unlikely places," she said. "Something might come along that changes the whole ball game."
The five cottagers, all rent-regulated tenants paying between $225 and $1,650 a month, are going their separate ways. One, Ruth Berns, 82, has found a one-bedroom co-op apartment and is waiting to be approved by the board, her neighbors said. Another, Elizabeth Pratt Holthusen, 87, has rented a place in the neighborhood. Rue Faris Drew, 76, is still looking. "The prices are horrendous," she said. The developers have offered to put the tenants up in a luxury hotel for 45 days if they have not found new homes by the end of the month.
Mr. Youngblood has picked out a one-bedroom rental in the neighborhood; because it is a sublease in a co-op building, he, too, is awaiting board approval. In the meantime, he is packing up the glossy photograph of himself as a young lieutenant commander just leaving for Korea, as well as the framed photographs of his boats, his friends and his family. He is putting them in square cardboard boxes and piling them along one side of his bed -- the big bed with the ship-motif wallpaper behind it.
To the tenants who agreed to be interviewed, the move is a wrenching one. Each has lived in the unusual enclave -- with its glass-block, vaguely Moderne shopfronts on Third Avenue and its Regency-style mini-villas facing the elaborate private garden in back -- for more than 25 years.
"It's heartbreaking," Ms. Drew said. "To me, the Cottages represents a kind of force field -- it wants to stay as it is. And I realize that my house is part of my identity."
To Mr. Youngblood, who on Wednesday was sporting bold red knee socks and khaki shorts, the move is a traumatic one.
"I feel it like the other ones," he confided over tea in his dining room. "But you know, I'm supposed to be macho. I'm not supposed to cry."

HEADLINE: Chalmers Wylie, G.O.P. Stalwart in House, Is Dead at 77

BYLINE: By DAVID STOUT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON, Aug. 14

 BODY:
Chalmers P. Wylie, who represented Ohio for 26 years in the House and helped to win approval of the Federal bailout of the savings-and-loan industry, died today in Columbus, Ohio. He was 77.
Mr. Wylie had a heart attack while waiting to have a routine eye examination at Ohio State University Medical Center, the center announced. 
 As the ranking Republican on the House Banking Committee, Mr. Wylie helped to tailor President Bush's plan to rescue the savings-and-loan industry so it could gain support in the Democratic-controlled Congress.
Although the precise causes and costs are still in doubt, there is widespread agreement that many members of the industry went astray in the 1980's, an era of relaxed regulation and high-flying finance, and plunged into risky investments outside their original mission of providing home mortgages.
When a deep real estate slump, undependable interest rates, hard times in the oil industry and other factors slowed the economy, the savings-and-loan industry was in big trouble, and since its deposits were federally insured it was certain that taxpayers would be left holding the bag. The total cost of the bailout, stretched over many years, has been estimated into the hundreds of billions of dollars.
Mr. Wylie, along with a Republican ally on the Banking Committee, Representative Jim Leach of Iowa, helped to win initial financing for the bailout in 1989 and renewed financing for several more years.
Mr. Wylie was able to work with lawmakers of both parties, The Almanac of American Politics said, because he was, basically, "a pleasant man."
He was also, by some standards, a proudly old-fashioned one. In 1984, Mr. Wylie, a Methodist, opposed giving Federal money to the Library of Congress so it could produce a Braille edition of Playboy magazine. The magazine featured "wanton and illicit sex," he said.
Mr. Wylie's district encompassed much of Columbus, including some of its black population, white working-class and rural areas, and the Ohio State neighborhood. Throughout his career, The Almanac of American Politics said in its 1988 edition, Mr. Wylie blended impulses that were "standard Republican" with political instincts that were "entirely practical, not theoretical."
Mr. Wylie was first elected to Congress in 1966, and his re-elections were often landslide victories. His worst showing was in 1990, when he won 59 percent of the vote against a relative unknown.
He strongly supported veterans' benefits, military spending and a law against desecration of the American flag. His stands on issues were dependably heartland Republican.
But a scandal involving the Department of Housing and Urban Development in the Ronald Reagan Administration distressed him, and he said so. The scandal involved former Reagan Administration officials who were paid large fees by developers seeking housing funds from H.U.D.
"My visceral reaction is that the fees paid were not appropriate," he said. Official inquiries would prove him right.
Chalmers Wylie was born in Norwich, Ohio, on Nov. 23, 1920. He attended Otterbein College and Ohio State and graduated from Harvard Law School.
Mr. Wylie enlisted in the Army in 1943 and rose to the rank of first lieutenant, serving with the 30th Infantry Division in France, Belgium and Germany. He was awarded a Silver Star for helping to evacuate wounded men from a mine field under enemy fire near the Rhine River in 1945. He was also awarded a Bronze Star, the French Croix de Guerre and the Purple Heart, for being wounded by artillery fire while helping to rescue wounded soldiers.
Before going to Congress, Mr. Wylie was the City Attorney for Columbus, an assistant Ohio attorney general and a member of the State Legislature.
Just before he retired from Congress in 1992, Mr. Wylie was one of more than 350 members who were hurt by disclosures that they had overdrawn their accounts on numerous occasions in the House's private bank. Although the overdrafts were simply covered by the deposits of other members, and there was no loss of taxpayer money, public surveys showed that many people thought erroneously that the offending representatives had "bounced" checks.
Upon his retirement Mr. Wylie said, "There is an ugliness in the House now which does not appeal to me." He practiced law in Columbus until his death.
Surviving are his wife, Marjorie Ann; a son, Bradley, and a daughter, Jacquelyn Poston, both of the Columbus area; three sisters, Ramona Wylie and Georgia Miller, both of Columbus, and Opal Bailey of Florida, and four grandchildren.

HEADLINE: TRACKING BAGHDAD'S ARSENAL: INSIDE THE ARSENAL: A special report.;
Defector Describes Iraq's Atom Bomb Push

BYLINE: By JUDITH MILLER and JAMES RISEN 

 BODY:
An Iraqi scientist who defected to the United States has publicly described for the first time the inner workings of Iraq's three-decade effort to build a nuclear bomb.
The scientist, Khidhir Abdul Abas Hamza, said that before he fled Iraq in 1994, he helped train a cadre of young scientists who with other scientists still working together on other projects would be capable of quickly resuming Iraq's atomic weapons program if the United Nations cut back on its inspections and, ultimately, lifted economic sanctions. 
 Dr. Hamza is the highest-ranking scientist ever to defect from Baghdad, and his comments, in nearly 10 hours of interviews, come as a new confrontation is building over whether Baghdad has dismantled its chemical, nuclear and biological programs. Iraq has in recent days refused to cooperate further with United Nations weapons inspectors.
In the interviews, the 59-year old Dr. Hamza, whose defection was an important intelligence coup for the United States that nearly slipped through American fingers because of the Central Intelligence Agency's inattention, drew a chilling picture of life as an Iraqi scientist. He said his colleagues were lavishly rewarded for their successes and tortured by the secret police when they failed to deliver.
He said Iraq's nuclear weapons program was personally directed from its inception 27 years ago by Saddam Hussein, Iraq's leader. It was abetted, he said, by a host of Western companies, which sold Iraq sophisticated equipment as they "winked and laughed" at patently false cover stories.
On the eve of the Persian Gulf war in 1991, Dr. Hamza said, Iraq had completed all the research and testing needed for an atomic weapon and was feverishly trying to make at least one crude bomb that would use uranium from its civilian reactors. This effort, Dr. Hamza said, could have produced a bomb in a few months, but it was disrupted by the allied bombing campaign.
Only after the war did American intelligence officials learn that they had grossly underestimated Iraq's nuclear program, which they believed to be 10 years from producing a nuclear bomb. But Dr. Hamza's defection to the United States and his subsequent debriefing by the C.I.A. brought fresh details to light, including these:
Iraq's peaceful nuclear power program, begun 30 years ago, was quickly turned into a cover for the secret bomb program, which went ahead even as Baghdad opened up its research reactors to Western inspection.
*Israel's intensive campaign in the 1970's and 80's to stop Iraq from acquiring a bomb accomplished little. The 1981 Israeli bombing raid that destroyed Iraq's French-built Osirak nuclear reactor prompted President Hussein to drop the pretense of a peaceful atomic effort and to go "full steam" on a covert program to build a bomb.
*Iraq took advantage of this country's open access to valuable scientific information. Dr. Hamza said that as a senior member of Iraq's nuclear program, he spent time at American university libraries studying the latest scientific journals and technical accounts of America's nuclear efforts.
Dr. Hamza, who intelligence officials said had been resettled here by the C.I.A., said he was speaking out now because he was frustrated that Mr. Hussein is still obstructing international inspections and deceiving the West. American officials said they did not authorize or encourage Dr. Hamza to speak publicly, but they have confirmed many elements of his account.
Until now, Dr. Hamza's defection has been a closely guarded secret. A 1995 article in The Sunday Times of London and a 1997 book by Andrew and Leslie Cockburn included detailed accounts of his alleged kidnapping and assassination by secret Iraqi agents.
In fact, his escape from Iraq is a remarkable spy yarn that almost went awry. According to former and current intelligence officials, the C.I.A. initially rebuffed Dr. Hamza's appeals to defect to the United States. He spent a year in Libya before the agency realized its mistake and agreed to resettle him and rescue his family from their home in downtown Baghdad.
 
Nuclear Ambitions
He Helped Start Secret Arms Program
Born in southern Iraq in a family of Shiite Muslims, Dr. Hamza graduated from Baghdad University and studied physics in the early 1960's at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology and Florida State University. After teaching briefly at Florida State and a small college in Georgia, Dr. Hamza returned home in 1970.
He became chairman of the physics department of Iraq's tiny nuclear research center outside Baghdad, and was approached a year later by two envoys from Mr. Hussein, then Iraq's Vice President but already its de facto ruler.
He said they had asked him to help start a secret nuclear weapons program under the cover of an expanded civilian atomic energy program. Dr. Hamza said that though he had reservations about building a nuclear bomb, he was enticed by the promise of extra money and stature as well as the possibility that the civilian program might benefit.
A round of recent public hangings in Baghdad, he said, underscored the dangers of refusing such a request.
In 1972, Dr. Hamza submitted to Mr. Hussein Iraq's first comprehensive plan for developing nuclear weapons -- naming it the "Hussein plan." "We didn't know then that Saddam hated his father and his father's name," Dr. Hamza sheepishly recalled.
The plan was quickly adopted, although Mr. Hussein rejected Dr. Hamza's ambitious proposals for a separate nuclear city and lavish benefits for its scientists. The Iraqi leader, he said, "thought that a separate atomic city would be too tempting a target for Iraq's enemies."
At first, Dr. Hamza dealt with the leader through intermediaries. But in 1973, he finally met his boss -- a volcanic encounter. During a visit to the nuclear center, Mr. Hussein berated Dr. Hamza, his chief planner, in front of his colleagues for failing to use frames to display photographs of famous scientists on the office wall.
"The man was basically illiterate," Dr. Hamza said of Mr. Hussein. "But here he was complaining about our insufficient respect for great minds. I knew what he was doing: Saddam had to establish his authority by putting the man who had made the plan in his place."
Mr. Hussein tightened his grip over the growing nuclear program in 1974, Dr. Hamza said, secretly naming himself chairman of the Iraqi Atomic Energy Commission -- a fact that Iraq has denied to United Nations inspectors. He also began controlling every aspect of the scientists' lives, ordering them to divorce foreign wives and marry Iraqi women, while forcing them to report any contact with foreigners.
Scientists ignored such orders at their peril. In January 1980, Mr. Hussein had Iraq's most senior nuclear scientist, Jaafar D. Jaafar , jailed and tortured until he agreed to work on an enrichment program that would separate uranium particles and make bomb-grade fuel. "Jaafar was so badly beaten that he still jumps out of his chair at the slightest scare," Dr. Hamza said.
 
Help From Abroad
Easy Purchases From Several Nations
Dr. Hamza said he found it surprisingly easy to negotiate nuclear cooperation agreements with the former Soviet Union, India, Brazil, France and others to buy nuclear technology that could be used for bombs under peaceful cover. "If you go with the money and some brains, it's easy to acquire the stuff," he said.
Among other things, Iraq bought a French reactor and an Italian fuel reprocessing facility, an I.B.M. mainframe computer from the United States, and machine tools to make centrifuge components from the Swiss. In 1987 it almost bought for between $110 million and $120 million a complete foundry to forge uranium and other bomb-related components from Leybold and Degussa, two West German companies.
Dr. Hamza, who monitored the negotiations in Germany from a room next door to the meeting, said the companies had offered to supply not only the foundry, but for $200 million, a complete installation that they promised could be built within months.
He said Mr. Hussein rejected the tempting offer mainly because he feared that such a large deal involving highly sensitive equipment would have tipped off Western intelligence that Iraq was transferring its bomb effort to a new site, known as Al Atheer.
"But we were astonished to see that the companies were actually helping us find cover stories for some of the equipment we needed," Dr. Hamza recalled.
Dr. Jorg Streitferdt, in-house counsel for Degussa, A.G., based in Frankfurt, Germany, which owned Leybold at the time, said the companies did sell some equipment that ended up in Iraq's nuclear program, and were later subjected to a series of investigations, including a criminal inquiry by Germany.
He noted that the Degussa was exonerated on the charges of selling Iraq vacuum furnaces largely because West Germany did not require export licenses at that time for such sales. Though the Degussa executives suspected that Iraq might use the equipment for military purposes given the ongoing Iran-Iraq war, he added, they did not know that Iraq wanted it for a nuclear program.
"DeGussa and Leybold did not know what the equipment was for," Dr. Streitferdt said. "The whole world did not know what Iraq was about to do. We have learned our lesson and now have very tough internal controls on our exports."
Years before Iraq's 1990 invasion of Kuwait turned the country into an international pariah, many of its nuclear-related purchases were made with the blessing of the International Atomic Energy Agency, the United Nations' atomic energy monitors. The agency assumed that Iraq was amassing the technical know-how for a peaceful power program, and did little to investigate. The inspectors, Dr. Hamza said, never asked even basic questions, "like why an oil-rich country like ours wanted nuclear power?"
Hans F. Meyer, the spokesman for the I.A.E.A., denied that the agency had ignored warning signs that Iraq was trying to build a bomb. "Our inspections were very tough," he said "but under the rules of the Nuclear Nonproliferation Treaty, we were only permitted to inspect the facilities that Iraq had declared."
Despite such easy purchases, Dr. Hamza said, the program was beset by almost constant setbacks -- the mysterious killings of senior Iraqi nuclear scientists traveling in Europe, corruption, technical blunders and vicious bureaucratic feuds among Iraq's scientists seeking to generate bomb-grade enriched uranium. But Mr. Hussein had an uncanny knack for turning such crises into opportunities, he said.
After Israel bombed Iraq's reactor in 1981, the Iraqi leader created the first completely independent, clandestine weapons program, most of which remained hidden from Western inspectors for nearly a decade. Liberated from having to march in lock step with its peaceful cover, the nuclear weapons program's staff grew from 400 to 7,000, Dr. Hamza said. And its budget soared.
At a time when Iraq's bloody war with Iran was draining the country's resources, nuclear scientists were insulated from the war's economic ravages and given as much as $150 million a month for the program, Dr. Hamza said.
 
Incomplete Results
Nuclear Scientists Beaten and Tortured
The Iraqi scientists were expected to produce results, and in one crucial aspect of the program, they had little to show. Despite years of effort, they had failed to produce the enriched uranium that is an essential ingredient in an atomic weapon.
When Hussein Kamel, President Hussein's ambitious son-in-law, took over the the nuclear program in 1987, Dr. Hamza said he helped him unmask a team of scientists who were falsely claiming success in enriching uranium.
Dr. Hamza was immediately named Iraq's director of weapons programs. "I went to the palace" he said, and "emerged with a new car and the title of a director general."
He said Hussein Kamel had ordered him to find a nuclear bomb trigger while other scientists pursued at least five different methods of separating uranium to make bomb-grade fuel. Dr. Hamza said that he had purchased a trigger in Poland, which did not work well, but that other Iraqi scientists developed a workable trigger in Iraq.
American intelligence officials knew little of the Iraqi effort, in part because the enrichment program relied on a technique abandoned by the United States after World War II's Manhattan Project some 40 years earlier. "They never put two and two together," Dr. Hamza said.
But the enrichment program was still slow to pay off, and Hussein Kamel grew restless. The inevitable result was the onset of beatings and torture for the scientists.
"Hussein Kamel used to send scientists who displeased him to the torture center in Al Taji," Dr. Hamza recounted. "You couldn't survive more than two weeks there." A director general of one Iraqi nuclear program was beaten so badly that "he couldn't come to work for a week."
Shortly before the 1991 gulf war, Hussein Kamel started a crash program to develop a bomb. "Kamel was crazy, but he managed to produce in a month things that would normally take a year," Dr. Hamza said. "Fear works well."
In December 1990 after Iraq's invasion of Kuwait, Dr. Hamza said, he asked to retire from the program. But he was told that he could do so only if he agreed to stay on as a senior adviser and help train Iraq's new generation of bomb-makers.
He left an important legacy. According to Dr. Hamza, the program had perfected two methods for enriching uranium, and each could have produced enough material to make a bomb as early as a year or two.
Dr. Hamza witnessed the intensive American and allied bombing campaign in the gulf war and was stunned at how little the Americans and their allies knew about Iraq's program. More than half of Iraq's major nuclear installations, most notably the sprawling Atheer complex, the program's busy new weapons center, were left largely untouched by the bombing raids.
Ultimately, Dr. Hamza's long-running bureaucratic feud with another leading bomb scientist, the terror of working inside the Iraqi police state and finally the killing of colleagues in the secret program convinced him to flee.
The final straw came when the body of Adil Fayadh, one of Iraq's chief nuclear procurement officers, was found near Dr. Hamza's farm. "He had a farm next to mine," he said. "They killed him and put him in the ditch on his farm. It got me very worried. It had to be Iraqi intelligence. That night, about two dozen people came to my house, pale-faced and worried. They didn't know what was going to happen."
Dr. Hamza defected soon after, and he continues to anxiously follow the Iraqi nuclear program from afar. He insisted that Mr. Hussein remains determined to reconstitute the chemical, biological and nuclear programs in which he invested so much. "Without these props, he would lose power," he said.

HEADLINE: NEWS SUMMARY

 BODY:

INTERNATIONAL A2-6
 
Terror Threat Closes U.S. Embassy in Albania
The State Department said it had shut down routine operations at the American Embassy in Albania because of "recent declarations by Islamic extremists against the United States." The department ordered some embassy employees to leave Albania and warned Americans not to travel there. A6 

Slow Rebuilding in Nairobi
Reconstruction has begun in Nairobi at the site of the blast, with cost estimates in the hundreds of millions of dollars. Big businesses have been immobilized, and small ones may be bankrupted, because insurers refuse to cover the losses. President Daniel arap Moi, whose ruling circle is widely viewed as corrupt, may act as a barrier to further outside aid. A6
 
Iraq's Nuclear Plans Detailed
An Iraqi scientist who defected to the United States has publicly described the inner workings of Iraq's three-decade effort to build a nuclear bomb. He said he had trained scientists to resume Iraq's atomic weapons program quickly if the United Nations cut back on its inspections and lifted economic sanctions. A1

Eighteen foreigners, including six Americans, were sentenced to five years of hard labor for handing out pro-democracy leaflets in Myanmar, but the Government immediately deported them, on the condition that they not violate Myanmar laws again. The 18 foreigners arrived in Bangkok today, many of them met by weeping relatives. (Associated Press)
 
Rights Review for East Timor
The United Nations and Indonesia signed an agreement to allow human rights observers access to East Timor. The region has endured civil unrest, guerrilla warfare and rights abuses since Indonesia invaded in 1975 and annexed it early the next year. The United Nations is brokering peace talks with Indonesia and Portugal, the territory's former colonial master, on East Timor's future. (Associated Press)

HEADLINE: INTERNATIONAL BUSINESS;
Finance Chief Confirms Steps To Aid Markets In Hong Kong

BYLINE: By MARK LANDLER 

DATELINE: HONG KONG, Aug. 14

 BODY:
After days of speculative attacks on Hong Kong's currency, the government confirmed today that it had intervened to shore up the stock and futures markets.
Sir Donald Tsang, the financial secretary of Hong Kong, said the government took the rare step of dipping into its reserves to buy shares and futures contracts because it thought currency traders were improperly manipulating the territory's financial markets to make "speedy profits." 
 "We do not tolerate attempts by speculators to manipulate our interest rates," a grim-faced Sir Donald said as he stood next to the chairman of the Hong Kong Monetary Authority, Joseph Yam, at a news conference here.
The monetary authority waded into the market to buy Hong Kong dollars late last week and earlier this week. But the government refused to characterize those moves as an intervention, saying instead that the government was merely raising local currency to finance a temporary budget deficit.
Today's action, which was announced after the stock market closed, is far more aggressive than merely buying dollars. Rumors of the intervention galvanized the market, which had been battered by heavy losses all week. The Hang Seng index rebounded 564.27 points, or 8.5 percent, to 7,224.69 -- its ninth-biggest point gain in history. The index had dropped about 16 percent since the end of July.
In addition to the government's purchases, rumors arose today that local companies with ties to the government were also buying shares to further prop up the Hang Seng.
Hong Kong's action underscores that after several weeks in which the foundering Japanese yen commanded the attention of Asia's markets currency trading is turning into a blood sport elsewhere in the region.
Using remarkably blunt language, Sir Donald accused traders of employing "a whole host of improper measures" to undermine the Hong Kong dollar. He said they had spread "vicious rumors" that Hong Kong was going to break its exchange rate, which is linked to the United States dollar; that China was about to devalue its currency, the yuan, and that Hong Kong's banks were unstable.
Sir Donald also opened the door to future intervention, though he cautioned that it would only occur in "exceptional circumstances."
Although the government's move rescued the Hang Seng from one of its most dismal weeks in recent memory, several analysts said the underlying reasons for Hong Kong's economic woes remained.
"The weak yen is clearly the fundamental driver, and it is growing weaker by the day because of domestic developments," said Jan Lee, the chief economist at the Hong Kong and Shanghai Banking Corporation here. "The Japanese authorities lack the political will to deliver the necessary changes."
 In New York Friday, the Japanese yen lost a bit of ground, trading at 146.35 yen to the dollar, down from 145.16 yen on Thursday.
Japan's Nikkei index turned in a similarly lackluster performance, declining 258.09 points, or 1.7 percent, to 15,123.93.
Some analysts also said they were troubled by the government's bellicose tone, which they said could erode the confidence of investors in Hong Kong. They noted that inflammatory remarks about currency traders by Malaysia's Prime Minister, Mahatir Mohamed, had alarmed many investors.
"It is legitimate to wage war against speculators in a calculated manner," said Miron Mushkat, a strategist at Indocam Asia here. "But Hong Kong is turning this into something of a jihad against the speculators."
Beyond the issue of tough talk, some analysts said they feared that Hong Kong might be unable to maintain its commitment to a linked exchange rate when the Japanese yen is spiraling downward and virtually all of its neighbors have already deeply devalued their currencies.
Under Hong Kong's monetary system, known as a currency board, the Hong Kong dollar is pegged to the United States dollar at a ratio of 7.8 to 1. When traders sell the currency in large volumes, the board can act to raise interbank interest rates, forcing down asset prices and eventually making the Hong Kong dollar attractive to investors.
The trouble with such a system is that the Government must be prepared to tolerate painful spikes in interest rates, which can strangle credit and hobble economic growth. Hong Kong is already limping through its worst downturn since World War II, with an unemployment rate of 4.5 percent and a 2.8 percent contraction in its gross domestic product in the first quarter.
"The politicians are absolutely committed to the exchange rate, but at what cost?" Mr. Lee asked. "At the cost of a very significant deflation in Hong Kong -- far more than what I believe people are willing to tolerate."
Previous efforts to defend the Hong Kong dollar have resulted in sharp drops in property prices and on the stock exchange, which is largely driven by real estate industry values.
By last Wednesday, after several days of intense selling of the Hong Kong dollar, the Hang Seng index was trading at a five-year low.
Sir Donald said today that the attacks on the Hong Kong dollar were designed to force a chain reaction of soaring interest rates and swooning stock prices. He said the same hedge funds that speculated against the dollar accumulated short positions in the shares of Hong Kong companies. When those stocks plunged, he said, the hedge funds stood to profit.
"The market is vulnerable to manipulation and has recently showed signs of becoming one of the main reasons of speculators attacking the Hong Kong dollar," Sir Donald said.
By engineering a rally in share prices, the government hopes to inflict heavy losses on the hedge funds -- a punishment it thinks will dissuade them from speculating on the currency in the future.
Still, analysts said Hong Kong would remain vulnerable to speculative attacks as long as its currency traded higher than those of its neighbors. Moreover, the gap between Hong Kong and other Asian countries seems likely to widen rather than narrow. The Japanese yen continues to weaken, and despite China's protestations, many analysts think it will eventually devalue the yuan.
Indeed, a Hong Kong brokerage firm released a report on Thursday predicting that China would devalue the currency at the end of the year. The firm, Indosuez W. I. Carr Securities, said Beijing would feel compelled to take such action in order to keep its economic reform program on track.
"If this were just a temporary crisis, you could just plug the gap for a year or so and get back to the reform process later," said Michael Taylor, an economist at Indosuez W. I. Carr Securities. "But it isn't."

HEADLINE: The Age of Reasons

BYLINE: By Jeff MacGregor; David C. McCourt is the chairman of RCN Corporation, a telecommunications and Internet company.

 BODY:
Language and technology march on. Even the excuse, once only a feeble handmaiden to reason, has been reconfigured to suit the new imperatives of our work-a-day postmodern age, Excuse-management techniques have lately taken our nation's capital by storm. In the "old" Washington, some misbehavior, personal or political, was too often explained away with one hackeneyed cliche after another - "I was drunk" being the formerly popular catchall.
 
 Now though, if reports of the tortuous maneuverings of the President's legal team are true and the legal team are true and the legal definition of "sexual relations" is being rewritten as we speak, we have learned the many benefits of a more refined and complex excuse strategy.
 Here is the well-lighted Wiggle Room of the Bland Corporation Think Tank, linguists, scholars, philosophers and theologians have been working overtime to provide the general public with their own updated set of plausible and judicious excuses for everyday misbehavior. Failed excuses from earlier in the decade are offered for comparison:
 Example #1: When stopped by the highway patrol for speeding.
 New Excuse: "Insofar as speed is defined as a function of distance traveled divided by the time it takes to do so; and insofar as all perceived times and distances are perforce relative in the Einsteinian paradigm of a saddle-shaped time/space continuum, who is to say just how fast any of us is really traveling, Officer?"
 Old Excuse: "I couldn't see the speedometer over this giant margarita."
 Example #2: When confronted by a teacher for failing to turn in homework.
 New Excuse: "Perhaps Thomas Wolfe said it best when he wrote, 'You can't go home again.' Thus, unable to return 'home' (defining 'home' here as a hypothetical sociological construct wherein persons related by blood or simply by a commonality of intention or a shared need or imperatives of personal economy), I was unable to perform any work there."
 Old Excuse: "It was two-for-one night at the National Press Club."
 Example #3: When apprehended for shoplifting.
 New Excuse: "The ongoing constitutional arguments in re the nature and definition of 'personal property,' especially those lately undertaken in the many nascent Emerging Democracies around the globe, might well lead one down a series of discursive cul-de-sacs as to the precise relation of the idea 'yours' to the idea 'mine.' Therefore, except in the few remaining Socialist outposts where property qua property is by assumption 'ours,' I can only assert that since ownership is a vague middle ground viz. a market economy as driven by the personal betterment of both buyer and seller, that I be allowed to return these to the rack they may or may not have come from in the first place."
 Old Excuse: "Hey! How'd these get in my purse?"
 Example #4: When the family pet has an accident on the living room rug.
 New Excuse: "Woof woof woof woof, woof woof, woof: woof woof. (Woof woof.) Woof woof woof. Woof woof woof woof woof woof woof woof woof woof woof woof."
 Old Excuse: "Woof."
 Example #5: When forgetting to buy milk.
 New Excuse: "That I 'forget' presumes a level of cognitive assonance between us by which it was a prioriunderstood that a transaction was to take place wherein 'milk' (skim, whole, 1 percent, 2 percent, or of an unspecified nature) was to be purchased and then brought here for disbursement into various pre-or unprepared foodstuffs. That these instructions were implied rather than explicit abrogates, de facto, any responsibility on my part for the absence of milk in this grocery bag."
 Old Excuse: "Don't we still have some Kahlua?"

HEADLINE: Framing Devices

BYLINE: By D. J. R. Bruckner; D. J. R. Bruckner is an editor at the Book Review.

 BODY:

TOWARDS A NEW MUSEUM
 By Victoria Newhouse.
 Illustrated. 288 pp. New York:
 The Monacelli Press. Paper, $45. 
 IN each of the last three decades 200 new art museums opened in this country. In Europe, where the pace is no less frantic, public investment in them is vast; they are used as engines of economic growth and urban renewal -- spectacularly just now in Helsinki and Bilbao, Spain. Many have no plans for a permanent collection; the museums exist before art is found for them. In Europe, as in America, they have taken over all kinds of unused structures built for other purposes, primarily empty industrial sites; in fact, some of the new ones are built to look like industrial sites. Most of the large new public museums encompass mixed media in some form, and a few seem bent on compressing World's Fairs inside their walls. The Centre Georges Pompidou in Paris, more familiarly the Beaubourg -- which houses many arts and much technology and commerce in what looks like a gas cracking facility -- was meant to regenerate a neighborhood, but the 8 million people visiting it every year have transformed it into the new center of Paris, reorienting the commercial structure and movement patterns of the city. Its lesson of museum power has not been lost on other cities around the world.
In "Towards a New Museum," Victoria Newhouse points out that in the 19th and early 20th centuries museums were conceived as temples of a new humanist religion. As they push toward ever greater popularity, they return to an older form, the 17th-century "cabinets of curiosities" that were the first museums -- collections of art, books, technology and natural wonders that challenged visitors to make their own discoveries. The cabinet of curiosities inspired the industrial fairs of the 19th century, from which modern theme parks take a lead, and now museums are borrowing ideas from theme parks.
Newhouse seems amused by a remark of the Italian architect Renzo Piano -- one of the designers of the Beaubourg, who is now turning the mammoth old Fiat factory in Turin, complete with its fabulous rooftop test track, into a cultural circus -- that the pursuit of popularity by museum designers could lead to the "profanation" of art. (He said that before anyone even knew that one of the giant hotel casinos now rising in Las Vegas will contain its own museum because, its developer says, people expect art as part of their total entertainment package.) Piano's word comes from old Roman religion, meaning a violation of a sacred precinct, as when the poet Horace, borrowing ritual temple rhetoric, proclaims: "Odi profanum vulgus" (I abominate pollution by the uninitiated). Now there is the authentic voice of an ancient hierarch.
Victoria Newhouse is no hierarch, although she has the social and professional qualifications to be one. She is on the side of the mold-breaking architects whose work seduces mobs to throng their buildings, if not always to enjoy the art. For her, the guides to the future are Frank Lloyd Wright's Guggenheim in New York; the Beaubourg, by Piano and Richard Rogers; and Frank Gehry's Bilbao Guggenheim. She also thinks the computer can be a popular gallery without limits for the exploration of art, the ultimate cabinet of curiosities.
"Towards a New Museum" is intended, she says, for architects; trustees, members, directors and creators of museums; "and, of course, their vastly expanding audience." I would reverse that order; for the general reader it is a comprehensive and friendly book. A researcher might find most of the information here in other publications, but having it brought together and ordered to support an argument gives it coherence, and the position and career of the writer give it authority. Newhouse established the Architectural History Foundation, and she has written about architecture for years in journals and magazines. She has insights into artists, architects, trustees and directors that few journalists could match, and she writes about them with rare candor, taking the reader into her confidence. As she makes judgments she defines her standards and lets us feel her passion for good building; so, reading her appraisals of museums, we come to know her mind and to appreciate how searing a quiet expression of disapproval can be, or how exalting a word of praise. The book is so intimate and unpretentious that its richness in history and the history of ideas comes as a surprise.
What trustees and directors must understand, Newhouse demonstrates, is that architecture is art, and a museum's architecture is part of the art experience. Too few of them do understand, but the reader begins to in her chapters on renovations of some famous museums. Additions can glorify existing institutions; her best examples are a new, separate Rafael Moneo wing of the Houston Museum of Fine Arts and Louis Kahn's gallery at Yale University. Readers will find little comfort but great illumination in her mournful discussions of the Metropolitan Museum, the Museum of Modern Art and the Guggenheim in New York, and in the acid treatment of I. M. Pei's pyramid entry to the Louvre. In fact, Pei, Richard Meier and Mario Botta come in for some rough handling altogether.
Wright's Guggenheim can be saved anytime the trustees find the guts to pulverize the slab glued to it in 1992 and then to use it the way it was meant to be used. The Met and MOMA are more serious cases -- casualties, Newhouse suggests, of the ignorance, willfulness or weakness of trustees and directors. "A seemingly unlimited willingness to satisfy donor demands" for separate galleries has helped turn the Met into a dizzying maze of caves, and MOMA's refusal to admit that the age of the Modern is over leaves the architect of its renovation with an order to design a building for . . . who knows what? In that respect even Meier is let off the hook an inch or two for his design of the new Getty in Los Angeles. The trustees wanted only the most extravagant excrescence possible on the southern California mountains (I once heard one of them mention John Winthrop's "city upon a hill" and found his innocence touching; he can have had no inkling of the judgment Winthrop would call down from God on the Getty, or its founder); Meier's real clients were competing officers of divisions of the all-purpose Getty Trust.
Clarity of purpose is all in this game, and a smart client is an architect's best blessing. So, some of the most enchanting buildings in this volume are private galleries, those that house a single collection, and artists' museums -- especially the Menil Collection and the Cy Twombly Museum in Houston; the private Goetz Collection in Munich, designed by Jacques Herzog and Pierre de Meuron; and a small studio and gallery nearby, built for the sculptor Beate Schubert, that glows with beauty. The range of what Newhouse presents is enormous and enlightening, from Claes Oldenburg's Mouse Museum, which will raise a smile, to the Olympian galleries created by the artist Donald Judd in massive former military sheds in Marfa, Tex., which leave one simply dumbfounded.
Most of the artists she quotes have a healthy wariness of museums unless the museums happen to be their own studios. There are exceptions, like Frank Stella, who designed four museums for cities in Europe. The space given them indicates that Newhouse rather likes them, but Stella's plans and maquettes tell me a lot about why none were built. It was the rebellion of the artists that led museums to lofts and other experimental venues in the first place. Some of them suggest a limited life span for any given museum. Others reject special places for art altogether, preferring to try to turn the environment that surrounds their art into art -- which is pretty much what Newhouse wants architects to do.
All this only suggests the wealth of "Towards a New Museum." But this fine collection of ideas, questions, critiques and inspirations never bewilders or exhausts the reader. And the large number of artists, architects and critics Newhouse draws into the discussion is never distracting; her clarity of purpose is exemplary. So is the book's design; pictures, plans and drawings are filled with ideas not repeated in words. Reading through these pages is to be engaged in a provocative conversation with passionate, very intelligent people.

HEADLINE: Fusion Cuisine

BYLINE: By Corby Kummer; Corby Kummer, a senior editor at The Atlantic Monthly, is the author of "The Joy of Coffee."

 BODY:

 WE ARE WHAT WE EAT
 Ethnic Food and the Making of Americans.
 By Donna R. Gabaccia.
 Illustrated. 278 pp. Cambridge, Mass.:
 Harvard University Press. $24.95.
 
NO FOREIGN FOOD
 The American Diet in Time and Place.
 By Richard Pillsbury.
 262 pp. Boulder, Colo.:
 Westview Press. Paper, $19.95. 
 LIKE language, cuisine changes as you try to define it. Food preferences shift constantly, depending on what makes people feel most comfortable and what they can afford. America's diet, rooted less firmly than most in common traditions -- at least in traditions that don't turn out to be myths of recent creation -- rarely stands still long enough for anyone to draw its portrait. Two new books try.
Donna R. Gabaccia, a professor of American history at the University of North Carolina, Charlotte, seems to wish that the many groups that settled the United States had taken better care to preserve their food as a way of preserving their identities. This is well-explored territory, and it takes almost half of "We Are What We Eat" for Gabaccia to state her theme: "With immigrants, Americans and ethnic foods regularly crossing over ethnic boundaries by the turn of the 20th century, the confrontation of values represented by America's many cultures of eating seemed inevitable." We expect to see heated clashes and passionate adherence to quaint "foodways." Instead Gabaccia recounts, with scolding dismay, the inevitable watering down of the few ethnic foods that found widespread acceptance and offers little idea of how these foods could possibly have maintained their purity -- even among the groups that originally ate them.
Those groups were eagerly assimilating into the larger culture and rejecting their own cuisine, even as the non-ethnic-owned companies the author so mistrusts were denaturing it. Gabaccia spends much of the book explaining how dishes that began by differentiating the people who cooked and ate them were dulled in order to appeal to the masses. "Ethnic foods," she writes, with her penchant for pointing out the obvious, "often lose their ethnic labels, their 'authenticity' and -- critics argue -- their taste once they are mass produced by large corporations. It happened to hot dogs, beer, egg rolls and bagels; it is happening right now to pizza, salsa, hummus and sushi."
One would hardly expect otherwise in such a heterogeneous country. Gabaccia does not suggest how one ethnic group could have been persuaded to appreciate genuine renditions of the unfamiliar foods of another. And she hardly notes the growing taste for "Mexican" and "Caribbean" dishes far hotter and more extreme than the originals. Ethnic foods do not only become bland when America adopts them. They become coarsened and distorted too. Subtlety is lost when industry rather than individual cooks prepare dishes, using mass-produced rather than home-grown ingredients, and flavors are exaggerated to compensate. The author seems unaware of this, and she also largely ignores the current ransacking of ethnic repertories for potentially curative foods.
In a rare sharp moment, Gabaccia notes that "new ethnics" are trying to "recapture through food and eating the closeness of a bygone era, when families always ate a home-cooked, mother-served, meal and spent holidays together." The way to do this would be to reverse the national restlessness and stay in one place with parents and cousins. But rather than invest the time and emotion necessary to reproduce the "close-knit familiar world" they miss, these roots-seekers -- "consumers to their American core" -- try to "re-create the past by buying it" in the form of cookbooks and dinners at community festivals.
Too bad the author ended, rather than began, with these ironies. One wishes, too, that she had gone much farther with her brief discussion of what various immigrants thought they were saying about themselves by their choice of foods; dietary climbing and slumming, as her few provocative examples show, is nothing new. Unfortunately, most of "We Are What We Eat" jumps confusingly from place to place, group to group and decade to decade without connective threads. It's also difficult to have complete confidence in someone who describes knishes as "crispy square potato pies."
Richard Pillsbury likes cooking, tasting and thinking about food. A professor of geography at Georgia State University (and no relation to the food manufacturer), he also knows a great deal about the economic and demographic trends that underlie food preferences, and he has written a far more persuasive and complete picture of the American diet. "No Foreign Food" is also a good deal more readable. Although there is much overlap with "We Are What We Eat," Pillsbury's book is less concerned with ethnic interchange than with how migration and the economy have shaped the American diet, region by region. His discussion is realistic, succinct and contemporary. In asides, for instance, Pillsbury corrects the notion that some American foods are timeless -- like cranberry sauce at Thanksgiving (a relatively modern invention of Ocean Spray) and biscuits, which became "a Southern staple" only as wheat flour "came into economic reach of the majority of the population, probably in the early 20th century." He is especially strong, and refreshingly open-minded, about the unstoppable rise of fast food; his agenda is less politicized and his style more direct.
Pillsbury manages a clear-eyed tolerance that seems to elude Gabaccia. He is less alarmed by the promiscuous mingling of cuisines and the Americanization of formerly distinct foods, which, however bastardized, have allowed people "unfamiliar with and fearful of 'foreign' cuisines to be a little more adventuresome." If some regional favorites have become endangered, it is because the home cooks who once made them could afford to try something new. The dishes that bored them and symbolized poverty have now become the province of roots-seekers (even if the roots are not theirs) who turn out gumbos "more authentic than the real thing ever was."
The American culinary interchange goes on with every new arrival and every population shift. Pillsbury is sanguine. "Ultimately," he writes, "the vitality and power of the nation's all-embracing culture has meant that there can be no foreign food." Perhaps the most useful attitude is simple curiosity about what's on the next guy's plate.

SECTION: Section 7; Page 24; Column 1; Book Review Desk

LENGTH: 886 words

HEADLINE: New & Noteworthy Paperbacks

BYLINE: By Scott Veale

 BODY:

Trail Fever: Spin Doctors, Rented Strangers, and Thumb Wrestlers on the Road to the White House
 By Michael Lewis. Vintage, $14. 
 In reporting on the 1996 Presidential campaign, the author details the nearly farcical demands of politics in the television age and discovers more wisdom and bravery among those at the bottom of the political food chain than at the top. The result is "deeper, funnier and more edifying" than the usual insider account of life on the hustings, Phil Gailey said in the Book Review last year.
 
Reality and Dreams
By Muriel Spark. Mariner/Houghton Mifflin, $12.
A hopelessly spoiled film director is tempted to play God, with ruinous results -- not for him but for his extended "family." Dame Muriel Spark, through the voice of her all-knowing narrator, is "as relentlessly observant of human habits and unguarded moments as she has ever been," Penelope Fitzgerald wrote here last year. An earlier novel, The Girls of Slender Means (New Directions, $10.95), follows the escapades of a varied group of young women living at a ladies' hostel in London after the Allied victory in Europe. In 1963 our reviewer, Virgilia Peterson, praised the author's "absolute pitch in dialogue, her economy of style and her sedulous avoidance of sentiment."
 
News of a Kidnapping
By Gabriel Garcia Marquez.
Translated by Edith Grossman. Penguin, $13.95.
The 1982 Nobel laureate in literature chronicles the brazen series of crimes committed by Pablo Escobar's Colombian cocaine cartel as it sought to undermine efforts to extradite Escobar and his fellow drug lords to the United States. Last year our reviewer, Robert Stone, said the author had "a quick eye for the illuminating detail and a capacity for assembling fact."
 
Tumble Home: A Novella and Short Stories
By Amy Hempel. Scribner, $10.
This slender collection features minimalist stories about parenthood, death and breakups, written as if assembled from fragments of conversation. "Hempel writes with an effortless wit . . . showing us the larger shapes of our lives by capturing their most fleeting and fragmentary moments," Elizabeth Gleick wrote here in 1997.
 
The Twentieth Century: A People's History
By Howard Zinn. Harper Perennial, $15.
In this abridged version of "A People's History of the United States" (1980), which has been updated into the Clinton years, a scholar takes sides with the losers, the downtrodden and the underdogs, arguing that too much history is written from the point of view of governments and elites. In his review of the original, Eric Foner found the approach to be limited, but said "Zinn writes with an enthusiasm rarely encountered in the leaden prose of academic history." The same publisher has reissued The American Century: Varieties of Culture in Modern Times, by Norman F. Cantor ($16), a sprawling guided tour of the century that was first published in 1988 and has also been revised and updated. In managing to cram in just about every notable trend, event and discipline, this is an "opinionated, idiosyncratic and thoroughly entertaining" survey, Hal Goodman said here last year.
 
Carson Valley
By Bill Barich. Vintage Contemporaries, $14.
Set against the shifting economic landscape of the wine country of northern California, this love story centers on a troubled young woman who returns from New York and has an affair with the manager of her father's vineyard. In 1997 our reviewer, Linda Gray Sexton, admired the author's "easy grace" and "elegant sleight of hand."
 
The Lady Who Liked Clean Rest Rooms:
The Chronicle of One of the Strangest Stories Ever to Be
Rumoured About Around New York
By J. P. Donleavy. St. Martin's Griffin, $9.95.
Jocelyn Guenevere Marchantiere Jones, a fresh-mouthed 43-year-old Scarsdale matron and Daughter of the Confederacy, finds herself slipping down the social ladder after her husband deserts her for a bit of "fresh flesh." Her travails make for a "rich, ribald and touching creation," Nina Sonenberg wrote here last year.
 
No<heart>l Coward: A Biography
By Philip Hoare. University of Chicago, $18.
Drawing on both careful research and gossip, the author maintains that the public image of Noel Coward as a languid hedonist was a fiction -- the actor, playwright, songwriter and world-class wit was driven by an intense passion for fame. "One of the many merits of . . . Hoare's book is to remind us of the man's self-discipline, his rigorous professionalism and his courage," Miranda Seymour wrote here in 1996. In Ghost of a Chance: A Memoir, by Peter Duchin with Charles Michener (Random House, $16.95), the last society bandleader tells the bizarre story of how he was left by his father, the bandleader Eddy Duchin, to be raised under the privileged wing of Averell Harriman. In 1996 our reviewer, George W. S. Trow, called this a "brave and stylish" book.
 
The Calcutta Chromosome:
A Novel of Fevers, Delirium & Discovery
By Amitav Ghosh. Bard/Avon, $6.99.
This mazelike thriller about weird science projects and global mind control begins when a computer programmer in 21st-century Manhattan stumbles onto the damaged ID card of a former colleague who disappeared in Calcutta in 1995. Last year our reviewer, James Saynor, called this "a finely carved mystery." Scott Veale
