LENGTH: 1725 words

HEADLINE: The Beige And The Black

BYLINE: By Michael Lind; Michael Lind is the Washington editor of Harper's magazine and a columnist for The New Leader.

 BODY:
Just when you think you're ready for 21st-century America, it changes on you yet again. A few years ago, predictions that whites would eventually become a minority group in the United States galvanized the multicultural left -- and horrified the nativist right. More recently, news of the growing number of mixed-race Americans has inspired the political center with a vision of a true racial melting pot, one in which white and black alike will blend into a universal brown. But a closer look at demographic trends suggests that neither of these futures -- a nonwhite majority, a uniformly beige society -- will very likely come to pass. Instead, shifting patterns of racial intermarriage suggest that the next century may see the replacement of the historic white-black dichotomy in America with a troubling new division, one between beige and black.
Racial intermarriage has long been a source of anxiety in America. After World War II, Senator Theodore G. Bilbo of Mississippi defended white supremacy in a book titled "Take Your Choice: Separation or Mongrelization." Like other racists of his era, Bilbo believed that an inevitable result of dismantling segregation would be the amalgamation of the races through intermarriage. He was right: since the U.S. Supreme Court, in Loving v. Virginia (1967), struck down the last antimiscegenation laws of the states, marriage across racial lines has grown at a remarkable rate. 
 Between 1960 and 1990, interracial marriages in this country skyrocketed by more than 800 percent. Roughly 1 in 25 American married couples today are interracial. In fact, there are at least three million children of mixed-race parentage in the United States -- and this figure doesn't even include the millions of Hispanic mestizos and black Americans who have European and Indian ancestors. Perhaps the best-known multiracial American is Tiger Woods, who has described himself as Cablinasian: a mix of Caucasian, black, Native American and Asian.
Oddly, the U.S. Census Bureau has yet to account properly for the presence of mixed-race Americans. As a result, many of its projections are off target. For example, the bureau has famously predicted that in 2050, whites will make up 52.7 percent of the U.S. population. (In 1990, it was 75.7 percent.) Hispanics will account for 21.1 percent of the population; blacks, 15 percent, and Asians, 10.1 percent. Presumably, 2050 will be white America's last stand. But this projection is dubious, because it assumes that for the next half-century there will be absolutely no intermarriage among the four major conventionally defined racial groups in the United States: whites, blacks, Hispanics and Asians. Each group is supposed to somehow expand -- or decline -- in hermetic isolation.
But according to an analysis of the 1990 U.S. Census data for persons ages 25-34 by Reynolds Farley, a demographer with the Russell Sage Foundation, 31.6 percent of native-born Hispanic husbands and 31.4 percent of native-born Hispanic wives had white spouses. The figures were even higher for Asians: 36 percent for native-born Asian husbands and 45.2 percent for native-born Asian wives. (In fact, Asian wives were as likely to marry white Americans as they were to marry Asian-Americans.) The highest intermarriage rates are those of American Indians. Majorities of American Indian men (52.9 percent) and American Indian women (53.9 percent) married whites rather than American Indians (40.3 percent and 37.2 percent, respectively). And these figures, which themselves document the creolization of America, undoubtedly understate the extent of racial intermarriage that the 2000 Census will reveal.
Of course intermarriage rates vary by region. White men in California in 1990 were more than six times as likely as Midwestern white men to marry outside their race. Overall, interracial marriages are more than twice as common in California (1 in 10 new couples) as in the rest of the country (1 in 25). According to the magazine Interrace, San Jose, San Diego and Oakland are among the Top 10 cities for interracial couples. America's racial complexion, then, will change more quickly on the coasts than in the heartland.
Nevertheless, the overall increase in intermarriage means that both multicultural liberals and nativist conservatives have misunderstood the major demographic trends in this country. There is not going to be a nonwhite majority in the 21st century. Rather, there is going to be a mostly white mixed-race majority. The only way to stop this is to force all Hispanic and Asian-Americans from now on to marry within their officially defined groups. And that is not going to happen.
Thus, the old duality between whites and nonwhites is finally breaking down. But don't cheer just yet. For what seems to be emerging in the United States is a new dichotomy between blacks and nonblacks. Increasingly, whites, Asians and Hispanics are creating a broad community from which black Americans may be excluded.
Disparities in interracial marriages underline this problem. Black-white marriages have risen from a reported 51,000 in 1960 (when they were still illegal in many states) to 311,000 in 1997. Marriages between white men and black women, though still uncommon, rose from 27,000 in 1980 to 122,000 in 1995. Although black out-marriage rates have risen, they remain much lower than out-marriage rates for Hispanics, Asians and American Indians. For the 25-34 age group, only 8 percent of black men marry outside their race. Less than 4 percent of black women do so.
While many blacks frown upon marriage by blacks to members of other groups -- such relationships are viewed by some as disloyal -- it seems very unlikely that such conservative attitudes are more pronounced among black Americans than among whites or Hispanic or Asian immigrants. The major cause of low black out-marriage rates may well be anti-black prejudice -- the most enduring feature of the eroding American caste system. Furthermore, antiblack prejudice is often picked up by immigrants, when it is not brought with them from their countries of origin.
In the past, the existence of an untouchable caste of blacks may have made it easier for Anglo-Americans to fuse with more recent European immigrants in an all-encompassing white community. Without blacks as a common other, the differences between Anglo-Americans, German-Americans, Irish-Americans and Italian-Americans might have seemed much more important. Could this be occurring again? A Knight-Ridder poll taken in May 1997 showed that while respondents were generally comfortable with intermarriage, a full 3 in 10 respondents opposed marriage between blacks and whites.
In the 21st century, then, the U.S. population is not likely to be crisply divided among whites, blacks, Hispanics, Asians and American Indians. Nor is it likely to be split two ways, between whites and nonwhites. Rather, we are most likely to see something more complicated: a white-Asian-Hispanic melting-pot majority -- a hard-to-differentiate group of beige Americans -- offset by a minority consisting of blacks who have been left out of the melting pot once again.
The political implications of this new racial landscape have not yet been considered. On the positive side, the melting away of racial barriers between Asians, Latinos and whites will prevent a complete Balkanization of American society into tiny ethnic groups. On the negative side, the division between an enormous, mixed-race majority and a black minority might be equally unhealthy. The new mixed-race majority, even if it were predominantly European in ancestry, probably would not be moved by appeals to white guilt. Some of the new multiracial Americans might disingenuously invoke an Asian or Hispanic grandparent to include themselves among the victims rather than the victimizers. Nor would black Americans find many partners for a rainbow coalition politics, except perhaps among recent immigrants.
One political response to a beige-and-black America might be a movement to institutionalize binationalism. In Canada, Anglophones and Francophones have been declared the country's two founding nations. Blacks, as a quasi-permanent minority, might insist upon a status different from that of voluntary immigrants who merge with the majority in a few generations. Such compromises, however, are difficult to maintain. If most immigrants blend into one of the two founding nations -- the Anglophone majority in Canada, the mixed-race majority in the U.S. -- then working out a stable modus vivendi between the expanding community and the shrinking community becomes almost impossible.
The other possibility is that black Americans will, in time, participate in the melting pot at rates comparable with other groups. Such a result cannot and should not be the aim of public policy -- how can you legislate romance? -- but it may be an incidental result of greater social mobility and economic equality. The evidence suggests that the association of people as equals erodes even the oldest and deepest prejudice in American life.
According to the 1990 census, white men 25-34 in the U.S. military were 2.3 times as likely to marry nonwhite women as civilians. And white women in the same age group who served in the military in the 1980's were seven times as likely as their civilian counterparts to have black husbands. Indeed, for all groups except for Asian men, military service makes out-marriage much more likely. The reason for this is clear: the U.S. military is the most integrated institution in American society because it is the most egalitarian and meritocratic. It is also -- not coincidentally -- the least libertarian and least tolerant of subcultural diversity. It may be that in the nation as a whole, as in the military, the integration of individuals can be achieved only at the price of the sacrifice of lesser differences to a powerful common identity.
In the end, racial intermarriage is a result, not a cause, of racial integration. Racial integration, in turn, is a result of social equality. The civil rights revolution abolished racial segregation by law, but not racial segregation by class. Ending racial segregation by class might -- just might -- bring about an end to race itself in America. It is certainly worth a try.

LENGTH: 2959 words

HEADLINE: In the Footsteps of the 49ers

BYLINE: By TODD S. PURDUM; TODD S. PURDUM is the chief of the Los Angeles bureau of The Times.

 BODY:
HUMANS have lived in what is now California for at least 7,000 years, and the land they live on was formed over a few million years of geologic time. But modern California -- the boisterous, roiling, polyglot place of dreams that so fills the American imagination -- was born on the morning of Jan. 24, 1848, at a sawmill on the South Fork of the American River in the foothills of the Sierra Nevada.
"This day some kind of mettle was found in the tail race that looks like goald," Henry Bigler, a Mormon worker at the mill, wrote in his diary. And from the moment that Bigler's boss, an itinerant carpenter named James Marshall, found two tiny nuggets, the first one about half the size and shape of a pea, in the water channel of the mill owned by John Sutter, nothing was ever the same. 
 Within a few years, more than a quarter million migrants from all over the world had come to seek their fortune, and though much of the boom went bust within a decade and population centers moved west and south, the settlers never really stopped coming. Today, the Marshall Gold Discovery State Historic Park in Coloma, a tiny village 50 miles east of Sacramento, readily recaptures the excitement of Marshall's find, with a reconstruction of the mill -- now run by electricity -- and a small museum with blown-up reproductions of Bigler's journal and other documents. It is as good a place as any to begin a sesquicentennial tour of the territory that made California the Golden State.
The patient -- or the merely romantic -- can still pan for placer, or particle, gold along the riverbank with wide, flat pans available at shops throughout the region, and the weary can swim in the Sierra-fed stream at a small campground across the way from the mill site. But Coloma is only the chronological starting point for visiting a region that, like the Cotswolds or Tuscan hill towns, best yields its treasures to unhurried exploration.
Stretching for more than 300 miles along California Route 49, the Golden Chain Highway, the Gold Country today is a collection of well-preserved Victorian frontier towns, historic museums, pristine parks and rivers for hikes and whitewater rafting -- and even a growing wine country -- all within easy reach of the grander splendors of Lake Tahoe and Yosemite National Park.
On a recent long weekend, my wife, Dee Dee, and I barreled north from Los Angeles in our own private stagecoach, a trusty Ford Explorer, racing across the vast agricultural expanse of the Great Central Valley into the rolling foothills northeast of Fresno. We drove almost the whole of Highway 49 over three and a half days, but confined our official wanderings to the northern half of the territory, the stretch from the town of Angels Camp north to Nevada City, with frequent stops in between.
It was in Angels Camp, in Calaveras County, that a young prospector with a literary bent first heard the tale of a celebrated jumping frog. A monument across the street from the old Angels Hotel on Main Street commemorates Mark Twain's inspiration, and an annual May Jumping Frog Jubilee at the county fairgrounds draws competitors from all over to re-enact the legend. Just south of town, atop a rise called Jackass Hill, a well-marked road off Highway 49 leads to a reconstructed cabin that may or may not be where Twain wrote the story that helped begin his career.
A short drive east on Route 4 lies the picturesque town of Murphys, where we stayed on an earlier trip to the region, with its old Main Street shaded by giant elms and locusts and looking unchanged from its heyday. There, the Murphys Historic Hotel, which once played host to Twain, Ulysses S. Grant, J. P. Morgan and others, still functions, and though guidebooks often cite its charm, it seemed a bit musty to us, and a steak and salad dinner in its restaurant was only passable. A far better redoubt is the Dunbar House 1880 bed-and-breakfast, a white frame Italianate cottage lovingly restored by Bob and Barbara Costa, who serve a delicious breakfast of home-baked goods in a peaceful garden.
Route 4, which heads up into the Sierras and in summer can be a delightful back-country route to Tahoe, with cattle wandering across the road in the high reaches of Ebbetts Pass, is a diverting detour, with at least one truly spectacular sight: the Calaveras Big Trees State Park. This stand of giant sequoias has neither the tallest nor the most-visited examples of this tree, but in the 1850's they were the first to be discovered by white settlers and for a time thought to be the only such specimens in the world. There are two groves in the park, one in the north with 150 trees, easily accessible from a parking lot; the other, in the south, with more than 1,000 trees, is reachable only by an easy milelong walk through an old-growth forest.
Back on Highway 49, the road continues north to the pretty, unspoiled town of Sutter Creek, named for the Swiss emigre whose sawmill started it all, but whose own efforts at mining here ended in dismal failure. A local merchant named Leland Stanford was luckier: he took a share of a nearby mine as payment for a customer's debt, and it ultimately became the basis of a fortune in railroading that propelled Stanford to the governorship and to the founding of Stanford University.
Now, Sutter Creek's Main Street is abuzz with a four-block stretch of gift shops, bed-and-breakfasts and antiques shops, and is home to what may be the finest luncheonette in North America, the Chatterbox Cafe. Sharing the name of Garrison Keillor's fictional restaurant but founded in 1946, long before "Lake Wobegon" was invented, it was taken over in 1991 by Mike Gill and his wife, Michele, longtime Keillor fans from the Los Angeles area who spied it on a visit and couldn't resist the name. It serves breakfast and lunch only, slowly, has just 14 stools and 5 tables, closes at 3 P.M. (4 P.M. weekends) and is practically perfect.
Mrs. Gill presides over an old-fashioned soda fountain that still pumps out syrup and seltzer in separate streams, requiring hand-dashing with a long spoon over crushed ice. In the kitchen, Mr. Gill grills fresh-made hamburgers on homemade buns with skinny, hand-cut fries from a bin of russet potatoes that juts out into the only passage to the tiny, immaculate bathroom. The waitresses are agreeably jaded and lippy, and virtually everything is homemade, from the iced tea to the cinnamon buns and biscuits, and after a lunch of two "Prospector" burgers (with thick locally smoked bacon and Jarlsberg cheese), and fresh blackberry and coconut-cream pie, we rolled out the door in a state of purest bliss.
Stuffed and sleepy after our indulgence, where did we go next? To a wine-tasting, of course, in the no-nonsense metal barn of Domaine de la Terre Rouge, just outside the haunting remains of Fiddletown, near Plymouth, in neighboring Amador County. Along with Calaveras and El Dorado Counties, Amador constitutes a growing local wine-producing region that dates back at least to the 1860's, when some of the immigrants -- Basques and Italians, for example -- brought grape cuttings with them; today it makes award-winning zinfandels, syrahs and other varietals.
IN fact, the growing conditions are not unlike the long, hot days of Provence, and Terre Rouge specializes in Rhone varietals like grenache, syrah and mourvedre. We were inspired to visit after tasting its Vin Gris d'Amador, a delightfully crisp dry rose. The winery is owned by Bill Easton and Jane O'Riordan, former wine merchants in Berkeley. The afternoon we visited, a friendly, though not especially knowledgeable, employee happily poured a half-dozen samples, and we went home with a case and a half.
Eager to make our Friday night's destination in Nevada City, we sped up the road, breezing through famous towns like Placerville (originally named Hangtown, for its rough justice), where my great-great-grandfather sought his fortune in vain in the Gold Rush but saw the money-making potential of the dry-goods business and returned to rural Illinois where he eventually opened a store of his own.
Having made our reservations on short notice for a crowded summer weekend, we had little choice of accommodations in Nevada City, a picture-book Old West town whose main thoroughfare, Broad Street, rises sharply up a steep hill. We stayed at a bed-and-breakfast called The Parsonage, and it was adequate, but we envied the inviting look of another, Grandmere's, in a sprawling house just up the street that was full that weekend, and decided it would be the preferred destination on our next trip.
Nevada City is best seen by walking its hilly streets, and there is plenty to see, from the small brick Nevada Theater, at 401 Broad Street, which dates from 1865 and is the oldest operating theater in the state, to the National Hotel, at 211 Broad, said to be the oldest continuously operating hotel west of the Rockies, with a broad upstairs porch. The Nevada County Historical Society Museum in Firehouse No. 1, at 214 Main Street, has a charming collection of old photographs and pioneer relics.
But by far the most interesting attraction in the area -- and one of the most compelling in all of the Gold Country -- is the Empire Mine State Historic Park down the road in nearby Grass Valley. This splendid 800-acre park is the site of the state's oldest, richest hard-rock gold mine, which operated from 1850 to 1956, when the price of gold made mining unprofitable. Here visitors can see what a big industrial business mining became after the era of the early 49ers, when technology made it possible to dig deep into underground quartz deposits, out of which gold was then laboriously "stamped" with giant smashing machines. We spent a fascinating half-day here, with an enthusiastic and articulate state park ranger as our guide, peering down a shaft of the abandoned mine. The mine, stretching 11,000 feet below ground, contains 367 miles of shafts, most of which are now flooded with groundwater.
There are plans for a ride that would carry visitors through part of the underground labyrinth, but even a tour of the mineyard is enough to sense the hardship of the miners, most of them emigres from the tin and copper mines of Cornwall, England. They brought with them their beloved meat pie, the pastie, which is still a staple in Grass Valley.
Just outside the mineyard, in a class juxtaposition worthy of Shavian drama, a gate leads to the lushly landscaped grounds and stone-and-brick cottage of the Bourn family, which owned the mine for much of its life. The family stayed here in Gilded Age luxury during their periodic visits to the mine, ensconced in gardens and a grove of trees but, even so, unable to escape the round-the-clock pounding of the giant stamping machines. Today there are tours and perpetual quiet.
After a quick lunch of delicious hot pasties at Mrs. Dubblebee's in Grass Valley, we headed off to Coloma, and then to a refreshing dip in the canyons of the North and Middle Forks of the American River at the Auburn State Recreation Area just east of Auburn on Route 49.
On Sunday, we wandered the winding streets of Nevada City, and then took one last stroll through natural beauty in the South Yuba River State Park at Bridgeport, a quick drive north of town on Pleasant Valley Road off Highway 49. Bridgeport is home to a beautiful 252-foot covered wooden bridge from 1862, one of the longest single-span covered bridges in the country, and offers a series of hikes and swimming holes in cool pools set back from the bubbling rapids of the South Fork of the Yuba River.
As we paddled from boulder to boulder in the soothing stream, we could feel the powerful tug of the current and couldn't help wondering if it still carried flecks of treasure. Reluctantly, we dried off with spare T-shirts and turned south to Sacramento for the long drive home down Interstate 5, the Golden State Freeway.
 
The Falklands connection
 As improbable as it sounds, the sesquicentennial of the California Gold Rush is also being commemorated in the Falkland Islands, the isolated and windswept British archipelago situated about 300 miles northeast of Cape Horn in the South Atlantic.
 The vast human migration to California set off by the discovery of gold affected even the remote Falklands. While a grand total of eight ships from the East Coast of the United States visited San Francisco in 1848, one year later nearly 800 vessels cleared Eastern ports bound for the Golden Gate, virtually all of them by way of Cape Horn. Given its location near the Horn, Stanley -- the Falklands' tiny capital and principal harbor -- was an important stop for repairs and provisioning, and the port's economy boomed.
 But Stanley apparently was not the port
of choice for 19th-century shipowners and captains. The few local companies able
to handle ship repairs charged such
excessive rates that it often made more sense to sell a damaged vessel for use as a storage hulk, jetty head or source of building materials.
 Despite its bad name among mariners, Stanley continued to serve ships until
the demise of the Cape Horn route, which followed the opening of the Panama Canal in 1914.
 Today maritime historians consider the Falklands the world's largest graveyard of 19th-century ships, and one of the most evocative reminders of the Gold Rush -- the sole survivor of the 1849 flotilla that converged on San Francisco -- is to be found at Goose Green, an hour and a half from Stanley over a fairly rocky road. Now just a partly submerged hull, preserved largely because of the sub-Antarctic cold and a protective seaward dock, the Vicar of Bray made its 1849 trip to San Francisco from the west coast of South America. The ship carried a cargo of mercury, an important ingredient in the processing of gold, and as soon as it dropped anchor the crew deserted and headed for the "diggins" in the Sierra foothills.
 The Vicar escaped the fate of much of the flotilla -- landfill in the bay for an expanding city -- because the captain was able to hire new hands at $80 a month, up from $10 just a few weeks earlier. The ship sailed for about 30 more years, part of that time on the London-Falklands route, and eventually became a coal hulk, or floating warehouse, at Goose Green.
 Given the Falklands' present population of 2,500 -- "barely enough to provide a good parade, never mind a crowd," according to John Fowler, the manager of the Falkland Islands Tourist Board -- the Gold Rush celebration will be decidedly low key. The principal public act of commemoration will be the issue of a special set of four postage stamps, including two that depict the Vicar of Bray and Stanley harbor in 1849. An American tour operator, Tread Lightly, (800) 643-0060, is organizing a two-week Gold Rush Days group tour to the Falklands in December 1999 that will be accompanied by Nicholas Dean, an authority on the islands' maritime history. HEADLINE: Lives;
An Even Exchange

BYLINE: By Karla Kuban; Karla Kuban is author of the novel "Marchlands."

 BODY:
At first glance, Taos, N.M., seemed to be heaven on earth. I moved there because it's beautiful: celery-sage-covered mesas, peach orchards, verdant pastures, mountain meadows full of clematis and fairy slippers, howling coyotes, the Rio Grande abundant with cutthroat trout.
My third week there I ran into a friend at the post office, and we walked next door to Dori's for coffee. When he warned me I should be careful in Taos -- lock my bike, bolt my doors, don't walk alone at night -- I was surprised. For all its beauty, he said, raising an eyebrow, Taos was a dark little place. 
 Taos has three major cultural communities -- Pueblo Indian, Hispanic and Anglo -- and has a high unemployment rate, 15 percent. When I went to the post office, our postal clerk handed my bundled mail to me. "Look at that," he said, glancing at a Taos News headline: "Teen Receives Skull Fracture in Fight on Bent Street." I had seen many headlines like it describing stabbing deaths, rapes, assaults with crowbars and other violent crimes. "That's sad," he continued. "That's sorry."
In 1997 Taos County police dispatchers received more than 16,000 calls. Nineteen local police officers, 13 New Mexico State Police officers and 18 Taos County sheriff's department officers serve a county of 28,000 inhabitants.
The newspaper had been reporting a peeping Tom for months, and a man was finally arrested. I learned he was one of the crew workers in my yard. He had knocked on my door and asked for my key so he could repair the balcony over the weekend while I was out of town. "How did you know I was going out of town?" I asked. He said he forgot.
A female friend and I went out for breakfast. I told her I was feeling unsafe. She pulled a .38 special out of her backpack and laid it on the table. I didn't feel that unsafe, I told her. Get one, she said. I couldn't. I was terrified of guns.
As I was riding my horse on a back road, four boys in a low rider pulled up, jeering and launching beer bottles over their car. The one on the passenger side, a kid, maybe 12, told me they could make me get off my horse and go with them. He pointed a finger at me and pulled the trigger. Blam, he mouthed.
I knew that violence was rarely random and without warning. Yet, at night, alone in my house, I began to worry. I could get a dog. I could take a course in self-defense.
I asked another friend whether I should buy a gun. He had one, he said. His former wife carried a short-barrelled .357 in her purse. Almost every woman he knew in Taos carried a gun.
At the post office I saw the kid from the low rider who had fired his finger at me. He was with a tiny woman who might have been his mother, and I was unafraid of him there. As he walked by I grabbed his arm. Hello, I said through clenched teeth. He stared vacantly into my eyes. He didn't ask, How do I know you; never mind, Did I scare you? I wanted to slap him for pointing a finger at me and pretending to shoot.
While crime around the country was decreasing, I realized I had chosen to live in a place where I felt more fearful than I ever had. I had made the wrong decision in moving there.
I went to the Wild West Trading Company, where Mike asked, "May I help you?" I filled out the Brady Bill form in case, down the road, he could help me.
A friend called to tell me that at 3 A.M. she woke to gunshots under her window, and when police arrived they found six bullet holes in the adobe wall of her house.
A few weeks later I went back to the gun store and saw Mike. I looked at several kinds of guns and within an hour I brought my new .357 home, three-fingering it gingerly by the butt of the stock as if it were dirty business, contaminated or unsanitary, the way I might have lifted a dead mouse by its tail and tossed it into the garbage.
Considering that my father is a gun collector and that I grew up with Remington, Ruger and Merkel rifles, Super Blackhawk .44 magnums, a Colt pistol and a Mossberg shotgun, to name a few, you would think I'd rest easy with a gun in my bedside drawer. But I knew that if someone broke into my house and I pulled out my gun, I had to shoot to kill. If I couldn't, I might die. Everything falls under headings: safety and fear, tranquillity and distress, darkness and light. Our every move is defined by antipodal forces. A gun's components bear contradictions: coldness and heat, pull giving way to push, a deafening blast followed by silence. My fear had shifted. In buying a gun I had exchanged one fear for another, perhaps even elevated it. But I could live with that.

HEADLINE: ART;
Lost in the Glow Of the Man at Her Side

BYLINE: By ROBERTA SMITH 

 BODY:
THE history of 20th-century art has had more than its share of female artists whose achievements have been overshadowed by the art of their better-known male companions. The list includes Sonia Delaunay, Lee Krasner, Frida Kahlo, Helen Torr, Marguerite Zorach and Anni Albers. Georgia O'Keeffe is one of the few exempted from this category, largely because her husband, the photographer Alfred Steiglitz, worked tirelessly on her behalf.
Of course, the importance of the male halves in the relationships varies a lot, as demonstrated simply by reciting, in parallel order, the names of the men attached to the women listed above: Robert Delaunay, Jackson Pollock, Diego Rivera, Arthur Dove, William Zorach and Josef Albers. But in comparison, the work of their female companions has received proportionately far less attention. One almost suspects some unwritten (or should we say unconscious?) agreement that a closer look at the women's art would be too threatening to the significance of their significant others. 
 But what is threatened is not so much an individual artist's stature as our understanding of artistic invention, and our tendency to view it as the province of a single artist rather than something shared and by definition collaborative. Lee Krasner, for example, is not equal in stature or importance to Jackson Pollock, and no amount of historical research will make her so. But her work deserves examination, and its quality, especially early on, strongly suggests that she had a role in Pollock's development -- that it would not have been the same without her.
It may be fine for Picasso to have identified Braque as "ma femme" during the early years of Cubism; it is less so for artists, or the art historians who tend their flames, to identify the women who really were their wives as artistic partners. But no artist is an island -- be he, or she, a movie director, composer or painter.
Which brings us to "Gabriele Munter: The Expressionist Years, 1903-1920," an exhibition of 70 paintings, drawings and prints at the Virginia Museum of Fine Arts in Richmond through Sept. 20. Even for students and knowledgeable admirers of 20th-century art, Munter (1877-1962) is little more than an elusive presence in the annals of German Expressionism. For decades she has been mentioned in these histories, when mentioned at all, as pupil and companion of the Russian painter Wassily Kandinsky. Such citings can't be avoided: with Kandinsky, Munter was one of the founding members of the Blaue Reiter group in 1911. But she did much more than that.
This show was organized by Reinhold Heller, a professor of art history at the University of Chicago, for the Milwaukee Art Museum, which has the largest group of works by Munter, 11 in all, outside Germany. Showing roughly a third of Munter's output during the period under scrutiny and none of her later paintings, the exhibition cannot be considered definitive. Still, it presents enough work -- much of it being seen in this country for the first time -- to verify that Munter and her art deserve far more attention than they have received. Backing this conclusion is Mr. Heller's catalogue text, which draws on Munter's letters and journals as well as on interviews from the late 1940's and 50's. It gives the first detailed account in English of her life, artistic development and relationship with Kandinsky.
The relationship seems to have been fairly tumultuous, punctuated by passionate times together, by separations crisscrossed with letters that often involved lengthy discussions of art, and finally by recriminations and betrayal. Munter and Kandinsky, 11 years her senior and married, met and fell in love in 1902, when Munter, determined to be an artist and dissatisfied with her training, enrolled in Kandinsky's drawing class at the experimental, short-lived Phalanx School in Munich. It was just about the only place in Germany where women could study art alongside men, the alternative being a dilettantish "ladies' art academy."
Over the next 11 years they often worked side by side and openly lived together. Kandinsky taught her, already a skilled draftsman, to draw in a quick, loose shorthand style -- as the prints and drawings in this exhibition strikingly attest -- and to translate this approach into painting. He praised her natural talent and innate vision and encouraged her to try this or that method or medium. But he was not above pettiness, reacting jealously if she wrote of interest in another artist's work (Picasso's, for example); complaining that their stressful situation, which made Munter something of a social outcast, was just as hard on him; and condescendingly patting her on the head, as when he suggested in a letter from 1903 that woodcuts might be "much too much for the small, poor (lazy) Ella."
They spent 14 crucial months (May 1907 to June 1908) together in and around Paris, working on prints and absorbing the ideas of the Parisian avant-garde, especially the work of van Gogh, Gauguin, the Fauves and Matisse. But when World War I forced Kandinsky back to Russia and he finally obtained a divorce, he married another woman. Munter spent most of the war waiting for him in Scandinavia. She did not learn of the marriage until after 1921, when Kandinsky sent a lawyer to collect paintings of his in her possession. Of such a saga, one can only say: screenwriters, start your laptops.
It would be nice to report that the show in Richmond will knock your socks off. It won't, but it will peel them off gradually and surreptitiously. Munter was, quietly and forcefully, a terrific artist -- a superb draftsman, inventive colorist and daring manipulator of paint and pictorial space, thanks to an innately casual, confident touch. Her tendency to simplify reality into economical, nearly abstract components is in step with her artistically momentous times, and sometimes a little ahead of them.
Especially riveting here are a series of small, radiant landscapes made in Murnau during the summer of 1908, in which she builds upon the tenets of Fauvism by concocting more unusual, discordant colors and broadening the often stippled brushwork that the Fauves carried over from Impressionism. The resulting bold shapes, which are really little autonomous slabs of paint, grant her extraordinary colors full voice.
In "The Murnau Moors" of 1908, for example, the landscape progresses through fields of light yellow-green, turquoise and peach to mountains of electric blue and then violet, finishing with a sky of more, but softer, light green and yellow. These hues are dramatized by small, framing intervals of darker, more traditional colors, greens and browns in quick, fat strokes that indicate trees and low-lying hills.
In her paintings of the village of Murnau, Munter's colors become even more electric, in part because the actual facades were painted different colors, but also because their contiguous planes, windows and shutters gave her more options for contrasts within a more restricted space.
One reason, beyond her sex, that Munter is only now beginning to receive her due may be that she doesn't entirely fit the German Expressionist profile. The people in her portraits rarely seem troubled or anxious; only occasionally does a landscape seem at all threatening, as in the uncharacteristically drab, barren terrain that isolates the single dwelling in "The Green House, Murnau" of 1911.
Even so, Munter's natural artistic inclinations -- her emphasis on color, direct paint handling and distortions of reality -- may have contributed to the style's development. Without reproducing any visual evidence, Mr. Heller argues as much, asserting that in August 1908, Kandinsky and Munter, along with the Russian painter Alexei Jawlensky, worked together closely in Murnau developing a new way of painting. He claims that no one artist was dominant and that their works were sometimes indistinguishable. In other words, a three-person version of Picasso and Braque.
But Munter's work fits in at several other locations on the map of early 20th-century modernism. She remained far more within the orbit of the French styles, especially Fauvism, that influenced all the German Expressionists. For her, Fauvism was not simply a jumping-off point for a more rhetorical mode, be it Kirchner's bitter social satire or Kandinsky's dynamic rumblings. Instead she built directly upon it, extending it as other French artists, most notably Matisse, were doing.
Like Matisse, Munter painted for the sake of painting, for the pleasure of recording her perceptions of the visible world in such a way that the colors and forms on the canvas took precedence, but without obliterating that world. And like Matisse, she envisioned art as an extremely intelligent armchair that soothed but also stimulated.
In particular, Munter's "Still Life, Yellow" and "Still Life, Red" of 1909, with their blunt compositions, bright dominant colors and black outlines, are startlingly close to Matisse's work at the time. She seems not so much to be borrowing from Matisse as to be paralleling his exploration while using other inspirations, especially the children's art that she began to collect around 1908.
BEYOND the French affinities, Munter's ability to imbue her images with a singular personality, through color and paint handling, also relates to certain American painters of the same period, especially Marsden Hartley, who visited her in Munich in 1913, Arthur Dove and to some extent O'Keeffe. Interestingly enough, Mr. Heller cites a journey to Texas to visit American relatives in 1898-99 as a formative influence on Munter, who photographed the landscape.
Munter was one of several European and American painters who continued to narrow the gap between method and meaning that the Impressionists had begun to close. Her paintings told the story of their own making with directness and honesty in a way that Kandinsky's large early abstractions, for all their influential all-overness, never mustered. Subsequent painting has made extensive use of both approaches.
This exhibition and its catalogue may raise more questions than they answer, but the questions are fascinating and raise equally fascinating larger ones about the nature of originality and the collaborative nature of all creativity. In the meantime, show and text also open a very specific field of inquiry for other art historians and curators concerning Gabriele Munter's art, her role in the development of Kandinsky's art and her contribution to the modernist enterprise. Munter could be the last artist's helpmate of the 20th century to be recognized in her own right; and she may be one of the most significant.

HEADLINE: Commercial Property/New Jersey;
With Occupancy High, Hotel Industry Adds Rooms

BYLINE: By RACHELLE GARBARINE 

 BODY:
SEIZING the moment while the state's lodging industry prospers, developers are scrambling to bring new rooms to the market.
Occupancy rates are high and room rates are rising. And with construction financing available and the cost of building a new hotel close to, or on par with, the cost of buying an existing one developers see this as a good time to build. Existing hotels are also expanding, industry analysts say. 
 The state now has 518 hotels with 67,523 rooms and 12 hotels with 1,480 rooms are to be added over the next 18 months, according to CB Richard Ellis, the national commercial brokerage, which tracks the hotel industry. Some 22 more hotels with a total of 3,541 rooms are planned.
Most of the new construction is all-suite, extended-stay and limited-service hotels. But now the economic stage has been set for a rise in the development of full-service hotels, for which there is a shortage of supply and an increase in demand, said Gregg Delany, vice president of the Lodging & Hospitality Services Group at the brokerage's Manhattan office.
The new hotels are sprouting up or being planned along highways and near office centers. They also are close to transportation hubs like Newark International Airport and in resorts like Atlantic City, where the number of casino hotel rooms, now at 9,177, will nearly triple over the next three years.
Among the factors stoking the activity, industry analysts said, are a favorable economic climate, the influx of companies expanding within or relocating to the state and the corresponding spate of development of office space. In turn, business travel is healthy, said Joseph A. Simonetta, executive vice president of the Hotel and Motel Association in Trenton, adding that tourism in the state has increased.
Manhattan's tight lodging market is also affecting New Jersey, especially close-in areas from the Secaucus Meadowlands to Newark, said John A. Fox, senior vice president at PKF, a hotel and real estate consulting firm in Manhattan. "It's not just a spilling over of demand, but a rate play as well," Mr. Fox said, adding that for Manhattan firms looking for more favorable rates New Jersey is an option.
Over the last 12 months ending in June the occupancy rate in New Jersey hotels was 70.9 percent, relatively unchanged for the same period in 1997, according to Smith Travel Research in Hendersonville, Tenn. Nationally, the rate was 64.3 percent. At the same time the daily room rate in New Jersey hotels rose to $89.04 from $84.03; in the nation it was $77.14, up from $73.31.
But Mr. Delany of CB Commercial pointed out that while occupancy and room rates for limited-service hotels are flattening because of the increase in supply, the rates for full-service hotels, buoyed by the lack of building, are rising. As a result, he said, "we expect to see more development" in this sector.
The next one to two years present a sanguine picture for New Jersey's hotel market. But Mr. Simonetta, of the state hotel association, said one wrinkle that could hamper its continued health is a bill that would expand the hotel occupancy tax law to permit all municipalities to impose the levy. Currently, only select cities may impose a tax, which is up to 6 percent for those communities.
THE bill, now in two committees in the State Assembly, would permit all other municipalities to levy a room tax of up to 2 percent on hotels with more than 100 rooms. Half the money collected would go to increase tourism and "provide advertising for hotels," said State Assemblyman Anthony Impreveduto, Democrat from Secaucus, who is the bill's sponsor.
The other half would go to municipalities to maintain and improve police, fire and emergency services since "hotels bring people into a community and put a strain" on those services, Mr. Impreveduto said. He said he was hopeful that the bill would pass by the end of the current legislative session.
Meanwhile, construction continues. One hot spot is the Hudson River waterfront, where 10 hotels are in various stages of development or planning. In Jersey City, where there are millions of square feet of occupied offices on the waterfront, one has opened, three are scheduled for construction within the next 18 months and two are under discussion.
The first hotel in seven years along the entire 18-mile shoreline opened last month in Jersey City at the corner of Washington Boulevard and Sixth Street, one block from the river's edge.
The 199-suite Club Hotel & Suites by Doubletree was developed by Hartz Mountain Industries, based in Secaucus, and Garden State Development of Jersey City. Room rates range from $149 to $189 a night at the hotel, the newest of six divisions owned by Promus Hotel Corporation of Memphis.
Near the Club Hotel, at the corner of Second and Hudson Streets, the Candlewood Hotel Company of Wichita, Kan., is to break ground in two weeks on a 213-room Candlewood Suites extended-stay hotel. And at the huge Newport mixed-used project at the waterfront's northern end, plans are advancing for a Marriott Courtyard Hotel, with 189 rooms plus 11 suites. Occupancy is expected in September 1999.
Mack-Cali Realty Corporation, a real estate investment trust based in Cranford, is moving forward with plans for a full-service hotel on a pier.
The hotel, with up to 250 rooms, will be part of the Harborside office complex Mack-Cali owns.
"We see a need for a hotel with conference and meeting rooms, which the area does not now have and for which there is sufficient demand," said Mitchell Hersh, president of Mack-Cali. He said construction is to start next year.
Among the other hotel projects elsewhere along the waterfront is the expansion of the 242-room Ramada Inn Suites Hotel at the 62-acre Lincoln Harbor mixed-used complex in Weehawken, a Hartz project. The company is expanding the hotel by 108 rooms.
Farther north in the community, Roseland Property Company of Roseland with Arcorp Properties of Weehawken is proposing a 300-room full-service hotel as part of an office complex to rise next to the ferry terminal there, which is to be expanded.
AND in Edgewater, the local Starwood Heller L.L.C. has a hotel on the drawing board as part of a residential, retail and entertainment development it plans to build at the river's edge. The hotel may have as many as 250 rooms.
"New York is underserved and there is a big shortage of hotel rooms in the riverfront area now," said Gene Heller, the company's president. "That's not to say the situation will be the same in three years," he added, noting that what it comes down to is "who can create a better product."
Suburban markets, with large pools of corporate tenants, are also getting their share of activity. Homestead Village of Atlanta entered the New Jersey marketplace last year as part of a national expansion program and is developing three extended-stay hotels in the state. The hotels, two with 140 rooms, the other with 141, are rising near established business corridors along Route 10 East in Whippany, Hoover Way in Woodbridge and Route 3 and the New Jersey Turnpike in the East Rutherford portion of the Meadowlands. Room rates at the hotel, which will open late this year or next year, have not been set.
"We look to see where corporations are locating their big back-office facilities and the north and central part of New Jersey has a growing number of them so they were obvious places to put the hotels," said Stephen N. Benjamin, vice president of development for Homestead.
That is also the strategy of Prime Hospitality Corporation of Fairfield. It is building a 128-room AmeriSuites hotel, its short-stay concept, on Route 4 in Fair Lawn, which is centrally located in relation to corporate centers in Bergen County and close to Manhattan, said David A. Simon, chief executive of Prime. It is set to open in January; rates will range from $90 to $100 a night on average.
Prime also is planning another such hotel in Edison as well as a Homegate Studio & Suites hotel, its extended-stay division, along the Route 1 business corridor in West Windsor, where it already has an AmeriSuites.
Mr. Simon said that while he was optimistic about the market because "the economy is moving forward, new offices are being built and there is demand for hotel rooms," he was also cautious. With all the hotels planned "we have to see" how deep the demand is, he said.

GRAPHIC: Photo: New Club Hotel & Suites by Doubletree in Jersey City, left. AmeriSuites hotel now rising in Fair Lawn, N.J. (Photographs by Frank C. Dougherty for The New York Times)

SECTION: Section 11; Page 1; Column 2; Real Estate Desk 

LENGTH: 2741 words

HEADLINE: Providing Places to Work, Places to Live

BYLINE: By DENNIS HEVESI 

 BODY:
BACK in Trinidad, a half century ago, Ortner Murray "never dreamed" that some day he might actually own property.
The only real estate Mr. Murray knew anything about then were the acres that he and his 11 brothers and sisters worked alongside their father, a sharecropper, urging bananas, coconuts and corn from earth entitled to an English landlord. 
 Now, because of an innovative program called Storeworks that tries to bolster the fortunes of less-than-affluent New York City neighborhoods, Mr. Murray is about to double the size of his sportswear business in Queens, and, to boot, become the landlord of several rental apartments.
"I wouldn't say we were poor," Mr. Murray, now 60, said in rose-tinted recollection of his boyhood days, working the fields with a machete and living in a spare house by a rutted, rural road. "We were happy with what we had, wearing worn shirts," he said. "My mother kept us clean."
These days, Mr. Murray and his son, Gerard, 31, ship 20,000 crisp new T-shirts a year, as well as jeans, jackets, shorts and socks -- most emblazoned with their self-designed logo, "School of Hard Knocks" -- to distributors as far-flung as Japan, Germany, England and the Netherlands.
And soon, thanks to potent doses of support from New York City and a not-for-profit group, the Murrays will expand their business in a mixed-use commercial and residential building along an increasingly bustling stretch of Northern Boulevard in Corona.
"This is gold for me, owning properties back to back on this boulevard here," Mr. Murray said. "This is for my son, and he knows it."
The Murrays, owners of Von's Sportswear at 106-11 Northern Boulevard, will soon take over 106-13, the building next door, with commercial space below and apartments above, that has been vacant for 34 years. They, along with 30 other prospective property buyers, are the first beneficiaries of Storeworks, a program created by Neighborhood Housing Services, the not-for-profit group, in partnership with the city's Department of Housing Preservation and Development.
The program allows small-business people and first-time home buyers to take title to deserted, ramshackle buildings in struggling neighborhoods by offering low purchase prices, favorable mortgage rates and, in particular, a city subsidy covering the difference between the purchase price and the cost of a complete rehabilitation -- a "gut rehab," in real estate parlance.
Storeworks, based on another, more extensive program called Homeworks that is operated by the city and eight not-for-profit groups, seeks to take advantage of the current real estate boom in many areas in hopes of seeing the opportunities filter out, even into the poorest sections of the city. It is, to be sure, a small start -- with only 40 buildings in the initial phase, 31 of which have been purchased by individuals, so far -- while hundreds of abandoned, so-called "in rem," buildings are still held by the city after foreclosure because previous owners failed to pay taxes.
But it comes at a time when signs of vitality are apparent in once-desolate neighborhoods. Crime is down. Rents are up, evidence of opportunity for some and -- with $700 to $900 for a two-bedroom apartment no longer uncommon -- a harsh squeeze for others.
Main thoroughfares are cleaner, though many side streets and vacant lots remain littered and rubble-strewn. The bricked-up buildings of the South Bronx, including those that not too long ago bore cartoonish decals pretending to be real windows, are slowly coming back on line. In East New York and Brownsville, Brooklyn -- still shadowed, of course, by phalanxes of public-housing towers -- affordable-housing groups are building new homes and private investors are renovating old ones, so that whole blocks resonate with the clang and clatter of construction.
According to Department of Housing Preservation and Development statistics, there are currently 2,232 buildings containing 19,084 apartments held in rem by the city. The department had no breakdown, however, for how many of those buildings are of the mixed-use type targeted by the Storeworks program.
Storeworks, as it grows, said Richard T. Roberts, the commissioner of Housing Preservation and Development, could be "one of the linchpins" in the city's efforts to "revitalize communities by renovating properties and returning them to the private sector.
"That creates," he said, "a platform not only for the properties themselves, but also for adjacent buildings. These properties become a catalyst. When a city-owned building is rehabbed, the adjacent owner feels an initiative to upgrade as well, attracting other investment, and helping to create a real environment for stability."
The underlying concept, said Francine Justa, executive director of Neighborhood Housing Services, "is to target an area with as many resources, human and capital, as possible. And if it works well, we'll do more of them across the city -- house by house, block by block."
A key component of the strategy, Dr. Justa said, is a study course for the fledgling landlords. "It builds people's capacity to help themselves," she said, "kind of an insurance. If you go to our home-maintenance training programs and learn how to install dry wall, understand BX cable, learn carpentry and plumbing, it's insurance for your investment."
GILBERT WOODFORD has already had hands-on experience as a landlord, and at 73, is about to give it another try. In fact, Mr. Woodford has a variety of experience: merchant mariner, postal worker, freight handler for the New York Central Railroad, taxi owner and, currently, bus driver for special-education children.
It was in the 70's that Mr. Woodford first became a landlord. "I had a couple of apartment houses, 16-family," he said, sitting in his minibus outside the three-story building at 524 Sutter Avenue in East New York that he is buying through Storeworks.
As he spoke, workers carried debris from the now-cavernous commercial space of the gutted building -- across from a weeded lot and down the block from the storefront Roca de Salvacio Church -- leaving only bare beams and rafters eerily lit by a string of bulbs.
"Did that for 15 years," Mr. Woodford said of being a landlord. "Had enough trouble with tenants."
Then why try again? "I'm 22 years older than my wife, Clara," he said. "So I'm trying to create some income for when I'm gone." The Woodfords plan to open a laundromat in the commercial space on Sutter Avenue. "We love cleanliness," Mr. Woodford said. "She believes laundry should be done correctly."
Observing that the neighborhood "has come back a great deal," Mr. Woodford said, "As people come in, they're going to have to get their clothes cleaned." The Woodfords do not intend to live in the building right away, "but I intend to be around," he said. "And having experience, I know you've got to get good tenants." He expects to charge "$750, $800" in rent for the two apartments.
"When I got into real estate they were practically giving these buildings away -- $65,000 for a 16-family building," he said. The purchase price for the Sutter Avenue building is $135,000, with a 5 percent down payment of $6,750 on a 7.875 percent, 30-year fixed-rate mortgage. The gut rehab on the building, paid for by the city, is costing $261,148.
"The city realizes that in the failure of these neighborhoods is the failure to collect taxes," Mr. Woodford said.
Peter Robbins, project manager for Storeworks, said the city sells the properties to Neighborhood Housing Services for $1 each. It has, so far, allocated $4 million to rehabilitate the first 40 buildings -- 31 in Brooklyn, nine in Queens.
"The old procedure was to auction off abandoned properties, and what you had was a bunch of starry-eyed entrepreneurs who thought they could make a killing buying cheap and doing an inexpensive rehab," Mr. Robbins said. "What they encountered was buildings in far worse shape than they imagined. So they couldn't rehab because they didn't have the cash, and the banks wouldn't lend because the rehab cost exceeded the property's market value. These guys would stop paying taxes, and the city had to take the building back again."
The Storeworks program is designed to find buyers who have a stake in the community, and it includes a mechanism to deter those trying to turn a quick profit -- requiring those who do to pay off substantial portions of the rehabilitation costs. And the program favors buyers who will either live or set up businesses in their building.
Denise George and Phillip Ashby, soon to be neighbors, fit that double bill. They will both live and work next door to each other -- she at 710, he at 712 Washington Avenue -- in two of three adjacent buildings that Storeworks has acquired at the corner of a hopefully appropriately named street, Prospect Place, in Prospect Heights, Brooklyn.
As Mr. Robbins pointed out: "The commercial strip is dense and dynamic south of Prospect Place, and we hope to bring that vitality to the other half of Washington Avenue. We're lucky we got three buildings together, because people will see that a lot of money is being invested here."
Ms. George, 30, an office manager with an architecture firm, is paying $180,000 for a building with 800 square feet of commercial space on the first floor, will live upstairs in one two-bedroom apartment and rent the other for "$700, $800." She plans to open a financial counseling business downstairs.
"It's my first time in business for myself, and as a first-time homeowner," she said. "It's a huge step, a little scary, but also a new-found opportunity." The rehab is costing $234,000.
MR. ASHBY, 29, a Fire Department paramedic, is also paying $180,000. He, along with a cousin, plans to relocate their currently home-based Internet business, New York City Web Corporation -- "we publish Web pages" -- to the renovated ground floor, and move in upstairs.
"It's a stepping stone that affords me the opportunity to have a commercial storefront and to market the way companies my size would, but without the overhead," Mr. Ashby said. "I won't have to deal with the exorbitant rent of a commercial space these days, being that I own the building."
Mr. Ashby estimated the market rate for the building at $380,000, "and a commercial mortgage would be incredibly difficult because you'd be putting down 25 percent up front." Under Storeworks, the down payment is 3 percent, or $5,400, with the rate on the 30-year mortgage at 7.875 percent.
It was in January 1997 that Mr. Robbins and other staff members at Storeworks began "windshield tours" of neighborhoods, stopping to knock on doors and talking to merchants, in search of the first 40 buildings.
After advertising for potential buyers in daily and weekly newspapers, the organization received about 500 applications. "They had to be city residents to qualify, and they had to qualify for a mortgage," Mr. Robbins said. "We asked everyone to send in documents, reams of paper, tax returns, bank statements, pay stubs."
Of the 500 initial applicants, about 125 completed the process and were deemed qualified. And on Aug. 6, 1997, a lottery was held to pick 40 finalists. Those 40 were then ranked according to criteria established by the city, giving priority to residents of the communities where the buildings were situated and, particularly, to those who live or operate businesses in the building. "Of those, 31 have signed on the dotted line," Mr. Robbins said.
Two types of mortgages are available to would-be buyers.
One is a Federal Housing Administration-insured loan offered through the Bank of New York that is usually limited to residential transactions. "If you are a first-time home buyer and you intend to occupy either the residential or the commercial space," Mr. Robbins said, "you can qualify for a 3 percent down payment. If you are not a first-time home buyer but still intend to occupy the property, the down payment is 5 percent."
The rate for that 30-year loan is 7.875 percent, "which is phenomenal as far as commercial buildings are concerned," Mr. Robbins said. Typically, commercial loans for the type of properties in the program have 15-year terms at 9.5 percent, with 30 to 40 percent down, depending on the financial condition of the borrower.
For an investor who will not occupy space in the building, the same loan program requires 15 percent down and the same rate and term.
Because the Bank of New York loan is government-insured, it carries rigorous underwriting standards and is document-intensive. "Often we have people conducting small, cash businesses who don't show enough income to qualify," Mr. Robbins said. "We didn't want to exclude those people we felt would have the best use for the property."
And so a second type of loan, not federally insured, was arranged through the Greenpoint Bank Community Development Corporation. "It's a no-doc loan," Mr. Robbins said -- no documents. "All they verify is the availability of the down payment; they don't check income." For that loan, the term is 15 years, the rate is 9.375 percent and the down payment, 20 percent.
To discourage "flipping" -- buying and selling for a quick profit -- the city places a non-interest-bearing second mortgage on the property in the amount of the rehab cost. If the buyer sells within three years, 100 percent of the profit goes to pay down that second mortgage. If the property is sold between years 4 and 25, the lesser of 50 percent of the profit or the balance of the second mortgage is due to the city from the owner.
As a compensating benefit, the city provides a real estate tax abatement. For the first 10 years, the building is taxed at its pre-rehabbed assessed value. For years 11 through 20, the assessed value increases by 1/10th of the difference between its pre-rehab and post-rehab value. So, at the end of 20 years, it will be taxed at full value.
"My personal read of these two subsidy mechanisms is that they make the building more affordable to people with lower incomes, because their annual expenses are reduced by the tax abatement," Mr. Robbins said.
ALL of which sounded like a real good deal to Michael Tate and his family in Brownsville, Brooklyn -- his wife, Wanda; his father, Bill Carr, and his three daughters, Asia, 17, Miasia, 9, and Nigeria, 4 -- all of whom pitch in to keep the family businesses going, particularly when Mr. Tate is shoveling coal into the furnace at nearby P. S. 150.
"He shovels 400 tons of coal a season, and has the hands to prove it," Mr. Carr said of his son. "Just look at those hands."
For 15 years, the family has operated Touch of Beauty, renting a storefront at 107 Belmont Street, where the sign says: "Curls, Dry Press, Neighborhood Florist, Funeral Designs, Balloons, Fruit Baskets."
It started as a beauty salon, but over the years diversified.
"I do everything," Mrs. Tate said, "hair stylist, barber, nail technician, body waxing, gift baskets, corsages."
"I go to Sarah J. Hale High School in downtown Brooklyn," said Asia. "In college, I'm going to learn chemistry so I can make my own product -- stuff to strengthen the nails. Since I was 11, I was passing rollers to mom, washing towels, being the go-fer."
Mr. Carr, the grandfather, works with flowers. "I do bleeding hearts for funerals," he said.
The family had been renting the store for $700. "The landlord stopped paying taxes," Mr. Tate said. "And when H.P.D. took over, the rent decreased to $500. But it was month-to-month; they wouldn't give us a long-term lease."
Then one day, Mrs. Tate said, "Peter Robbins paid a visit and told us about the program."
"And the lottery," Mr. Carr piped in.
Diversification was about to become expansion.
After winning the lottery, the Tates paid $125,000 for 107 Belmont, with a 3 percent down payment of $3,750. And last November, in anticipation of the $216,643 rehabilitation, they moved their business to a nearby store -- "next to the check cashing place, which is booming," said Mr. Tate, "near a laundry, a cleaner, a bank, a bus stop."
So, come October, there will be two Touches of Beauty in the neighborhood.
"We see this as a double opportunity," Mr. Tate said. "We come from this neighborhood. We've seen it coming up. Now we see ourselves going from nothing, a hole in the wall, to like the establishment of a mansion.
"I feel victorious."

SECTION: Section 14CN; Page 10; Column 3; Connecticut Weekly Desk

HEADLINE: Filling the Need for More Tee Time

BYLINE: By JACK CAVANAUGH

 BODY:
IN the early 90's, with the shade-tobacco business lagging, Kip Shepard and his three sisters and brother began to wonder if there might be better ways to use the family's 162-acre spread in South Windsor. "It had been a family-owned tobacco farm since the 1800's," Mr. Shepard said, "but we felt there must be some other way to derive revenue from our property."
The thought of building houses came up, but was quickly dismissed as an option, Mr. Shepard said. "For one thing, we wanted to preserve the open space and yet build equity," he said. 
 So what to do? "None of us is a golfer, but I knew that it was hard to get a tee time in the area because the golf courses were all overcrowded," Mr. Shepard said. "And I suggested that we build a golf course on the farm, and the rest of the family agreed."
So it was that a 6,580-yard 18-hole golf course, named Topstone for a onetime wholesale tobacco customer in Bridgeport, was built and then opened for business last summer on the site. Not too far away, in the town of Ellington, the last 9 holes of a new 18-hole course named Rolling Meadows opened on June 27 on what had been first a tobacco farm and then a dairy farm.
Using farm land for golf course development would seem to be at least one way of alleviating the overcrowding of courses in at least some parts of the state. But it is hardly feasible in some areas, like Fairfield County, where open space is at a premium and where tee times have been getting scarcer every year during the past decade.
Expansion of existing courses is another partial solution, but only when sufficient land is available. That is the case at the town-owned 18-hole Smith-Richardson course in Fairfield, where another 9 holes are scheduled to be built next year. This year, an additional nine holes are being added to several other courses in the state, including Quarry Ridge in Portland, the Stonington Country Club in Stonington, the Harbor Ridge Golf Club in Wallingford, Tashua Knolls in Trumbull and the Black Ledge Country Club in Hebron.
Though the second nine holes of Rolling Meadows only opened two months ago, John Gale said that he and his five siblings may add another nine holes in the near future. "We're doing very well and I can seen where there could be a need for another nine," he said. "And we have the space. Eventually, we'll also open a driving range."
Part of the Gale farm, which has been owned by the family since 1923, is still used for farming. "Two of my brothers, Andrew and Phillip, still grow corn and alfalfa on about 100 acres," John Gale said. "And my sister, Anne, keeps the books for the golf course and even helps mow the grass."
After most of the tobacco farm, including about a dozen buildings, was leveled during the 1938 hurricane, the Gale family switched to dairy farming. Then, in 1973, John Gale invested in the Cedar Knobs Golf Club in Somers, which is north of Hartford. "After that, I began thinking about possibly converting our farm to a golf course," Mr. Gale said. "I felt we had to diversify. Then in 1989, which was five years before our Dad died, I told him about my thoughts and he said, 'John, go ahead and do it.' "
Did all of his five siblings agree? "Well, not exactly," Mr. Gale said with a laugh. "It's hard to get six brothers and sisters to agree on something, but they finally came around." Ultimately, the course was designed by a Maine golf course architect, Al Zikorus, who also did some of the design on Topstone in South Windsor before he died a few years ago.
Although about 25 acres of farmland had to be cleared before the Rolling Meadows course could be built, scores of trees were planted, both for esthetic reasons and to separate fairways, Mr. Gale said.
By contrast, before work began on the Topstone course, hundreds of trees had to removed from an area that covered about 40 percent of the projected course, said Joseph Kelley, a part owner of Topstone. "We also had to take down about 12 tobacco sheds," said Mr. Kelley, who owns three golf clubs in Portland and was asked to become involved in the project because of his expertise.
Both new golf clubs, while privately operated, are open to the public at nominal fees. At Rolling Meadows, greens fees are $23 on weekdays and $25 on weekends and holidays, while at Topstone they are $27 on weekdays and $29 on Saturdays, Sundays and holidays. Nine-hole rates are also available, along with special rates for younger and older players. Rolling Meadows also offers season-long membership rates. Both clubs have clubhouses that include pro shops, restaurants and bars.
While Topstone and Rolling Meadows have been built and are already getting a considerable amount of use, and more than a half-dozen other courses are being expanded, plans are afoot to build about six more courses in Connecticut, which now has nearly 200 private and public courses overall.
Most of the projected courses would be the centerpieces of housing developments being planned. But so far, only one, Pistol Creek, which is scheduled to be built on 165 acres of private land in Middletown, has received all of the necessary approvals. Other projected sites for new courses are in Trumbull, East Haddam, Bolton, Guilford, Milford, Branford, Litchfield, New Milford and Harwinton.
Almost as many other proposed courses have either been turned down or delayed because of opposition from several sources, usually on environmental or conservation grounds, or both.
When voters in Bloomfield, by a 3-to-1 margin, approved a plan last November to borrow $6.9 million to build an 18-hole course on state-owned land, it appeared that the town would get its first public golf course. What made the deal all the more enticing was that the course designer, Peter Dye, had agreed to the job for only a $1 as a favor to a friend who lives in the town.
But then the Department of Environmental Protection vetoed the plan on environmental grounds.
"We're not so silly that we would have gone as far as we did if we had not received encouragement from the D.E.P.," said Ross Hollander, the chairman of the Bloomfield Economic Development Commission, and a proponent of the golf course proposal. "But then all of a sudden, the state administration became committed to the preservation of open space. They said that by building a golf course, it would interfere with hunting and general use of the space, when in fact no one goes in there now."
Mr. Hollander, who is a member of the Tumble Brook Country Club, the only course in Bloomfield, said proponents of a public course "are on track for another parcel," but declined to say where it was.
In Easton, a proposal to build a public golf course and about 100 luxury houses on 735 acres of property owned by the Bridgeport Hydraulic water company also fell through when the Aspetuck Land Trust, a conservation organization, exercised its right of first refusal.
The Land Trust then joined with the Audubon Society, the Nature Conservancy and the state to buy the property for open space at a cost of $12.4 million, of which the state will pay $6 million out of a $160 million fund set aside for the purchase of open space.
"The Governor's position is clear," said Dean Pagani, the press secretary for Gov. John G. Rowland. "He wants all of the land to be preserved for open space."
In Easton, as in some other cases involving efforts to use open space for golf courses, proponents contend that golf courses both preserve open space -- and, in the process, often beautify it -- and provide a recreational outlet for town residents. Further, they note, towns receive tax revenues from golf courses, both public and private.
Sean Garrity, the head professional and manager of the town-owned Smith-Richardson Golf Course in Fairfield, said it was becoming increasingly difficult to build new courses, or even to expand existing courses, "because of opposition from conservationists and preservationists."
"There are a lot of obstructionists out there, and it's becoming more political," said Mr. Garrity while adding that Smith-Richardson was adding nine more holes to handle an overflow of golfers. "It couldn't be busier than it is," he said.
With more young people becoming involved in golf -- many of them black and Hispanic, who've been drawn to the game by the success of the 22-year-old professional golf star, Tiger Woods -- another problem has arisen, namely, the availability of tee times on public golf courses, most of which are already overloaded.
"One of the solutions could be three-hole golf courses, where young people could at least be able to get out and play a bit," said Del Kinney, the executive director of the Connecticut State Golf Association, the governing body for amateur golf.
Or individuals can go out and build their own golf courses. That is precisely what Mike and Sally Donovan, a couple in their 30's with no golf construction expertise whatsoever, did in the town of Putnam over the last few years.
Mainly because Mr. Donovan, a landscaper, was having a hard time getting tee times at a course in Thompson, about 20 miles from Putnam -- plus the fact that he and his wife, a former school teacher, were looking for a new business venture -- they decided to borrow money from a relative and purchase 500 acres of mostly wooded property in the town that was available at a very reasonable rate.
On their own, over a three-year period, the Donovans -- after poring over materials on golf course design and construction -- proceeded to build an attractive, and challenging, 18-hole course in rural eastern Connecticut.
"People who ask who built the course still don't believe us when I tell them that Mike and I did," said Mrs. Donovan who often operated a bulldozer with her daughter, Bethany, strapped to her back. "But we did, all by ourselves, with help from the loggers who had to take down thousands of trees and from some family members during the summertime. The trouble is, we've been so busy running the course" -- the Putnam Country Club -- "that we rarely get a chance to play ourselves."
