HEADLINE: THEATER;
Of Endangered Lives, Real Heroes

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
WHEN it stays put, the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater produces plays, in English and Spanish, in its own space on West 47th Street in Manhattan. Since 1969, two plays a year, with Equity actors, have been seen at the troupe's home theater at top ticket price of $20. But that's indoors, and not in summer.
This month, the company's main stage takes second billing to all manner of makeshift platforms and scaffolding, and the company, not necessarily with professional actors, truly travels. In motion, it remains true to its beginnings and its mission: "to bring theater to the people," in the words of its founder, director and producer, Miriam Colon. 
 Now in the midst of its 32d tour of parks, playgrounds, parking lots and streets, mostly in New York City, the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater is staging "The Beautiful Soul of Don Damian," a dramatization of five stories by Juan Bosch, briefly president of the Dominican Republic in the early 60's. He has also been a prolific writer whose oeuvre includes novels, novellas, histories and political tracts, published from 1925 to 1987. The tour visits Danbury and Bridgeport this week. Performances are in Spanish, but a synopsis in English is provided.
Before a preview performance on Tuesday at Highbridge Park in upper Manhattan, teen-agers were breezing by on in-line skates or bicycles. Some were just hanging out; others were throwing basketballs and footballs. Children were spinning yo-yos and toddlers sliding and climbing on new play gear.
Shirts were not required; hats were O.K. Speakers blared combia, merengue, gaga and Afro-Latin music. Such was the real people's prelude to "The Beautiful Soul of Don Damian."
For the 75-minute performance, electrical equipment, costumes and sets had been transported on a single truck. Eight actors darted behind the roll-out stage for their off-the-rack costume changes. People sitting on folding chairs, resting on blankets or just leaning against trees watched Mr. Bosch's five stories being played out against fold-out scenery.
The short plays are about landowners and country folk, abandoned houses and erupting fires, endangered lives, horrific creatures and real heroes. In "Two Pesos' Worth of Water," one of his most popular stories, "the encounter between a woman's profound faith in divine justice and the brutal forces of nature" are depicted, in the words of the synopsis.
Ms. Colon's considerable acting credentials include stage appearances as Calpurnia in "Julius Caesar" for the New York Shakespeare Festival and in the lead role of Federico Garcia Lorca's "House of Bernarda Alba" at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis and the Milwaukee Repertory Theater. Her many films include "Scarface" with Al Pacino and in "One-Eyed Jacks" with Marlon Brando; she has just returned from filming a version of the Oedipus story set in Colombia.
Of the theater's street productions, she said: "They are very self-contained. The action is extracted and choreographed around a non-literal set.
"The important thing is the basic stuff: economy, enunciation, interpretation, passion. We are telling stories we want everybody to hear and to feel, and our narrator is the guide."
The opening performances in Manhattan were held during Dominican Heritage Week, which ends today. "Bosch is a major patriarch in the history of the Dominican Republic who writes about the destiny of his people," Ms. Colon added. "None are of his stature and relevance. And this is our first Dominican work."
This is the company's first time in Connecticut, "We need to have the pride of giving theater away for free," Ms. Colon said.
The company's home on 47th Street is just five blocks north and one block west of the New Amsterdam, home of "The Lion King" (top ticket $75 to $85) and the Ford Center for the Performing Arts (up to $135 for V.I.P. suite tickets to "Ragtime").
"It's appalling that people cannot afford so much of the theater that surrounds us in New York," she said. "We cannot be part of the spectacles for hundreds of thousands of tourists. So we create our own."
 
"The Beautiful Soul of Don Damian" is to be performed on Wednesday at 6:30 P.M. at the City Center Band Shell on Danbury Green in Danbury and on Aug. 29 at 5 P.M. in the parking lot at Aspira of Connecticut Community Center, State Street and Fairfield Avenue, Bridgeport. Information: (212) 354-1293.

HEADLINE: Can Baseball Shake Off a City's Economic Woes?

BYLINE: By FRED MUSANTE 

 BODY:
DR. ROB ZIKAROS said he was at a game earlier this year at Yankee Stadium, where he has box seats along the first baseline, when he overheard some fans in the seats behind him talking about the Bridgeport Bluefish. They had gone to a game at the Bluefish's new stadium, Harbor Yard in Bridgeport's South End, and had enjoyed it.
That made Dr. Zikaros, a physician who grew up in Bridgeport, practices there, and lives in Trumbull, the town immediately to the north, decide to attend a Bluefish game. On his way into the Harbor Yard stadium on a balmy evening with his father, John, and two young children, Matt and Jill, he summed up what seems to be the consensus about the team and its city. 
 "It's a comeback story," he said. Indeed, the Bluefish won that night, recovering first place in the Atlantic League with a 3 to 2 victory over the Newburgh, N.Y., Black Diamonds, and secured a spot in the league play-offs in September.
The Bluefish had been the center of the buzz in Bridgeport even before the city's mayor, Joseph P. Ganim, threw out the first ball in April. The plucky team seems to have single-handedly shaken off all of the city's decades of defeat and disappointment and ushered in a feeling of optimism.
Behind the talk, rife with baseball metaphors, is something more complicated, said Michael Freimuth, Bridgeport's Director of Planning and Economic Development. The Bluefish are a symbol and a focal point for public attention, he said, but the real cause for the optimism is the sudden blossoming of years of economic development efforts, fed by significant sums of local and state government seed money.
"The spring's been wound for a couple of years, and it's just sprung," Mr. Freimuth said.
New commercial projects, like wildlife emerging from winter hibernation into the spring sunshine, have proliferated so much as to leave some disoriented.
"It's frightening," said Paul Timpanelli, executive director of the Bridgeport Regional Business Council. "We have concerns about the capacity to manage all these projects simultaneously and have them continue expeditiously."
Mr. Timpanelli said there are discussions behind the scenes about quickly beefing up the city's staff of business development professionals to prevent this sudden boom from stalling. "Mike Freimuth can't do it all himself," he said.
Still, the Bluefish are the center of the whirlwind. From Mr. Freimuth's perspective, the quick and cooperative manner that the new team was established and its ballpark built, seemingly overnight in a moribund part of the city at the edge of its downtown business district, drew the attention of out-of-town developers to all that was happening in Bridgeport.
"It kind of woke people up, and now other projects in the city are being noticed,"
"There's a lot of people out there who are making the connection," said Jack McGregor, one of the owners of the Bluefish. Mr. McGregor and his wife, Mary Jane Foster, own a development company, Bridgeport Waterfront Investors. "We struggled for two or three years to get outside developers to look seriously at Bridgeport, but now we're on the receiving end of two or three calls a month."
The location of the Harbor Yard stadium is fortuitous. It is prominently visible from the Port Jefferson ferry, Interstate 95 and Conrail commuter trains that pass a few dozen yards from the outfield wall.
"I've had over a hundred people tell me directly they've seen the ballpark from the train," Mr. McGregor said. "They say, 'I saw it and I had to come by. I couldn't resist.' "
It is clear that baseball fans find the Bluefish a draw. Few of them, even those like Dr. Zikaros who do business in Bridgeport, bothered to visit its downtown in the past. But Charlie Dowd, the Bluefish's general manager, said neighboring restaurants have noticed an increase in business since the team began to play, and some have even extended their hours.
"It was an undesirable area," said Mike Mineo, a Stratford resident, who said his trip to Harbor Yard with a group of friends and relatives was his first into downtown Bridgeport in a long while.
"It's tremendously improved the spirit of the Bridgeport area," said David DeGrood, a retired Bridgeport schoolteacher who also lives in Stratford. He hadn't thought it would have as much of an effect as it has, he added.
Even Mr. Ganim's mother, who the mayor said "couldn't tell a foul ball from a line drive," has become an enthusiastic fan. On opening day, she said she only wanted to stay long enough to watch her son throw out the first ball, but instead stayed for the whole game. She's gone back for three more games, he said.
Early in the season, average attendance at the games ranged between 3,000 and 4,000, but by early July it had swollen to nearly 5,000, nearly filling the 5,300-seat stadium to capacity. Mr. McGregor said he expects that to be the average attendance for the second half of the season that will end on Labor Day.
For Mr. Freimuth, the team is emblematic of Bridgeport's new growth surge. "It puts the name of the city across the chest of somebody rooting to win," he said. But, he noted, it is hardly the whole story.
He said the memory of the city's failure to gain approval of a casino three years ago has faded, and along with it the resignation to an economic slump.
More conventional development projects gradually gathered momentum. A moribund downtown mall was converted to house Housatonic Community-Technical College. Fairfield County's state police barracks was moved to Bridgeport. A new ferry terminal was built, and a combination bus and train station is in the works.
Industrial property in the city's West End was redeveloped, and important new truck routes are being built linking parts of the East Side and downtown. Several large retail stores opened, and more are being built. Most of these developments were done wholly or partly with millions of dollars of state and local grants and loans.
Mr. Ganim noted that a $900 million development of the Steel Point property on the east side of Bridgeport Harbor is progressing. "That's nothing to sneeze at," he said.
Mr. McGregor said he expects to announce two new projects by the end of the year, one of them rumored to be a skating rink complex.
The opening of the Bluefish's baseball season corresponded with the start of the construction season as well as the release of much of the public financing that had been in the pipeline for years, Mr. Freimuth said.
He acknowledged Mr. Timpanelli's concern over the ability of the city government to manage the new growth. "We're working 100-hour weeks right now," he said. "That's very taxing on the staff."
To address this, the City Council recently authorized the hiring of two new development officers, and he and other city officials are putting together plans for a Development Management Division that will be independent of his department.
But he was more than happy to cheer on the Bluefish, both as a fan and as an economic development official. "I think the city needed a good old-fashioned serving of apple pie," he said.

HEADLINE: Youths See Summer Jobs As Training For the Future

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
IN a job market with strikingly low unemployment, many high school and college students in Westchester have been busily at work filling vacancies in a variety of job categories this summer. Like Andre Williams, 15, a busboy in Mount Vernon; Toni Susi, 16, an aspiring actress in Yorktown; Vincent Straface, 21, a peace officer in Rye, and Manoj Cheriyan, 19, a lab technician in Valhalla, they have been trying on part of their future for size.
Because he hopes to become a restaurateur someday, Andre is working in a Mount Vernon delicatessen, responsible for everything from preparing cookie trays to washing dishes. Recently he savored the rewards of his hard work (the job pays $5.15 an hour) by opening a savings account, buying two CD's and getting his fall wardrobe in order. 
 In Yorktown, Toni hit the boards this summer, playing the lead role in "Hello, Dolly!" at the Yorktown Theater Workshop and following in at least one of the footsteps of her idol, Barbra Streisand. "She's my absolute ideal!" the aspiring young actress and singer said. But except for the proceeds from an occasional baby-sitting job, there was no money to go in the bank, although as she said, "In my own way, I'm investing in the future."
At Playland Park in Rye, Mr. Straface, a student at Westchester County Community College who is majoring in criminal justice, was sworn in as a public safety park ranger for Westchester in June. Packing a pistol and wearing the uniform of the County Police, he sets out every afternoon to maintain peace and order in the popular summer amusement park. For $8.50 an hour, his duties include breaking up fights and arresting those who commit petty larceny on the county's property.
A former summer lifeguard at a county pool in White Plains and an emergency medical technician with the Harrison Volunteer Ambulance Squad, he was honored by the county last year as a hero for saving the life of a drowning 3-year-old. "Now that boy is growing up to be the man he was meant to be," said a proud Mr. Straface, who will enter a police academy in Albany this fall.
And in Valhalla, at the county's Department of Labs and Research, Mr. Cheriyan, a student at New York University from Croton-on-Hudson who is majoring in biochemistry, has been watching tuberculosis cultures grow. Like many other teen-agers, he is using the summer to get a leg up on his future.
"Some of my friends are tending bar or working in a grocery store, but I wanted to get first-hand experience in my field," he said. "This is better than selling shoes." His hourly earnings: $6.10.
Some of Westchester's students sought employment through a Federal program for the economically disadvantaged. Others found jobs with the county or in the private sector. Whatever summer endeavor they chose, most have forsaken just hanging out at a pool for a taste of the nitty-gritty world of work. With unemployment rates low and the economy robust, it has been a profitable season for many.
It has not, however, been a good year in the New York City region for teen-agers who wanted jobs in the private sector, some employment specialists reported.
"For most, it has actually been quite difficult in that respect," said Marilyn K. Shea, a regional administrator for the United States Department of Labor. "I don't know any teens who have had much of a choice of jobs." Contrary to what some labor reports have indicated in other parts of the United States, summer jobs for youths are hard come by in the area surrounding New York City, and Westchester is no exception, she said.
Westchester's unemployment rate was 3.6 percent in June, the latest month for which figures are available. "That's way below the national average of 4.7 percent," saidJohn L. Wieting, regional commissioner for the United States Bureau of Labor Statistics in Manhattan. But even though the hot United States economy was showing some signs of cooling down, it was only by a few degrees, he said.
In New York, among the state's 62 counties, only 7 had a lower jobless rate, with the lowest -- 2.9 percent -- reported in Putnam.
In many places, those kinds of rock-bottom unemployment figures have meant that youth unemployment is at its lowest point in a decade. In South Carolina, for example, any 16-year-old who wants a job can find one, labor officials reported.
And while overall unemployment dropped and retailing promised more entry-level, temporary and part-time jobs in the New York region, Mr. Wieting said, many of those jobs were going to older workers who want or need to stay in the work force and to women with families seeking flexible schedules. Typically, those kinds of jobs are found in restaurants, laundry and dry-cleaning establishments and in places offering amusement and recreation
At The Westchester mall in White Plains, Stephen Haney, an assistant marketing administrator, said retailers were indeed seeking "a more mature, reliable" work force and eschewing teen-agers who typically did not espouse a strong work ethic.
At the Galleria at White Plains, another major shopping center, it was a similar story. Stores catering to a young crowd, however, have hired young salespeople to match the clientele, opening some private sector retailing jobs to teen-agers, Paula Kelliher, a marketing director there, said.
And at the County Office of Employment and Training in White Plains, which oversees Federal funds for employing economically disadvantaged youths, Joanne Clementoni, a program administrator, confirmed that only some high school and college students were landing private-sector jobs, "I don't know too many 14-, 15- or 16-year-olds who found that kind of employment," she said.
Younger teen-agers, however, may have a chance at those positions now, because college students are returning to their studies. Susan Welling, an assistant director for employment in the county's Personnel Office, said summer hiring for teen-agers was opening again this summer. Playland Park is seeking ticket-takers, ride operators and cashiers, and lifeguards are a hot commodity at county pools and beaches. Lifeguards in the private sector, at private beaches and condominium complexes are also in demand.
Meanwhile, there is a growing worry that the Federal program for economically disadvantaged students like Andre Williams may be at risk. To qualify for the program, a student's family cannot earn more than $20,620 a year. "In a sense, they're punished if the family earns more," said Marlene Furtick, executive director of the Youth Bureau in Mount Vernon, where 155 teen-agers have found jobs at City Hall, Mount Vernon Hospital, neighborhood health centers and Y camps.
Countywide, the program -- known as the Job Training Partnership Act -- serves students 14 to 21. Ms. Clementoni, the program administrator at the county's Office of Employment and Training, said that economically disadvantaged students, who are mostly from minority groups, "traditionally lose precious academic ground over the summer" while other students from middle- and upper-income groups experience enriched summers at camps or through traveling.
Whites also fare better in the job market, according to labor statistics: whites overall have an unemployment rate of about 4.0 percent compared with blacks at 8.2 percent and Hispanic workers at 7.6 percent.
Those figures notwithstanding, the Appropriations Committee of the House of Representatives recently debated the merits of the 40-year-old jobs program for disadvantaged youths and recommended ending it in light of the robust economy.
Ms. Shea, the regional administrator for the Department of Labor, lamented that "$71 million nationwide will be zeroed out."
She said the program helps coordinate both job and academic skills for economically disadvantaged students who were also statistically in danger of dropping out of school and remaining unemployed.

HEADLINE: Office Market Booms in Strong Economy

BYLINE: By PENNY SINGER 

 BODY:
AS a rising tide raises all boats, a strong economy lifts the entire Westchester office market.
"Almost 1.4 million square feet of office space was leased in the county during the first six months of this year, which is a 43 percent increase over the first half of 1997," said Michael A. Klein, who, as executive director of Insignia/ESG, oversees commercial real estate activity in Westchester and Fairfield Counties. 
 Insignia/ESG, one of the largest commercial real estate services company in the United States, provides services for a property portfolio of more than 165 million square feet nationwide.
"The Westchester office market is reaping the benefits of a strong regional economy and significant expansion by local businesses," Mr. Klein observed. "What's more, the market's strength is broad based, a far cry from the 80's when large corporate tenants such as I.B.M., AT&T and Nynex dominated the market. In the late 80's when those major tenants started cutting back and pulling out, the office market was hit with a serious downturn."
By contrast, today's leasing activity is being generated by a diverse group of small to midsize companies in a cross section of businesses. Represented are those in the financial services industry, telecommunications, software designers and health care providers. On the average, leases are for 10,000 to 16,000 square feet, and the mix of tenants is balanced, Mr. Klein reported.
Although much of the first part of the year's market activity involved companies moving or expanding within the county, Westchester also continues to attract companies from Fairfield and Manhattan, Mr. Klein added. "When you realize Class A space in Manhattan is now commanding $50 a square foot with Class A space in lower Fairfield at $35-$37, Westchester's going rate for Class A space, $25 a square foot, is a bargain," he said. "Take the largest lease transaction in the county so far this year: Starwood Hotels and Resorts 77,000-square-foot, three-year lease at 777 Westchester Avenue in White Plains. Starwood searched for suitable space in Fairfield and Manhattan before deciding to consolidate its Phoenix, Chicago, Seattle and Manhattan operations in the former Tambrands headquarters in White Plains."
The second-largest lease transaction this year within Westchester was the Lillian Vernon Corporation's move from New Rochelle into new headquarters of 65,000 square feet at 1 Theall Road in Rye.
"The timing was right for the company to upgrade," Mr. Klein said. "Lillian Vernon moved from Class B minus and C plus space in New Rochelle to Class A space, vacated by C.V.S in the Melville Building in Rye."
Other lease transactions include Coca-Cola Bottling Company of New York's 55,343-square-foot expansion at 3 Skyline Drive in Hawthorne, Abitibi Consolidated Sales Corporation's 37,237-square-foot lease at 4 Gannett Drive in White Plains, Castle Oil's 35,000-square-foot renewal at 500 Mamaroneck Avenue in Harrison and Roper Starch Worldwide's 30,000-square-foot lease, also at 500 Mamaroneck Avenue.
"Although there was a nice number of these large-lease transactions, the market is still dominated by small deals," Mr. Klein said. "In fact, nearly 50 percent of all the space leased during the first six months was for transactions totaling 10,000 square feet or less with 69 percent of all space leased for 20,000 square feet or less."
Mr. Klein said that four of the five market areas reported an increase in occupied space. "Even downtown White Plains, the county's central business district, which has had high vacancy rates due to the return to the market of large blocks of space, saw its vacancy rate fall 4.4 percentage points to 26.5 percent," he said.
Westchester's largest market area, Westchester East, which includes Harrison, Purchase, Rye and eastern White Plains, was also its busiest during the first half of the year. Approximately 623,000 square feet of space was leased, up 79 percent from last year.
Overall, the county's midyear vacancy rate was 14.2 percent down almost 3 percentage points from midyear 1997, Mr. Klein said, adding that the county's average asking price for Class A & B space -- $22.46 a square foot -- rose $1.56 a square foot from last year's level.
As for new office construction, Mr. Klein said it was "almost nonexistent."
"I doubt that there will be any significant speculative office building until rents rise to the $28-to-$30-per square-foot level, which would make new construction feasible," he said.
Yet in Goldens Bridge, site work has begun on a 313,930- square-foot corporate office park consisting of two four-story office buildings connected by a main entrance lobby along Route 22, reported David J. Friedman, Northeast regional vice president of the Louis Dreyfus Property Group based in Stamford.
Louis Dreyfus Property Group is a subsidiary of Louis Dreyfus & Company, a family-owned business, founded in 1851 in Paris. The Property Group was formed in 1970 and owns and manages more than 2.5 million square feet of office space in North America and Europe and plans to develop and additional 2.5 million square feet.
"Our Stamford office, which serves Westchester and the Northeast, was opened in 1982 just at the time of major consolidations in the office market," Mr. Freidman said. "So we bided our time until the market turned around, and now we are back on track planning to develop several major corporate office projects in Fairfield and Westchester Counties totaling approximately 1.4 million square feet."
Goldens Bridge, one of the few speculative new office park projects approved for construction in Westchester, will not be completed until a major tenant signs a lease for 40 percent of the space. "We are in serious discussions with a possible tenant now," Mr. Friedman said, adding that site work is under way at the 58-acre property.
Sutton Park North, a 99,000-square-foot corporate office building in Valhalla, the first of three buildings to be built on the site owned and managed by the Dreyfus Property Group, is almost 100 percent leased, Mr. Friedman said. "Only 4,500 square feet remain," he said. "We've found that the demand for quality space is strong."
The prospective tenants are equally divided between Westchester and Manhattan who are interested in leasing space in two additional buildings planned for Sutton park, totaling 300,000 square feet.
Sutton Park North, named "The Office Building of the Year" for the Middle Atlantic Region by a trade group, the Building Owners and Managers Association, has features like an exterior of Italian granite panels framed by continuous gray glass windows and a vaulted glass-enclosed atrium.
"The two additional buildings will be equally handsome," Mr. Friedman said. "By building on a smaller portion of the land and putting much of the parking underground, we are able to preserve a larger percentage of the 30-acre wooded site in its natural state."

HEADLINE: THEATER;
Dominican Tales, Acted With Pride

BYLINE: By ALVIN KLEIN 

 BODY:
WHEN it stays put, the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater produces plays, in English and Spanish, in its own space on West 47th Street in Manhattan. Since 1969, two plays a year, with Equity actors, have been seen at the troupe's home theater at a top ticket price of $20. But that's indoors, and not in summer.
This month, the company's main stage takes second billing to all manner of makeshift platforms and scaffolding, and the company, not necessarily with professional actors, truly travels. In motion, it remains true to its beginnings and its mission: "to bring theater to the people," in the words of its founder, director and producer, Miriam Colon.
Now in the midst of its 32d tour of parks, playgrounds, parking lots and streets, the Puerto Rican Traveling Theater is staging "The Beautiful Soul of Don Damian," a dramatization of five stories by Juan Bosch. Briefly the president of the Dominican Republic in the early 1960's, he is also a prolific writer of novels, novellas, histories and political tracts, published from 1925 to 1987. The tour visits New Jersey this week for three free performances in Spanish, with an English synopsis provided.
Before a preview on Tuesday at Highbridge Park in upper Manhattan, teen-agers were breezing by on in-line skates or bicycles. Some were just hanging out; others were throwing basketballs and footballs. Children were spinning yo-yos and toddlers sliding and climbing on new play equipment. Speakers blared combia, merengue, gaga and Afro-Latin music. Such was the real people's prelude to "The Beautiful Soul of Don Damian."
For the 75-minute performance, electrical equipment, costumes and sets had been transported on a single truck. Eight actors darted behind the roll-out stage for their off-the-rack costume changes. People sitting on folding chairs, resting on blankets or just leaning against trees watched Mr. Bosch's five stories being played out against fold-out scenery.
The short plays are about landowners and peasants, abandoned houses and erupting fires, endangered lives, horrific creatures and real heroes. In "Two Pesos' Worth of Water," the synopsis says, "the encounter between a woman's profound faith in divine justice and the brutal forces of nature" are depicted.
Ms. Colon's considerable acting credentials include stage appearances as Calpurnia in "Julius Caesar" for the New York Shakespeare Festival and in the lead role of Garcia Lorca's "House of Bernarda Alba" at the Guthrie Theater in Minneapolis and the Milwaukee Repertory Theater. Her many films include "Scarface" and in "One-Eyed Jacks"; she has just returned from filming a version of the Oedipus story set in Colombia.
Of the theater's street productions, she said: "The important thing is the basic stuff: economy, enunciation, interpretation, passion. We are telling stories we want everybody to hear and to feel."
The opening performances in Manhattan were held during Dominican Heritage Week, which ends today. "Bosch is a major patriarch in the history of the Dominican Republic who writes about the destiny of his people," Ms. Colon added. "None are of his stature and relevance. And this is our first Dominican work."
The company's home in Manhattan just five blocks north and one block west of the New Amsterdam, home of "The Lion King" (top ticket $75 to $85) and the Ford Center for the Performing Arts (up to $135 for V.I.P. suite tickets to "Ragtime").
"We need to have the pride of giving theater away for free," Ms. Colon said. "It's appalling that people cannot afford so much of the theater that surrounds us in New York," she said. "We cannot be part of the spectacles for hundreds of thousands of tourists. So we create our own."
 
THE BEAUTIFUL SOUL OF DON DAMIAN
Puerto Rican Traveling Theater

HEADLINE: ON POLITICS;
How a Man of Many Firsts Isn't Done Collecting Them

BYLINE: By James Dao; James Dao reports from Washington for The New York Times.

DATELINE: WEST NEW YORK

 BODY:
It is not often that a politician will look out of place at his own event. But there was Representative Robert Menendez last week, hands in his pockets and a slightly distracted look on his face, standing practically in the audience at a ceremony dedicating a pavilion -- to him.
But when it came time for the three-term Democrat to speak, the absent-minded gaze behind the owlish glasses became focused. The hands emerged from their pockets, chopping the air. And the voice, always silky, turned as forceful as an evangelist on Sunday. 
 "At a time when many anti-poverty agencies withered on the vine, this agency continued to grow," he told the audience gathered at the North Hudson Community Action Corporation, a group he has helped build with Federal funds. "It shows what government can do."
He has had much practice at this.
It has been 25 years since Mr. Menendez, the son of a Cuban immigrant carpenter and his seamstress wife, stepped precociously onto Union City's rollicking political stage.
Mr. Menendez was just a freshman at St. Peter's College when he helped organize a movement that brought Union City its first elected school board, ending years of mayoral control. At the tender age of 20, Mr. Menendez was elected to that original board.
It would be just the first of many firsts. In 1986, he was the first Cuban American elected mayor of Union City, bucking the entrenched machine. In 1987, he became the first Cuban American in the New Jersey Legislature. And in 1992, he was the first Cuban American from New Jersey elected to Congress.
Now, Mr. Menendez, 44, is looking to move up again. He has entered the race for the fourth-ranking position in the House Democratic leadership, vice chairman of the Democratic conference, a position many politicians in Washington think he will win.
But to people who know him, Mr. Menendez's leadership campaign is just the prelude to his real goal: a Senate seat. Mr. Menendez does not deny it.
"If he decides to retire," Mr. Menendez said of Senator Frank R. Lautenberg, whose term expires in 2000, "that is something I would seriously pursue."
But to win a statewide race, many politicians say, Mr. Menendez must prove that he can appeal to more than Hispanic voters. And that is where holding a prominent role in the House leadership could help.
"It gives him greater visibility on the main issues of the day," said Representative Robert E. Andrews, a Democrat from Camden who is a friend of Mr. Menendez.
Mr. Menendez chafes at the notion that his appeal is mainly restricted to Hispanic voters, bitterly recalling an early campaign where an opponent tried to portray him, as he puts it, "as someone who wore a sombrero, smoked a cigar and couldn't command the language."
As a state legislator, he says, he wrote legislation that spurred the use of fiber optics technology. And in Congress, he has worked at keeping New Jersey's seaports competitive by speeding dredging permits and expanding economic development programs.
"For the most part," he said, "our issues are broad based."
Still, Mr. Menendez has clearly spent much of his time in Congress championing Hispanic causes. He is one of Capitol Hill's most outspoken critics of the Castro regime, and has vehemently opposed any efforts by the Clinton Administration to loosen trade restrictions on Cuba.
He also was the leading defender of Representative Loretta L. Sanchez, a California Democrat whose narrow victory over Robert Dornan in 1996 was hotly disputed by Republicans.
Mr. Menendez must also overcome the image that he was elected largely because he is Hispanic. His district was drawn in 1992 to favor a Hispanic candidate, stretching from the Little Havanas in West New York and Union City, where he still lives with his wife and two children, through New Jersey's rumpled but immigrant-rich seaport towns: Jersey City, Elizabeth and Perth Amboy.
"Sixty-eight percent of the voters here are not Hispanic," he said. "You have to appeal to a wide cross section of people to win here."
And win he does. In 1994, he took more than 70 percent of the vote; in 1996 he got nearly 80 percent. Indeed, his lack of serious competition this year will enable him to spend much of his $1.5 million campaign war chest helping Congressional Democrats around the country facing tight races -- a sure way to build support for his leadership race.
As he worked the crowd at the North Hudson Community Action Corporation last week, Mr. Menendez did what good politicians do, promising to meet with local officials and posing for photographs with elderly patients, all the while shifting fluidly between Spanish and English.
"We want to welcome you when you are strong, healthy and at the top of your career," Michael A. Leggiero, the agency's executive director, told him.
Mr. Leggiero paused, perhaps for comic effect. "Well, not quite at the top of your career," he added.

HEADLINE: BUSINESS & PLEASURE;
What Drought? The Sun Is Shining On Shore Towns

BYLINE: By KAREN DeMASTERS 

 BODY:
Farmers may call a string of rainless days a disaster, but for those who profit from tourism at the Jersey Shore, that is a formula for a bountiful season.
A spot check of shore areas and attractions shows that most are booming, though not across the board. 
 Steel Pier in Atlantic City and to the Ocean City Family Go Cart Park, for example, report that attendance is up about 10 percent over last year, said Anthony Catanoso, whose family owns the two amusement parks, as well as two others in New Jersey. The family's amusement business in Seaside Heights also is thriving, boosted in part by a temporary MTV studio on the boardwalk that has drawn thousands of young people to the beach, Mr. Catanoso said. But at his Dinosaur Beach in Wildwood, attendance has fallen off.
"In most places we are doing well, but not everywhere," Mr. Catanoso said. "Maybe the Canadian dollar is hurting Wildwood."
The exchange rate for Canadian money has been dropping against the United States dollar. That makes vacations in the United States more costly for Canadians, who make up a significant part of the tourist trade at East Coast resorts.
"If you want Canada geese, we have lots of them, but as far as Canadians are concerned, we have had lots of cancellations," said Diane Wieland, director of the tourism department for Cape May County. Canadians usually account for 25 percent of summer business in the county, but this year make up only 10 percent, she said.
But other factors may make up for the loss. "July was kind of spotty," Ms. Wieland said, "but August and September look like they are going to be spectacular. Gas prices are down, the economy is good, people seem to have more vacation time and the weather has been gorgeous."
Atlantic City casinos reported a 4.5 percent jump in winnings this July over last, reflecting in part the number of people going to beaches, said Alan C. Marcus, a lobbyist for the three Donald Trump casinos.
On Long Beach Island, inquiries about rentals are up, according to Jim Joeriman, manager of Prudential Zack, Realtors in Ship Bottom, though the number of actual rentals is down because the pool of rental properties has been shrinking.
Merchants in Ocean County report seeing more day trippers and fewer overnight or weeklong visitors, according to Jeanne DiPaola, executive director of the Southern Ocean County Chamber of Commerce. But she said that this summer of good weather has left the towns and business people with little to complain about.
Long Beach Township beach badge sales were down the first part of the summer, but "in August the money has been rolling in for daily, weekly and even seasonal badges," said Don Myers, a beach supervisor, "so it looks great for the rest of the season."
And with five weekends in August and Labor Day not falling until Sept. 7, the visions of big profits shine like the summer sun. "But don't let anyone kid you," said Mr. Myers. "A lot depends on the weather."

HEADLINE: IN BRIEF;
Housing Grants

BYLINE: By ELSA BRENNER 

 BODY:
Westchester has received three grants from the United States Department of Housing and Urban Development to improve services to low- and moderate-income households, County Executive Andrew J. Spano said last week.
Westchester's award consists of $6.6 million for its Community Development Block Grant program, $1.4 million for what is known as the Home program and $234,000 for an Emergency Shelter Grant program. 
 "This $8.2 million commitment from the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development is a welcome contribution to improving the overall quality of life for much of the county's population," Mr. Spano said.
The County Executive said that the community development funds will support new recreation, business and health services for the elderly. The home grant will increase the county's affordable housing inventory for homeowners and renters and "go a long way in meeting my goal of adding 5,000 additional housing units over the next four years," he added. And the Emergency Shelter Grant will provide rent subsidies for 90 families and offer eviction-prevention counseling, job training for domestic violence victims, safety training for children in shelters and literacy courses for homeless adults.
The block grant funds will be distributed to municipalities and non-profit agencies to improve parks and expand or rehabilitate youth centers and senior centers, among other things.
"These grants provide the county with the resources to improve living and quality-of-life conditions for two key segments of our county's community," Mr. Spano said. "By improving their lot, we improve the county as a whole."

HEADLINE: VOICES: FROM THE DESK OF;
In Radio's Past, a Hint Of the Internet's Future

BYLINE: By ALFRED BALK; Alfred Balk, a former editor of The Columbia Journalism Review and founding editor of World Press Review, is writing a book about the golden age of radio.

 BODY:
AMONG many Internet enthusiasts, especially students, mentioning the Internet and regulation in the same breath is unwise. Veins swell, faces redden and someone announces, in effect: "Regulation would ruin it! We'll fight it!"
If they do, the bell for the first round is likely to sound on Sept. 30, the Clinton Administration's deadline for transferring the authority to register Internet addresses and domain classifications from its present, benign overseer, Network Solutions Inc. of Reston, Va., to a nonprofit international group. 
 What group? Accountable to whom? With what, if any, enforcement powers?
The answers to these questions will determine much of the Internet's future regulatory course. The history of radio, the century's first electronic wonder, offers clues: As the Internet's closest analog in economic, technological, cultural and psychological impact, it seems an almost perfect mirror image.
Before Marconi patented his "wireless telegraph" in 1896, instant communication was wire-bound to the capital-intensive and then largely nonegalitarian telegraph and telephone. Marconi's first trans-Atlantic transmission -- the letter "S" in 1901 -- portended not only military, commercial and maritime revolutions but, as Popular Mechanics magazine put it, "a new epoch in the interchange of information."
For the first time, communications could bind the globe into one, and anyone to anyone else within wireless range. Along with commercial enterprises, a subculture of amateur ham radio operators sprang up, nurtured by mail-order catalogues, technical magazines, wireless-oriented pulp fiction and the coast-to-coast Radio Relay League. No one needed a license then -- it was nirvana.
Not for long, however. Soon, Morse-code chatter overwhelmed limited frequencies. In 1907, wireless activity by amateurs garbled communications between the Great White Fleet of the United States and its home port. Some hams intercepted and disseminated proprietary commercial messages. Others transmitted fake military orders, bogus distress signals and false weather and navigation data. In 1912, amid confusion over the fate of the Titanic, one ham operator spread misinformation that resulted in an erroneous headline in The New York Evening Sun: "All Saved From Titanic After Collision."
Does all this bring to mind Internet gossip columns and today's system-busting, virus-spreading computer hackers?
 NOR is William H. Gates of Microsoft the first of a breed. Marconi initially insisted on leasing, not selling, his equipment and prohibited its use to communicate with anyone else's.
In fact, in 1903, the Kaiser's brother found himself incommunicado on a yacht in the mid-Atlantic with a German-made wireless. Spurred by Marconi's wireless snub of its royal family, Germany convened a handful of members of the International Telegraph Union. By 1906, protocols were adopted mandating wireless units on large passenger liners, making SOS the standard distress call and implementing other safety measures.
American interests resisted, but amid mounting signal interference, deceptive transmissions and other problems, Congress incorporated the protocols into the Wireless Ship Act of 1910 and the more comprehensive Radio Act of 1912. These measures required licensing by the Commerce Department of all transmitters (then virtually automatic upon application); separate radio spectrums for government, maritime and amateur use; confidentiality of messages and assigned wavelengths, transmitter power and transmission hours. Receivers remained unlicensed.
In short, the medium needed regulation to expand.
When voice and music broadcasting burst on the scene in the 1920's, the sequence recurred: a flood of transmitters (licensing had remained pro forma), growing signal interference, swelling complaints, pleas to preserve "self-regulation", expedients like the voluntary rotation of some stations' broadcasting hours and, finally, a series of conferences convened by Commerce Secretary Herbert Hoover.
These culminated in a new radio law in 1927, which created a regulatory rubric under the Federal Radio Commission (forerunner of the Federal Communications Commission). Since then, newer technologies like broadcast and cable television, FM radio, satellite relays and digital transmissions have continually roiled the regulatory waters, resulting in deregulation of the medium that started it all -- radio.
Arguably, radio's early history foretells the Internet's regulatory future. No medium is an island, and certain communications issues are universal: privacy, copyrights, defamation, pornography, fraud, commercialism, anti-trust and parents' prerogatives over what passes home portals.
Stay tuned for many years.

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends: Social Security, Chilean Style;
Pensioners Quiver As Markets Fall

BYLINE: By CLIFFORD KRAUSS 

DATELINE: SANTIAGO, Chile

 BODY:
OTTO VON BISMARCK, Germany's "Iron Chancellor," started a worldwide revolution when he created the first state-run social security system in 1883. No one seriously challenged that model until another man of iron will, Gen. Augusto Pinochet of Chile, installed the first privatized pension system here 98 years later, in 1981.
Today a lot of conservatives are proclaiming that a century of increasing government responsibility for social welfare is over in the West, and aging populations and dropping birth rates will make pay-as-you-go social security impossible to sustain even in the United States. 
 So they are looking at the Chilean solution: privately managed, individually owned retirement accounts based on the compounded magic of stocks and bonds, as a replacement.
But before Pinochet replaces Bismarck in any pantheon of jackbooted social reformers, his new model must first survive a test: the contagion spreading from Asia's deepening economic crisis, which is shaking Chile harder than almost any other country in Latin America.
In 12 months, Chile's stock market has lost more than 25 percent in dollar terms, largely in response to faltering exports to Asia and falling copper prices tied to Japan's economic slowdown. Some analysts fear that a deep recession will replace years of steady growth.
Although supporters of the Chilean pension system point out that the diversified portfolios in Chile's retirement accounts have eased the losses, pensioners and workers are lining up in the offices of pension management companies with questions fraught with doubt. Simply put, privatization has proven no panacea for the insecurities people feel when thinking about retirement.
"You are forcing me to acquire risk that I may not want," said Luis Felipe Jimenez, an economist for the United Nations, paraphrasing the fears. Andres Uthoff, another United Nations economist, added, "It will take a generation to see if this will work or not."
Still, the international response to the Chilean model has been bullish. Argentina, Bolivia, Colombia, El Salvador, Mexico, Peru and Uruguay adopted some form of Chile's system over the last five years, and a similar system is working its way through Poland's parliament.
In Washington, the Federal Reserve Chairman, Alan Greenspan, as well as conservatives who include a former Reagan Administration economist, Martin Feldstein, have praised the Chilean experiment as a model for boosting national savings, stimulating economic growth and securing the futures of the elderly. Even a few liberals, notably Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan of New York, have said the United States should consider some privatization of Social Security.
"This is a megatrend," said Jose Pinera, who designed the Chilean pension system as General Pinochet's Secretary of Labor and Social Security. "The pay-as-you-go system is like the Titanic going directly toward the iceberg of an aging population and declining fertility rates. Fortunately there is Chilean ship of individual private accounts nearby."
But before jumping ship, policy makers can look at Chile's model as a lesson in what a privatized pension system can and cannot do.
Chile's plan requires those who entered the work force after 1981 to automatically put 10 percent or more of their wages into an individual retirement account, which is not taxed until withdrawal. (Older workers had the option of remaining in the traditional social security system). The amount of pension due upon retirement depends on the amount a worker accumulates, along with the investment returns earned by whichever one of 14 private pension fund companies the worker selects to manage the account. The portfolios are regulated and the returns monitored by the Government.
Once retired, a worker can put the accumulated capital into an annuity provided by a life insurance company. Or the funds may remain in the retirement account, from which regular withdrawals can be made. A basic guarantee remains: those who have not accumulated a minimum pension receive a Government allowance that can be considerably below the poverty line.
Critics point out that workers must pay high management fees to funds that, because of regulation, offer little choice in investments. Nevertheless, in their early years, the funds were a smashing success.
More than 90 percent of the workers who had a choice opted for the new system. The funds accumulated $30 billion by 1997, delivering a stunning 12 percent average annual return in the first 15 years. The savings rate blossomed from single digits to 25 percent of gross domestic product, helping to fuel a rapid expansion in the securities markets.
The winning streak has faltered in recent years, however. The average returns for the pension funds declined from an 18 percent gain in 1994 to a 2.5 percent loss in 1995, followed by gains of 3.5 percent in 1996 and 4.7 percent in 1997.
 
An Exit Strategy
Over the last 12 months, the average fund is down about 5 percent -- not bad, considering the plunge in the Chilean stock market. But the reason for the modest losses is instructive: The pension funds have been dumping Chilean stocks. They have reduced their exposure in the local stock exchange from over 30 percent four years ago to under 20 percent today, while acquiring more conservative fixed-income investments and foreign stocks. One effect is that the funds have effectively helped drive down the same stock market they once drove up. And the market swings have prompted some workers to put off retirement.
This illustrates one of the risks that critics of privatization are fond of pointing out: Linking social security and the securities markets may spread wealth in boom times, but it can multiply the intensity and effects of a recession as well.
How accurate a gauge the Chilean experience -- both good and not so good -- can be for the United States is not quite clear. No one, for example, seriously believes that the same system adopted under a dictatorship in a developing country of 15 million people would be so easily adopted or regulated in a country as wealthy, large, complex and politically voluble as the United States.
Meanwhile, Chileans are learning the downside of a system tied to fluctuating markets. "I may seem calm on the outside, but my stomach is churning," said Fabian Moraga, a 33-year-old computer technician. He has accumulate $10,000 in his pension account over 10 years. But with a chronically sick child at home, Mr. Moraga said, any risk frightens him. "I don't know what will happen tomorrow with these stock markets," he says.
Mr. Pinera, the Chilean system's designer, has a response to that kind of fear: It's all part of accepting individual responsibility. "I can bet you 10 to 1," he said, "that the average annual rate of return for the funds over the next 45 years will not be negative after 17 years of 11.5 percent returns."
Mr. Pinera may well be right about the odds. But what Mr. Moraga wants is a sure thing.

HEADLINE: STORM CLOUDS OVER WALL STREET: THE FORECASTER;
A Bear Sees the Return Of 'the Reality Principle'

BYLINE: By PETER TRUELL 

 BODY:
MICHAEL METZ is relieved that the stock market has retreated more than 10 percent from the dizzying heights of mid-July.
If the remarkable bull run had continued, stocks would have just had that much further to fall and would have caused greater havoc than they are now, said Mr. Metz, one of the market's leading bears. 
 "I think the reality principle is coming back to Wall Street," Mr. Metz said last Wednesday at the CIBC Oppenheimer Corporation's headquarters in the World Financial Center in lower Manhattan..
"The reality is that Asia is not a passing fancy," he said. "The idea, which was the consensus going into the summer -- that you would have a resumption of 10 percent or 12 percent earnings gains in the second half of the year -- is disappearing."
Mr. Metz, a managing director in CIBC Oppenheimer's equity research department, said he expected cash to outperform the main indexes over the next 18 months.
Such predictions are not new for Mr. Metz, 69. He has been calling stocks overpriced for four years. But he is not a perennial bear. He advocated aggressively buying stocks during the gulf war in 1991.
He also advocated buying stocks in 1982, the dawn of the longest bull market in history. "Stocks were as cheap as mud then," he recalled.
Mr. Metz also wryly acknowledges his forecasting errors. "I have been wrong about the direction of the market," he said. "But I still think it has been overvalued."
A frequent pundit in print and on television, Mr. Metz has his critics and defenders.
Joseph V. Battipaglia, the chief investment strategist at Gruntal & Company and a leading bull, criticized Mr. Metz -- with whom he has sparred often -- as being overly pessimistic, particularly on oil and commodity prices in the early and mid-1990's, and on the prospects for American productivity improvements. "Michael has been a bit of an alarmist about certain things," Mr. Battipaglia said.
But Mr. Metz also has his defenders. "Michael Metz has been victimized by the bull market," said James Grant, editor of Grant's Interest Rate Observer. "He's the 'yes, but' guy in a gee-whiz world. I am certain when all this is over, he will be seen as more of a prophet than a fool."
Mr. Metz said he did not think the market's latest gyrations presaged a financial Armageddon. But he painted an alarming picture about the collapse in oil prices, which has been caused partly by reduced demand from Asia.
"If oil prices stay at $12 a barrel for the next six or nine months, you can say goodbye to the house of Saud, to Yeltsin, to Mexico, to Venezuela and to Indonesia," he said. "If you think oil prices are going to stay here for the next six to nine months, my advice is to sell everything. Because you're going to be in a period of unspeakable political instability around the world."
Mr. Metz suggested that United States policy-makers should put pressure on friendly oil-producers like Norway, Britain and Mexico to cut production and bolster prices.
Given his pessimistic views, it is not surprising that Mr. Metz warns investors to be conservative, accrue cash, pay down debts and selectively acquire beaten-down stocks like semiconductor companies and undervalued second-tier stocks in the United States and Asia. "Hong Kong hotel chains are selling at a huge discount to book," he said. "There probably won't be another hotel built in Hong Kong for 10 years."
He also sees bargains in some energy stocks. "I'd look at a lot of middle-tier exploration and development companies, and particularly those in North America. I was thinking of things like Pennzoil, maybe Swift Energy, Apache, Burlington Resources."
At the same time, Mr. Metz said he was more convinced than ever that the market has been in the grips of the bear since April, when the vast population of stocks began to slide, eventually pulling bigger stocks along with it this month.
"You have got an overcrowded, overinvested universe of market participants against a background where the so-called fundamentals are deteriorating," he said.
He ridiculed Wall Street analysts who expect corporate earnings growth to continue at unprecedented levels for years. "If you think about it, if you extrapolate on that, you're going to have earnings higher than revenues at some point. And that's not going to happen."
Mr. Metz was Oppenheimer's investment strategist for more than seven years until April. "Right at the peak," as he put it.
As for talk in the market that CIBC Oppenheimer was eager to replace Mr. Metz with a more bullish strategist, Mr. Metz said, "It's an interesting observation, but in any case, I was wrong" about the market. CIBC Oppenheimer has not yet named a new strategist to replace Mr. Metz.
The huge run-up in the stock market reflects a fundamental change in the people who are investing, Mr. Metz said. Americans who once put savings in banks now plow it into mutual funds and 401(k) plans, lured by higher rates of return. Such a shift, he said, "creates enormous vulnerability for the economy."
It has given rise to some misleading canards, too, in Mr. Metz's view. "People talk about the baby boomers saving more," he said. "It happens not to be true. What's happened is that the American householder has depended mostly on appreciation in the stock market to do his savings for him."
So, does Mr. Metz feel vindicated now that the market finally seems to be retreating? "No," Mr. Metz said, but he recalled John Maynard Keynes's warning about the foolishness of trying to impose "a rational structure on an irrational institution," like the stock market. "Every once in a while," Mr. Metz said, "it's wonderful when it seems to be more rational."

SECTION: Section 3; Page 1; Column 1; Money and Business/Financial Desk 

LENGTH: 1697 words

HEADLINE: STORM CLOUDS OVER WALL STREET: THE UPPER EAST SIDE;
On the East Side, A Market Blowout Is Just a Breeze

BYLINE: By JENNIFER STEINHAUER 

 BODY:
THERE are many prisms through which to view the state of the economy. Stock prices are the current fixation, of course. But there are also consumer confidence figures, the long bond perhaps. And then there is dinner.
Sirio Maccioni, owner of Le Cirque 2000 on Manhattan's Upper East Side, said he sold more filets of halibut, chocolate souffles and creme brulees last week than he has in many, many months. At neighboring Daniel, this summer has been the season of the $5,000 bottle of wine. Elaine's, the famous local watering hole, has been selling filet mignon and martinis smartly every night. 
 Correction? Up here, that could mean: "Please recheck the bill. You forgot to add my goat cheese tart."
"Sometimes I have the impression when the market is bad people just want to eat more," Mr. Maccioni said. "In the last couple of days, I have been really focusing on this issue, and I have to tell you that I have seen more people drinking and eating than ever before. Maybe they just want to be good sports."
Maybe, market experts would say, they've lost their minds. Gurus and analysts aplenty contend that something has changed. That reality is finally throwing its wet blanket onto a market long fueled by euphoria. That with the Dow Jones industrial average down 9.8 percent from its peak just a month ago, the good times are over.
But on the Upper East Side -- where people think nothing of doing their entire grocery shopping at the gourmet market on the corner, where 28-year-old market mavens call nine-room apartments with walk-in humidors their bachelor pads, where the goings-on along Wall Street are watched with the same intense interest usually reserved for one's loved ones -- sentiment remained strong last week that the good times are now.
"You still see all the signs of a bull market on the Upper East Side," said Nicole Gresham Perry, a stockbroker who lives in the East 80's with her husband, George Perry, a specialist in commercial real estate deals. "You still need a reservation to get in the local hamburger joint, and the limos from Wall Street are lined up outside it every night."
Not that people aren't watching the market's movements closely. Some of the selling that has knocked stocks off their heights emanated from this neighborhood, as profits were converted into real estate holdings or, more often, plain green cash.
But the much-talked-about wealth effect -- the translation of money made on paper to money spent on stuff -- appears to be on an almost giddy high, as if New York's aristocrats subconsciously believe that spending in and of itself can help prevent a further, more serious, market correction.
"Even as the market dived, the business here has been phenomenal," said Christopher Dziadosz, manager of Eagles Antiques on Madison Avenue at 83d Street, as he leaned back into a wildly expensive leather chair. It thrilled him, certainly, to sell dozens of antique end tables and imported decorative pillows in the dead of summer. But he acknowledged that he was also somewhat frightened.
"We never see this kind of money coming in this time of year," Mr. Dziadosz said. "I'm perplexed. If people are skittish, why are they throwing hundreds of thousands of dollars at me?"
 ECONOMISTS warn that the stalling of the bull market cannot help but take a toll, eventually, on consumer spending. Indeed, with more people than ever owning stocks, many experts say a big drop would hurt the economy more now than in the past. And if so, New York's economy -- in which Wall Street has become the biggest force -- will feel the pain.
Merchants certainly recognize the connection.
"People have to feel rich," said Mr. Dziadosz, who recently sold a $45,000 English table the day it arrived in his store -- about three months and a day faster than he had expected. "There is an emotional tie. Sometimes a person isn't feeling great one day and they decide not to redecorate their apartment, and then their daughter marries a nice guy and suddenly they feel happy and come in and buy, buy, buy."
Remember the 1920's, when everyone was partying before the infamous fall? Or what about all those ill-timed real estate purchases in early 1987? If people uptown are reflecting on the past, it does not seem to scare them. In any event, stocks have not yet fallen enough for average Americans, let alone the East Side's upper crust, to be panicking.
"Nineteen eighty-seven was a real eye-opener to people," said James Glassman, senior United States economist at Chase Manhattan Bank. "They learned that the market can have very sharp drops but recover so dramatically that the average investor now views a market drop as a buying opportunity. I think it will take a lot, a very large correction, to really shake people up."
Of dozens of people working or living on the Upper East Side who were interviewed last week, most said they were leaving their money just where it was -- or even picking up some beaten-down stocks. "What I am doing is staying put," said Diane Terman Felenstein, a public relations executive who also runs a women's investment club. "I sold after the '87 crash. Then I wept. All those companies came back. So now I am in for the long haul."
Laurence Leeds, who manages money at Buckingham Research Group and lives on Fifth Avenue, shares his neighbors' views. "This is no time for panic," he said. "Most people have gotten some cash or bought some bonds, but I don't think anyone is running out of the market. They are going to reinvest at a lower price." He is giving similar advice to his clients.
 STILL others say they have no reason to worry about the market's volatility.
"Business is wonderful," said Selda Chender, an interior designer. As for stocks, Ms. Chender said she avoids all equities. "I lost too much money," she said. In 1987? "No, dear," she replied. "In 1974."
Peter Elliot, who owns women's and men's clothing stores bearing his name on Madison Avenue, said he could judge what was happening in the economy by which store had better sales.
"A woman shops when she's happy, she shops when she's sad, she shops when she's mad, she shops when she's glad," said Mr. Elliot, holding court from a wooden chair in his women's store. "When men are sad, they drink themselves into a stupor. That is probably why the men's business over the last week and a half dropped dramatically and the women's business has been phenomenal."
For those who have lived through decades of bull and bear markets, a swift and sharp correction off a giant base can seem almost inconsequential.
"You have to be practical and believe in capitalism," said Arthur E. Crumlish, a salesman for a high-end printing concern who lives off Park Avenue with his wife, Gabrielle, a schoolteacher.
Mr. Crumlish, 60, said he learned long ago not to liquidate stocks in a panic, not to spend all his investment profits, and to believe that a bear market is like an unwelcome guest who will ultimately agree to leave.
"You have to try and hope you're in a situation where you're assured of a basic existence," he said. "I always wanted to be so successful that you'd have to call me at the beach right now. But the important thing is that we've raised the kids and sent them all to college. I feel optimistic about the future."
You have to call the beach to reach plenty of other East Siders this time of year.
"People are definitely taking money out of the market and are buying houses out here," said Andrea Ackerman, managing partner of the Southampton office of Dunemere Associates Real Estate, which serves a large Upper East Side clientele. Ms. Ackerman said her record-breaking summer included sales in East Hampton of a small cottage for $5 million and a luxury home for $12.5 million -- neither of them on the water.
"There is not the kind of negotiating on the asking price that there used to be," she said. "Chances are if someone comes down 10 percent, that is about it."
In Manhattan, the story is much the same. "Over the last year, a lot of people have taken money out of the market and bought their dream house," said Barbara Corcoran, chairwoman of Corcoran Group, the broker for 40 percent of the Upper East Side's luxury apartments. "Earlier, the market was our foe, because people were making so much money they felt it would be too expensive to get out," fearful they would miss out on further gains.
Are people the slightest bit nervous? "I am finding that our clients are talking concerned but not acting concerned," Ms. Corcoran said.
What gives economists, retailers, manufacturers and other participants in the American economy the jitters, of course, is the prospect that the affluent may start to act on their concerns. And at least some have.
"I've already reined in spending," said Ann Rapp, an art dealer who was out shopping along Madison Avenue the other day. "In the last few months, I've been cutting back on restaurants -- not that I can't still get a table at Mortimer's -- but I am cutting back. On clothes too, definitely. You've got to be ready."
Signs of incipient inflation could send the stock market into a steep plunge -- and the economy with it. Formal gauges of the cost of living remain in check. But the Upper East Side has its own measures, and, again, they involve food.
Cemal Tezean, who has been selling fruit on the corner of Third Avenue and 84th Street for three years, notes an annoying connection between market drops and the price of cherries, grapes and plums. "Stock market down, fruit prices up!" he declaimed. "Last week, I get a box of grapes for $20; this week, same box $28." Shoppers paid $1.25 a bunch, compared with $1 the previous week. "Customers complain," Mr. Tezean, 38, said.
Still, there are some people on the East Side who don't give the financial markets the first thought.
"I hear the bond guys crying," said Elaine Kaufman, owner of Elaine's, the Second Avenue restaurant favored by novelists, journalists and Woody Allen. "The writers aren't affected by it; they go on writing and just don't care. The small business owners keep going. The computer geniuses don't care. These people are just going on with their lives."

HEADLINE: Ideas & Trends;
Monopoly: Nuclear Power Version

BYLINE: By MATTHEW L. WALD 

 BODY:
STATES around the country are breaking up utility monopolies, hoping to create a competitive marketplace for electricity. But that does not mean the monopolies are disappearing; some may just be turning sideways, moving away from vertical operations that controlled coal mines, power stations and meters and toward a horizontal business that manages huge groups of generating stations. Leading the turn, some experts predict, will be nuclear power.
Deregulation has attracted suitors for the generating stations and created an opportunity to operate them almost like McDonald's franchises. Big regional utilities like Pacific Gas & Electric, Duke Power Company and Entergy have set up affiliates that build or buy generating stations far from their home territory. 
 Two nuclear power plants in Maine and Pennsylvania have recently been cast out into the cold by owners facing deregulation and they have tried to market themselves like middle-aged managers laid off in corporate downsizing.
 
Small Consortiums
 "They will end up owned by people who can run them efficiently and do well, not by all these mom-and-pop utilities," said one utility shopper, Richard H. Bornemann, a former vice president of United Illuminating, an electric company in southern Connecticut that is part owner of several nuclear plants.
Few people think of a company running nuclear reactors as a "mom and pop" operation. But one of Mr. Bornemann's partners, Shelby T. Brewer, a top executive of Combustion Engineering when that company was an independent reactor manufacturer, predicted that the industry would become so consolidated in a few years that only two or three companies -- not scores of them -- would be running the remaining reactors in the country.
Making the right decision about old reactors is important to consumers' bills. In the 1970's and 1980's the utility industry wasted tens of billions of dollars on more than 100 reactors that were later abandoned before completion because they were uneconomical. It spent tens of billions completing others that should not have built. Now the industry must decide which plants can continue to operate efficiently and at low risk.
The idea of assembling reactors into chains is rather stunning. In the late 1950's tiny utilities banded together to tackle the giant new nuclear technology and the "Yankee" system began. The 26-year-old Maine Yankee reactor in Wiscasset has eight owners; ownership of Vermont Yankee, Connecticut Yankee and Yankee Rowe in Massachusetts was also shared. Now giant conglomerates want to manage strings of tiny reactors.
Mr. Bornemann and Dr. Brewer, together with Timothy E. Smith, a former industry lobbyist, made a bid late last month for Maine Yankee, which has been on the market two years. The three said they would run it as a "merchant" plant, selling its power to whomever wanted it that hour, that week or that month, like a taxi in a field previously served only by private cars. Many companies have built merchant plants that run on natural gas or coal. No one is likely to build a nuclear plant, but existing reactors could be sold by utilities and become merchant plants.
Their bid came too late. The consortium that owns the plant recently hired Stone & Webster, which built it, to tear it down.
Dr. Brewer's prediction might have sounded outlandish years ago. But last month the first-ever sale of an operating reactor was completed; the undamaged twin of the Three Mile Island reactor that melted down near Harrisburg, Pa., in March 1979, was bought by Amerigen, a consortium of Philadelphia Electric and British Energy.
But it will have competition. "We've said for a number of years we'd like to be an operator," said Cyril Guerrera, a spokesman for Entergy, which is based in New Orleans and supplied Maine Yankee's most recent managers. It already owns five reactors, and Entergy recently said it wanted to buy reactors, or at least shares in them. Deregulation enables the companies to collect some of their losses from their customers, and may spur them to sell cheap, partly because the cost of decommissioning reactors is huge.
 
Consolidation
 Analysts have long criticized the American nuclear program for having too many companies, each running too few plants to get any economies of scale or skill. Now the programs seem to face the kind of consolidation that has transformed everything from grocery stores to cable television companies. However it occurs, consolidation could be good for consumers, say people inside the industry.
But Roger Fontes, the assistant general manager at the Northern California Power Agency, which represents 15 small utilities that buy their power wholesale, disagreed. When one company owns most of the generation in an area, he said, "prices will reflect the owners desires more than the market demand."

HEADLINE: The Nation: Blacks Crunch the Numbers;
Figuring Out Hispanic Influence

BYLINE: By STEVEN A. HOLMES 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
IN seven years, according to the Census Bureau, blacks will no longer be the nation's largest minority group, for the first time since the Federal Government began keeping an official count of the population.
As the country hurtles toward this demographic Rubicon, the ascendancy of Hispanic people as the leading minority, in terms of their share of the population, is generating a range of reaction among experts on the country's racial dynamic. Some are fearful, sensing a lessening of black influence and an increase in tension as many black and Hispanic Americans compete to move up the economic ladder. Some are optimistic that strong alliances can be formed on issues like education, affirmative action and reform of Social Security. 
 Others argue that blacks will continue to set the pace with regard to the racial climate. Still others suggest that this dynamic depends not only on the increased Hispanicpopulation and whether the large proportion of it who are aliens -- legal and illegal -- become citizens and vote, but also on the rate of intermarriage with whites.
 
Less Strident
"This is a major demographic shift that's going to hit and it will have some significant political ramifications," said Eddie Williams, president of the Joint Center for Political and Economic Studies, a research organization that studies racial issues.
Among some liberals and some conservatives, there is surprising agreement that the burgeoning Hispanic population and the fast-growing Asian population -- both of which are much more diverse and perhaps less strident on racial matters than are blacks -- will alter racial dialogue that, as Jim Sleeper, author of "Liberal Racism" (Viking, 1997) said, has been dominated by "whites or blacks who have been locked in a kind of psychic and physical embrace for the last 300 years."
One liberal black civil rights leader, who asked not to be identified, said that as a result of the increase in the Hispanic and Asian populations "the emergence of class interests has the potential to be as significant to the next century as race was in this one."
For all the talk of solidarity of people of color -- in part, because both groups are disproportionately poor -- their interests often diverge. According to exit polls conducted by The Los Angeles Times, 47 percent of black voters in California supported a 1994 ballot initiative to restrict benefits to illegal aliens and 48 percent backed another voter initiative this year to curtail bilingual education severely. The two groups have also squabbled over control and jobs at the Martin Luther King, Jr., Hospital in Los Angeles, access to public housing in Chicago and political power in South Florida.
 
Often Allies
 If the Democrats hold on to the White House, a flash point may loom in the coming years over the next vacancy on the Supreme Court. In the wake of the retirement or death of a justice, Hispanic leaders will likely press for the appointment of the country's first Hispanic justice. That demand may put them at odds with blacks who feel poorly represented by Justice Clarence Thomas and want a more liberal black justice on the Court.
But the newspaper's poll also showed that 74 percent of California's blacks and 76 percent of its Hispanic citizens voted against a ballot measure that ended affirmative action in state hiring, contracting and public university admissions. And both groups are jointly fighting Republicans, who want to prevent the Census Bureau from using modern statistical methods for a more accurate count in the 2000 Census, which would probably increase minority numbers.
"The hope is that we can now begin to form alliances and it need not be a zero sum game," said Raul Yzaguirre, president of the National Council of La Raza, a Hispanic civil rights organization.
The changing racial dynamic may also depend on another phenomenon. In the 1990 Census, 31.4 percent of Hispanic women who were married reported that their husband was non-Hispanic, with the overwhelming majority of these spouses being non-Hispanic whites.
In contrast, only 6.3 percent of black women who were married had husbands of another racial group. The census data underrepresents the black intermarriage rate since it is based on the woman's choice of partner and demographers note that black men marry white women in greater numbers than black women marry white men.
Still, it is clear that Hispanic people are far more likely to marry outside their ethnic group than blacks are. No one knows what this high rate of intermarriage between Hispanic and non-Hispanic whites portends. The children of such unions could just as easily identify with the larger Anglo society as with disadvantaged "people of color," making the notion of solidarity with blacks either a reality or a pipe dream depending on which way they go.
"They could end up being honorary whites," said Ronald Walters, a political scientist at the University of Maryland. "We could end up with a situation like they had in South Africa or Brazil."
