HEADLINE: Health Clubs Consolidate as Membership Grows

BYLINE: By TERRY PRISTIN 

 BODY:
Spurred by the rising popularity of health clubs among people more interested in improving cardiovascular fitness than parading toned pecs, two companies are aggressively expanding in the New York City area. With investment dollars pouring into the industry, scores of independent gyms and smaller chains are likely to be absorbed by major chains over the next few years.
One fast-growing company, Town Sports International, the owner of New York Sports Clubs, acquired 18 gyms in the area in recent weeks -- 6 of them this month -- and is building or planning to build 7 more. The company, which is based in Manhattan and is the largest owner of gyms in the city, now has 59 clubs in the area and 17 others throughout the Northeast. 
 Bally Total Fitness, the nation's largest chain, runs 37 clubs in the area and will soon open 7 more.
The company plans to build a dozen clubs in the area within two years, part of a national strategy that calls for adding 22 new clubs and buying 25 more each year, said Lee S. Hillman, the company's president.
The rapid expansion of these companies comes at a time when growing numbers of mom and pop operations and less-successful smaller chains across the country are eagerly seizing their first opportunity to sell.
The industry is so fragmented that only about a third of the nation's 13,799 commercial health clubs are owned by companies with 2 or more clubs, according to analysts. (Even Bally has only 325.)
"Smaller operators have been waiting for years for the opportunity to sell out," said Naomi R. Talish, an analyst at Merrill Lynch. Until now, she said, "there was no one out there with the capital to buy them."
Unlike other industries undergoing consolidation, the $9 billion health club business is not considered "mature," meaning that there appears to be plenty of room for growth.
Club membership nationwide has increased sharply in recent years -- to 22.4 million in 1997 from 13.8 million in 1987, according to American Sports Data of Hartsdale, N.Y., a company that specializes in sports and fitness research. But those figures represent only a fraction of the potential market, analysts say.
Health clubs are more popular in urban areas -- where the major chains are concentrating their expansion drives -- but in the New York area, only 1.6 million people are members, about 11.2 percent of the population.
With the mountain of research emphasizing the health benefits of exercise, including a 1996 report by the Surgeon General, club operators say they believe that membership will continue to grow as more people are recruited from what they euphemistically refer to as the "deconditioned" market.
Health clubs used to draw primarily from the 20-something age group, but today, the members' average age is 35, said Cathy Masterson McNeil, a spokeswoman for the International Health, Racquet & Sportsclub Association, based in Boston. Last year, 8.5 million people ages 35 to 54 belonged to health clubs, an increase of 103.3 percent over the 1987 figure. And the clubs had 2.7 million members age 55 or older, an increase of 123.5 percent over the same period.
Some older club members began working out years ago and have continued to stay fit, said Harvey Lauer, the president of American Sports Data. But others have been lured by the development of effective low-impact activities that are easy on the joints, he said. "I think there has been a general elevation of fitness consciousness," Mr. Lauer said.
Reflecting that heightened consciousness, Adele Bacon, 78, goes to the David Barton Gym on the Upper East Side four times a week. Joining a gym with so many younger members made her feel awkward at first, she said, but she quickly adjusted.
"There are a couple of people who walk around like prima donnas," Mrs. Bacon said. But most people, she said, go to work out. "They're not here for a fashion show." Indeed, at many gyms, form-fitting leotards and tights are far less prevalent than loose track pants and baggy T-shirts.
The health club industry has also caught the eye of investors, because it has dropped some of its questionable business practices. The days when operators made their money by signing up members who could be counted on as no-shows are largely over.
"They realized it was a very shortsighted strategy," said Vincent Zinno, the editor of Club Industry magazine, a trade publication. "They were not growing their business doing that. It was like selling a newspaper subscription to people who can't read."
Only two companies, Bally and Sports Club Company, which owns the luxurious Reebok Sports Club New York (with an initiation fee of $1,100 and monthly dues of $150), are publicly traded. But several other companies, including Town Sports International, are expected to go public soon.
With Reebok Sports Club New York at the wealthier end of the clientele spectrum and muscle gyms at the other, Town Sports has positioned itself in the middle, drawing college-educated people between 25 and 40 who earn more than $50,000 a year, said Mark Smith, the company's chairman and chief executive. Members who wish to travel freely among various clubs pay $76 a month, he said, and can cancel with 30 days' notice.
To finance its expansion, Town Sports raised $100 million from the bond market.
Although some of its clubs are equipped with pools and racquetball courts, the company is focusing on machines like treadmills and stair climbers and popular activities like weight training and spinning, a high-intensity workout using a stationary bicycle.
Mr. Smith's company is buying clubs from people like Christian Pacifico, who entered the business in 1991, eventually becoming the co-owner of Gold's Gym franchises on Staten Island and in Brooklyn and Fort Lee, N.J., employing a total of 150 people.
This year Mr. Pacifico decided it was time to sell because it was getting harder to compete for employees and to keep updating equipment.
"There's only so much a small business can do," said Mr. Pacifico, who now works for Bally as an area manager. "We were losing employees."
At Bally, part of the strategy is to diversify its membership. Known for operating at the lower end of the market, the company recently opened a slightly more high-end health club in Manhattan's financial district and is upgrading several others in midtown. Fees range from $25 to $45 a month at the typical Bally clubs, and from $49 to $69 a month at the fancier ones, called Bally Sports Clubs.
As the industry grows, club operators will inevitably be more conscious of the bottom line, said Paul Roukis, an analyst at Schroder & Company. But he said that the corporations would benefit from economies of scale in marketing and acquiring equipment and that consumers were not likely to feel that pennies were being pinched because of consolidation.
"On the contrary," Mr. Roukis said, "it's going to give people a lot more."
But Dr. Gary M. Prince, a chiropractor who owns Prescriptive Fitness, an independent club on West 54th Street that charges its members $60 a month, said that consolidation would deprive consumers of the personal touch and hands-on management he is able to offer.
"We're the local bar on the corner, where everyone knows your name," he said.

PUB-DATE: August 16, 1998

SECTION: Section 6; Page 34; Column 1; Magazine Desk 

LENGTH: 3279 words

HEADLINE: Still Living With '68

BYLINE: By Mark Lilla; Mark Lilla is an associate professor of politics at New York University and the editor, most recently, of New French Thought: Political Philosophy.

 BODY:
August was the cruelest month. after the tet offensive and the escalation of the Vietnam War in early 1968, after the assassinations of Martin Luther King Jr. and Robert Kennedy, and then riots and looting in several major cities, Americans ended the summer watching the Democratic Party implode at its Chicago convention while policemen beat demonstrators on the streets outside. The country seemed to be coming unglued.
Or was it the whole Western world? The situation in Europe certainly made it seem so. In the spring, universities in Madrid and Rome were closed after clashes between students and police, while in West Germany the leader of the largest student organization was shot, setting off arson attacks by a newly formed terrorist group called the Red Army Faction. The following month, a student strike at a suburban university outside Paris metamorphosed into the now famous "events of May," which began with marches and the occupation of buildings and ended with barricades, Molotov cocktails, hand-to-hand street combat and a general strike that brought the French economy to its knees. 
 In the summer of '68 it seemed safe to assume that America and Western Europe were undergoing the same "revolution," a word that came easily to the lips back then. But within a few years it became obvious that very different dramas were being played out on the two continents. After a brief but significant flirtation with armed violence on the fringes of the "60's movement," the American left began to turn its attention from strictly political issues, like segregation and imperialism, to new cultural ones, like feminism. As the war in Vietnam de-escalated, a cultural war that is still with us began at home.
In Europe, however, it was the political repercussions of '68 that remained most significant over the next decade. French students and intellectuals made a fetish of Chairman Mao and genuflected before it, while German and Italian terrorists kidnapped, "kneecapped" and murdered leading figures in business and government. The coldblooded execution of the former Prime Minister Aldo Moro by the Italian Red Brigades on the 10th anniversary of May '68 was only the most spectacular of these attacks, which lasted into the 1980's.
Given these violent political contestations, you might expect passions about the 60's to run higher in Europe today than in the politically stable United States. Instead, the tumult has disappeared: the 60's are over in Europe. This past spring, the 30th anniversary of May '68 was calmly commemorated across the continent without bloodshed -- indeed, without significant controversy. Conferences were held, television specials were broadcast, day-by-day chronicles of the events appeared in the newspapers and hundreds of books (more than 80 in France alone) were printed. Yet as the French newspaper Le Monde reported, the anniversary was a publishing disaster. It appears there was neither enough nostalgia for, nor rage against, the 60's revolution to induce the French to read about it -- especially the young, for whom it is ancient history.
This indifference is common today, though not because Europe has returned to some pre-'68 slumber. It is simply that Europeans have made their peace with the revolution's successes and failures. Unlike the United States, where pro- and anti-'68 factions continue to militate in the worlds of academia, journalism and politics, Europe has comfortably entered a post-'68 age.
Which raises the question: Why haven't we? Why do the American 60's, whose political conflicts no longer rage in our streets, continue to rage in our heads?
What distinguishes the American and European 60's is less the nature of the political and cultural changes that eventually took place than the spirit in which they were pursued. Was the revolution, as Europeans seemed to believe, essentially about bringing an end to an old political order that also supported a stifling bourgeois culture? Or was it, as Americans appeared to think, about extending the reach of a noble if imperfectly realized political ideal into every corner of cultural life?
The European 60's were politically contentious from the start, for reasons that lie in a half-century of ideological polarization. Until World War II, much of the continent looked not much different from the Europe of the 19th century: it was rural, religious, socially conservative and, especially in German-speaking territories, admiring of military virtues. This was the traditional home of the European right. The European left, on the other hand, was centered in the rapidly growing cities and divided between Communists and Social Democrats. These forces polarized European politics in the decades leading up to the Second World War, and most observers expected the continent to fall back into this pattern at its conclusion.
Yet in the three decades following the war, a social transformation began that would eventually turn over the tired soil that had nourished hostile political relations in Europe for so long. Its causes were fundamentally economic and military: 30 years of unprecedented growth in production and public investment under the American nuclear umbrella. As the bounty arrived, the centuries-long divide between urban and rural mentalities that underlay the right-left split began to close up. Villages across Europe were depopulated and, through television, people who remained behind began to take part, at least from a distance, in the life of the capitals. As working-class families acquired more consumer goods, the distinctions between classes came to depend more on taste than on buying power. This is not to say that postwar Europe became a classless continent, simply that traditional social divisions were being replaced by more complex ones -- the most significant new one being generational.
At bottom, "catching up" was what the European 60's were all about. Although Western Europe managed to get on the liberal-democratic rails remarkably fast in the 20 years after the war, its ideological frame of reference was still that of the polarized prewar era. The new Christian Democratic parties were, to be sure, nothing like the old right, yet neither were they committed to the modernization of social institutions. The Communists came out of the war strengthened by their (often exaggerated) role in resisting Fascism, but their language of "class struggle" and "leading role of the party" rang hollow. While European workers continued to give their ballots to the Communists, with their wallets they -- and especially their children -- were voting for consumer capitalism. Out of this gap between the reality of postwar European society and its prewar ideologies a new political force was born. Because it appealed to so many of the traditional symbols of the European left -- and even radicalized them, replacing class struggle with generational struggle, Marx and Lenin with Mao and Che, "socialism in one country" with worldwide peasant revolution -- it stood to reason that it was taken to be a "new" left. But, in fact, it was not essentially a revitalized left but a third force that helped to extinguish an established European left that could trace its lineage back to 1917 and even to 1789. Its new demands for hedonistic fulfillment and individual self-expression had nothing to do with Marxism, as the nervous Communist parties of Europe understood perfectly well. And its skepticism toward the experiences of real existing socialism was such that disenchantment with the entire revolutionary tradition was bound to set in.
And it did. The first shock came in 1972 with the murder of 11 Israeli athletes at the Munich Olympic Games by the Palestinian Black September group. Suddenly it seemed that the celebration of terrorism and unconditional support of third-world struggles by the most radical of the '68ers had, at least indirectly, sanctioned the death of Jews again in Europe. Then in 1974 Alexander Solzhenitsyn's "Gulag Archipelago" appeared, convincing many younger intellectuals on the left, especially in France, of the necessary connection between Communism and totalitarian repression. The fall of Saigon brought the heartbreaking flight of the boat people; there was the Cambodian genocide, and in 1979 a "people's revolution" in Iran brought to power a reactionary religious clique that repressed secular intellectuals, women and homosexuals.
Because the European left took seriously the possibility of Communism and third-world revolution, in the end it was forced to reckon with their historical records. And while this was happening, the leftist dogma that real reform was impossible within "formal" democracy was proving to be a myth. Socialist parties came to power in Portugal and France, then in Italy and Spain. The German new left, which had been Europe's most intransigent, progressively made its peace with parliamentary democracy. This political "normalization" of the European left was accompanied by an intellectual "normalization," and by the mid-80's the radical newspapers founded in the wake of the 60's agitation -- Liberation in Paris, La Repubblica in Rome, Die Tageszeitung in Berlin -- had become perfectly conventional publications. Thus, when perestroika began and as the regimes of the East Bloc started to crumble on the bicentennary of the French Revolution, the European left had already divested itself of its holdings in the enterprise that had been founded in Russia in 1917. It was now clear to almost everyone that a 50-year tradition of thinking and living politics had come to a close. And with it ended the political dreams of '68.
This dramatic story of the European left's political maturation, of revolutionary promise and betrayal, of illusions embraced and lost, was not the story that unfolded in the United States. And the reason for this is quite simple: the fate of the Communist idea, and even of the French revolutionary tradition, had virtually no significance for American '68ers. Politically speaking, they were, and by and large still are, provincials. While European radicals like Regis Debray spent the 60's in the jungles of South America spreading the revolutionary gospel, students in the U.S. stayed on campus and demanded that America "come home." Home was where its heart was, even when it foolishly denounced "Amerika."
What these '68ers originally demanded was that America fulfill its own democratic promise, not that it take up a new revolutionary mission. The temple of the American democratic ideal had to be cleansed. A ritual cleansing began with the civil rights movement and resistance to the war, and was finished once Richard Nixon resigned and the troops came home. Yet it was these very successes that fed the American left's passion for greater purification, for an extension of the '68 spirit from the strictly political sphere to the whole of American culture.
Aspects of American life that hitherto had been spared the exacting scrutiny of pure democratic principles -- family, marriage, the regulation of morals, the authority of law, even the authority of learning -- now seemed somehow suspect, if not illegitimate. For the '68ers, it was perfectly obvious that the struggle begun in the streets of Selma and Chicago's Grant Park should be followed by new campaigns in the classrooms and bedrooms of America. The line between politics and culture looked absurd to them for the simple reason that they did not take the democratic idea to be a merely political principle. It was, so to speak, an existential one that deserved to be applied to every aspect of our lives.
This existential character of the American democratic faith has been noted by alert European observers of our country ever since Tocqueville and Mrs. Trollope began writing about us in the 19th century. They immediately notice two things: that democracy in America is considered not just a set of institutions and principles but a way of life and that it is promoted with a unique sort of passion. We Americans have trouble entertaining the notion that there might be aspects of life -- let alone whole parts of the globe -- where it cannot or should not apply. To suggest this might be the case is to risk being burned by the fire of democratic passion.
The American Founders had a strong sense of the passions to which democratic politics is subject, which is why they placed such a high value on moderating and canalizing them in the system of government they fashioned. What they did not anticipate was that the American conception of democracy would become an existential one progressively chipping away at the distinction between politics and culture that they took for granted. Nor did they imagine that once democratic political passions spilled over into the morally and psychologically fragile sphere of culture, they would be more difficult to moderate and their damage more difficult to repair.
It is little wonder that since the 60's we have become such a "sensitive" nation, in every sense of the term, for we have extended the democratic project into extremely intimate areas of life: sexual identity, marital relations, authority in the family and moral education, not to mention the eternal complications of race and ethnicity. This conception of democracy as an all-encompassing way of life is utterly foreign to European society, in large part because its own past, like that of most human cultures, was aristocratic and hierarchical. Europeans have therefore been somewhat anxious about this trans-Atlantic difference, wondering whether America is exceptional or merely more advanced in fashioning a democratic culture destined to spread across the globe. Whatever one's views on these speculations, the Europeans are right to think that American democratic passions are still unique in the world. Although democracy is becoming more widely recognized abroad as a political value, there is still only one nation on earth that takes it to be an existential one.
Which is not to say that European culture has not been transformed since the 60's, in many ways following the American democratic example. There has been something of a continental cultural revolution, though it has been carried out much more slowly than our own and without our red-hot passion. The list of legal reforms stemming from the 60's is long and familiar: the legalization of abortion, the near abolition of censorship, guarantees of sexual equality in the workplace, the decriminalization of homosexual activity, the parity of husbands and wives before the law and the loosening of parents' statutory authority over their children. Informal changes in cultural mores also took place after '68, as life became more relaxed and flexible in the workplace and the home. And, not surprisingly, many of the dispiriting repercussions of the 60's that we have experienced have also followed this transformation in Europe, including increased divorce and illegitimacy rates, the decline in public civility, drug problems and violent youth crimes.
Yet after the shock of '68 and the flood of accumulated cultural demands it unleashed, the institution of these reforms in Europe met with general social consensus, mostly because of unspoken agreement about the limits to cultural democratization. European feminists have won many victories over recent decades without taking on the joyless militancy of American feminism, without questioning the naturalness of family or upsetting the psychologically delicate ritual of seduction. European schools that used to be strictly hierarchical and indifferent to laggards have become more attentive to students' needs. The curriculum, however, remains much as it was 30 years ago, and there are no agonizing debates about making it "representative." In short, cultural issues Americans instinctively frame in terms of nonnegotiable democratic principles have been treated in Europe through an informal balancing of those principles with other, nonpolitical ones.
Indeed, because the modernization of post-'68 European culture was not brought about through the sort of messianic moral crusade that has been so divisive in America, in certain ways its reforms have gone further than our own, and with fewer untoward effects. As the '68 anniversary was marked in France this spring, there were calm public debates about two measures that would be unthinkable in the United States even today. One would require that half of each political party's candidates for office be women; the other would establish a legal framework for recognizing homosexual couples.
In short, despite the extreme political violence of the 60's, there has been no post-'68 "culture war" in Europe. And the culture warriors so familiar to us -- aging '68 professors promoting the Glorious Revolution, agitated conservative journalists portraying America as Gomorrah -- are nowhere to be found.
All revolutions inevitably face the same crisis: how to bring themselves to a close. This is because revolutionary success depends on stirring up passions that subsequently prove difficult to cool. With modern revolutions such passions are even more difficult to calm because they are accompanied by revolutions in ideas, which have a way of digging in their heels and resisting retirement after they have been overtaken by events. To the extent that the European 60's revolution was driven by an idea, it was an old conception of political revolution that had been born in 1789, revived in 1917 and began collapsing after World War II under the weight of a new social reality and its own evident failures around the globe. The 60's were about the end of this tradition in Europe, and perhaps that is why they are finally over. European culture has been, and continues to be, reformed in light of that experience, but not in the shadow of the revolutionary ideal.
The American 60's were also about an idea, though not about burying it. For better or worse, our cultural revolution has now entered the pantheon of victories for the American democratic project and there it will remain, flanked on one side by the abolition of slavery and segregation and on the other by an empty altar reserved for heroes of the next campaign. Americans today see the 60's as continuing a native tradition, not as departing from it, and in this respect our revolution was more conservative than the European one. It does not, at least in public perception, represent a break in our history.
Yet the reason this revolution continues to haunt us is that by breaking down the last fences between democratic politics and culture, it entered unexplored territory. And there it has begun to lose its bearings and cause some harm -- to our families, our schools, our cultural institutions, our public life and, indeed, to our psychological well-being. These harms are real, not the figment of the conservative imagination. But they are virtually impossible for pro- and anti-'68 partisans to consider dispassionately, so strong is the grip of the democratic idea on us all. Even American conservatives today can find no compelling democratic reason to question the extension of the democratic principle to the realms of morals, sex, family and education, which means they can find no reason at all.
In this sense, our 60's are over, too: we are all '68ers now. And that is our problem. We are anxious about the America the '68 revolution has bequeathed us, but we avoid thinking too deeply about it, fearing, perhaps with good reason, that our faith -- our all-encompassing democratic faith -- might not stand the test.

PUB-DATE: August 17, 1998

SECTION: Section E; Page 1; Column 1; The Arts/Cultural Desk 

LENGTH: 1773 words

HEADLINE: A Utopia Awakens and Shakes Itself;
Chautauqua, Once a Cultural Haven for Religion Teachers, Survives

BYLINE: By DINITIA SMITH 

DATELINE: CHAUTAUQUA, N.Y.

 BODY:
In 1899, after the philosopher William James visited Chautauqua, the combination arts festival and resort here in southwestern New York, he wrote that he was "spellbound by the charm and ease of everything, by the middle-class paradise, without a victim, without a blot, without a tear." But James said he was astonished on entering "the dark and wicked world again, to catch myself quite unexpectedly and involuntarily saying: 'Ouf! what a relief! Now for something primordial and savage.' "
Indeed, Chautauqua, founded in 1874 by Lewis Miller, an Akron, Ohio, inventor, and father-in-law of Thomas Edison, and John Heyl Vincent, a Methodist minister, as a summer school for Sunday-school teachers, is a utopian community of 7,500 summer residents seemingly devoted to the highest ideals of the spirit and the intellect. Nestled on 750 acres on the shores of Lake Chautauqua, the Chautauqua Institution is a place of pastel-colored Victorian cottages with filigreed trim and gardens coordinated with pink and white flowers. Children ride their bikes without fear of cars. And sometimes it does seem a little like Truman Burbank's artificial hometown of Seahaven in the Jim Carrey movie "The Truman Show." 
 But in its heyday in the 19th century, Chautauqua was one of the most important cultural institutions of its time, with an incalculable effect on the dissemination of education and culture in the United States, particularly for women, who had little access to higher education. Today, after exhausting its original mission, Chautauqua, almost incredibly, has carried on, averting financial crises, and prospering.
Four sitting American Presidents have visited Chautauqua, including Ulysses S. Grant, Theodore Roosevelt and Franklin D. Roosevelt, who gave his "I hate war speech" in the amphitheater in 1936. President Clinton prepared for his debate with Robert Dole here in 1996. And George Gershwin composed his Concerto in F in one of the practice shacks in 1925.
Still, as it gears up for its 125th anniversary celebration next year, Chautauqua is undergoing a profound self-examination, asking how it can broaden its anachronistic population of mostly white, older and prosperous Americans so that it can remain true to its fundamental mission: serious debate about contemporary issues in an atmosphere of cultural vitality.
"We're asking ourselves a lot of important questions about our future," said Dr. Daniel L. Bratton, Chautauqua's president and a Methodist minister. "We're using the anniversary as a time to bring these issues to a head."
But what exactly is Chautauqua? "Even Chautauquans have difficulty explaining Chautauqua," said Joan Fox, the director of public information. Chautauqua is a nonprofit institution, not too different from a giant co-op. Most of the common ground is owned by the Chautauqua Foundation. The 1,100 houses are privately owned, some of them by eighth-generation Chautauquans. The institution operates on a budget of some $14 million a year with a year-round staff of about 90, which in the summer grows to 1,500 people. It is governed by a 24-member board of trustees.
The Chautauqua Institution has its own daily newspaper, The Chautauquan, its own symphony orchestra, conservatory theater, opera company, ballet company. A total of 8,000 students attend its schools of music, ballet, opera, theater, visual arts. At the center of Chautauqua life is the 10:45 A.M. lecture in the 5,000-seat amphitheater, with the summer divided into subject weeks. This summer's topics have included "Ethics: Teaching Virtue, Educating for Character" and "The Road to Educational Excellence."
Cultural events are open to outsiders, and over the course of a summer about 142,000 people visit. There is a children's school and day camps, called the Boys' and Girls' Clubs. Chautauqua has its own security force, which has little to do but rebuke teen-agers who pour soapsuds in the fountains. There is a 158-room wooden hotel, the Athenaeum, built in 1881, also run by the institution.
Chautauqua has its own deeply ingrained rituals, Old First Night Day, for instance, its annual birthday celebration, and Recognition Day, when members of the Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle, one of the oldest continuous book clubs in the country, graduate, each class with its own motto, emblem and officers. Those who read extra books can join the Guild of the Seven Seals.
"Chautauqua is kind of the memory of America," said Jeffrey Simpson, whose family has been coming here for 88 years, and whose book "Chautauqua," will be published next year by Harry N. Abrams. "One of the reasons it was so successful is that it reflected a small-town America many Americans were moving away from. We know from Sinclair Lewis that small towns could be culturally arid places. But because of its transitory nature, Chautauqua could be the perfect small town. It reflected that wonderful American curiosity, that omnivorous interest in information, and it is contained in this picture-perfect place."
On a recent Saturday, there was a Catholic Mass in the Chapel of the Good Shepherd and Jewish Services in the Hurlbut Church, followed by bridge instruction in the Women's Clubhouse and an Alumni Association "Great American Picnic." Bard O'Neill, director of Middle East Studies at the National War College, was lecturing on Islamic fundamentalism to a group in the Hall of Philosophy, built to resemble the Parthenon.
Every 15 minutes or so, the bells in the campanile of the Miller Bell Tower chimed, sometimes pealing out hymns. Down by the lake, children played not far from Palestine Park, a contour model of the Holy Land, with a pond representing the Dead Sea, and a trickle of water the River Jordan. At McKnight Hall there was a School of Music voice master class, while at the Chautauqua Center for the Visual Arts there was a demonstration, "Making an Adirondack Twig Basket." Later, there was another Mass in the Hall of Philosophy, and a choir rehearsal for Sunday services.
Religion is fundamental to Chautauqua, although many residents do not attend church. Most Chautauquans are Christian, and about 20 percent are Jewish.
"There is an inarticulated awareness of the sacred and the holy in the whole community because of the natural surroundings and because of the created human beauty," said Ross Mackenzie, director of the department of religion. "Civil discourse, friendship, dance, music, all of these are expressions of human created beauty. They all give us an awareness of the holy."
 
'The Heart' Of the Movement
Although Chautauqua was originally founded with a religious purpose, its major influence has been secular, primarily through the Chautauqua Literary and Scientific Circle, formed in 1878. The circle has been called "the heart of the Chautauqua movement." Members were required to read books from a list with the aid of study guides. In the first 20 years, 10,000 local reading circles were formed, a quarter of them in villages of less than 500. There were circles in prisons and country stores.
By 1918, more than half a million people had taken the Chautauqua correspondence course. "This permeation of American life through its smallest units is perhaps the most significant social fact about Chautauqua," said Arthur E. Bestor Jr., Chautauqua's president from 1915 to 1944. Today there are few local reading circles left, and the movement continues today mainly at the summer institution, with each "class" required to read 12 books in four years. There were 127 graduates this year.
In 1883, Chautauqua was chartered as a university and remained one for 12 years, until other universities began offering summer courses. By the end of the 19th century, Chautauqua was, Russell Lynes, the historian, wrote, "a cultural phenomenon with some of the sweep and force of a tidal wave." There were about 300 independent or loosely affiliated chautauquas. Traveling chautauquas, or "tent chautauquas," provided forums for famous speakers like William Jennings Bryan, who once gave 50 lectures in 28 days on the circuit.
With the advent of talking pictures and cars, which enabled people to travel to find culture, the traveling chautauquas began to decline. Today there are about 28 loosely affiliated local chautauquas, including one in Lakeside, Ohio, on Lake Erie, and the Ocean Grove Camp Meeting Association in New Jersey.
In 1933, Chautauqua went into receivership. Money was raised by deeding back the houses, which had been rented, to members for 20 percent of their assessed value.
By the 1970's, Chautauqua seemed to be going into a decline. Attendance was lagging; the buildings were in disrepair, and it was having a hard time meeting its budget. Richard Miller, a Milwaukee lawyer, and great-grandson of Lewis Miller, became chairman of the Chautauqua board.
He began an aggressive fund-raising campaign and built up the endowment. The old buildings were repaired. Today, Chautauqua has an endowment of about $40 million with another $50 million in promised bequests from its wealthy members.
But today's typical Chautauquan is no longer a Sunday school teacher, or a public-school teacher, but is over 50 and a wealthy professional. Houses can cost up to $1 million.
Trying to Attract
Younger Poeple
"The concern is that some of the people who make it interesting -- like professors -- can't afford to keep coming," said Twig Branch, a fourth-generation Chautauquan, who is an insurance agent. "We business people are really boring," he added with a laugh.
Chautauqua is also struggling to attract younger people, and indeed there has been an increase in the number of children on "the Grounds." It is also trying to attract a more diverse population. For one thing, in order to get foundation support, it needs diversity.
"There is a rapidly expanding black middle class, and they haven't discovered it," said Dr. Bratton, the president of Chautauqua. "Everybody, including blacks, likes to have people like them around," he said. "The absence of a critical mass makes it a longer task."
Most people believe that diversity will develop. "This is a time of growth," said Alfreda L. Irwin, 85, the institution's official historian, whose family has been coming to Chautauqua for six generations. "Learning is a sport here. Dr. Vincent and his son, George, said we needed to stay close to the movements of society.
"Because the society is diverse, we aim to be like society. Chautauqua is very open and would like to have all sorts of people come here and participate. I think it will happen, just naturally."

HEADLINE: Strikes Raise Key Issues Of How Bells Can Compete

BYLINE: By SETH SCHIESEL 

 BODY:
The stock of the Bell Atlantic Corporation has lost 11.8 percent of its value since Aug. 3, when the 73,000 of its employees who are represented by the Communications Workers of America authorized the union to call the strike that began the next weekend.
Over the same period, shares of the other four local Bell telephone companies -- each with their own big union contingents -- have declined by an average of 3.8 percent. While three of them -- Ameritech, BellSouth and SBC Communications -- have signed new labor contracts since last spring, about 34,000 union workers at U S West walked off the job early Sunday after failing to reach an accord over contract issues that include a new performance-based pay structure. 
 It was not surprising that Bell Atlantic's shareholders showed signs of being spooked before the strike. More intriguing was that investors showed no sign of relief even after workers returned to their jobs last Tuesday after a two-day walkout. The company's stock remained essentially flat for the rest of the week, closing at $41.125 on Friday, down $1.8125. Nor, with U S West's labor situation unsettled, have the shares of the other Bells rebounded.
In light of the stock market's broad downturn, of course, there may be no need to read labor implications into the dip of the Bell shares. But strikes, or even the threat of them, raise important questions about the Bells' ability to compete in the $200 billion telecommunications industry -- a business where they will try to move beyond conventional local service to offer long-distance and Internet services.
Significantly, a key victory for the communications workers at Bell Atlantic was the union's securing rights to install and maintain sophisticated new data networks, limiting the company's ability to use lower-paid nonunion labor for such work.
Heading into this future marketplace, where few of their rivals are unionized, the Bells will carry a significant labor legacy. According to the Communications Workers of America, overall union representation, including the International Brotherhood of Electrical Workers, at each of the five Bells is an average of 60.7 percent of the work force. Meanwhile, among the companies with which the Bells will be competing -- alternative local carriers, long-distance companies, Internet service providers and cable companies -- only the AT&T Corporation has a large union work force.
All of this raises key questions. Do their large proportions of union workers put the Bells at a long-term disadvantage in a brutally competitive market where almost all of the other players use mostly nonunion labor? And even if labor costs end up representing only a fraction of the Bells' business costs, will the need to negotiate new ways of operating with a big union hamper the companies' ability to move nimbly in a fast-changing environment?
Bell Atlantic executives refused to discuss these matters last week. But the issues seem unlikely to go away. True, labor issues will probably not be the defining factor in the fate of the regional Bells over the next few years. More influential will be technological change, regulatory shifts and corporate takeovers. And as Frank J. Governali, the head telecommunications analyst for Credit Suisse First Boston, pointed out, good, creative management can almost always trump potentially problematic labor questions. But that management burden will undoubtedly be higher on the leaders of the Bells than on their counterparts.
And it cannot help but be an issue for the big corporate customers who will have an expanding choice of service providers. In awarding contracts, how do they factor in the potential costs of a strike like Bell Atlantic's, in which installations and repairs were simply not performed. Corporate communications managers might ponder: This time the strike was only two days, but what if next time it's two weeks? Or two months? Or four months, as with the Nynex Corporation in 1989?
Morton Bahr, president of the Communications Workers of America, said that his union's power actually provided a competitive advantage to the unionized communications companies because they offer customers a more knowledgeable, better trained work force. "All the empirical evidence indicates that the best continuous education programs for workers are in union shops," Mr. Bahr said last week.
In an interview before the U S West strike began, Jerry W. Brown, a company spokesman, said that the union provided an efficient way for management to communicate goals and strategies to its workers. Yet, he also said that the main sticking point in the talks was the company's plan to link more of a worker's pay to performance -- which, of course, tends to be the way pay is set in nonunion workplaces.
Such sticking points can only grow more important as competition heats up in the industry, in the view of Eric Strumingher, a telecommunications analyst at Paine Webber.
"Short term, what's going to happen over the next three years, I don't think labor's a major issue," Mr. Strumingher said. "But on a longer-term issue, and once the marketplace stabilizes and everything evens out a bit, then we will get down to who has a low operating cost structure. The Bells are going to have some questions to answer."

HEADLINE: Beyond Boosterism in the Alley;
New York's Web Industry May Be Outgrowing Its Image

BYLINE: By AMY HARMON 

 BODY:
The restless clan of chic geeks and entrepreneurs who populate New York's new media industry may not be anywhere near as rich as their West Coast counterparts. But in the pages of Jason McCabe Calacanis's monthly Silicon Alley Reporter, they emerge far more glamorous.
"The industry here is driven by people," Mr. Calacanis, 27, lectured a magazine job applicant recently over breakfast at Balthazar's. "On the West Coast there are a handful of celebrities -- Bill Gates, Larry Ellison," Mr. Calacanis said, referring to the chairman of the world's two largest software companies. "Those people are boring. They don't take good pictures." 
 Mr. Calacanis's irreverence is either refreshing or hopelessly sophomoric, depending on one's point of view. Yet his shameless boosterism of Silicon Alley -- New York's downtown multimedia hub -- has helped create the aura of community and even home-team spirit for a disparate group of colleagues and competitors who otherwise might have little more in common than being located in Manhattan and trying to find some sort of profitable business on the World Wide Web.
Certainly Mr. Calacanis's application of celebrity journalism to the world of New York new media has earned him a certain measure of success. In less than two years the Silicon Alley Reporter has grown from a few photocopied sheets to 116 glossy pages, on the strength of advertising sales and revenue from the periodic industry conferences Mr. Calacanis has organized like last month's "Rising Tide Summit," which attracted more than 200 registrants who paid $500 each to attend.
And yet, there is a growing sense in some quarters that the community identity that Silicon Alley Reporter has worked so hard to sell may no longer be the way many members of that community want to see themselves -- or be seen by the larger business world.
Although there are some holdouts, notably the on-line magazines Feed and Word, increasingly, the definition of "new media" in New York seems to be moving away from artsy, underfunded Web sites like Stim, a Prodigy pop-culture project that fell by the wayside, or the interactive soap opera The East Village. The new media seem to be maturing instead into on-line extensions of the old-line Manhattan media -- whether in advertising, marketing, publishing or broadcasting.
And as venture-capitalized start-ups evolve into I.P.O.-financed corporations, some industry executives are concerned that Mr. Calacanis' unflagging promotion of an image evoking artists' lofts and SoHo may be at odds with the businesslike demeanor that will play well in boardrooms and on Wall Street.
"He is a hypester in an industry that could do with less hype," said Kyle Shannon, co-founder of Agency.com. The company's major shareholder is the giant advertising holding company the Omnicom Group, which, through a series of acquisitions, has become the largest agency devoted to creating advertising on the Internet. "There are two Silicon Alleys -- the one where people go to the parties and the one where people actually do the work," Mr. Shannon said.
To be sure, many of the citizens of Silicon Alley are not yet ready to go completely corporate -- to stop dressing in black or bleaching their hair blonde or, among the men, raising goatees.
"We have to work very hard to balance the kind of accountability we have to have now with the creative risk-taking that brought us to where we are," said Nicholas Butterworth, president of Sonicnet, an Internet broadcaster acquired last year by the cable giant Tele-Communications Inc.
"We have to move to new office space, and I'm scared," said Mr. Butterworth, whose company has been located in a loft. "One of the terrible and great things about Sonicnet is we have no walls. What happens if we put up walls?"
Mr. Butterworth said he reads the Silicon Alley Reporter because Mr. Calacanis, a former gossip columnist from Brooklyn, manages to tell it mostly like it is. "Is it balanced? No. It's partisan. But it delivers the goods."
Few would fault Mr. Calacanis for not speaking his mind -- although he seems to save his rants for subjects beyond the borders of downtown Manhattan. Born of a new-media column that he was writing for Paper magazine, the first issue of Silicon Alley Reporter carried the headline "Microsoft Alienates Alley." And in his daily E-mail feed last week, Mr. Calacanis' critiqued Texas-based Zapata's Internet acquisition strategy as "over-simplistic 1995 thinking."
Other characteristic fixtures of Mr. Calacanis's magazine include a controversial map that highlights a revolving -- some say random -- bunch of new media firms below 57th Street. Then there's the monthly feature labeled "Digital Dim Sum: They lead the charmed life so you don't have to," which presents paparazzi-style photographs of aspiring Silicon Alley business leaders.
"Jason's challenge will be to figure out what his focus is as the industry fragments into its logical genres," said Josh Harris, co-founder of the online research firm Jupiter Communications and now chief executive of an Internet television venture. "I look at my contemporaries and we've all been through the war and we all know it's never going to be the same. It's like after my freshman year, it's time to leave the dorm."
At last month's conference, for instance, some attendees grumbled at the hour devoted to interviewing the Belgian anarchist who won notoriety earlier this year by throwing a cream pie in the face of Microsoft's chairman, Bill Gates.
"Jason doesn't represent Silicon Alley," said one attendee, who insisted on anonymity because he didn't want to risk retribution in print. "This is someone who is busy being flip and glib when the industry is really about serious people who are running serious businesses."
But such criticism may also belie a certain defensiveness about the industry's lingering immaturity, even as it struggles through adolescence.
"What people try to avoid saying about Jason, and it's not really about Jason but about the industry in New York, is that it's small-time," said Michael Wolff, the newly appointed media columnist for New York magazine and author of "Burn Rate," (Simon and Schuster, 1998) a book about the rise and fall of his own New York new media company. "The point about New York is we have not had a defining business here," Mr. Wolff said.
The Alley's derivative nickname first caught on in 1995, with the explosion of Web and the conviction that its "content" -- the techie catch-all for magazines, newspapers, music, movies, TV, advertising and various vaguely defined interactive stuff -- would be produced in the world's media capital. But of all of those things, only advertising has shown a propensity to make money on the Web. Moreover, the truly successful Web content -- at least this month -- appears to be the information tools or "portals" aggregated by major search engines like Yahoo, Excite and Snap, which are all located on the West Coast.
Still, New York partisans are quick to point to the initial public offering of Doubleclick, an advertising services firm, which went public last winter at $17 a share and closed Friday at $43. City officials cite a survey conducted by Coopers & Lybrand that shows that by mid-1997, the number of new media jobs and companies had doubled to 105,771 and 4,881, respectively, in a mere 18 months.
And on Friday, shares of 24/7, another Web advertising firm, rose 45 percent to close at $20.25 in its first day of trading. Two more New York companies, The Globe, an on-line community Web site and Earthweb, an interactive services firm, also recently announced their intention to go public.
By most accounts, the disadvantage of being across the continent from Sand Hill Road where Silicon Valley's venture capitalists hold court is not as sharp as it once was, as East Coast investors like Flatiron Partners take up some of the slack.
Yet, in the insular new media community, the fact that Joanne Wilson, wife of a Flatiron partner, Fred Wilson, sells advertising for the Silicon Alley Reporter has raised eyebrows in some circles.
Mr. Calacanis denies critics' contention that the companies Mr. Wilson invests in get special editorial consideration.
A black belt in karate who put himself through Fordham University repairing electronic equipment, Mr. Calacanis makes no pretense to vaunted journalistic objectivity. "It's no secret I'm a fan of this industry," he said. "We write about every failure. We cover it. We don't obsess over it."
After graduating with a degree in psychology, Mr. Calacanis landed a job in technical support for the Sony Corporation's legal department. A habitual hustler, he managed to talk his way into a ride on the corporate jet to chat about the Internet with Sony's then-president, Michael P. Schulhof.
A project for America Online that he developed after leaving Sony did not take off, but in the winter of 1996, Mr. Calacanis took the modest sum America Online paid him for his efforts and started Silicon Alley Reporter, which he initially wrote, produced and distributed almost entirely himself.
Now, with a staff of eight helping him put out the magazine, Mr. Calacanis is growing up and branching out. Forsaking neighborhood loyalties for the prospect of a new market, he has been spending a lot of time in Los Angeles lately and has begun running a "Digital Coast Reporter" insert in the magazine, appropriating the appellation a group of Southern California new-media entrepreneurs recently bestowed on the region.
Back home, meanwhile, to compete with a local on-line news service, @NY, Mr. Calacanis recently started a daily E-mail news feed.
And he has entered into a partnership with Gordon Gould, 28, who has put more than $100,000 into the magazine -- its first investment. On behalf of the magazine, Mr. Gould also organized a conference last month at the New York Historical Society, where Palm Pilot-toting new-media executives dined on sushi and were invited to think beyond their business concerns to the social implications of the Web and related media.
David Bunnell, a West Coast technology publishing veteran who attended the conference, said he came away bullish on the New York new-media enclave and on The Silicon Alley Reporter.
"What good magazines do is identify some kind of audience and provide the members of that audience with a sense of membership and belonging; and they've done that remarkably well," said Mr. Bunnell, who runs the trade publication Upside. "What they lack in resources they make up for in enthusiasm."
And as with the industry Mr. Calacanis covers, maturity shows signs of tempering raw enthusiasm One evening last week, dressed in black with sunglasses atop his head, Mr. Calcanis made an appearance at a SoHo courtyard party held by the Web ad-tracking company I-Traffic. Six months ago he might have been carrying a camera to snap the faces of his favorite entrepreneurs and their hangers-on. But this time he said there would be no party report in his magazine.
"I have other things to do; I have to write an analysis of the Ticketmaster-City Search deal," he said, referring to last week's announcement of a West Coast new-media merger. "I have to get the daily out. I have work to do."

HEADLINE: DuPont May Be Seeking Sale of Conoco

BYLINE: By DAVID CAY JOHNSTON 

 BODY:
The DuPont Company, which in May announced plans to sell the public 20 percent of its Conoco Inc. oil subsidiary, may now be looking to sell all of Conoco.
DuPont declined to comment on a report yesterday in a London newspaper that the French oil company Elf Aquitaine wants to buy Conoco for $24 billion, but analysts said a sale to Elf or another middle-size petroleum company would make strategic sense for DuPont. 
 The article in the London newspaper, The Financial Mail, which said Elf was preparing an offer that would include swapping some assets with DuPont, said other oil companies were also looking at Conoco, the ninth-largest oil company in the United States. The report, citing an unidentified industry official, did not name any other potential bidders.
The report comes less than a week after British Petroleum P.L.C. said it would buy Amoco for $48.2 billion in stock and cash, setting off speculation that more middle-size oil companies may merge so they can hold down costs in an era of cheap oil and compete with the biggest of the oil giants, Exxon and Royal Dutch/Shell. British Petroleum acquired Standard of Ohio in 1987.
Catherine Durand, an Elf Aquitaine spokeswoman reached at her home in Paris, said the company would not comment on "stock exchange speculation."
Susan Gaffney, a DuPont spokeswoman, said the company would not comment on the report. But nothing in DuPont's planned initial public offering of Conoco shares would preclude an outright sale of the company, she said.
In May, DuPont announced that it would make an initial public offering for 20 percent of Conoco as part of its strategy to rely less on its cyclical petrochemicals business. Instead, DuPont wants to concentrate more on development of genetically engineered products to generate future growth and existing products, such as speciality chemicals, that it believes are less subject to wide swings in demand and price.
DuPont, which has been expected to hold a so-called road show for potential Conoco investors next month, said in May the I.P.O. was a step toward divesting itself of Conoco.
Conoco was acquired in 1981 to insure DuPont a steady supply of oil as a feed stock for its chemicals business in an era of rapidly rising oil prices and high inflation. Now, with oil selling at a fraction of the inflation-adjusted price in 1981 and exploration of offshore fields requiring massive capital investments, owning an oil company is no longer attractive to DuPont.
If it sold all or part of Conoco, whether for cash outright or through a public offering, DuPont would be liable for billions of dollars in capital gains taxes. So an offer that allows for a tax-free exchange of assets -- as Elf is reportedly proposing -- would be especially attractive, said Theodore S. Semegran, an analyst with Brown Brothers Harriman.
Elf is the majority owner of Sanofi, a large French pharmaceutical company, and it makes perfumes under such brand names as Oscar de la Renta and Fendi. If these or other assets were swapped for part of Conoco, the deal could be structured to reduce DuPont's capital gains taxes.
"They have to make a decision about whether they will get a greater total return by starting with an I.P.O. and then spinning Conoco off or by selling it outright," Mr. Semegran said. "An offer that would help them avoid some fairly significant capital gains taxes would be attractive."
He said Conoco was worth between $22 billion and $23 billion, slightly less than the price Elf is reportedly willing to pay.
Conoco has developed large tracts of oil in the North Sea, Indonesia and, recently, off the West Coast of Africa. Conoco also has large refineries and a chain of retail gas stations in the United States. In early 1995 the company tried to arrange a deal to develop two oil fields in Iran. But that deal fell apart because of opposition by the Bronfman family, which at the time held the controlling stake in DuPont, but has since sold its stake and invested in MCA, the Hollywood entertainment company.
Elf also has fields in the North Sea which, if combined with Conoco's, could potentially allow for lower-cost operations there.

HEADLINE: King Hussein Gives His Brother Some Powers

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: AMMAN, Jordan, Aug. 16

 BODY:
King Hussein, who is undergoing cancer treatment in the United States, has given his brother and heir to the throne the power to shuffle the Government, officials said today.
The move was made public as the Government has come under increasing criticism in recent weeks. It has been accused of negligence in allowing Amman's water system to become polluted and for fudging economic statistics to hide the extent of Jordan's recession. 
 The King issued the decree from his hospital bed in the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn., a Government official said, speaking on condition of anonymity. The move gives 51-year-old Crown Prince Hassan, who is acting as regent in the absence of the King, more constitutional powers.
Another official said King Hussein had barred Prince Hassan from shuffling the Government in a decree issued in late July, when he left for the United States. He deleted that reference in the new decree, the official said. Neither decree was made public.

HEADLINE: In America;
Clinton's Own Web

BYLINE: By BOB HERBERT 

DATELINE: WASHINGTON

 BODY:
Headlines are calling it the moment of truth. We'll see.
Presidential candidate Bill Clinton went on the "60 Minutes" program right after the Super Bowl in late January 1992 to clear up the Gennifer Flowers mess. The idea was to tell the truth, to be straight with the American people, and thus save his damaged candidacy. Here's what happened. With more than 30 million viewers looking on, and with Hillary Clinton at his side, he lied. 
 It worked. The Flowers story, replete with taped conversations between Ms. Flowers and Mr. Clinton, was so sordid the press was uncomfortable with it and the public soon grew sick of it. When Mr. Clinton came in second in the New Hampshire primary in February, he dubbed himself "the comeback kid."
Within weeks of the "60 Minutes" appearance, Mr. Clinton was facing new questions about how he had avoided the draft during the war in Vietnam. He didn't want to be seen as a draft dodger. If he won the nomination, he would be facing George Bush, who had a strong record of service in World War II. So, as he so often does, Mr. Clinton gave the truth the slip.
Had he received a draft notice or not? Did he escape simply by virtue of a high number in the draft lottery or had he pulled strings? Was he a committed anti-war activist willing to pay a price for sticking by his principles, or just a coward willing to let others fight and perhaps die in his place?
Who knew? The candidate told so many stories, crafted so many evasive answers, came up with so many lame excuses that he gave everybody a headache. The public got tired of the matter and the story went away.
It took Mr. Clinton years to come up with the classic "I didn't inhale" response to questions about marijuana. He danced around that issue like Fred Astaire, saying he hadn't broken this law, or violated that statute. We've gotten used to it. It's as if the idea of a straight answer to a difficult question is completely alien to the man.
Now he is going before a Federal grand jury in an effort to salvage what remains of his Presidency. Just about every question he'll be asked will be tough. The danger is that he has woven so many lies he'll be trapped in his own insidious web.
The issue at the moment is not about impeachment. The Republicans have neither the clout nor the inclination, based on what is now known, to remove Mr. Clinton from office. Rather than fiddling with the dangerously unpredictable bomb of impeachment, the Trent Lotts, Newt Gingriches and Orrin Hatches of the world would much rather see the President, the hope of so many Democrats, sitting humiliated in the White House through the year 2000.
The real issue is the President's relationship with the American people. Mr. Clinton's poll numbers may be high but the nation's sense of trust in its President is collapsing. He lied about Gennifer Flowers. He seems to have lied about Monica Lewinsky. Why would it not be plausible to believe he lied about Paula Jones and Kathleen Willey? Or, for that matter, about delicate foreign policy issues, or legislative deal-making, or favors granted to fund-raisers?
Mr. Clinton's strength in the polls, I think, is the result of an economy that is going well, the contemptible qualities of so many of his enemies, the reluctance of a large number of Americans to turn even more power over to the ideologues in the Republican Party, and certain personal qualities that have long benefited Mr. Clinton -- his charm, intelligence, good looks, work ethic, resilience and toughness.
None of this will matter if he lies to the grand jury, or if he looks the public in the eye and lies again about that woman, Ms. Lewinsky.
Mr. Clinton is getting advice, solicited and unsolicited, from many quarters. Most of his longtime advisers and close friends are urging him, directly or indirectly, to tell the full truth to the grand jury and the public.
Is he capable of telling the truth when the going gets tough? Who knows. If it turns out he's not, the last two years of his already damaged Presidency won't be worth much. At some point the public will lose its patience, even with Bill Clinton.

LANGUAGE: ENGLISH

HEADLINE: The Day After In Ulster Town: Now 'It's Back'

BYLINE: By JAMES F. CLARITY 

DATELINE: OMAGH, Northern Ireland, Aug. 16

 BODY:
The day after the deadliest paramilitary attack in 29 years of sectarian violence in this British province, dozens of people sat blank-faced or weeping this afternoon at a community center set up as a command post to find people still missing.
The attack, at the height of downtown shopping on Saturday, killed 28 people and wounded more than 200. It stunned Omagh, which is mostly Roman Catholic, and the rest of this predominantly Protestant province. 
 "One day I was watching the bombs against America in Africa," said Michael MacAnespae, a 54-year-old mushroom farmer. "We thought all that was behind us here. But suddenly it's back on your own doorstep."
No group has claimed responsibility for the attack, but the police and political leaders, both Protestant and Catholic, said it appeared to have been the work of a group calling itself the Real I.R.A., a splinter group of the overwhelmingly Catholic Irish Republican Army. The I.R.A. itself has been observing a cease-fire for 13 months.
Both Catholics, who constitute 70 percent of the population of the town, and Protestants were killed in the blast on Saturday.
Prime Minister Tony Blair of Britain interrupted a vacation in France to fly here this morning. The Prime Minister of the Irish Republic, Bertie Ahern, went to Belfast tonight to discuss ways of combating the splinter group.
The object of the attack was clearly to disrupt or destroy the peace agreement reached by leaders of Protestants and Catholics and overwhelmingly approved in May referendums in both Northern Ireland and the Irish Republic, to the south.
The police had unwittingly herded a crowd of people toward the bomb because of a misleading telephone warning.
Among those who died abruptly at 3:10 P.M. Saturday, was Brenda Logue, described as an ordinary teen-ager full of laughter and hope. Her blood spilled on the pavement of Market Street, along with the others killed and wounded by the 500-pound car bomb.
Friends and relatives said she seemed happy on Saturday morning as she came in from the countryside to this usually calm. well-scrubbed town in the hills of central Ulster. After days of mist and rain, the sun had come out.
Brenda Logue and her mother, Mary, strolled by the floats and exhibits of the annual town festival. They went into a household goods shop on Market Street that was full of weekend shoppers. She left the shop while her mother stayed inside, putting her in the way of the bomb, while her mother was slightly wounded but survived.
Brenda, 17, had a job prospect on a mushroom farm, and she was a good Gaelic football player. She was, her friends and relatives said, looking forward to life.
"She has a sense of humor, " said Mr. MacAnespae, who had offered her a job on his farm. "She was bubbly." Mr. MacAnespae, a local council member of Sinn Fein, the I.R.A. political wing, said he could not understand the attack, apparently by a Catholic group.
"They say they want to unite Ireland," he said. "Is this the way to unite Ireland? It may have been the way long ago, but that way has been tried and it failed."
Sinn Fein, and every other party and church, has condemned the attack.
At the information center, people scanned a bulletin board for new postings identifying the dead and the wounded. Most declined politely to talk to reporters, shaking their heads and lowering their eyes.
Brenda's uncle, Michael Logue, 28, an unemployed salesman, left Brenda's parents and went into a men's room, where he broke into unrestrained weeping. "Just a teen-ager," he said. "I saw it on TV. It's just like Beirut."
The others who died included Mary Grimes, 65, her daughter Avril Monaghan, 30 -- who was pregnant with twins -- and her granddaughter, Maura, who lived in outlying towns and were visiting Omagh to shop.
A mother of four buying a school uniform for her youngest girl was also killed, as well as three boys from the Irish Republic traveling with a 12-year-old Spanish student as part of an exchange program, and the 24-year-old teacher leading them.
The Spanish exchange students had been studying English for a month in Donegal, in the northwest corner of the Irish Republic. They made a day trip across the border with some Irish students to visit the Ulster-American Folk Park near Omagh, and some decided afterward to shop in town. Eleven members of the group were among those wounded.
The police said those who died in the bombing included 14 women, 5 men and 7 children, with two others not yet identified.
Of the 220 people wounded in Omagh, about 100 remained in hospitals across Northern Ireland on Sunday, including 11 people in critical condition.
"All of our patients will be disfigured in some way," Dr. Laurence Rocke, a surgeon at Royal Victoria Hospital in Belfast, told The Associated Press, speaking of the wounded being treated there. "Some will be disabled very severely, and some may not survive." .
Outside County Tyrone Hospital, where many of the wounded were treated, two prominent political enemies stood together in the heavy rain in a show of unity. Seamus Mallon is the Catholic deputy leader of the new Northern Ireland Assembly, which is to carry out the peace agreement. He said terrorism would not destroy the assembly, which is to give Catholics more political power. Ken Maginnis, a leader of the Protestant Ulster Unionist Party, agreed.

HEADLINE: NORTH KOREA SITE AN A-BOMB PLANT, U.S. AGENCIES SAY

BYLINE: By DAVID E. SANGER 

 BODY:
United States intelligence agencies have detected a huge secret underground complex in North Korea that they believe is the centerpiece of an effort to revive the country's frozen nuclear weapons program, according to officials who have been briefed on the intelligence information.
The finding has alarmed officials at the White House and the Pentagon, who fear that it may be an effort to break out of a four-year-old agreement in which North Korea pledged to give up its nuclear weapons program in exchange for billions of dollars in Western aid. 
 The finding also follows a string of provocations by the North, including missile sales to Pakistan and the incursion of a small North Korean submarine carrying nine commandos off the South Korean coast this year.
The North has said in recent months that the United States is reneging on its side of the agreement because Congress has failed to authorize tens of millions of dollars in fuel shipments for the North. The shipments are the main American contribution to a $6 billion program, under which South Korea, Japan and other nations are supposed to finance a major electric energy program as a quid pro quo for the North's abandonment of its ambitions to develop nuclear arms.
A senior Administration official said the North had not yet technically violated that accord, called the Agreed Framework, because there is no evidence that Pyongyang has begun pouring cement for a new reactor or a reprocessing plant that would convert nuclear waste into bomb-grade plutonium. The accord explicitly bars that activity.
But spy satellites have extensively photographed a huge work site 25 miles northeast of Yongbyon, the nuclear center where, until the 1994 accord, the North is believed to have created enough plutonium to build six or more bombs. Thousands of North Korean workers are swarming around the new site, burrowing into the mountainside, American officials said.
Other intelligence, which the officials would not describe, led the Administration in recent weeks to warn important members of Congress and the South Korean Government in classified briefings that they believed that the North intended to build a new reactor and reprocessing center under the mountain. Intelligence estimates of how long it would take to complete the project have ranged from two to six years, depending in part on how much outside help is received.
South Korean officials have played down the finding, officials said, because they fear undermining President Kim Dae Jung's "sunshine policy" toward North Korea, an effort to reopen aid and dialogue with the Stalinist Government in Pyongyang.
When Mr. Kim went to Washington in the spring he urged President Clinton to drop sanctions against the North that date from the end of the Korean War. But the new finding makes it far less likely that the United States will ease up on the North.
"It's a very, very serious development," said one American official, who as with the others insisted on anonymity, "to say nothing of incredibly stupid, because it endangers both the nuclear accord and humanitarian aid."
Other officials said they were clearly concerned that Congress was now less likely than ever to finance the fuel oil. If Congress refuses to fulfill the American commitment, the officials fear, that would, in turn, give the North an excuse to abandon the nuclear pact officially and, perhaps, to expel inspectors from the International Atomic Energy Agency who are at Yongbyon. The North has prohibited inspectors from examining sites outside Yongbyon.
At a meeting this week between North Korean officials and the American special envoy for Korean nuclear issues, Charles Kartman, the United States is expected to demand that the North stop all work at the new site. It is not clear whether the North already knows that its activity has been detected.
As always in matters involving North Korea, it is virtually impossible to divine the country's real intentions.
It is possible, officials say, that the mysterious North Korean leader, Kim Jong Il, is trying to rebuild a nuclear program that the West stopped in 1994. Mr. Kim may also be hoping to bolster his standing with the North Korean military. This may be a particularly critical time to placate the right wing, because Mr. Kim is expected, next month, to be given all of the titles held by his father, Kim Il Sung, North Korea's founder.
The elder Mr. Kim died in July 1994, just weeks after having defused the confrontation with the United States by telling former President Jimmy Carter that he was willing to trade away the nuclear program in return for Western aid.
Another possibility is that Kim Jong Il is intending to trade away the new nuclear complex the way his father traded away the last one -- if he can extract a high enough price. American officials note that building a nuclear reactor underground is an enormously difficult technical task for any country, much less one that is starving as a result of economic collapse, drought and floods.
"Is this a nuclear breakout, a hedge, a bargaining chip?" asked Joseph Nye, dean of the John F. Kennedy School of Government at Harvard University. "It's hard to know."
Mr. Nye worked extensively on the North Korean nuclear issue at the Central Intelligence Agency and as a top Pentagon official in the first term of the Clinton Administration.
Mr. Nye noted that in 1993, as the United States was confronting North Korea over its efforts to reprocess nuclear waste into plutonium, the intelligence community was deeply divided on the question of whether the North wanted a bomb or was simply playing for aid. "The majority said the North would never give up the bomb, but a deal was struck," he said.
But it is not necessarily certain that the country would follow the same pattern today, he and other experts warn. In the four years since the agreement was reached, the North has grown far weaker, both economically and militarily.
"The danger is that the weaker they become the less willing they are to bargain," he said. "While that may seem counterintuitive, the North Koreans usually get tougher as they get cornered. In cultural terms, they may be more willing to accept risks in a situation of desperation."
As a result a number of experts and former officials, along with many inside the Administration, are warning that the United States should once again be alert to the possibility that the North could strike out across the demilitarized zone that separates North and South Korea.
In recent years the United States, which has 37,000 troops stationed in South Korea, has gradually increased its defensive posture, including new antimissile and antimortar artillery intended to suppress an attack on Seoul, which is within 30 miles of the border.
But the North has also improved its ability to inflict a tremendous -- if short-lived -- artillery attack on the South Korean capital.
