HEADLINE: Clinton and the Court of Public Opinion

BYLINE: By Andrew Kohut 

 BODY:
No matter what President Clinton says to the grand jury today, public reaction will have a lot to do with how the Monica Lewinsky matter ultimately turns out.
So far the American people have protected their President to an extraordinary extent. To the surprise of most of the chattering class, Mr. Clinton's job approval ratings actually increased in the weeks after the allegations first surfaced in late January. And they have remained high, even as most Americans, according to opinion polls, have come to believe that he had some sort of sexual relationship with Ms. Lewinsky and lied to them about it. While the President's personal image has suffered, the public has consistently held the view that this is a private matter, not one of policy and not one of great importance to the country. 
 But the degree of comfort the President can take in public opinion as he testifies is not so clear. As we've seen, this public has been highly unpredictable. Mr. Clinton has already defied the experts. The percentage of people saying that he should be impeached and removed from office, if it turns out that he did not tell the truth, has fallen from 50 percent in February to 29 percent last week, according to a Pew Research Center nationwide survey, even as the belief that he has lied about the matter rose from 49 percent to 70 percent!
The President's advisers may see these numbers as proof that he will weather this crisis, no matter what. But the public's unexpected reaction so far should ring warning bells that its views should not be taken for granted, even when its course seems clear. Popular thinking could take yet another unexpected turn, should the President change his story.
While most polls have found respondents saying that would gratefully accept an apology from the President and forgive him any transgressions, they could change their minds, if and when confronted with reality rather than a pollster's subjunctive question. Indeed it is not unusual for real-world reaction to be different from that of "concept tests" (remember the New Coke?). Anger that the President has dragged the country through a distracting seven months when he could have confessed much sooner might be the response if it turns out that he changes his story. Reaction might be the same should Mr. Clinton adamantly stick to his account, only to be contradicted by the DNA testing of Ms. Lewinsky's dress.
In any case, the odds are that people will initially continue to support the President, because that is what they have said they would do if he changed his story. But the reaction might be different in the longer term.
In the last "he said, she said" melodrama, the Clarence Thomas confirmation hearings, polling found strong support for his Supreme Court confirmation despite Anita Hill's dramatic televised accusations. But the public reaction subsequently changed in a relatively short time. One year later, the public looked back and was deeply divided as to whether Mr. Thomas should have been confirmed.
A similar delayed effect could reverse initial opinion today with regard to Mr. Clinton. If the economy and bull market begin to sour, the public could eventually condemn the President for a scandal that diverted Washington's attention while the nation's prosperity withered away. Other delayed reactions might have a greater impact on the Congressional election, for example, or on Vice President Al Gore's political future.
Whatever the course of public opinion on the President and his problems, only a decent interval of time will give some idea of the real reactions. For now beware of the blizzard of overnight and instant surveys headed our way. Unless the President shocks the nation -- a tall order in this environment -- polls may be taken and reported before the average American has had enough time to mull this one over. People will make up their minds on their own schedule.

HEADLINE: At U.S. Open, Food's No Game;
Organizers Hope Return Of Caterer Will Sate Fans

BYLINE: By GLENN COLLINS 

 BODY:
These days, as New York City prepares to serve up the last Grand Slam tournament of the year, are tennis die-hards focused on whether Patrick Rafter can defend his title? Are they rooting for Pete Sampras to retrieve his No. 1 ranking? Do they worry whether Martina Hingis can hold off the Williams sisters yet again?
Not exactly. 
 This is the United States Open at the National Tennis Center in Flushing Meadows, Queens, the most star-powered fortnight in all of sports. And naturally, New York's tennis mavens are obsessed with the menu.
"You cannot believe the incredible preoccupation with the food at the Open," said the comedian Alan King, who has attended the tournament since the 1950's and said that the cuisine has become "just about as legendary as the tennis."
Thanks to some stunning culinary volleys recently, courtside gourmets will be studying the menu with new urgency at this year's Open, which begins Aug. 31. Last year, when the newly renovated National Tennis Center made its debut with much fanfare, there were howls of protest over slow service and the price of pizza. The caterer, Sportservice Corporation of Buffalo, resigned in February after completing only two years of its seven-year contract.
So the United States Tennis Association brought back Restaurant Associates, the street-smart New York food provider that served the Open from 1976 to 1995, introducing courtside delicacies ranging from quiche to panini and baguettes.
Then, in spring, Restaurant Associates -- creator of some of New York's most popular restaurants, including the Four Seasons and the Brasserie -- was acquired by a British concern that is the world's largest food-service company, Compass Group P.L.C. And suddenly, the Open became the first public test of this new multinational corporate pairing.
"Open food" has been a subject of compulsive scrutiny since Restaurant Associates introduced quiche Lorraine in 1978.
Hard-breathing news bulletins on such introductions as tamarillo fruit and ciabatta bread, as well as on the price of pizza, have been one of the longest-running cliches of the coverage of the Open. "When they don't have any interesting matches to show, the TV crews always feel they have to do reports on the food," said Malcolm M. Knapp, who heads a restaurant consulting concern in Manhattan that bears his name.
And Restaurant Associates "will be under the microscope because they're coming back," he added. "People think the food service last year stank, so there will be a lot of questions: is the food good again? Is it being served on time at parties and in the suites? Has R.A. been affected by the acquisition? And what about the cost?"
These days, the food crews are slaving round the clock at the National Tennis Center, under fierce pressure to prepare for the assault of the expected 550,000 visitors over 14 days who will buy $12 million worth of food. Restaurant Associates is putting 1,300 hourly workers on the front line, and bringing in 200 managers.
By the end of the tourney, tennisdom is expected to go through 40,000 pounds of hot dogs, 50,000 pounds of hamburgers, 3 tons of shrimp, 2,000 gallons of tomato sauce, 12,000 cases of Evian water, 15,000 baguettes and 15 tons of french fries.
"It is like the biggest opening of the biggest show you can imagine," said Nick Valenti, chief executive of Restaurant Associates. "You have to stay focused or you'll be overcome."
While most spectators' perception of the cuisine is shaped by hamburgers and pizza slices, the ultimate judgments are made by corporations that have parties for hundreds in their hospitality suites or entertain clients in the restaurants and private boxes.
"The stadium restaurants have to look permanent and feel permanent, and then you shut them down in two weeks after satisfying the most demanding audience in the world," Mr. Valenti said.
This year the operations include the 5 restaurants, 35 concession stands and the Food Village stands as well as the 90 luxury suites and the dining operations for the Open staff, the umpires, the news media and more than 600 players.
"You go all over the place to 42 different matches and you always walk past a food court," said Mr. King. "They get you coming and going."
Complicating the job for Restaurant Associates is the unpredictability of the demand for food, which "ebbs and flows every day due to the matchups, the scores and the weather," Mr. Valenti said.
In the past, summer brownouts have shut off the electronic registers. A near-tornado tore down food tents. Hundred-degree days have tested soda inventory and 50-degree nights have challenged hot-coffee delivery. "When the temperature goes above 90 degrees, we sell no food," said Joe Polidoro, the company's vice president for special events. "It's just water, soda and beer."
 Mr. Knapp, the consultant, said the Open is always a food gamble because "all you need is one or two rain days and your profit is gone."
That sentiment was echoed by Michael J. Bailey, president and chief executive of the North American subsidiary of Compass, the new corporate parent of Restaurant Associates. "The risks are always great at sporting events, the uncertainties many," he said. "But of course, customers aren't interested in the problems of organizing the event, they just want a good sandwich."
The stakes are high for Compass, the dominant force in the lucrative European event-catering and stadium-service industry, which acquired Restaurant Associates to move into the concession market in the United States. "R.A. will allow us to seriously bid for more museums, performing arts centers and sports groups nationwide," Mr. Bailey said.
Also under pressure is the tennis association, which was stung last September by corporate displeasure. "Some people had a bad time last year," acknowledged Suzanne Maguire, who supervises food-service operations for the association. "I hope they'll give us a chance and give Restaurant Associates a chance."
Thus far, corporations are pleased. Recently, Restaurant Associates held a tasting for suiteholders and corporate-hospitality planners. "The presentations were beautiful and the choices were smart," said Rosemarie Salvatore, a coordinator of the Open suite for Arthur Andersen, the accounting and consulting firm.
"People want to be eating light in summertime," she said. "Last year they had hot food in chafing dishes, all wrong for the season."
"It was such a shame -- the stadium was gorgeous but the food was lacking, disorganized and everything was last-minute," she said. "So many people had food delivered late, and didn't get what they wanted."
The hiring of Sportservice in 1996 generated seismic waves of food-world gossip thanks to the fame of the restaurant companies involved. The Buffalo caterer took as its local subcontractors two of the biggest names in New York's food firmament: the Joseph Baum & Michael Whiteman Company in Manhattan, a restaurant management group, and Glorious Food, the upscale caterer for society, celebrities and art galleries.
But in March, Sportservice exercised the exit clause in its contract. "We are in business to make money and, unfortunately, the way our contract with the U.S.T.A. was structured, that simply wasn't possible," said Nancy Parker, president of Sportservice.
Indeed, that was the reason Restaurant Associates decided in 1995 against accepting a stringent contract offered by the tennis association.
Analysts said Sportservice did not click in part because it had no local pool of experienced, motivated troops to fight the battle of the Open. This year, as in the past, Restaurant Associates has turned to the neighborhood work force "that it has recruited for decades in Flushing, Forest Hills, Elmhurst and Jackson Heights," said Kristin Kurtz, whose job it has been this summer to hire waiters, kitchen workers, bartenders and others.
Ms. Kurtz is a member of that little-known talent pool. As a 15-year-old from Glendale, Queens, 11 years ago, she started out scooping ice cream at the Open. Her mother, Jeanne, started working for the Open as a substitute for her mother, Eileen Sadler.
"It's really a family thing," Ms. Kurtz said. It can be lucrative, too: many of the employees earn $100 to $300 a day or more; in two weeks college students can earn spending money for the whole school year.
At the Open, high food prices "seem outrageous, but they're about the same at Madison Square Garden or at stadiums," said Marlie Buehler, a tennis pro at the Manhattan Plaza Racquet Club.
But it's a captive audience. "You go all over the place to 42 different matches and you always walk past a food court," Mr. King said. "They get you coming and going."
Now that Restaurant Associates is back, Mr. Valenti is promising aficionados better food at a lower price. Slices of pizza will be $4.25 instead of $5; at $3.25, the all-beef frankfurter on caraway bun with Grey Poupon mustard will be 25 cents cheaper than its less-distinguished predecessor last year, and ham and Brie on a baguette will be a dollar cheaper, at $7.50, than last year's more ho-hum ham and Swiss.
Restaurant Associates has also tried to reinvent the menu at the concession stands, adding fajitas and cheese quesadillas, bowls of steamed rice with exotic toppings, as well as ficelles, 12-inch-long baguettes filled with everything from bresaola (sliced aged beef) to grana padana cheese.
Prices will also be lower for the luxury suites; and entrees at Aces, the Asian-accented seafood restaurant, will cost $19 to $32, a decrease of $1 to $11 from last year.
Despite this price-cutting, Mr. Knapp said that Restaurant Associates could make a profit thanks to its "operating efficiencies and the economies of scale they have."
Mr. Valenti has no intention of losing money. "This may be a high-profile event, but it certainly can't be a loss leader," he said.
But for now his troops are focused less on profit, or loss, than on doing battle. "This year Yogi Berra is our philosopher," Mr. Valenti said. "It ain't over till it's over."

HEADLINE: Medicaid Rolls Have Declined In Last 3 Years

BYLINE: By NINA BERNSTEIN 

 BODY:
In a trend that has alarmed health care providers, the number of poor people enrolled in Medicaid in New York State has been declining for the last three years.
While the strong economy may account for some of the drop, many analysts say the decline is, in part, a side effect of the overhaul of the nation's welfare system in late 1996, legislation that was intended to move recipients into the work force. 
 When Congress drafted the overhaul, it took pains to spell out that people no longer entitled to welfare, particularly children, would continue to be eligible for Medicaid, the Federal and state health benefits program created more than 30 years ago for the very poor and the very sick. But in practice, health care analysts contend, people who have been removed from welfare or discouraged from applying in the first place have also been swept from the Medicaid rolls.
In New York State, whose efforts at reforming welfare were taking shape before the Federal overhaul began, the number of poor people enrolled in Medicaid declined 26 percent, to 1.28 million, between January 1995 and January 1998, according to analysts at the United Hospital Fund, a nonprofit philanthropic and medical research organization based in Manhattan.
The magnitude of the drop is a matter of debate, because of growth in other, overlapping Medicaid categories, like disabled adults and the "medically needy," whose high medical expenses offset their higher income. State officials, taking into account some of those categories, put the decline in the number of poor Medicaid recipients at closer to 17.5 percent.
But whatever the figure, health care providers and analysts are increasingly alarmed by the trend, which they say reflects an emerging national pattern.
"The very group that is eligible for Medicaid and not getting it are the kids who have the highest rates of asthma, anemia and every imaginable health care problem," said Dr. Irwin Redlener, director of community pediatrics for Montefiore Medical Center in the Bronx. He added: "They are suffering without the treatment they need because they have no insurance. Our concern is that these kids are now at enormous risk."
Officials estimate that 4.5 million children in New York State are eligible for Medicaid but are not enrolled.
Nobody can say for sure why Medicaid enrollment has fallen, but analysts offer many reasons. The most optimistic is that in a stronger economy, more people are finding jobs that offer private health insurance. But Kathryn Haslanger, director of policy analysis for United Hospital Fund, said this was unlikely to account for much of the change, because the ranks of the uninsured have been growing even faster in New York than in the nation as a whole, and many low-wage jobs do not offer affordable private health insurance.
Another partial explanation is that more low-income families may be forgoing both welfare and Medicaid because new workfare rules make it harder to combine a relief check with off-the-books earnings, even as a better economy makes it easier to find a part-time job. Many parents may not realize that their children probably are still eligible for Medicaid.
Other reasons concern new barriers in the public-assistance system, and the factor that Jim Tallon, president of the United Hospital Fund, described as "demand suppression -- where people are simply not coming in the front door of the public-assistance program because they perceive it not to be open to them."
Historically, the vast majority of low-income Medicaid beneficiaries were enrolled at the same time they qualified for cash assistance in their local welfare office. This is still the case, but fewer people have been seeking welfare, and more are being turned away. The number of welfare recipients in the state has shrunk since 1995 by at least 547,000, two-thirds of them children.
"In welfare and Medicaid we are asking the former public assistance system to do two opposing things," Mr. Tallon noted. "One is to divert people away from benefits, and the other is simultaneously to maintain their eligibility for benefits. The data suggests that there has been an enormous underestimation of the administrative difficulty of implementing two conceptually conflicting requirements."
The tension between the two public policy goals is evident in New York. Gov. George E. Pataki has been in the forefront of a national push to extend health insurance to more children, and state lawmakers recently passed bills expanding both Medicaid and Child Health Plus, a program aimed at insuring children of families with somewhat higher income than the limit for Medicaid.
But in New York City, where most of the state's poor and uninsured families live, Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani has been just as outspokenly committed to redesigning welfare centers so that poor people are discouraged from public assistance at the front door by being directed to seek jobs or charity before they are allowed to apply.
Debra Sproles, a spokeswoman for the city's Human Resources Administration, which oversees both welfare and Medicaid, said the city is beginning an internal review of how welfare centers handle Medicaid, "to make sure that people are getting what they should."
She added: "We're telling people they don't have to be on welfare to get Medicaid services. We don't think that's a discouragement."
As a practical matter, however, such people are referred to a separate city Medicaid office to begin another application process that sometimes daunts even people with pressing medical needs.
At the same time, people who still obtain Medicaid along with a welfare grant are now at greater risk of losing both. Thousands of recipients are cut from the rolls each month for failing to meet strict workfare requirements, according to city data. People who lose public assistance for any reason automatically lose Medicaid, too, unless they appear in person at a Medicaid office for a "redetermination" of eligibility within 30 days -- a process that state officials acknowledge has led to erroneous terminations.
In Wisconsin, which pioneered the job-center model now gearing up in New York City, a recent study by researchers at the Medical College of Wisconsin in Milwaukee documented a 24 percent drop in Medicaid enrollment among the state's children when they compared the three-year period before that state's version of welfare reform and the six-month period after full implementation in September 1997. Wisconsin recently started an aggressive Medicaid outreach campaign, largely because state Medicaid caseloads had fallen so much more than expected.
Though national Medicaid enrollment figures are not yet available for the period following the Federal welfare overhaul, during the 1995-1996 period, when similar welfare changes were already well under way in many states, the decline already was taking shape, said Leighton Ku, a health policy analyst at the Urban Institute, a nonpartisan social policy research organization based in Washington.
Few state Medicaid directors have been willing to draw attention to the problem, Mr. Ku said. "One, welfare reform is sacrosanct in many states," he said. "And the decline in caseload means for the first time Medicaid is not eating the budget."
Penny Schwartz, the director of REAP, the Resource, Entitlement and Advocacy Program sponsored by Mount Sinai Medical Center in Manhattan, said she has a window on the obstacles that poor patients and their families must now overcome to get or keep Medicaid coverage. "Forget about user-friendly," she said. "We're talking about user-hostile."
Among the cases she cited was that of a severely asthmatic father of three whose doctor wrote a letter saying he could not work outdoors. The man took the letter to the outdoor workfare site where he had been ordered to report and was told to go home and wait for an indoor assignment. Instead, he received a letter of sanction and was cut from both public assistance and Medicaid, leaving him without asthma medication. When he reapplied for Medicaid alone, as instructed, he was denied on the erroneous ground that the welfare sanction was still in place.
Another REAP client was a 37-year-old mother of three who could not attend a work assessment on Jan. 29 because she had an emergency appointment at the school that her emotionally disturbed son attends. Though the principal of the school contacted the work program to explain and reschedule, the entire family mistakenly lost all public assistance, Medicaid and food stamps.
The New York State Coalition of Prepaid Health Services Plans recently reported that "involuntary disenrollments" are running 20 percent higher this year than last year among more than 200,000 Medicaid managed care members and now affect more than 4.17 percent of the caseload each month, wreaking havoc with health care and billing.
Analysts at the Greater Hospital Association of New York said they hoped the loss of children from Medicaid would be partly offset and stemmed by Child Health Plus and "enrollment-friendly" measures recently passed by the state for children receiving both welfare and Medicaid. But since 1995, 136,000 children have lost Medicaid, not counting the disabled, while only 65,000 -- not necessarily the same children -- were newly enrolled in Child Health Plus, state figures show.
While subway posters lure newcomers to Child Health Plus, which allows mail-in applications, has no work requirement and now covers children in families with income of up to 200 percent of the poverty line, REAP advocates are still trying to win retroactive Medicaid benefits for the family of a 30-year-old immigrant mother whose 3-year-old son, a United States citizen, has been hospitalized with leukemia. They both lost aid after a welfare investigator who went to the wrong address did not find the mother at home, Ms. Schwartz said.
Lucy Quacinella, a lawyer and health care specialist in the Sacramento, Calif., office of the Western Center on Law and Poverty, sees a net loss in these opposing trends. "You have significant declines in Medicaid coverage for families, at the same time as you have major initiatives to reach out and insure children," she said. "But after all, children live in families."

HEADLINE: Northeast Is Still Reeling From Ice Storm's Economic Punch

BYLINE: AP 

DATELINE: SOUTH COLTON, N.Y., Aug. 16

 BODY:
Seven months ago, Glen Thomas was staring at financial ruin. His maple sugar business had been put on ice by a stunning winter storm.
"It was devastating," said Mr. Thomas, who has 48 acres of maple trees in this rural town, about 120 miles northeast of Syracuse. "The damage was so massive I was really discouraged. But I'm repairing the damage." 
 Mr. Thomas is still evaluating his losses from the vicious ice storm, which smacked the Northeast in January. And he is still cleaning up the broken tree limbs from the forest floor and re-installing the plastic tubing that transports his sap.
In January, the future seemed bleak. Mr. Thomas estimated that the storm cost him $15,000 to $20,000. He said he usually makes 800 to 1,000 gallons of syrup each season; this year he struggled to produce 50 gallons.
Mr. Thomas is among hundreds of maple syrup producers, dairy farmers and others in six northern New York counties who suffered substantial losses from the storm.
The latest estimates by the 25 largest insurers in northern New York show that the companies paid $68.5 million on 48,753 claims from storm damage.
Disaster workers estimated that the state and Federal governments have spent $44.5 million so far on ice storm and flooding recovery.
Niagara Mohawk Power Corporation has spent the most by far -- more than $125 million to repair lines to 120,000 customers who in some cases were left without power for weeks.
The House of Representatives recently passed a $2.9 billion emergency spending bill intended to help upstate New York and New England recover from the storm. About $5 million was included that would compensate dairy farmers who lost livestock and suffered from decreased milk production. About $4 million would help tree farmers.
With Federal emergency funds, Mr. Thomas said, he will be able to hire a contractor to clean out the fallen trees and branches and will eventually recover.
But others are on the verge of hanging up their buckets for good.
"They've been dealt a pretty severe blow," said Lewis Staats, a maple specialist at Cornell Cooperative Extension.
Mr. Staats said an estimated 380,000 taps were lost in northern New York as a result of the storm.
Statewide, 231,000 gallons of maple syrup was produced in the 1998 season, down from 269,000 gallons in 1997 and 350,000 in 1996.
Loyal Drake, who has made syrup for 55 years in Nicholville, in St. Lawrence County, is one of those producers ready to fold.
"I'm 73, and with what it's going to cost to get everything put back the way it was, even with Government help, I'm not sure it's worth it," Mr. Drake said. "I lost 40 percent of the limbs on my trees, and it's so bad we can't even walk in the woods."
